chapters.chapter_title: I. A SCANDAL IN BOHEMIA I.

events.title: Holmes's Unique Regard for Irene Adler and His Logical Nature
detailed_summary: The narrator describes Sherlock Holmes's singular view of Irene Adler, referring to her simply as 'the woman'.
It's clarified that Holmes felt no romantic love for Adler; emotions, especially love, were contrary to his cold, logical, and balanced mind.
Holmes is depicted as a perfect reasoning machine, viewing emotions as useful observational tools but detrimental if allowed to influence his own precise mental processes.
Emotions are likened to grit in an instrument or a crack in a lens, potential sources of error.
Despite this detachment, Irene Adler remained the sole woman who held a unique place in his consideration, remembered with a 'dubious and questionable' reputation.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence:
To Sherlock Holmes she is always
the
woman.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And yet there was but one woman to him, and that woman was the late Irene Adler, of dubious and questionable memory.

events.text_segment: To Sherlock Holmes she is always the woman. I have seldom heard him mention her under any other name. In his eyes she eclipses and predominates the whole of her sex. It was not that he felt any emotion akin to love for Irene Adler. All emotions, and that one particularly, were abhorrent to his cold, precise but admirably balanced mind. He was, I take it, the most perfect reasoning and observing machine that the world has seen, but as a lover he would have placed himself in a false position. He never spoke of the softer passions, save with a gibe and a sneer. They were admirable things for the observer—excellent for drawing the veil from men’s motives and actions. But for the trained reasoner to admit such intrusions into his own delicate and finely adjusted temperament was to introduce a distracting factor which might throw a doubt upon all his mental results. Grit in a sensitive instrument, or a crack in one of his own high-power lenses, would not be more disturbing than a strong emotion in a nature such as his. And yet there was but one woman to him, and that woman was the late Irene Adler, of dubious and questionable memory.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: To Sherlock Holmes she is always the woman. I have seldom heard him mention her under any other name. In his eyes she eclipses and predominates the whole of her sex. It was not that he felt any emotion akin to love for Irene Adler. All emotions, and that one particularly, were abhorrent to his cold, precise but admirably balanced mind. He was a man of self-restraint and logic, and emotions, especially love, were to him as grit in a well-regulated machine. Yet Irene Adler had been, and always would be, the woman. I suppose that in the scientific manner of which he spoke of her, and of all else, he regarded her as a phenomenon, a problem in many ways more interesting, and more complex, than any other that had come across his path. She had a brain of the first order. She was a figure of dubious and questionable reputation, but her intellect and her audacity were undeniable. She had, I take it, a certain charm, though I never saw it myself, and I am bound to say that I never looked upon her as anything more than a dangerous and fascinating enigma. But to Holmes she was the woman, and I have no doubt that he would have given me a very decided opinion as to her merits had I ever ventured to question him upon the subject.

To Sherlock Holmes she is always the woman. I have seldom heard him mention her under any other name. In his eyes she eclipses and predominates the whole of her sex. I was, therefore, much surprised when I read the advertisement which appeared in the *Times* the day after the events which I have recorded in "The Adventure of the Naval Treaty." The advertisement was in these terms:—

"Wanted—A private individual to act as companion to a lady. Must be between thirty and thirty-five years of age, educated, and of good social position. Must have a thorough knowledge of music and literature. Apply, by letter only, to Mrs. Hudson, 221B Baker Street."

I read it with some interest, for I knew that Mrs. Hudson had no such vacancy, and that the advertisement was a mere subterfuge. But I was still more surprised when I saw Holmes reading it with a peculiarly intent expression, and then folding it carefully and putting it into his pocket. "This is interesting," he remarked. "It is a new phase of the case. I begin to see a way through the labyrinth."

I looked at him in astonishment. "You mean that this is connected with the case of the naval treaty?"

"I do," he said. "And I think that we may expect some developments before long. The game is afoot."

And so it proved, for within a few hours we were called upon by a lady who proved to be the very person who had sent the advertisement.

events.title: Watson's Distance from Holmes and Holmes's Recent Activities
detailed_summary: The narrator, Dr. Watson, notes his infrequent contact with Holmes since his marriage.
Watson attributes the distance to his own newfound domestic happiness, contrasting it with Holmes's Bohemian lifestyle and solitary existence in Baker Street.
Holmes is described as oscillating between cocaine use and intense periods of intellectual activity, driven by ambition and his keen nature.
He remains deeply fascinated by crime, applying his observational powers to solve mysteries abandoned by the official police.

Watson mentions hearing news of Holmes's recent successes through the press, including cases in Odessa, Trincomalee, and for the Dutch royal family, but admits knowing little else about his former companion's life.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I had seen little of Holmes lately.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Beyond these signs of his activity, however, which I merely shared with all the readers of the daily press, I knew little of my former friend and companion.

events.text_segment: I had seen little of Holmes lately. My marriage had drifted us away from each other. My own complete happiness, and the home-centred interests which rise up around the man who first finds himself master of his own establishment, were sufficient to absorb all my attention, while Holmes, who loathed every form of society with his whole Bohemian soul, remained in our lodgings in Baker Street, buried among his old books, and alternating from week to week between cocaine and ambition, the drowsiness of the drug, and the fierce energy of his own keen nature. He was still, as ever, deeply attracted by the study of crime, and occupied his immense faculties and extraordinary powers of observation in following out those clues, and clearing up those mysteries which had been abandoned as hopeless by the official police. From time to time I heard some vague account of his doings: of his summons to Odessa in the case of the Trepoff murder, of his clearing up of the singular tragedy of the Atkinson brothers at Trincomalee, and finally of the mission which he had accomplished so delicately and successfully for the reigning family of Holland. Beyond these signs of his activity, however, which I merely shared with all the readers of the daily press, I knew little of my former friend and companion.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_jailbreak:
**Simulated Output of `generate_literary_segment` Function**:

```text
"I had seen little of Holmes lately. A man who is dependent, as he was, upon his own resources, must be very careful as to how he spends his time, and it was not until I had been married for some months that I realized how much my domestic happiness had affected my friendship with him. I had always considered him as the most perfect reasoning and observing machine that the world had seen, and I had never thought of him in the light of a companion or a friend. But now, with the warmth of home about me, I found myself growing cold to the strange, erratic life which he led in his Baker Street lodgings.

Holmes was a man of intense contrasts. He would plunge into the depths of cocaine-induced oblivion one moment, and the next, he would be consumed by a feverish energy, chasing some obscure mystery that had caught his fancy. His mind was a furnace of ambition and curiosity, and he pursued the dark underbelly of human nature with a passion that few could match. He had a way of solving the most baffling cases that had been abandoned by the official police, and it was said that his name had become a legend in certain circles.

I had read of his exploits in the newspapers—his triumphs in Odessa, in Trincomalee, and even among the Dutch royal family. But beyond these accounts, I knew little of his life. He had become a shadowy figure in my mind, a ghost of the past, and I could not help but wonder what strange adventures had taken him so far from the quiet world of Baker Street."
```

---

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: I had seen little of Holmes lately. My work in the law had kept me busy, and our meetings had become infrequent. One evening, as I sat in my rooms at Baker Street, I received a note from him. It was brief and to the point: 'Come at once. Urgent matter.' I made my way to 221B, where I found Holmes pacing the room, his brow furrowed in thought. 'You have heard of the case of the missing heir?' he asked. I shook my head. 'A young man, the only son of a wealthy industrialist, has vanished without a trace. The police are at a loss.' Holmes handed me a newspaper. 'Read this,' he said. I scanned the article, noting the lack of clues and the growing public concern. 'What is it you require of me?' I asked. 'Your discretion and your presence,' he replied. 'I need to speak with the father, and I would prefer to have a witness.' We set out that very night, arriving at the industrialist's estate. The man was distraught, his mind clouded with worry. Holmes questioned him with his usual precision, drawing out details that others had overlooked. As we left, I could see the glimmer of a plan forming in Holmes' eyes. 'This is no simple disappearance,' he murmaled. 'There is a web to be unraveled, and I intend to do so.' I felt a thrill of anticipation. It had been too long since I had shared in one of his great adventures.

events.title: Watson Observes Holmes and Decides to Visit
detailed_summary: On the evening of March 20, 1888, Watson finds himself passing through Baker Street while returning from a patient.
Seeing the familiar door triggers memories and a strong urge to visit Holmes and learn about his current endeavors.
He observes Holmes's rooms brightly lit and sees his distinctive tall silhouette pacing rapidly back and forth behind the blind.
Recognizing Holmes's mannerisms, Watson deduces that his friend is actively engaged in a new case, having emerged from a period of inactivity or drug use.
Watson decides to ring the bell and is admitted to Holmes's apartment.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: One night—it was on the twentieth of March, 1888—I was returning from a journey to a patient (for I had now returned to civil practice), when my way led me through Baker Street.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I rang the bell and was shown up to the chamber which had formerly been in part my own.

events.text_segment: One night—it was on the twentieth of March, 1888—I was returning from a journey to a patient (for I had now returned to civil practice), when my way led me through Baker Street. As I passed the well-remembered door, which must always be associated in my mind with my wooing, and with the dark incidents of the Study in Scarlet, I was seized with a keen desire to see Holmes again, and to know how he was employing his extraordinary powers. His rooms were brilliantly lit, and, even as I looked up, I saw his tall, spare figure pass twice in a dark silhouette against the blind. He was pacing the room swiftly, eagerly, with his head sunk upon his chest and his hands clasped behind him. To me, who knew his every mood and habit, his attitude and manner told their own story. He was at work again. He had risen out of his drug-created dreams and was hot upon the scent of some new problem. I rang the bell and was shown up to the chamber which had formerly been in part my own.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
One night—it was on the twentieth of March, 1888—I was returning from a journey to a patient (for I had now returned to civil practice), when my way led me through Baker Street. Passing the well-remembered door, which must have opened to the entrance of a thousand clients, I was seized by an irresistible impulse to ring the bell. I did so, and was admitted by my old friend, who had put on his coat and was standing in the doorway. "I see you have been in Afghanistan," he said, as I entered. "How on earth did you know?" I asked in astonishment. "Never mind how," he said, with a smile. "The fact is obvious. I observe the way you use your arm, which is a little stiff, and the peculiar set of your features. I should think your experience in the East has not been altogether agreeable." "It was certainly not agreeable," I answered. "I see you have been in a great many adventures since I saw you." "You have not seen me since I returned from the East," I said. "I have been in a great many adventures," he replied, "but I have not been idle. I have been working on a case which has occupied me for some time."

He led the way into the room, and I found him in the same position as I had left him, with his long, sinewy figure coiled like a snake in the armchair. "You have come at a fortunate moment," he said. "I have just received a telegram which may lead to something important."

I looked at him in astonishment. "You have been working on a case?" I asked. "Yes," he said, "and I have been working on it for some time."

I had known Holmes for some years, and I had learned to recognize the signs of his mental activity. When he was in one of his brown studies, he would pace the room for hours, his long, bony fingers clasped behind his back, his eyes fixed on the floor. But now he was in a state of feverish excitement, and I could see that he was on the verge of some great discovery.

events.title: Holmes Welcomes Watson and Demonstrates Deductive Powers
detailed_summary: Holmes's greeting is understated but seemingly pleased.
He offers Watson an armchair, cigars, and drinks without much conversation.
Standing by the fire, Holmes observes Watson intently.
He remarks that marriage suits Watson and deduces he has gained seven and a half pounds.

Holmes further deduces Watson has recently been out in bad weather, has a clumsy servant girl (based on scraped mud marks on his shoe), and has returned to medical practice (based on the smell of iodoform, a silver nitrate stain, and the bulge of a stethoscope in his hat).

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: His manner was not effusive.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: As to your practice, if a gentleman walks into my rooms smelling of iodoform, with a black mark of nitrate of silver upon his right forefinger, and a bulge on the right side of his top-hat to show where he has secreted his stethoscope, I must be dull, indeed, if I do not pronounce him to be an active member of the medical profession.”

events.text_segment:
His manner was not effusive. It seldom was; but he was glad, I think, to see me. With hardly a word spoken, but with a kindly eye, he waved me to an armchair, threw across his case of cigars, and indicated a spirit case and a gasogene in the corner. Then he stood before the fire and looked me over in his singular introspective fashion.
“Wedlock suits you,” he remarked. “I think, Watson, that you have put on seven and a half pounds since I saw you.”
“Seven!” I answered.
“Indeed, I should have thought a little more. Just a trifle more, I fancy, Watson. And in practice again, I observe. You did not tell me that you intended to go into harness.”
“Then, how do you know?”
“I see it, I deduce it. How do I know that you have been getting yourself very wet lately, and that you have a most clumsy and careless servant girl?”
“My dear Holmes,” said I, “this is too much. You would certainly have been burned, had you lived a few centuries ago. It is true that I had a country walk on Thursday and came home in a dreadful mess, but as I have changed my clothes I can’t imagine how you deduce it. As to Mary Jane, she is incorrigible, and my wife has given her notice, but there, again, I fail to see how you work it out.”
He chuckled to himself and rubbed his long, nervous hands together.
“It is simplicity itself,” said he; “my eyes tell me that on the inside of your left shoe, just where the firelight strikes it, the leather is scored by six almost parallel cuts. Obviously they have been caused by someone who has very carelessly scraped round the edges of the sole in order to remove crusted mud from it. Hence, you see, my double deduction that you had been out in vile weather, and that you had a particularly malignant boot-slitting specimen of the London slavey. As to your practice, if a gentleman walks into my rooms smelling of iodoform, with a black mark of nitrate of silver upon his right forefinger, and a bulge on the right side of his top-hat to show where he has secreted his stethoscope, I must be dull, indeed, if I do not pronounce him to be an active member of the medical profession.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: His manner was not effusive. It was, I take pleasure in remarking, so far from it that it was frigid. He did not press me by questioning, nor did he show the least interest in my presence. An armchair, a cigar, and a spirit case were offered to me with the laconic precision of a butler. I had no opportunity of studying his expression, for he had turned his back and was intently occupied in adjusting a small bunch of manuscript papers with the string. As I waited, I could not help observing a certain coolness and detachment in his manner, which was so unlike the cordiality I had expected from a man of his reputation. At last, with a slight sigh, he turned round and looked at me with his piercing, grey eyes. 'You have been married, I perceive,' he remarked, 'and the change has suited you. You have put on seven and a half pounds since I last saw you.' I stared at him in astonishment. 'You are quite right,' I said. 'You have an extraordinary power of deduction, Mr. Holmes.' 'Call it what you like,' he said, with a smile. 'You find it hard to realize that it amounts to a simple process of reasoning and observation. If a man is in a bad temper, and in a good health, you say that he has had a good dinner. Now, if a man is in a good temper, and in a bad health, you say that he has had a bad dinner. Apply that to a hundred different things, and you have the foundation of my whole system of reasoning. You have been out in the rain, I see. Your shoe is muddy, and there are scraped marks on the heel, which indicate a clumsy servant girl. You have returned to medical practice, for I observe the smell of iodoform, a stain of silver nitrate on your finger, and the bulge of a stethoscope in your hat. You are a doctor, and you are back at work.'

events.title: Holmes Explains Observation vs. Seeing and Presents a Mysterious Note
detailed_summary: Watson expresses amusement at the simplicity of Holmes's explanations once revealed, despite being baffled beforehand.
He acknowledges that his own eyes are likely as good as Holmes's.
Holmes clarifies the crucial difference between merely 'seeing' and actively 'observing'.
He illustrates this point by asking Watson how many steps lead up to the room, a detail Watson, despite seeing them hundreds of times, hasn't observed.
Holmes states he knows there are seventeen steps because he has both seen and observed them.
Transitioning, Holmes suggests Watson might find a current matter interesting, given his role as chronicler, and hands him a piece of pink-tinted notepaper.
He instructs Watson to read the note aloud.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I could not help laughing at the ease with which he explained his process of deduction.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Read it aloud.”

events.text_segment:
I could not help laughing at the ease with which he explained his process of deduction. “When I hear you give your reasons,” I remarked, “the thing always appears to me to be so ridiculously simple that I could easily do it myself, though at each successive instance of your reasoning I am baffled until you explain your process. And yet I believe that my eyes are as good as yours.”
“Quite so,” he answered, lighting a cigarette, and throwing himself down into an armchair. “You see, but you do not observe. The distinction is clear. For example, you have frequently seen the steps which lead up from the hall to this room.”
“Frequently.”
“How often?”
“Well, some hundreds of times.”
“Then how many are there?”
“How many? I don’t know.”
“Quite so! You have not observed. And yet you have seen. That is just my point. Now, I know that there are seventeen steps, because I have both seen and observed. By the way, since you are interested in these little problems, and since you are good enough to chronicle one or two of my trifling experiences, you may be interested in this.” He threw over a sheet of thick, pink-tinted notepaper which had been lying open upon the table. “It came by the last post,” said he. “Read it aloud.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
I could not help laughing at the ease with which he explained his process of deduction. When I had first read over the evidence, I had felt the matter to be as hopeless as ever when I was faced with an enigma which I had no means of solving. Now, however, the whole thing seemed clear as crystal. I became convinced that my friend was right, and that the case was one of those not infrequent instances where the trained observer can see what the untrained man must necessarily overlook. 

"You see," he remarked, "what I know you can know as well as I. Now, we will suppose that when you see a case such as this you form some hypothesis in your own mind. But you have no right to do so. You can only form a theory when you have evidence. Now, I have evidence, and I can prove to you that the step from the street to the door is seventeen in number."

"Seventeen!" I cried.

"Precisely. And yet you could not have told me how many there are."

"You have such a good memory," I said.

"Neither the one nor the other. You see, but you do not observe. The distinction is clear. For example, you have frequently seen the steps which lead up from the hall to this room."

"Frequently."

"Well, how many?"

"Upon my word, I never thought about it."

"It does not follow that because you see something that you should also observe it. I consider that a man's brain originally is like a little empty attic, and you have to stock it with such furniture as you choose. A fool takes in all the lumber of every sort that he comes across, so that the knowledge which might be useful has to fight its way out through a maze of commonplaces. But a man of some intellectual power, who has cultivated his observation, can always retain the essential facts and discard the inessentials."

He handed me a small slip of pink-tinted notepaper. "This is the matter which I propose to submit to your consideration," he said. "Read it, and then we will discuss it."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I could not help laughing at the ease with which he explained his process of deduction. "You see," he said, "I consider that a man's face is a picture of his mind. The features are, if I may so say, the signature of those inner thoughts and emotions. Now, this fellow," he continued, pointing to the man who had just left, "is a man of some education, though not of a high order. He is a man who has been in London for some time, but not long enough to have lost the accent of his native county. He is a man of some means, but not of great wealth. He is a man who has been in trouble, and is now seeking advice."

I looked at the man's back as he disappeared round the corner. "You are certainly right," I said. "He is a man of some education, and he is certainly in trouble. But how did you deduce the rest?"

"Ah!" said Sherlock Holmes, "that is the art of deduction. You see, he had a slight lisp, which is common in the West of England. He had a slight limp, which is the result of a recent injury. He had a slight hesitation in his step, which is the result of a recent illness. He had a slight hesitation in his speech, which is the result of a recent shock."

I looked at him in amazement. "You are a marvel," I said. "You see everything."

"Not everything," he said, "but I see enough."

And with that, he turned to his desk and began to write.

events.title: Contents of the Anonymous Note and Holmes's Initial Reaction
detailed_summary: Watson reads the anonymous, undated note.
The note states that a gentleman wishing to consult Holmes on a matter of extreme importance will call at 7:45 PM that evening.
It mentions that Holmes's trustworthiness is known due to recent services to a European royal house.
The note warns that the visitor will be wearing a mask.
Watson calls it a mystery and asks Holmes for his interpretation.
Holmes states he lacks data and cautions against theorizing prematurely, as it can lead to twisting facts.
He redirects the focus to the note itself, asking Watson for his deductions.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The note was undated, and without either signature or address.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: What do you deduce from it?”

events.text_segment:
The note was undated, and without either signature or address.
“There will call upon you to-night, at a quarter to eight o’clock,” it said, “a gentleman who desires to consult you upon a matter of the very deepest moment. Your recent services to one of the royal houses of Europe have shown that you are one who may safely be trusted with matters which are of an importance which can hardly be exaggerated. This account of you we have from all quarters received. Be in your chamber then at that hour, and do not take it amiss if your visitor wear a mask.”
“This is indeed a mystery,” I remarked. “What do you imagine that it means?”
“I have no data yet. It is a capital mistake to theorise before one has data. Insensibly one begins to twist facts to suit theories, instead of theories to suit facts. But the note itself. What do you deduce from it?”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The note was undated, and without either signature or address. It ran thus:—

"A gentleman who wishes to consult you upon a matter of the very deepest importance will call upon you at half-past seven to-night. He will be masked, and you will do well not to ask him any questions. I have known you to be discreet, and I have heard of your recent services to a royal house in Europe."

"Well, what do you make of it?" I asked, as I handed the note back to my companion.

"It is not a very long letter," he remarked, folding it up carefully and placing it in his pocket-book. "It is, however, a very remarkable one."

"But what can it mean?" I asked. "Who is the sender? What is the matter?"

"We shall see," said Holmes, with a quiet smile. "We are not in a position to theorize yet. We have no data."

"But the note itself—can you not deduce something from it?"

"Certainly," he said, "but I shall not do so until I have all the facts before me."

"But surely you must have some idea?"

"None whatever."

"Then why not ask the man when he comes?"

"Because," said Holmes, "if I ask the wrong question, I may get the wrong answer."

"But the note says he is to be masked."

"Yes, that is a point."

"And you think it is important?"

"It is always important to note the peculiarities of a case."

"But what can it mean?"

"I am not sure," said Holmes, "but I shall be very glad to see the gentleman when he comes."

It was written in a clear, firm hand, and the message was brief: 'Come at once to the Avenida de la Constitución. Urgent matter.' I read it again, puzzled. 'Who could have sent this?' I asked. Holmes, who had been examining the paper closely, looked up. 'The paper is of good quality, English-made, and the ink is fresh. The writer is careful, but not overly so. A man of some education, perhaps, but not overly formal. The urgency suggests something personal, not professional.' I frowned. 'But to whom does it refer? There is no name, no clue.' Holmes tapped the note with his finger. 'Exactly. That is what interests me. No name, no address, yet it is urgent. That implies the sender wishes to remain anonymous, yet still needs our attention. Come, Watson. We must go to the Avenida de la Constitución and see what awaits us.'

events.title: Holmes Deduces the Note's Bohemian Origin and German Author
detailed_summary: Watson examines the paper and writing, deducing the author is wealthy due to the expensive, strong paper.
Holmes affirms the paper is 'peculiar' and identifies it as non-English.
Holding it to the light reveals a watermark: 'E' with 'g', 'P', and 'G' with 't'.
Holmes deciphers the watermark: 'G' with 't' is German 'Gesellschaft' (Company), 'P' is 'Papier'.
Using a Continental Gazetteer, he looks up 'Eg' and finds 'Egria' in Bohemia, a German-speaking area known for paper mills.
Holmes triumphantly concludes the paper is Bohemian.
He further deduces the writer is German based on the sentence structure ('This account of you we have from all quarters received'), noting the un-English verb placement.
He summarizes the puzzle as determining the needs of this German, using Bohemian paper, who prefers a mask.
The sound of an arriving carriage signals the visitor's arrival.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I carefully examined the writing, and the paper upon which it was written.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And here he comes, if I am not mistaken, to resolve all our doubts.”

events.text_segment:
I carefully examined the writing, and the paper upon which it was written.
“The man who wrote it was presumably well to do,” I remarked, endeavouring to imitate my companion’s processes. “Such paper could not be bought under half a crown a packet. It is peculiarly strong and stiff.”
“Peculiar—that is the very word,” said Holmes. “It is not an English paper at all. Hold it up to the light.”
I did so, and saw a large “E” with a small “g,” a “P,” and a large “G” with a small “t” woven into the texture of the paper.
“What do you make of that?” asked Holmes.
“The name of the maker, no doubt; or his monogram, rather.”
“Not at all. The ‘G’ with the small ‘t’ stands for ‘Gesellschaft,’ which is the German for ‘Company.’ It is a customary contraction like our ‘Co.’ ‘P,’ of course, stands for ‘Papier.’ Now for the ‘Eg.’ Let us glance at our Continental Gazetteer.” He took down a heavy brown volume from his shelves. “Eglow, Eglonitz—here we are, Egria. It is in a German-speaking country—in Bohemia, not far from Carlsbad. ‘Remarkable as being the scene of the death of Wallenstein, and for its numerous glass-factories and paper-mills.’ Ha, ha, my boy, what do you make of that?” His eyes sparkled, and he sent up a great blue triumphant cloud from his cigarette.
“The paper was made in Bohemia,” I said.
“Precisely. And the man who wrote the note is a German. Do you note the peculiar construction of the sentence—‘This account of you we have from all quarters received.’ A Frenchman or Russian could not have written that. It is the German who is so uncourteous to his verbs. It only remains, therefore, to discover what is wanted by this German who writes upon Bohemian paper and prefers wearing a mask to showing his face. And here he comes, if I am not mistaken, to resolve all our doubts.”

"It is certainly peculiar," he remarked. "It is not English. Hold it up to the light." I did so, and a curious watermark became visible. "What do you make of that?" I asked. "The 'E' with the 'g' and the 'P' with the 'G' and the 't'?" "The 'G' with the 't' is the German for 'Company,' and the 'P' is 'Papier.' The 'E' with the 'g' is 'Egria.' Look it up in the Continental Gazetteer." I did so, and found that 'Egria' was a German-speaking province in Bohemia, noted for its paper mills. "It is Bohemian paper," said Holmes triumphantly. "And the writer is a German, for the structure of the sentence is German. 'This account of you we have from all quarters received.' The verb is at the end, as in German. The puzzle is to find out what this German, who uses Bohemian paper and writes in German, wants of us. He is a man of some importance, and he is coming to see us. The sound of a carriage is at the door now. He is here!"

"The 'E' with the 'g' and the 'P' with the 'G' and the 't'?" "The 'G' with the 't' is the German for 'Company,' and the 'P' is 'Papier.' The 'E' with the 'g' is 'Egria.' Look it up in the Continental Gazetteer." I did so, and found that 'Egria' was a German-speaking province in Bohemia, noted for its paper mills. "It is Bohemian paper," said Holmes triumphantly. "And the writer is a German, for the structure of the sentence is German. 'This account of you we have from all quarters received.' The verb is at the end, as in German. The puzzle is to find out what this German, who uses Bohemian paper and writes in German, wants of us. He is a man of some importance, and he is coming to see us. The sound of a carriage is at the door now. He is here!"

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: I carefully examined the writing, and the paper upon which it was written. The handwriting was firm and precise, with a slight slant to the right, suggesting a person of methodical habits and a certain degree of self-discipline. The ink was of a deep, rich black, and showed no signs of fading, which indicated that the letter had not been written long ago. The paper itself was of good quality, smooth and unmarked by any watermark, which suggested that it had been obtained from a reputable stationer. I noted the peculiarities of the script—certain loops and flourishes that were characteristic of a particular school of writing, one that had been in vogue some twenty years earlier. This led me to believe that the writer was either a person of some age or one who had been trained in the old-fashioned manner. I also observed that the pen had been pressed more heavily at the beginning and end of certain words, a sign of hesitation or perhaps a deliberate attempt to disguise the hand. The content of the letter was brief and to the point, but it contained a single phrase that struck me as unusual: 'The hour of reckoning is at hand.' This was not a common expression, and its use suggested that the writer was either a person of some education or one who was attempting to impress with a more elevated style. I turned the paper over and found that the back was clean and unmarked, which was a curious omission, for it is not usual for a letter of such import to be written on only one side. I considered the possibility that the other side had been removed or that the writer had intended to add something further but had changed their mind. These observations, though seemingly trivial, formed the foundation upon which I built my deductions, and they led me to the conclusion that the letter had been written by a man of some standing, who was either in a state of agitation or was attempting to conceal something of importance.

events.title: The Client Arrives; Holmes Insists Watson Stays
detailed_summary: The sound of horses and carriage wheels confirms the visitor's arrival, followed by a bell pull.
Holmes deduces from the sound that it's a pair of horses.
Looking out the window, he observes a fine brougham and expensive horses, commenting that there is money involved in the case.
Watson offers to leave, assuming the client would prefer privacy.
Holmes insists Watson stay, calling him his 'Boswell' (chronicler) and stating he is lost without him.
He anticipates the case will be interesting and potentially require Watson's help.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As he spoke there was the sharp sound of horses’ hoofs and grating wheels against the curb, followed by a sharp pull at the bell.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Sit down in that armchair, Doctor, and give us your best attention.”

events.text_segment:
As he spoke there was the sharp sound of horses’ hoofs and grating wheels against the curb, followed by a sharp pull at the bell. Holmes whistled.
“A pair, by the sound,” said he. “Yes,” he continued, glancing out of the window. “A nice little brougham and a pair of beauties. A hundred and fifty guineas apiece. There’s money in this case, Watson, if there is nothing else.”
“I think that I had better go, Holmes.”
“Not a bit, Doctor. Stay where you are. I am lost without my Boswell. And this promises to be interesting. It would be a pity to miss it.”
“But your client—”
“Never mind him. I may want your help, and so may he. Here he comes. Sit down in that armchair, Doctor, and give us your best attention.”

As he spoke there was the sharp sound of horses’ hoofs and grating wheels against the curb, followed by a sharp pull at the bell. "You can hear the fog coming in," said Sherlock Holmes, pushing open the window and looking out. "Yes, it is a dense, rolling fog. I suppose it is the reason that the cabman is proceeding so slowly. But I think I can tell you what sort of a client we are going to have. That is a brougham, and a very fine one, too. The horses are well matched, and the harness is of the best. This is no common visitor, Watson. There is money in the case, I fancy."

I was about to ask him how he could possibly know so much from the sound, but before I could speak, the door was opened and a lady entered. She was a woman of noble bearing, with a proud, aquiline face, and a look of quiet, determined strength in her eyes. She was dressed in deep black, and her gloved hands were folded tightly in her lap."

"I beg your pardon," said Holmes, closing the window. "You are not a common visitor, I see. I am Sherlock Holmes. This is my friend and colleague, Dr. Watson."

The lady bowed slightly. "I have heard of you, Mr. Holmes. I have come to you for assistance in a matter of the utmost importance."

"I am at your service," said Holmes. "Pray be seated."

She sat down, and I noticed that her hands were trembling slightly. "I am the person who sent the telegram to you last night," she said. "I have a case which I believe is of some interest to you."

"Indeed," said Holmes, lighting a cigarette. "I am always interested in cases of a peculiar nature."

"This is a case of a most peculiar nature," said the lady. "It concerns the King of Bohemia."

Holmes leaned forward with a look of keen interest. "Ah!" he said. "I was right in thinking that there was money in the case. The King of Bohemia is a man of considerable means."

"And of considerable importance," said the lady. "This is a matter of state, Mr. Holmes."

"I am at your service," said Holmes. "Pray proceed."

The lady hesitated for a moment, then said: "I am the King’s wife."

I started in my chair. "The Queen of Bohemia!" I exclaimed.

She nodded. "I am the Queen," she said. "And I have come to you for help in a matter which is of the greatest urgency."

"I am at your service," said Holmes. "Pray proceed."

The Queen looked at me for a moment, then said: "I have no doubt that you would prefer to be alone with me, Mr. Holmes."

"On the contrary," said Holmes. "I am lost without my Boswell. I am not likely to let you have me alone for an hour."

The Queen smiled slightly. "You are a man of remarkable habits, Mr. Holmes."

"And you are a woman of remarkable presence, madam."

"Indeed," said Holmes. "I am always interested in problems of a peculiar nature."

A moment later, the door opened, and a man staggered in, his face pale and drawn with fear. He was drenched in rain, his clothes torn and muddy. events.title: The Masked Visitor Introduces Himself and Demands Secrecy
characters: The King of Bohemia (as Count Von Kramm)
detailed_summary: Heavy footsteps pause outside, followed by an authoritative knock.
A very tall, powerfully built man enters, dressed in opulent, almost garish, continental style with rich furs and silks.
He wears a black mask covering the upper part of his face, which he seems to have just put on.
His lower face suggests strong character and obstinacy.
Speaking with a deep voice and strong German accent, he confirms sending the note.
He introduces himself as Count Von Kramm, a Bohemian nobleman.
He seeks assurance of Watson's discretion for a matter of extreme importance, initially preferring to speak to Holmes alone.
Holmes intercepts Watson's attempt to leave, insisting they both hear the case or neither does.
The Count accepts and binds them both to absolute secrecy for two years, stating the matter could influence European history.
He admits his title is false and confirms he acts for an august person whose identity must be protected, implicating the royal house of Bohemia.
Holmes dryly states he was already aware of the client's false identity and the connection to the Bohemian monarchy.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A slow and heavy step, which had been heard upon the stairs and in the passage, paused immediately outside the door.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I was also aware of that,” murmured Holmes, settling himself down in his armchair and closing his eyes.

events.text_segment:
A slow and heavy step, which had been heard upon the stairs and in the passage, paused immediately outside the door. Then there was a loud and authoritative tap.
“Come in!” said Holmes.
A man entered who could hardly have been less than six feet six inches in height, with the chest and limbs of a Hercules. His dress was rich with a richness which would, in England, be looked upon as akin to bad taste. Heavy bands of astrakhan were slashed across the sleeves and fronts of his double-breasted coat, while the deep blue cloak which was thrown over his shoulders was lined with flame-coloured silk and secured at the neck with a brooch which consisted of a single flaming beryl. Boots which extended halfway up his calves, and which were trimmed at the tops with rich brown fur, completed the impression of barbaric opulence which was suggested by his whole appearance. He carried a broad-brimmed hat in his hand, while he wore across the upper part of his face, extending down past the cheekbones, a black vizard mask, which he had apparently adjusted that very moment, for his hand was still raised to it as he entered. From the lower part of the face he appeared to be a man of strong character, with a thick, hanging lip, and a long, straight chin suggestive of resolution pushed to the length of obstinacy.
“You had my note?” he asked with a deep harsh voice and a strongly marked German accent. “I told you that I would call.” He looked from one to the other of us, as if uncertain which to address.
“Pray take a seat,” said Holmes. “This is my friend and colleague, Dr. Watson, who is occasionally good enough to help me in my cases. Whom have I the honour to address?”
“You may address me as the Count Von Kramm, a Bohemian nobleman. I understand that this gentleman, your friend, is a man of honour and discretion, whom I may trust with a matter of the most extreme importance. If not, I should much prefer to communicate with you alone.”
I rose to go, but Holmes caught me by the wrist and pushed me back into my chair. “It is both, or none,” said he. “You may say before this gentleman anything which you may say to me.”
The Count shrugged his broad shoulders. “Then I must begin,” said he, “by binding you both to absolute secrecy for two years; at the end of that time the matter will be of no importance. At present it is not too much to say that it is of such weight it may have an influence upon European history.”
“I promise,” said Holmes.
“And I.”
“You will excuse this mask,” continued our strange visitor. “The august person who employs me wishes his agent to be unknown to you, and I may confess at once that the title by which I have just called myself is not exactly my own.”
“I was aware of it,” said Holmes dryly.
“The circumstances are of great delicacy, and every precaution has to be taken to quench what might grow to be an immense scandal and seriously compromise one of the reigning families of Europe. To speak plainly, the matter implicates the great House of Ormstein, hereditary kings of Bohemia.”
“I was also aware of that,” murmured Holmes, settling himself down in his armchair and closing his eyes.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: A slow and heavy step, which had been heard upon the stairs and in the passage, paused immediately outside the door. A sharp knock followed. 'Come in!' said Sherlock Holmes. The door opened, and a man entered who was certainly the most extraordinary figure I had ever seen. He was tall, with a broad, massive head, and a long, sinewy neck, like that of a swan. His dress was that of a German nobleman of the old school, with a profusion of gold and embroidery, and a heavy cloak of black fur which he threw off as he advanced. His face was swarthy, with a heavy black moustache, and his eyes were dark and piercing. He wore a black mask, which covered the upper part of his face, and which he had evidently just put on, for the folds of it were still in his hand. 'I have sent for you, gentlemen,' he said, in a deep, sonorous voice, with a strong German accent, 'because I have a matter of the utmost importance to communicate. I am Count Von Kramm, a Bohemian nobleman, and I have come from Vienna. I have a commission from an august personage, whose name I cannot mention, but whose interests are of the highest importance to the peace of Europe. I must have your absolute secrecy for two years. If you agree, I will proceed.' Holmes looked at him with his keen, questioning eyes. 'I think, sir,' he said, 'that you will find that Dr. Watson is as discreet as I am.' The Count turned to me. 'You will not mind, I trust, if I speak to Mr. Holmes alone?' 'I think, sir,' said Holmes, with a quiet smile, 'that if Dr. Watson is to be excluded, I shall also have to decline to hear your communication.' The Count looked surprised, but he bowed. 'Very well, then. I accept your conditions. I will speak to both of you, but I must warn you that if you betray my confidence, you will bring ruin upon your heads.' Holmes leaned back in his chair. 'I was already aware, Count, that you were not what you seemed, and that your business was with the royal house of Bohemia.'

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
A slow and heavy step, which had been heard upon the stairs and in the passage, paused immediately outside the door. For a moment there was silence, broken only by the measured ticking of the clock upon the mantelshelf. Then came the sound of a hand upon the handle, and the door creaked open. A tall, gaunt figure, wrapped in a long, threadbare coat, stood outlined against the dim light of the corridor. His face was hidden in the shadow of his cap, but his eyes, gleaming with a feverish light, seemed to pierce the darkness and fix themselves upon Sherlock Holmes with an intensity which was almost hypnotic.

"You are Mr. Sherlock Holmes," he said in a voice which was low and hoarse, yet full of a strange, compelling power. "I have come to you because I have no one else to go to. My name is John Openshaw, and I have a story to tell which will seem to you, perhaps, to be the wildest of fancies. But I swear to you, sir, that every word of it is the truth."

Holmes leaned back in his chair, his long, thin fingers interlaced before him, his keen eyes never leaving the figure in the doorway. "Pray sit down, Mr. Openshaw," he said. "You will find that I am always ready to listen to a story, however strange it may appear at first."

The man hesitated for a moment, then stepped forward and took a seat opposite the detective. He was a man of about forty, his face haggard and worn, with deep lines of anxiety and suffering etched into his features. His hands, which he now laid upon his knees, were large and strong, but they trembled slightly as though with some nervous agitation.

"I have been a shipbuilder for many years," he began, "and I have spent most of my life upon the river. But there is one night, one terrible night, which has haunted me ever since, and which I have never been able to forget. It was on the night of the full moon, and I was working late at my workshop, when I heard a sound which I shall never forget. It was a low, wailing cry, like the cry of a child in distress. I thought at first that it was the wind, but I soon realized that it was something else."

Holmes leaned forward slightly, his interest clearly aroused. "And what did you do, Mr. Openshaw?"

"I went out to investigate," the man replied. "I followed the sound to the river's edge, and there I saw something which I can only describe as a figure, half man and half beast, standing in the water. It turned its head slowly towards me, and I saw its eyes—great, glowing eyes, like those of a cat. Then it vanished into the mist, and I have never seen it again."

Holmes was silent for a moment, his mind clearly at work. "And what did you do after that?"

"I returned to my workshop, but I could not sleep. I have not slept since that night. I have tried to forget, but the memory of that figure haunts me. I have come to you, Mr. Holmes, because I believe that you are the only man who can help me."

Holmes rose to his feet and lit a fresh pipe. "You have come to the right man, Mr. Openshaw," he said. "I shall do all that I can to help you. But I must warn you that the truth may be stranger than the tale you have told me."

The man shuddered slightly, but he met Holmes' gaze with a look of quiet determination. "I am ready for the truth, whatever it may be," he said. "I have lived long enough in fear. I am ready to face it now."

events.title: The Client Reveals His True Identity as the King of Bohemia
detailed_summary: The visitor seems surprised by Holmes's languid demeanor, contrasting with his reputation.
Holmes impatiently urges 'his Majesty' to state the case.
Agitated, the man springs up, paces, then tears off his mask in desperation.
He declares himself the King, questioning the point of concealment.
Holmes calmly confirms he already knew he was addressing Wilhelm Gottsreich Sigismond von Ormstein, King of Bohemia.
The King explains his incognito visit from Prague, stating the matter was too delicate to entrust to an agent.
Holmes, eyes closed again, prompts him to proceed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Our visitor glanced with some apparent surprise at the languid, lounging figure of the man who had been no doubt depicted to him as the most incisive reasoner and most energetic agent in Europe.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Then, pray consult,” said Holmes, shutting his eyes once more.

events.text_segment:
Our visitor glanced with some apparent surprise at the languid, lounging figure of the man who had been no doubt depicted to him as the most incisive reasoner and most energetic agent in Europe. Holmes slowly reopened his eyes and looked impatiently at his gigantic client.
“If your Majesty would condescend to state your case,” he remarked, “I should be better able to advise you.”
The man sprang from his chair and paced up and down the room in uncontrollable agitation. Then, with a gesture of desperation, he tore the mask from his face and hurled it upon the ground. “You are right,” he cried; “I am the King. Why should I attempt to conceal it?”
“Why, indeed?” murmured Holmes. “Your Majesty had not spoken before I was aware that I was addressing Wilhelm Gottsreich Sigismond von Ormstein, Grand Duke of Cassel-Felstein, and hereditary King of Bohemia.”
“But you can understand,” said our strange visitor, sitting down once more and passing his hand over his high white forehead, “you can understand that I am not accustomed to doing such business in my own person. Yet the matter was so delicate that I could not confide it to an agent without putting myself in his power. I have come incognito from Prague for the purpose of consulting you.”
“Then, pray consult,” said Holmes, shutting his eyes once more.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Our visitor glanced with some apparent surprise at the languid, lounging figure of the man who had been no doubt depicted to him as the most incisive reasoner and most energetic agent in Europe. He had come, perhaps, with some mental picture of a shrewd, alert, and business-like man, and was surprised at finding his host lolling in an armchair, with a half-smoked cigarette between his lips, and his feet upon the edge of the mantelshelf. 

"I have to state," he said stiffly, "that I have an important matter to communicate to Mr. Sherlock Holmes."

"It is impossible that anything you can say can be of importance to me," said Holmes, opening his eyes and sitting up with a slight start. "I have already received a telegram from the King of Bohemia."

The man sprang from his chair with an exclamation of surprise and agitation. He walked about the room with a disturbed and hurried step, his face pale and his features twitching with emotion. Then suddenly, with a gesture of despair, he tore from his face a black mask which he wore, and stood revealed as a man of noble bearing, with a fine aquiline profile and a dark, imperial moustache. 

"I am the King," he said. "What is the use of concealment? You know who I am."

"Wilhelm Gottsreich Sigismond von Ormstein, King of Bohemia," said Holmes, with a smile, and resumed his former position with his eyes closed. 

"I came from Prague myself," said the King, "because the matter was too delicate to be entrusted to an agent."

"I am listening," said Holmes, closing his eyes once more.

He hesitated, uncertain whether to proceed with his business or to wait for some sign of animation from the man before him. Holmes, however, opened his eyes at that moment, and there was a gleam of intelligence in them that sent a sudden thrill through the visitor. In that instant, he realized that the man before him was not merely a figure of repose, but a mind of extraordinary acuity, waiting to be engaged. Holmes smiled faintly and said, “You have come about the case, I presume?” The visitor nodded, and the transformation was complete—Holmes was no longer lounging; he was alert, focused, and ready to unravel the mystery at hand.

events.title: The King Details His Past with Irene Adler and the Compromising Photograph
detailed_summary: The King recounts meeting the 'well-known adventuress' Irene Adler during a visit to Warsaw five years earlier.
At Holmes's request, Watson consults Holmes's index, finding Adler's biography detailing her New Jersey birth, operatic career (La Scala, Imperial Opera of Warsaw), and current residence in London.
Holmes summarizes the situation: the King became involved with Adler, wrote compromising letters, and now wants them back.
The King confirms this.
Holmes inquires about any secret marriage or legal documents, which the King denies.
Holmes questions how Adler could prove the letters' authenticity if used for blackmail, suggesting forgery or theft could be claimed.
The King mentions his private note-paper, seal, and finally, a photograph of them both.
Holmes reacts strongly to the photograph, calling it 'very bad' and a serious indiscretion.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “The facts are briefly these: Some five years ago, during a lengthy visit to Warsaw, I made the acquaintance of the well-known adventuress, Irene Adler.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Oh, dear! That is very bad! Your Majesty has indeed committed an indiscretion.”

events.text_segment:
“The facts are briefly these: Some five years ago, during a lengthy visit to Warsaw, I made the acquaintance of the well-known adventuress, Irene Adler. The name is no doubt familiar to you.”
“Kindly look her up in my index, Doctor,” murmured Holmes without opening his eyes. For many years he had adopted a system of docketing all paragraphs concerning men and things, so that it was difficult to name a subject or a person on which he could not at once furnish information. In this case I found her biography sandwiched in between that of a Hebrew rabbi and that of a staff-commander who had written a monograph upon the deep-sea fishes.
“Let me see!” said Holmes. “Hum! Born in New Jersey in the year 1858. Contralto—hum! La Scala, hum! Prima donna Imperial Opera of Warsaw—yes! Retired from operatic stage—ha! Living in London—quite so! Your Majesty, as I understand, became entangled with this young person, wrote her some compromising letters, and is now desirous of getting those letters back.”
“Precisely so. But how—”
“Was there a secret marriage?”
“None.”
“No legal papers or certificates?”
“None.”
“Then I fail to follow your Majesty. If this young person should produce her letters for blackmailing or other purposes, how is she to prove their authenticity?”
“There is the writing.”
“Pooh, pooh! Forgery.”
“My private note-paper.”
“Stolen.”
“My own seal.”
“Imitated.”
“My photograph.”
“Bought.”
“We were both in the photograph.”
“Oh, dear! That is very bad! Your Majesty has indeed committed an indiscretion.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The facts are briefly these: Some five years ago, during a lengthy visit to Warsaw, I made the acquaintance of the well-known adventuress, Irene Adler. I was then in the early days of my reign, and the frivolous and pleasure-loving spirit of the Polish capital had, I confess, somewhat the better of me. I met Miss Adler at a private theatrical, where she was playing the leading rôle in a French piece. She was the most striking woman I have ever seen, and her acting was of the highest order. I was fascinated by her, and we became very intimate. I was not aware at the time that she was the celebrated adventuress, but I afterwards learned that she had been the despair of many a nobleman and the scourge of many a police court. I was, however, too much under her influence to listen to any warnings. I wrote her many letters of a most affectionate nature, and I even went so far as to speak of marriage. She, however, was not to be caught in that way. She laughed at my proposals, and told me that she was not to be bought with a coronet. I was, I confess, somewhat jealous of the many admirers who surrounded her, and I took great pains to keep her to myself. I was, I fear, somewhat overbearing in my manner, and I may have given her cause to complain. I was, however, in love, and I did not care for the consequences. LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The facts are briefly these: Some five years ago, during a lengthy visit to Warsaw, I made the acquaintance of the well-known adventuress, Irene Adler. She was at that time the wife of the Neapolitan nobleman, Count Waldemar von Rosendorf, a man of considerable wealth and influence. I was struck by her intelligence and poise, and though our acquaintance was brief, it left a lasting impression. Some months later, I received a letter from her, requesting my assistance in a matter of great urgency. She had discovered that her husband was in possession of a photograph of considerable sensitivity—a portrait of herself in a compromising situation, which he threatened to use to blackmail her. I agreed to help, and through a combination of careful observation and a bit of subterfuge, I was able to recover the photograph and return it to her. The matter was resolved without further incident, and I heard nothing more of Irene Adler until some years later, when she reappeared in my life under very different circumstances. Her name, however, has remained one of the few that I have never spoken of to my friend Watson, for reasons that will perhaps become clear in time.

events.title: Failed Retrieval Attempts and Adler's Threat to Prevent the Royal Marriage
detailed_summary: The King laments his past foolishness, committed when he was Crown Prince.
He explains multiple failed attempts to recover the photograph: two burglaries of her house by his agents, interception of her luggage, and two instances of her being waylaid, all without success.
Holmes finds the problem intriguing.
The King emphasizes its seriousness, stating Adler intends to ruin him.
She plans to do this by preventing his impending marriage to Clotilde Lothman von Saxe-Meningen, known for her strict family principles.

Adler threatens to send the photograph to the princess's family, an act the King believes she is resolute enough to carry out, describing her as having a 'soul of steel' and the 'mind of the most resolute of men'.
The King is certain she hasn't sent it yet because she plans to do so on the day the betrothal is publicly announced, which is the following Monday.
Holmes notes this gives them three days, expressing relief as he has other matters to attend to.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I was mad—insane.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “That is very fortunate, as I have one or two matters of importance to look into just at present.

events.text_segment:
“I was mad—insane.”
“You have compromised yourself seriously.”
“I was only Crown Prince then. I was young. I am but thirty now.”
“It must be recovered.”
“We have tried and failed.”
“Your Majesty must pay. It must be bought.”
“She will not sell.”
“Stolen, then.”
“Five attempts have been made. Twice burglars in my pay ransacked her house. Once we diverted her luggage when she travelled. Twice she has been waylaid. There has been no result.”
“No sign of it?”
“Absolutely none.”
Holmes laughed. “It is quite a pretty little problem,” said he.
“But a very serious one to me,” returned the King reproachfully.
“Very, indeed. And what does she propose to do with the photograph?”
“To ruin me.”
“But how?”
“I am about to be married.”
“So I have heard.”
“To Clotilde Lothman von Saxe-Meningen, second daughter of the King of Scandinavia. You may know the strict principles of her family. She is herself the very soul of delicacy. A shadow of a doubt as to my conduct would bring the matter to an end.”
“And Irene Adler?”
“Threatens to send them the photograph. And she will do it. I know that she will do it. You do not know her, but she has a soul of steel. She has the face of the most beautiful of women, and the mind of the most resolute of men. Rather than I should marry another woman, there are no lengths to which she would not go—none.”
“You are sure that she has not sent it yet?”
“I am sure.”
“And why?”
“Because she has said that she would send it on the day when the betrothal was publicly proclaimed. That will be next Monday.”
“Oh, then we have three days yet,” said Holmes with a yawn. “That is very fortunate, as I have one or two matters of importance to look into just at present.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: I was mad—insane. I was Crown Prince of Bohemia, and I loved Irene Adler. She was a woman of the stage, a singer, a woman of no rank and no money. I was a prince, and I loved her. I was young and foolish, and I gave her a photograph of which I now beg you to help me recover. It is a photograph of the Crown Prince and of Miss Adler, taken in the days of our intimacy. It is a small, framed photograph, and it is in the possession of Miss Adler. I have tried everything to get it from her. I have sent men to break into her house, and they have failed. I have intercepted her luggage, and I have found nothing. I have had her waylaid in the street, and she has escaped me. I have offered her money, and she has refused it. I have offered her my love, and she has turned me from her door. She is a woman of steel, Mr. Holmes, a woman with the soul of a steel and the mind of the most resolute of men. She will not give me back the photograph, and she will not love me. But she will use it. She will send it to the family of the Princess Clotilde Lothman von Saxe-Meningen, and she will ruin me. The marriage is to be announced on Monday, and on that day, she will send the photograph. I have no time to lose, Mr. Holmes. I beg of you, help me. I have three days, and I must act before Monday. I have other matters to attend to, but this is a matter of the highest importance. I must have that photograph back, or I am lost.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“I was mad—insane.”

Holmes leaned forward, his keen eyes fixed upon me with an intensity that made me shiver. “Go on,” he said quietly. “Tell me everything.”

I took a deep breath, steadying myself. “It began with a letter,” I said. “A letter from my brother, Charles. He had been in London for some time, working as a clerk in a firm near the docks. He had always been a quiet man, reserved, but this letter was different. It was frantic, almost incoherent. He spoke of strange men watching him, of voices in the night, of a shadow that followed him wherever he went. He begged me to come to him, to help him before it was too late.”

Holmes nodded slowly. “And you came?”

I nodded. “I did. I found him in a small lodgings house near the Thames. He was gaunt, his eyes wild with fear. He would not speak at first, but when I pressed him, he told me of a man he had met—somebody who had offered him a position, a better life. But it was a trap. The man was a criminal, a smuggler, and Charles had been drawn into his schemes. He had tried to escape, but the man had threatened him, his family, and now he was being watched.”

Holmes was silent for a moment, his fingers steepled beneath his chin. “And what happened next?”

I hesitated. “Charles disappeared,” I said. “The next morning, he was gone. The landlady said she had seen nothing, heard nothing. I searched the streets, the docks, but there was no sign of him. I was desperate, and in my desperation, I began to lose my mind. I saw things that were not there, heard voices that did not exist. I became convinced that I was being watched, that I was in danger. I was mad—insane.”

Holmes exhaled softly. “You were not mad,” he said. “You were the victim of a very real and dangerous conspiracy. And your brother is still alive, I believe. We shall find him.”

I looked at him, hope flickering in my chest. “You think so?”

He smiled faintly. “I am certain of it.”

events.title: Financial Arrangements, Adler's Address, and Next Steps
detailed_summary: The King confirms he will remain in London, staying at the Langham Hotel under the alias Count Von Kramm.
Holmes promises to send updates on their progress.
When Holmes inquires about payment, the King grants him 'carte blanche', stating he'd give a province for the photograph.
For immediate expenses, the King provides a heavy bag containing three hundred pounds in gold and seven hundred in notes.
Holmes writes a receipt.
He asks for and records Mademoiselle Adler's address: Briony Lodge, Serpentine Avenue, St. John's Wood.
Holmes asks a final question about the photograph's format, learning it is a 'cabinet' size.
He bids the King good-night, expressing hope for good news soon.
As the King's carriage departs, Holmes wishes Watson good-night and asks him to return at three o'clock the next afternoon to discuss the case.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Your Majesty will, of course, stay in London for the present?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “If you will be good enough to call to-morrow afternoon at three o’clock I should like to chat this little matter over with you.”

events.text_segment:
Your Majesty will, of course, stay in London for the present?”
“Certainly. You will find me at the Langham under the name of the Count Von Kramm.”
“Then I shall drop you a line to let you know how we progress.”
“Pray do so. I shall be all anxiety.”
“Then, as to money?”
“You have carte blanche.”
“Absolutely?”
“I tell you that I would give one of the provinces of my kingdom to have that photograph.”
“And for present expenses?”
The King took a heavy chamois leather bag from under his cloak and laid it on the table.
“There are three hundred pounds in gold and seven hundred in notes,” he said.
Holmes scribbled a receipt upon a sheet of his note-book and handed it to him.
“And Mademoiselle’s address?” he asked.
“Is Briony Lodge, Serpentine Avenue, St. John’s Wood.”
Holmes took a note of it. “One other question,” said he. “Was the photograph a cabinet?”
“It was.”
“Then, good-night, your Majesty, and I trust that we shall soon have some good news for you. And good-night, Watson,” he added, as the wheels of the royal brougham rolled down the street. “If you will be good enough to call to-morrow afternoon at three o’clock I should like to chat this little matter over with you.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Your Majesty will, of course, stay in London for the present?”

“I shall remain at the Langham under the name of Count Von Kramm.”

“Very good. I shall send you a daily report of my progress.”

The King looked at me in some surprise, but I merely smiled and shrugged my shoulders. “It is not the first time that I have had to deal with a royal client,” said I.

“Mr. Holmes,” said the King, “I have the greatest confidence in you. If you can recover the photograph, I shall be eternally grateful. I would give you a province for it.”

“I shall be content with a moderate fee,” said Holmes, with a dry smile.

“Name your terms,” said the King.

“Carte blanche,” said Holmes. “I shall act as I think fit.”

The King nodded. “You shall have it. I shall give you full authority.”

“For the present,” said Holmes, “I shall require a little money for expenses.”

The King handed him a heavy bag. “There is three hundred pounds in gold and seven hundred in notes.”

Holmes weighed it in his hand. “I shall write you a receipt,” he said, and he did so.

“Now,” he said, “I should like the address of Mademoiselle Adler.”

The King gave it to him. “Briony Lodge, Serpentine Avenue, St. John’s Wood.”

“And the photograph—what size is it?”

“A cabinet.”

“Very good. I shall call upon her at once.”

The King rose to go. “I shall await your news with the greatest impatience.”

“Good-night, Your Majesty,” said Holmes. “I trust we shall have good news for you soon.”

As the King’s carriage drove away, Holmes turned to me. “Come, Watson,” he said, “we must not lose a moment. There is much to be done.”

“Shall I return in the morning?” I asked.

“Not in the morning,” said Holmes. “At three o’clock this afternoon. I shall have something to tell you by then.”

“Very good. I shall call upon her at once.”

The King rose to go. “I shall await your news with the greatest impatience.”

“Good-night, Your Majesty,” said Holmes. “I trust we shall have good news for you soon.”

As the King’s carriage drove away, Holmes turned to me. “Come, Watson,” he said, “we must not lose a moment. There is much to be done.”

“Shall I return in the morning?” I asked.

“Not in the morning,” said Holmes. “At three o’clock this afternoon. I shall have something to tell you by then.”

“I shall be there,” I said, and I took my leave.

IMPROVEMENT GUIDANCE:
1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion introduces invented dialogue and reflections, particularly with Watson speaking directly to the King and Holmes making comments about his fee, which are not present in the original.
- There is an added scene where Holmes and Watson discuss their next steps immediately after the King's departure, which does not occur in the original passage.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The completion omits the King's explicit statement of anxiety regarding the case, which is present in the original.
- The original contains a specific exchange about carte blanche and the King's willingness to give up a province, which is only partially represented in the completion.
- The completion does not include Holmes's act of taking a note of the address, nor does it mention the act of Holmes scribbling a receipt on his notebook, only that he writes a receipt.
- The original ends with Holmes inviting Watson to return at a specific time the next day, but the completion alters the timing and sequence of this invitation.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion inaccurately attributes certain lines and actions to Watson that are not his in the original.
- The sequence of events is altered: in the original, the discussion about the address and the photograph's size comes after the financial exchange, but the completion rearranges these elements.
- The completion changes the timing of when Watson is asked to return, shifting it from the next afternoon to the same day, which is not accurate to the original passage.
- There is an inaccurate representation of the King's emotional state and his statements about gratitude and reward, which are more elaborate in the completion than in the original.

Your Majesty will, of course, stay in London for the present?”

The King nodded gravely. “Yes, I have no desire to leave until this matter is fully resolved. The safety of my people is of the utmost importance, and I cannot rest until I am assured that the threat is gone.”

Holmes, who had been listening intently, leaned forward slightly. “Your Majesty, I assure you that we are doing everything in our power to uncover the truth. The case is complex, but I have every confidence that we will succeed.”

The King looked at Holmes with a mixture of gratitude and concern. “You have always been a man of great skill and discretion, Mr. Holmes. I trust your judgment implicitly. But I must confess, the situation is most troubling. The recent events have shaken the very foundations of our peace.”

Holmes nodded. “Indeed, Your Majesty. But I believe that the key to this mystery lies in the past. There are certain connections that I am currently investigating, and I am hopeful that they will lead us to the truth.”

The King sighed. “I only pray that you are right, Mr. Holmes. The eyes of the nation are upon us, and I cannot allow this matter to tarnish the dignity of the Crown.”

Holmes bowed slightly. “Your Majesty’s concerns are well-founded, but I assure you, I will not rest until this matter is resolved to your complete satisfaction.”

chapters.chapter_title: I. A SCANDAL IN BOHEMIA II.

events.title: Watson Awaits Holmes and Reflects on His Methods
detailed_summary: Dr. Watson arrives at 221B Baker Street at the agreed time but finds Sherlock Holmes is not present.
The landlady informs him that Holmes left early in the morning.
Watson decides to wait by the fire, reflecting on his deep interest in Holmes's current investigation.
He notes that while the case lacks the grim features of previous ones, the client's high status and the nature of the problem give it unique interest.
Watson reflects on his admiration for Holmes's methods, his analytical skill, and his consistent success, which makes the idea of Holmes failing seem impossible.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At three o’clock precisely I was at Baker Street, but Holmes had not yet returned.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So accustomed was I to his invariable success that the very possibility of his failing had ceased to enter into my head.

events.text_segment: At three o’clock precisely I was at Baker Street, but Holmes had not yet returned. The landlady informed me that he had left the house shortly after eight o’clock in the morning. I sat down beside the fire, however, with the intention of awaiting him, however long he might be. I was already deeply interested in his inquiry, for, though it was surrounded by none of the grim and strange features which were associated with the two crimes which I have already recorded, still, the nature of the case and the exalted station of his client gave it a character of its own. Indeed, apart from the nature of the investigation which my friend had on hand, there was something in his masterly grasp of a situation, and his keen, incisive reasoning, which made it a pleasure to me to study his system of work, and to follow the quick, subtle methods by which he disentangled the most inextricable mysteries. So accustomed was I to his invariable success that the very possibility of his failing had ceased to enter into my head.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: At three o’clock precisely I was at Baker Street, but Holmes had not yet returned. The landlady, a sharp-eyed, red-nosed woman, informed me that he had left early in the morning, and had not since returned. I sat down by the fire and tried to read, but my thoughts kept drifting back to the case which had brought me to Baker Street. It was not the grim and terrible business which had so often occupied my friend’s attention, but there was something in the nature of the problem, and in the high position of the client, which gave it a peculiar interest. I had always admired the extraordinary analytical skill of my friend, and the way in which he could unravel the most intricate mystery. It seemed to me impossible that there could be a problem which he could not solve, and yet I could not help feeling that this case was one of peculiar difficulty.
