I was admitted by the landlady, who informed me that he had gone out shortly after breakfast. I waited in the room, which was in its usual state of disorder, the papers and books scattered about as if they had been hastily abandoned. The fire had long since died down, and the room was cold and cheerless. I lit a fresh fire and sat by it, trying to read, but my thoughts kept returning to the case. I was still pondering the strange events of the previous day when I heard the door open and Holmes entered, his face grave and his manner preoccupied. He greeted me with a nod and, without a word, took his seat by the fire. I looked at him in astonishment, but he merely lit a pipe and puffed in silence for some time before speaking. At last he said, 'You have heard nothing of the case, I suppose?' I shook my head, and he leaned forward, his eyes gleaming with the excitement of a new mystery.

events.title: Holmes Returns in Disguise
detailed_summary: Shortly before four o'clock, a man appearing to be a disheveled, drunken groom enters the room.
Watson, despite his familiarity with Holmes's disguises, has to look closely multiple times to recognize his friend.
Holmes nods, disappears into his bedroom, and quickly reappears dressed normally in tweed.
He sits down, stretches out by the fire, and laughs uncontrollably for several minutes.
Intrigued, Watson asks what is so amusing.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was close upon four before the door opened, and a drunken-looking groom, ill-kempt and side-whiskered, with an inflamed face and disreputable clothes, walked into the room.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “What is it?”

events.text_segment:
It was close upon four before the door opened, and a drunken-looking groom, ill-kempt and side-whiskered, with an inflamed face and disreputable clothes, walked into the room. Accustomed as I was to my friend’s amazing powers in the use of disguises, I had to look three times before I was certain that it was indeed he. With a nod he vanished into the bedroom, whence he emerged in five minutes tweed-suited and respectable, as of old. Putting his hands into his pockets, he stretched out his legs in front of the fire and laughed heartily for some minutes.
“Well, really!” he cried, and then he choked and laughed again until he was obliged to lie back, limp and helpless, in the chair.
“What is it?”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: It was close upon four before the door opened, and a drunken-looking groom, ill-kempt and side-whiskered, with an inflamed face and disreputable clothes, walked into the room. I started up with an exclamation of surprise, for the man was so utterly unlike my companion that I could hardly believe that he was the same person. He walked heavily, with a somewhat unsteady gait, and his manner was that of a man who had been drinking. I looked at him again and again, and I could not help laughing outright at the absurdity of the disguise. "You have certainly done it this time," I said. "I should never have known you." He nodded, and with a sudden spring he vanished into his bedroom, and in a minute reappeared in his usual dress of tweed and flannel. He flung himself into his armchair, and for several minutes he lay back, laughing until the tears ran down his cheeks. "It is a triumph," he gasped at last. "I have been in the house for three hours, and I have never once been suspected. The very man who took my card at the door said that I was the most disreputable-looking customer he had seen all week."

events.title: Holmes Recounts His Morning Surveillance in Disguise
detailed_summary: Holmes declares the situation extremely funny and doubts Watson could guess his morning activities.
Watson correctly guesses Holmes was observing Irene Adler and her home.
Holmes confirms this but hints at an unusual outcome.
He explains he left early disguised as an unemployed groom, leveraging the camaraderie among horse handlers.

He located Briony Lodge, noting its layout: a small villa, garden at the back, close to the road, two stories, specific lock type, large front sitting-room with accessible windows, and a passage window reachable from the coach-house.
He found nothing else significant during his initial external examination.
Holmes describes going to a nearby mews (stables) down a lane by the garden wall.
He helped the ostlers with their horses.
In return for his help, he received small payment, drinks, tobacco, and abundant information about Miss Adler and other locals, whose life stories he patiently endured.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “It’s quite too funny.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I lent the ostlers a hand in rubbing down their horses, and received in exchange twopence, a glass of half-and-half, two fills of shag tobacco, and as much information as I could desire about Miss Adler, to say nothing of half a dozen other people in the neighbourhood in whom I was not in the least interested, but whose biographies I was compelled to listen to.”

events.text_segment:
“It’s quite too funny. I am sure you could never guess how I employed my morning, or what I ended by doing.”
“I can’t imagine. I suppose that you have been watching the habits, and perhaps the house, of Miss Irene Adler.”
“Quite so; but the sequel was rather unusual. I will tell you, however. I left the house a little after eight o’clock this morning in the character of a groom out of work. There is a wonderful sympathy and freemasonry among horsey men. Be one of them, and you will know all that there is to know. I soon found Briony Lodge. It is a bijou villa, with a garden at the back, but built out in front right up to the road, two stories. Chubb lock to the door. Large sitting-room on the right side, well furnished, with long windows almost to the floor, and those preposterous English window fasteners which a child could open. Behind there was nothing remarkable, save that the passage window could be reached from the top of the coach-house. I walked round it and examined it closely from every point of view, but without noting anything else of interest.
“I then lounged down the street and found, as I expected, that there was a mews in a lane which runs down by one wall of the garden. I lent the ostlers a hand in rubbing down their horses, and received in exchange twopence, a glass of half-and-half, two fills of shag tobacco, and as much information as I could desire about Miss Adler, to say nothing of half a dozen other people in the neighbourhood in whom I was not in the least interested, but whose biographies I was compelled to listen to.”

It’s quite too funny. I have been watching Miss Adler’s house all the morning, and I have seen her drive out with a young man who, if I am not very much mistaken, is the celebrated Lord Blackwater. I have also seen her receive a letter which, judging from her manner, must have been of the greatest importance. Now, I want to know, Watson, what do you think I have been doing all this time?"

"I should imagine," I answered, "that you have been watching Miss Adler’s house."

"Exactly!" he cried, clapping me on the shoulder. "You have hit it off at once. But I must say, I think you will find it difficult to guess the result of my observations."

"I shall try," I said, smiling.

"Well, then, I will tell you. I found out that the house is a small villa, with a garden at the back, and a coach-house and stable at the side. It is built of red brick, with a slated roof, and has two stories. The front door is protected by a strong iron gate, and the windows are all of the same pattern, with small panes of glass. The sitting-room is at the front, and the windows are large and easy to reach. There is also a passage window which opens from the coach-house, and which, I think, might be of some importance."

"You have been there all the morning?"

"Yes, and I have not found out much more than that. But I have been in the neighborhood, and I have made a few inquiries. events.title: Gathering Intelligence on Irene Adler and Godfrey Norton
detailed_summary: Watson prompts Holmes for details about Irene Adler.
Holmes relays the mews workers' unanimous opinion: Adler is captivatingly beautiful and charming.
He learned her routine: she lives quietly, performs at concerts, takes a drive daily from five to seven PM, and rarely goes out otherwise.
She has only one regular male visitor, Mr. Godfrey Norton, a lawyer from the Inner Temple, who visits frequently (once or twice daily).
Holmes notes the value of cabmen as informants, as they knew Norton well from driving him.
After gathering this information, Holmes returned to Briony Lodge to contemplate his strategy.
He identifies Norton as a key figure, speculating about his relationship with Adler (client, friend, or lover) and how it affects the photograph's location.
The uncertainty about their relationship complicates his investigation, forcing him to consider investigating Norton's residence as well.
Holmes acknowledges these details might bore Watson but emphasizes their importance for understanding the case's complexities.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “And what of Irene Adler?” I asked.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I fear that I bore you with these details, but I have to let you see my little difficulties, if you are to understand the situation.”

events.text_segment:
“And what of Irene Adler?” I asked.
“Oh, she has turned all the men’s heads down in that part. She is the daintiest thing under a bonnet on this planet. So say the Serpentine-mews, to a man. She lives quietly, sings at concerts, drives out at five every day, and returns at seven sharp for dinner. Seldom goes out at other times, except when she sings. Has only one male visitor, but a good deal of him. He is dark, handsome, and dashing, never calls less than once a day, and often twice. He is a Mr. Godfrey Norton, of the Inner Temple. See the advantages of a cabman as a confidant. They had driven him home a dozen times from Serpentine-mews, and knew all about him. When I had listened to all they had to tell, I began to walk up and down near Briony Lodge once more, and to think over my plan of campaign.
“This Godfrey Norton was evidently an important factor in the matter. He was a lawyer. That sounded ominous. What was the relation between them, and what the object of his repeated visits? Was she his client, his friend, or his mistress? If the former, she had probably transferred the photograph to his keeping. If the latter, it was less likely. On the issue of this question depended whether I should continue my work at Briony Lodge, or turn my attention to the gentleman’s chambers in the Temple. It was a delicate point, and it widened the field of my inquiry. I fear that I bore you with these details, but I have to let you see my little difficulties, if you are to understand the situation.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“And what of Irene Adler?” I asked.

Holmes leaned back in his chair and smiled. “Ah, you are beginning to take an interest in the case, Watson. You are beginning to perceive that there are depths in it. I was not sure at first whether you would rise to the occasion. But now you are asking questions which show that you are following the thread. You are inquiring about the woman who is the central figure in this affair.”

“Central figure?” I repeated.

“Precisely. You have heard, no doubt, of the celebrated beauty, Irene Adler, the woman known as the ‘Woman’ in the papers. She is a remarkable person, and I confess that I have a high regard for her. The mews men are all agreed that she is the most beautiful woman in London. She is also, I believe, the most fascinating. I have studied her habits with some care. She lives quietly, plays at the opera, drives every afternoon from five to seven, and is otherwise rarely seen. She has but one regular male visitor, Mr. Godfrey Norton, a lawyer of the Inner Temple, who calls upon her once or twice a day. The cabmen know him well, for he is a frequent passenger. I have learned much from them, Watson. They are a most useful class of informants.”

“And what is your opinion of Mr. Norton?” I asked.

“I have not yet formed one. He may be a client, a friend, or a lover. That is a question which I must determine. It is of the utmost importance, for it may lead me to the photograph. But I confess that the matter is complicated. I must consider the possibility of searching his house as well as hers. You see, Watson, the case is not so simple as it might appear. There are many threads to be followed, and I must not lose sight of any of them.”

I looked at my friend in astonishment. “You are making a mystery of it, Holmes,” I said.

“Not at all,” he replied. “I am merely stating the facts as they appear to me. You may find them dull, but I assure you they are of the greatest interest to me.”

“Not at all,” he replied. “I am merely stating the facts as they appear to me. You may find them dull, but I assure you they are of the greatest interest to me.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“And what of Irene Adler?” I asked.

Holmes leaned back in his chair, his expression unreadable, his eyes fixed on the ceiling as if searching for the answer in the cracks of the plaster.

“She is a woman,” he said at last, “of a rare and radiant beauty, of an intelligence which might have made her a great man, and of a will which could have bent the world to her will. But she is not a woman to be loved—no, Watson, not in the way that you or I might love. She is a woman to be admired, to be feared, and perhaps, in the end, to be pitied.”

I looked at him, surprised. I had never seen Holmes speak of a woman with such reverence, nor with such sorrow.

“She was once engaged to the King of Bohemia,” he continued, “and though the engagement was broken, the King still holds her in the highest esteem. She is a woman of many secrets, and it was for one of those secrets that I was called to her case.”

I waited, but he said no more. I knew better than to press him. Some things, I had learned, were not for me to know. But I could not help but feel that Irene Adler was a woman who had left a mark on my friend, a mark deeper than any case he had ever taken.

And so, I left it at that. I did not ask again. I did not need to. I had seen the look in his eyes, and I knew that Irene Adler was not just a name in a case file. She was a ghost in his mind, a shadow in his past, and perhaps, in some small way, a part of the man I had come to call my friend.

events.title: Holmes Witnesses the Hasty Wedding of Irene Adler and Godfrey Norton
detailed_summary: Watson assures Holmes he is following intently.
Holmes continues, explaining that while pondering, a hansom cab arrived at Briony Lodge.
A handsome, dark man (identified as Godfrey Norton) jumped out in a great hurry, telling the cabman to wait.
Norton rushed past the maid into the house familiarly.
Holmes observed Norton pacing agitatedly and talking inside the sitting-room for about half an hour, but couldn't see Adler.

Norton emerged looking even more rushed, checked his watch, and instructed the cabman to drive furiously to two locations: Gross & Hankey's and then the Church of St. Monica, offering a bonus for speed.
As Norton departed, Holmes considered following, but then a small landau arrived hastily.
Irene Adler rushed out of the house and into the landau, giving Holmes only a glimpse of her remarkable beauty.
She instructed her coachman to drive to the Church of St. Monica quickly, also offering a bonus.
Recognizing the significance, Holmes hailed a passing cab, despite his shabby appearance.
He instructed the driver to go to the same church with the same urgency and offered payment.
He notes the time (11:35 AM) made the situation's meaning clear (a wedding).
Holmes's cab drove fast, but Norton's cab and Adler's landau arrived at the church first.
Paying his cabman, Holmes hurried inside the church.
He found only Norton, Adler, and a clergyman at the altar, the clergyman appearing to argue with them.
Holmes casually moved up the aisle.
Unexpectedly, the group at the altar turned, and Norton ran towards Holmes.
Norton urgently pleaded for Holmes to act as a witness, stating there were only three minutes left for the marriage to be legal.
Holmes was pulled to the altar and found himself participating in the wedding ceremony of Irene Adler and Godfrey Norton, prompted with responses and vouching for unknown details.
The ceremony concluded instantly, with the couple thanking him and the clergyman beaming.
Holmes describes the situation as utterly preposterous, the memory of which caused his earlier laughter.
He explains an issue with their license required a witness, and his arrival prevented Norton from having to find one on the street.
Adler gave Holmes a sovereign coin as thanks, which he intends to keep on his watch chain.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The bride gave me a sovereign, and I mean to wear it on my watch chain in memory of the occasion.”

events.text_segment:
“I am following you closely,” I answered.
“I was still balancing the matter in my mind when a hansom cab drove up to Briony Lodge, and a gentleman sprang out. He was a remarkably handsome man, dark, aquiline, and moustached—evidently the man of whom I had heard. He appeared to be in a great hurry, shouted to the cabman to wait, and brushed past the maid who opened the door with the air of a man who was thoroughly at home.
“He was in the house about half an hour, and I could catch glimpses of him in the windows of the sitting-room, pacing up and down, talking excitedly, and waving his arms. Of her I could see nothing. Presently he emerged, looking even more flurried than before. As he stepped up to the cab, he pulled a gold watch from his pocket and looked at it earnestly, ‘Drive like the devil,’ he shouted, ‘first to Gross & Hankey’s in Regent Street, and then to the Church of St. Monica in the Edgeware Road. Half a guinea if you do it in twenty minutes!’
“Away they went, and I was just wondering whether I should not do well to follow them when up the lane came a neat little landau, the coachman with his coat only half-buttoned, and his tie under his ear, while all the tags of his harness were sticking out of the buckles. It hadn’t pulled up before she shot out of the hall door and into it. I only caught a glimpse of her at the moment, but she was a lovely woman, with a face that a man might die for.
“‘The Church of St. Monica, John,’ she cried, ‘and half a sovereign if you reach it in twenty minutes.’
“This was quite too good to lose, Watson. I was just balancing whether I should run for it, or whether I should perch behind her landau when a cab came through the street. The driver looked twice at such a shabby fare, but I jumped in before he could object. ‘The Church of St. Monica,’ said I, ‘and half a sovereign if you reach it in twenty minutes.’ It was twenty-five minutes to twelve, and of course it was clear enough what was in the wind.
“My cabby drove fast. I don’t think I ever drove faster, but the others were there before us. The cab and the landau with their steaming horses were in front of the door when I arrived. I paid the man and hurried into the church. There was not a soul there save the two whom I had followed and a surpliced clergyman, who seemed to be expostulating with them. They were all three standing in a knot in front of the altar. I lounged up the side aisle like any other idler who has dropped into a church. Suddenly, to my surprise, the three at the altar faced round to me, and Godfrey Norton came running as hard as he could towards me.
“‘Thank God,’ he cried. ‘You’ll do. Come! Come!’
“‘What then?’ I asked.
“‘Come, man, come, only three minutes, or it won’t be legal.’
“I was half-dragged up to the altar, and before I knew where I was I found myself mumbling responses which were whispered in my ear, and vouching for things of which I knew nothing, and generally assisting in the secure tying up of Irene Adler, spinster, to Godfrey Norton, bachelor. It was all done in an instant, and there was the gentleman thanking me on the one side and the lady on the other, while the clergyman beamed on me in front. It was the most preposterous position in which I ever found myself in my life, and it was the thought of it that started me laughing just now. It seems that there had been some informality about their license, that the clergyman absolutely refused to marry them without a witness of some sort, and that my lucky appearance saved the bridegroom from having to sally out into the streets in search of a best man. The bride gave me a sovereign, and I mean to wear it on my watch chain in memory of the occasion.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“I am following you closely,” I answered.

He turned and looked at me with a curious expression, his sharp eyes narrowing slightly as if he were measuring my words. “You are not the first to say so, Dr. Watson,” he said, his voice calm but with a hint of amusement. “But I must confess, I have yet to meet anyone who truly does.”

I felt a slight sting at his remark, though I knew it was not meant to be unkind. “I have followed you through many adventures,” I replied, “and I have never shied away from danger or difficulty.”

Sherlock Holmes smiled faintly, the ghost of a smile that rarely reached his eyes. “Indeed, you have been a most valuable companion. But following me is not merely a matter of presence, it is a matter of perception. You must see what I see, think as I think, and only then can you truly say you are following me.”

I was not sure how to respond to this. I had always considered myself a keen observer, and I had certainly learned much from Holmes over the years. But I knew that in his eyes, I was still a long way from being his equal.

He turned away from me and began to pace the room, his long, lank figure moving with a restless energy that was so characteristic of him. “There is a case I am working on at the moment,” he said, “and I believe it may interest you. A most peculiar case, involving a missing heir and a forged will.”

I was intrigued. “I should be delighted to assist you, if you think I can be of any help.”

He looked at me again, his expression unreadable. “I do not think you will be of much help,” he said. “But I do think you will find the case most interesting. And perhaps, if you are very attentive, you may learn something from it.”

I was not sure whether to take this as a compliment or an insult, but I decided to take it as a challenge. “Very well,” I said. “Tell me more about the case.”

Holmes sat down in his chair and leaned back, steepling his fingers beneath his chin. “The heir in question is the son of a wealthy industrialist, a man named Sir Reginald Ashcombe. He was found dead in his study last week, the victim of what the police believe to be a heart attack. But I have my suspicions that it was something more sinister.”

I raised an eyebrow. “You suspect murder?”

“Not murder, exactly,” he said. “But I suspect foul play. The will that was found in the study was not the one that Sir Reginald had made in recent years. It was an old one, dating back to ten years ago, and it left the entire estate to his son, Reginald junior. But the son has been missing for several months now, and no one seems to know where he is.”

I was beginning to see the connection. “You think the will was forged?”

“I think it is possible,” he said. “And I think that someone may have gone to great lengths to ensure that the son would inherit the estate. Perhaps even to the point of murder.”

I was fascinated. “And what do you propose to do?”

“I propose to find the son,” he said. “And to discover the truth about his father’s death. It is a most intriguing puzzle, and I believe it will take all my faculties to solve it.”

I could not help but feel a sense of pride at being included in this case, even if only as an observer. “I shall do my best to assist you,” I said.

Holmes looked at me for a long moment, then nodded. “Very well, Dr. Watson. Let us begin our investigation.”

events.title: Post-Wedding Developments and Enlisting Watson's Aid
detailed_summary: Watson expresses surprise at this turn of events and asks what happened next.
Holmes explains the wedding seriously threatened his plans, fearing the couple might leave immediately.
However, at the church door, Adler and Norton separated, Norton returning to the Temple and Adler to her home.
Holmes overheard Adler confirming she would maintain her usual five o'clock drive.
With the immediate threat averted, Holmes went off to make his own arrangements.
Watson inquires about these arrangements.
Holmes rings for food, requesting cold beef and beer, explaining he's been too busy to eat and expects a busier evening.
He formally requests Watson's cooperation for the evening's activities.
Watson readily agrees.
Holmes confirms Watson is willing to break the law and risk arrest.
Watson affirms his willingness for a good cause, which Holmes assures him it is.
Holmes expresses his confidence in Watson's reliability.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “This is a very unexpected turn of affairs,” said I; “and what then?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I was sure that I might rely on you.”

events.text_segment:
“This is a very unexpected turn of affairs,” said I; “and what then?”
“Well, I found my plans very seriously menaced. It looked as if the pair might take an immediate departure, and so necessitate very prompt and energetic measures on my part. At the church door, however, they separated, he driving back to the Temple, and she to her own house. ‘I shall drive out in the park at five as usual,’ she said as she left him. I heard no more. They drove away in different directions, and I went off to make my own arrangements.”
“Which are?”
“Some cold beef and a glass of beer,” he answered, ringing the bell. “I have been too busy to think of food, and I am likely to be busier still this evening. By the way, Doctor, I shall want your co-operation.”
“I shall be delighted.”
“You don’t mind breaking the law?”
“Not in the least.”
“Nor running a chance of arrest?”
“Not in a good cause.”
“Oh, the cause is excellent!”
“Then I am your man.”
“I was sure that I might rely on you.”

“This is a very unexpected turn of affairs,” said I; “and what then?”

Holmes leaned back in his chair with a look of quiet satisfaction. “It means, my dear Watson, that we are on the brink of a most singular and intriguing case. The facts are these: a man was found this morning in the alley behind the Criterion, half-dead from exposure and bearing marks of violence. He is now in the care of a surgeon, and he has asked for me by name. I have reason to believe that he is the key to a mystery involving the highest circles of society. The man is a pawn in a game of intrigue, and it is our task to uncover the players. I propose we visit him at once. You will, I trust, accompany me?”

I rose at once, for the interest of the case was now as keen to me as to my friend. We hailed a hansom, and in a few minutes we were speeding through the foggy streets of London toward the unknown.

events.title: Holmes Details the Plan to Retrieve the Photograph
detailed_summary: Watson asks what Holmes needs him to do.
Holmes defers the explanation until the landlady (Mrs. Turner) brings food.
Once the food arrives, Holmes begins eating hungrily, stating he must discuss the plan while eating due to limited time.
He notes it is nearly five o'clock and they need to be at Briony Lodge by seven, when Irene Adler (now Madame Norton) returns from her drive.
Watson asks about the plan.
Holmes states he has arranged events but insists Watson must not interfere under any circumstances, remaining completely passive.
He predicts some minor 'unpleasantness' which Watson should not join.
This event will result in Holmes being taken into Briony Lodge.
A few minutes later, the sitting-room window will open.
Watson's task is to position himself near this open window and watch Holmes, who will be visible.
Upon seeing Holmes raise his hand as a signal, Watson must throw an object (provided by Holmes) into the room and simultaneously shout 'Fire!'.
Watson confirms he understands the instructions.
Holmes reveals the object is a plumber's smoke-rocket designed to self-ignite.
He clarifies Watson's role ends there; the fire cry will be echoed by others, after which Watson should walk to the street's end and wait for Holmes.
Watson precisely restates his instructions: remain neutral, get near the window, watch Holmes, throw the object on signal, cry fire, and wait at the corner.
Holmes confirms this is correct, and Watson assures his reliability.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Then you may entirely rely on me.”

events.text_segment:
“But what is it you wish?”
“When Mrs. Turner has brought in the tray I will make it clear to you. Now,” he said as he turned hungrily on the simple fare that our landlady had provided, “I must discuss it while I eat, for I have not much time. It is nearly five now. In two hours we must be on the scene of action. Miss Irene, or Madame, rather, returns from her drive at seven. We must be at Briony Lodge to meet her.”
“And what then?”
“You must leave that to me. I have already arranged what is to occur. There is only one point on which I must insist. You must not interfere, come what may. You understand?”
“I am to be neutral?”
“To do nothing whatever. There will probably be some small unpleasantness. Do not join in it. It will end in my being conveyed into the house. Four or five minutes afterwards the sitting-room window will open. You are to station yourself close to that open window.”
“Yes.”
“You are to watch me, for I will be visible to you.”
“Yes.”
“And when I raise my hand—so—you will throw into the room what I give you to throw, and will, at the same time, raise the cry of fire. You quite follow me?”
“Entirely.”
“It is nothing very formidable,” he said, taking a long cigar-shaped roll from his pocket. “It is an ordinary plumber’s smoke-rocket, fitted with a cap at either end to make it self-lighting. Your task is confined to that. When you raise your cry of fire, it will be taken up by quite a number of people. You may then walk to the end of the street, and I will rejoin you in ten minutes. I hope that I have made myself clear?”
“I am to remain neutral, to get near the window, to watch you, and at the signal to throw in this object, then to raise the cry of fire, and to wait you at the corner of the street.”
“Precisely.”
“Then you may entirely rely on me.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“But what is it you wish?” I asked, as I sat down.

Holmes chuckled to himself and got out his scrap-book, while he recounted with the energy of a man who relishes his work the whole history of the case which I have summarised in the preceding pages. “I have written it all out,” said he, “for the benefit of the divisional police, and I have also sent a copy to the Commissioner of Police, with a covering letter. But I have not yet told you the exact part which you are to play in the matter.”

“I am ready to do anything that is not too dangerous,” I said.

“Danger is a very relative term,” said Holmes. “But I shall not ask you to run any serious risk. I shall be quite explicit with you. First, however, I must have some lunch, for I have not had time to eat since yesterday. Mrs. Turner will be up directly with the tray. I must discuss the matter while I eat, for I have no time to spare.”

He looked at his watch and smiled. “It is nearly five now, and we must be at Briony Lodge by seven, when Madame Norton returns from her drive. I have arranged everything, and I shall be in the house by half-past seven at the latest. But I must have your help in a very small matter.”

The landlady had already brought the tray, and Holmes began to eat with a hearty appetite. “You must not interfere in any way,” said he, between mouthfuls. “You must be absolutely passive. I foresee a little unpleasantness, but you must not join in. The result will be that I shall be taken into Briony Lodge. A few minutes after I am in, the sitting-room window will open. You will be near it, and you will see me. When I raise my hand, you will throw this into the room and cry, ‘Fire!’”

He handed me a small, red object. “It is a plumber’s smoke-rocket,” he explained. “It will self-ignite. That will be your signal. Then you will walk to the corner of the street and wait for me.”

“I understand,” I said. “I shall remain neutral, get near the window, watch you, throw the rocket on your signal, cry fire, and wait at the corner.”

“Exactly,” said Holmes. “You are a man of precision, Watson.”

“I shall not fail you,” I said.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“But what is it you wish?”

I looked at him in some surprise, for I had not expected him to take the matter so seriously. “I wish,” I said slowly, “to understand the nature of the case. You have been so accustomed to my assistance in the past that I fear you may not have considered the matter from my point of view. I am not a mere observer, Mr. Holmes. I am a partner in these investigations.”

He smiled, a faint, enigmatic curve of his lips. “Indeed, Watson. And I value your partnership more than you know. But this case is of a peculiar nature. It is not one of the usual crimes that come to my door. It is something more delicate, more personal. I have reason to believe that a man of some standing in society is in grave danger, and I would not have you exposed to the same.”

I bristled slightly at this. “I have faced danger before, Holmes. I have been shot at, I have been beaten, I have been threatened. I have never once turned away from a case because it was dangerous.”

He raised a hand in a gesture of peace. “I do not doubt your courage, my dear Watson. But this is not a matter of courage. It is a matter of discretion. The man in question is not a criminal, nor is he a victim in the usual sense. He is a man who has made a mistake, and now he is paying the price for it. I must tread carefully, and I would not have you caught in the crossfire.”

I considered this for a moment. “And yet, if you do not tell me what is at stake, I cannot help you. I cannot be a partner in the dark.”

He sighed, and for a moment, I saw a flicker of something in his eyes—perhaps weariness, perhaps regret. “Very well,” he said at last. “I will tell you what I know. But understand this, Watson: once you know, there is no turning back. The game is afoot, and it is a game that may cost us both more than we are prepared to lose.”

events.title: Disguise, Arrival at Briony Lodge, and Strategic Deductions
detailed_summary: Holmes expresses satisfaction and prepares for his next disguise.
He goes into his bedroom and returns transformed into a kind-looking Nonconformist clergyman, complete with appropriate attire and a benevolent demeanor.
Watson observes that Holmes doesn't just change clothes but seems to alter his entire personality with each disguise, lamenting the loss to the stage.
They leave Baker Street at 6:15 PM and arrive in Serpentine Avenue near Briony Lodge around 6:50 PM.
Dusk is falling, lamps are being lit, and they walk back and forth.
The house matches Holmes's description, but the street is surprisingly busy for a quiet area.
Watson notes various people around: shabbily dressed men, a scissors-grinder, guardsmen flirting, and well-dressed young men smoking.
Holmes remarks that Adler's marriage simplifies things, making the photograph a threat to her relationship with Norton, just as it is to the King's.
The key question now is the photograph's location.
Watson echoes the question.
Holmes reasons Adler likely doesn't carry the cabinet-sized photo, especially knowing the King has tried to have her searched twice.
He dismisses the idea of it being with her banker or lawyer, believing women prefer personal control over secrets and wouldn't trust a third party susceptible to influence.
Furthermore, her intent to use it soon implies it must be readily accessible within her own house.
Watson points out the house has been burgled twice.
Holmes dismisses the burglars as inept.
When Watson asks how Holmes will search, Holmes states he won't look himself.
Instead, he plans to make Adler reveal its location.
He confidently asserts she won't be able to refuse.
Hearing carriage wheels, Holmes identifies it as Adler's and instructs Watson to follow orders precisely.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “That is excellent.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Now carry out my orders to the letter.”

events.text_segment:
“That is excellent. I think, perhaps, it is almost time that I prepare for the new role I have to play.”
He disappeared into his bedroom and returned in a few minutes in the character of an amiable and simple-minded Nonconformist clergyman. His broad black hat, his baggy trousers, his white tie, his sympathetic smile, and general look of peering and benevolent curiosity were such as Mr. John Hare alone could have equalled. It was not merely that Holmes changed his costume. His expression, his manner, his very soul seemed to vary with every fresh part that he assumed. The stage lost a fine actor, even as science lost an acute reasoner, when he became a specialist in crime.
It was a quarter past six when we left Baker Street, and it still wanted ten minutes to the hour when we found ourselves in Serpentine Avenue. It was already dusk, and the lamps were just being lighted as we paced up and down in front of Briony Lodge, waiting for the coming of its occupant. The house was just such as I had pictured it from Sherlock Holmes’ succinct description, but the locality appeared to be less private than I expected. On the contrary, for a small street in a quiet neighbourhood, it was remarkably animated. There was a group of shabbily dressed men smoking and laughing in a corner, a scissors-grinder with his wheel, two guardsmen who were flirting with a nurse-girl, and several well-dressed young men who were lounging up and down with cigars in their mouths.
“You see,” remarked Holmes, as we paced to and fro in front of the house, “this marriage rather simplifies matters. The photograph becomes a double-edged weapon now. The chances are that she would be as averse to its being seen by Mr. Godfrey Norton, as our client is to its coming to the eyes of his princess. Now the question is, Where are we to find the photograph?”
“Where, indeed?”
“It is most unlikely that she carries it about with her. It is cabinet size. Too large for easy concealment about a woman’s dress. She knows that the King is capable of having her waylaid and searched. Two attempts of the sort have already been made. We may take it, then, that she does not carry it about with her.”
“Where, then?”
“Her banker or her lawyer. There is that double possibility. But I am inclined to think neither. Women are naturally secretive, and they like to do their own secreting. Why should she hand it over to anyone else? She could trust her own guardianship, but she could not tell what indirect or political influence might be brought to bear upon a business man. Besides, remember that she had resolved to use it within a few days. It must be where she can lay her hands upon it. It must be in her own house.”
“But it has twice been burgled.”
“Pshaw! They did not know how to look.”
“But how will you look?”
“I will not look.”
“What then?”
“I will get her to show me.”
“But she will refuse.”
“She will not be able to. But I hear the rumble of wheels. It is her carriage. Now carry out my orders to the letter.”

events.title: Staged Disturbance and Holmes's Feigned Injury
detailed_summary: A smart landau carrying Irene Adler arrives at Briony Lodge.
As it stops, two loafers rush to open the carriage door, hoping for a tip, and immediately start quarreling.
Two guardsmen join in, taking sides, and the scissors-grinder supports the opposing side, escalating the conflict.
A blow is struck, and suddenly Adler, having just stepped out, is surrounded by a struggling group of men fighting fiercely.
Holmes rushes forward, seemingly to protect her.
Just as he reaches her, he cries out and collapses, fake blood appearing on his face.
At his fall, the combatants (guardsmen and loafers) quickly disperse.
Bystanders crowd around to assist Adler and the injured man (Holmes).
Irene Adler, after initially hurrying up her steps, pauses at the top, framed by the hall lights, looking back anxiously.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As he spoke the gleam of the sidelights of a carriage came round the curve of the avenue.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: looking back into the street.

events.text_segment: As he spoke the gleam of the sidelights of a carriage came round the curve of the avenue. It was a smart little landau which rattled up to the door of Briony Lodge. As it pulled up, one of the loafing men at the corner dashed forward to open the door in the hope of earning a copper, but was elbowed away by another loafer, who had rushed up with the same intention. A fierce quarrel broke out, which was increased by the two guardsmen, who took sides with one of the loungers, and by the scissors-grinder, who was equally hot upon the other side. A blow was struck, and in an instant the lady, who had stepped from her carriage, was the centre of a little knot of flushed and struggling men, who struck savagely at each other with their fists and sticks. Holmes dashed into the crowd to protect the lady; but, just as he reached her, he gave a cry and dropped to the ground, with the blood running freely down his face. At his fall the guardsmen took to their heels in one direction and the loungers in the other, while a number of better dressed people, who had watched the scuffle without taking part in it, crowded in to help the lady and to attend to the injured man. Irene Adler, as I will still call her, had hurried up the steps; but she stood at the top with her superb figure outlined against the lights of the hall, looking back into the street.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: As he spoke the gleam of the sidelights of a carriage came round the curve of the avenue. A smart landau, with its pair of spirited bays, was seen to draw up in front of the lodge gates. A tall, stately woman, with a face of marvellous beauty and a bearing of perfect dignity, stepped from the carriage. She was followed by a maid, who carried a small valise. As the carriage door was flung open, two loafers, who had been lounging near the gate, sprang forward with alacrity, hoping for a tip. But the sight of the lady's retinue had already set them at variance, and they began to quarrel in a loud and angry tone. Two guardsmen, who had been on duty in the vicinity, joined in the fray, taking sides with the loafers. A scissors-grinder, who had been sharpening his shears a few paces off, added his voice to the other side, and the quarrel became a battle. A blow was struck, and in an instant the whole group of men were locked in a fierce struggle. I saw, to my horror, that the lady was caught in the midst of it, her face pale with alarm. With a quick movement, Holmes rushed forward, his long, sinewy limbs carrying him swiftly across the lawn. He reached her side just as the struggle was at its height, and with a sudden cry of pain, he staggered and fell. A stream of blood, which I knew to be artificial, trickled from his face. At the sound of his fall, the combatants sprang apart, and in an instant the place was deserted. The loafers and guardsmen had vanished like shadows, and only the scissors-grinder remained, staring at the scene with a look of bewilderment. A crowd of bystanders, who had been drawn by the noise, now gathered around us. They assisted the lady to the steps of the house, and one or two of them carried Holmes, who still lay motionless, to a seat beneath the trees. Irene Adler, after a hurried glance at the prostrate form of my friend, ascended the steps of the house, but at the top she paused, and for a moment stood framed in the light of the hall, looking back at us with a face of mingled anxiety and concern.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: As he spoke the gleam of the sidelights of a carriage came round the curve of the avenue. A moment later it stopped at the gate, and a footman alighted and opened the door. A lady stepped out, wrapped in a heavy cloak, and was assisted by the footman to the steps of the house. She paused for a moment, as if hesitating, then rang the bell. The sound echoed through the still night air. I looked at Sherlock Holmes, but his face was inscrutable, his eyes fixed on the figure at the gate. After a short pause, the door opened, and the lady entered without a word. The footman closed the door behind her and re-entered the carriage, which drove slowly away into the darkness. Holmes rose to his feet. 'Well, Watson,' he said, 'I think we may as well go in now. The game is afoot, and I fancy we shall find our friend in the drawing-room.' I followed him into the house, where the lady was already seated by the fire, her face partially hidden by the shadow of the hood. 'Mrs. Hudson,' said Holmes, 'a cup of tea, if you please. And perhaps a brandy for our guest.' The lady looked up, and I saw that her face was pale and drawn, her eyes filled with a deep and troubled anxiety. 'You have heard of the tragedy at Blackwater, I presume?' she said in a low, trembling voice. Holmes nodded. 'Indeed, I have. And I believe you have some information to share with me.' 'Yes,' she replied. 'I have something to tell you—something that may help you to solve the mystery.'

events.title: Executing the Plan: Smoke Rocket and False Alarm
detailed_summary: Adler asks if the 'poor gentleman' (Holmes) is badly hurt.
Conflicting voices from the crowd suggest he is dead, then alive but unlikely to reach a hospital.
A woman praises his bravery, suggesting he prevented a robbery by a gang.
Someone notes he is breathing and suggests bringing him inside.
Adler agrees, directing them to bring him into the sitting-room with the comfortable sofa.
Holmes is carried solemnly into Briony Lodge and laid on the sofa.
Watson continues observing from his post by the window, noting the lamps are lit but blinds are open, allowing him a view of Holmes.
Watson feels deep shame about conspiring against the kind and graceful Adler as she tends to the 'injured' Holmes, but resolves not to betray his friend.
He takes the smoke-rocket from his coat, rationalizing that they are preventing harm, not causing it.
Holmes sits up on the couch, gesturing as if needing air.
A maid opens the window.
Simultaneously, Holmes raises his hand (the signal).
Watson throws the smoke-rocket into the room and shouts 'Fire!'.
Instantly, the entire crowd outside (accomplices and onlookers) joins in shouting 'Fire!'.
Thick smoke fills the room and billows out the window.
Watson glimpses figures rushing inside, then hears Holmes assuring everyone it's a false alarm.
Watson slips away through the crowd to the designated meeting point.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Is the poor gentleman much hurt?” she asked.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Slipping through the shouting crowd I made my way to the corner of the street, and in ten minutes was rejoiced to find my friend’s arm in mine, and to get away from the scene of uproar.

events.text_segment:
“Is the poor gentleman much hurt?” she asked.
“He is dead,” cried several voices.
“No, no, there’s life in him!” shouted another. “But he’ll be gone before you can get him to hospital.”
“He’s a brave fellow,” said a woman. “They would have had the lady’s purse and watch if it hadn’t been for him. They were a gang, and a rough one, too. Ah, he’s breathing now.”
“He can’t lie in the street. May we bring him in, marm?”
“Surely. Bring him into the sitting-room. There is a comfortable sofa. This way, please!”
Slowly and solemnly he was borne into Briony Lodge and laid out in the principal room, while I still observed the proceedings from my post by the window. The lamps had been lit, but the blinds had not been drawn, so that I could see Holmes as he lay upon the couch. I do not know whether he was seized with compunction at that moment for the part he was playing, but I know that I never felt more heartily ashamed of myself in my life than when I saw the beautiful creature against whom I was conspiring, or the grace and kindliness with which she waited upon the injured man. And yet it would be the blackest treachery to Holmes to draw back now from the part which he had intrusted to me. I hardened my heart, and took the smoke-rocket from under my ulster. After all, I thought, we are not injuring her. We are but preventing her from injuring another.
Holmes had sat up upon the couch, and I saw him motion like a man who is in need of air. A maid rushed across and threw open the window. At the same instant I saw him raise his hand and at the signal I tossed my rocket into the room with a cry of “Fire!” The word was no sooner out of my mouth than the whole crowd of spectators, well dressed and ill—gentlemen, ostlers, and servant maids—joined in a general shriek of “Fire!” Thick clouds of smoke curled through the room and out at the open window. I caught a glimpse of rushing figures, and a moment later the voice of Holmes from within assuring them that it was a false alarm. Slipping through the shouting crowd I made my way to the corner of the street, and in ten minutes was rejoiced to find my friend’s arm in mine, and to get away from the scene of uproar.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"Is the poor gentleman much hurt?" she asked.

"He is dead," cried a voice from the crowd.

"No, no, he still lives," said another. "But he is past help."

"He is a brave man," said a woman. "He has saved us all from the robbers."

"He is breathing," said a third. "We must get him in."

"Yes, yes, bring him in," said Irene Adler. "Carry him into the sitting-room."

They carried him solemnly into Briony Lodge, and laid him upon the sofa. I remained at my post by the window, watching the lights flicker in the room, and the blinds drawn so that I could not see within. But I could see the lamps outside, and I could see the smoke curling up from the rocket which I had taken from my coat.

I felt a deep shame as I watched the kind and graceful Irene Adler tending to the 'injured' Holmes. I resolved not to betray my friend, but I could not help feeling that I was doing wrong. I took the smoke-rocket from my coat, and I told myself that we were preventing harm, not causing it.

Holmes sat up on the couch, and made a gesture as if he needed air. The maid opened the window. At the same moment, Holmes raised his hand. I threw the rocket into the room, and cried, "Fire!"

The whole crowd outside joined in the cry, and thick smoke filled the room and billowed out of the window. I saw figures rushing in, and I heard Holmes's voice saying, "It is a false alarm."

I slipped away through the crowd to the appointed place, where I met Holmes, and we walked away together, free and unharmed."}

I felt a deep shame as I watched the kind and graceful Irene Adler tending to the 'injured' Holmes. I resolved not to betray my friend, but I could not help feeling that I was doing wrong. I took the smoke-rocket from my coat, and I told myself that we were preventing harm, not causing it.

Holmes sat up on the couch, and made a gesture as if he needed air. The maid opened the window. At the same moment, Holmes raised his hand. I threw the rocket into the room, and cried, "Fire!"

The whole crowd outside joined in the cry, and thick smoke filled the room and billowed out of the window. I saw figures rushing in, and I heard Holmes's voice saying, "It is a false alarm."

I slipped away through the crowd to the appointed place, where I met Holmes, and we walked away together, free and unharmed."}

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Is the poor gentleman much hurt?” she asked.

The woman who had spoken was a stout, elderly lady, dressed in a faded black dress and wearing a cap of the same sombre hue. Her face, though lined with age, was sharp with concern, and her eyes, which were a pale blue, seemed to take in every detail of the scene before her. She stood just inside the doorway of the modest flat, her hands clasped tightly in front of her, as if to steady herself against the weight of the moment.

The man she had addressed was a young officer of the Metropolitan Police, his uniform slightly rumpled and his face pale with the strain of the night’s events. He looked up at her with a mixture of gratitude and weariness.

“He’s alive, ma’am,” he replied, his voice low and hoarse. “But he’s in a bad way. The doctor’s with him now. We don’t know yet if he’ll pull through.”

The elderly lady let out a soft gasp and pressed a hand to her chest. “Oh, dear, dear! What happened?”

The officer hesitated, glancing briefly at the closed door behind which the injured man lay. “It’s a bit of a mystery, ma’am. The man was found in the alley behind the chemist’s shop, badly beaten. No one saw it happen, and there’s no sign of a struggle inside the flat. It’s as if he was attacked for no reason at all.”

The woman’s face darkened with worry. “He’s a good man, that one. Always was. I’ve known him since he was a boy. He’s never had a quarrel with anyone, as far as I know.”

The officer nodded. “That’s what makes it all the more puzzling. He was carrying a small leather case when he was found. We think it might be important. We’re trying to find out who he is and what he was doing in the alley.”

The woman stepped forward slightly, her eyes narrowing. “He’s Mr. James Morland, if that helps. He’s a bookseller, lives alone in that flat. Quiet man, keeps to himself. I’ve never heard a bad word about him.”

The officer’s brow furrowed. “Mr. James Morland, you say? I’ll make a note of that. Thank you, ma’am. If you could stay close for a moment, we might need to ask you a few more questions.”

The elderly lady nodded, her expression resolute. “Of course, officer. I won’t leave until I know he’s safe.”

As the officer turned back to the room where the injured man lay, the woman stood a moment longer in the doorway, her face set with determination. Something about the night’s events had stirred her deeply, and she was not about to let the mystery of Mr. Morland’s attack go unsolved.

events.text_segment:
He walked swiftly and in silence for some few minutes until we had turned down one of the quiet streets which lead towards the Edgeware Road.
“You did it very nicely, Doctor,” he remarked. “Nothing could have been better. It is all right.”
“You have the photograph?”
“I know where it is.”
“And how did you find out?”
“She showed me, as I told you she would.”
“I am still in the dark.”
“I do not wish to make a mystery,” said he, laughing. “The matter was perfectly simple. You, of course, saw that everyone in the street was an accomplice. They were all engaged for the evening.”
“I guessed as much.”
“Then, when the row broke out, I had a little moist red paint in the palm of my hand. I rushed forward, fell down, clapped my hand to my face, and became a piteous spectacle. It is an old trick.”
“That also I could fathom.”
“Then they carried me in. She was bound to have me in. What else could she do? And into her sitting-room, which was the very room which I suspected. It lay between that and her bedroom, and I was determined to see which. They laid me on a couch, I motioned for air, they were compelled to open the window, and you had your chance.”
“How did that help you?”
“It was all-important. When a woman thinks that her house is on fire, her instinct is at once to rush to the thing which she values most. It is a perfectly overpowering impulse, and I have more than once taken advantage of it. In the case of the Darlington Substitution Scandal it was of use to me, and also in the Arnsworth Castle business. A married woman grabs at her baby; an unmarried one reaches for her jewel-box. Now it was clear to me that our lady of to-day had nothing in the house more precious to her than what we are in quest of. She would rush to secure it. The alarm of fire was admirably done. The smoke and shouting were enough to shake nerves of steel. She responded beautifully. The photograph is in a recess behind a sliding panel just above the right bell-pull. She was there in an instant, and I caught a glimpse of it as she half drew it out. When I cried out that it was a false alarm, she replaced it, glanced at the rocket, rushed from the room, and I have not seen her since. I rose, and, making my excuses, escaped from the house. I hesitated whether to attempt to secure the photograph at once; but the coachman had come in, and as he was watching me narrowly, it seemed safer to wait. A little over-precipitance may ruin all.”
“And now?” I asked.
“Our quest is practically finished. I shall call with the King to-morrow, and with you, if you care to come with us. We will be shown into the sitting-room to wait for the lady, but it is probable that when she comes she may find neither us nor the photograph. It might be a satisfaction to his Majesty to regain it with his own hands.”
“And when will you call?”
“At eight in the morning. She will not be up, so that we shall have a clear field. Besides, we must be prompt, for this marriage may mean a complete change in her life and habits. I must wire to the King without delay.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
He walked swiftly and in silence for some few minutes until we had turned down one of the quiet streets which lead towards the Edgeware Road. I had no idea where he was taking me, but I followed without question, for I had learned to trust his judgment implicitly. At last he halted and turned to me with a smile. 

"You have done very well, Watson," he said. "Your part of the plan was executed with precision."

"But have you the photograph?" I asked eagerly.

"I know where it is," he replied. "I saw it just as I predicted."

"I confess I do not follow you," I said, frowning.

"It is really very simple," he explained. "Every man who took part in the street disturbance was engaged for the evening. The injury I sustained was no accident. I had concealed a little moist red paint in my palm, which I applied at the moment of my fall. It was an old trick, but an effective one. Being carried into the house was inevitable, and it brought me into the very room we suspected. My request for air forced the window open, and that gave you your opportunity."

"And the fire alarm?" I asked.

"Ah, that was the critical point," he said. "A woman's instinct in a fire is to rush to her most valued possession. I have used this psychological ploy before. I reasoned that Adler's most precious item in the house would be the photograph. The smoke and shouting were well executed, and they unnerved her. She acted exactly as I expected. She rushed to a hidden recess behind a sliding panel above the right bell-pull. I caught a glimpse of the photograph as she partially withdrew it. When I declared it a false alarm, she replaced it, looked at the smoke-rocket, and left the room."

"And then?" I asked.

"I made my excuses and left the house," he said. "I did not seize the photograph at once because the coachman had entered and was watching me closely. It was safer to wait."

"What happens next?" I asked.

"The investigation is practically complete," he said. "I propose to visit Adler's house with the King tomorrow morning. We shall be shown into the sitting-room, but I anticipate that she may flee, taking the photograph with her. However, it may be more satisfactory for the King to retrieve it himself. I intend to call at eight o'clock, before she is awake, to ensure a clear field, especially in view of the possible changes in her life indicated by her marriage. I must wire the King at once."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He walked swiftly and in silence for some few minutes until we had turned down one of the quiet streets which lead towards the Edgeware Road. I had no opportunity of speaking to him, for he was wrapped in deep thought, and his long, lank figure moved with a kind of restless energy that showed the intensity of his mental activity. At last, as we passed the corner of a narrow alley, he suddenly halted and turned to me with a sharp, questioning look in his eyes.

"You are not surprised, Watson," he said, "to find me so eager to pursue this case?"

"I confess," I answered, "that I am not. You have always shown a peculiar interest in matters of crime, and this one, with its strange circumstances, has certainly roused your curiosity."

He gave a short, dry laugh.

"Curiosity is but the beginning of wisdom, my dear Watson. But in this case, there is something more than mere curiosity at work. I have a presentiment that we are dealing with a mind of singular acuteness and resource."

"You mean the criminal?"

"I mean the criminal, yes. And I have a feeling that we shall find him to be a most formidable opponent."

We had now reached a small, dimly lit house, the door of which was opened by a man who looked up at us with a mixture of surprise and apprehension. Sherlock Holmes stepped inside without a word, and I followed him. The room into which we entered was small and poorly furnished, but it was clean and orderly, and the air was heavy with the scent of tobacco.

A man was seated at a table, his back to us, and he did not turn as we entered. Holmes walked up to him and placed a hand on his shoulder.

"Mr. Wilson," he said, "I have come to speak with you about the matter of the missing documents."

The man started and turned around, his face pale and drawn.

"I was afraid of this," he said. "I have been expecting you, Mr. Holmes."

"You have been expecting me?"

"Yes. I have been watching for you. I thought you would come."

"And why is that?"

"Because I know that you are the only man who can help me."

Holmes sat down opposite him and looked at him with a keen, searching gaze.

"Tell me, Mr. Wilson," he said, "what is it that you fear most?"

The man hesitated for a moment, then answered in a low voice.

"I fear that I am being watched. That I am being followed. That I am not safe."

"And who do you think is watching you?"

"I do not know. But I have seen a man in the street, always at a distance, always watching. I have seen him in the park, in the shops, in the streets. He is always there."

Holmes leaned forward slightly.

"And what is it that you have done, Mr. Wilson, that has brought this upon you?"

The man looked at him with a mixture of fear and determination.

"I have done nothing, Mr. Holmes. I swear it. I have done nothing."

"Then why are you afraid?"

The man did not answer. He looked down at the table, his hands trembling slightly. Holmes watched him for a moment in silence, then rose to his feet.

"We shall see," he said. "We shall see what the truth is."

And with that, he turned and walked out of the room, leaving me to follow as he disappeared into the night once more.

We had reached Baker Street and had stopped at the door. He was searching his pockets for the key when someone passing said:
“Good-night, Mister Sherlock Holmes.”
There were several people on the pavement at the time, but the greeting appeared to come from a slim youth in an ulster who had hurried by.
“I’ve heard that voice before,” said Holmes, staring down the dimly lit street. “Now, I wonder who the deuce that could have been.”

chapters.chapter_title: I. A SCANDAL IN BOHEMIA III.

events.title: Impatient King Learns of Irene's Marriage
detailed_summary: Dr. Watson spends the night at Baker Street.
The King of Bohemia arrives urgently while Holmes and Watson are having breakfast.
The King anxiously asks if Holmes has retrieved the photograph.
Holmes replies that he hasn't got it yet, but he has hopes.
Impatient, the King urges them to leave immediately.
They decide to take the King's waiting brougham.
As they travel to Briony Lodge, Holmes informs the King that Irene Adler married an English lawyer named Norton the previous day.
Holmes suggests that if Irene loves her new husband, she will no longer pose a threat to the King or his plans.
The King acknowledges the logic but wistfully remarks on Irene's qualities, wishing she could have been his queen.
The King falls into a contemplative silence until they reach their destination.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I slept at Baker Street that night, and we were engaged upon our toast and coffee in the morning when the King of Bohemia rushed into the room.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He relapsed into a moody silence, which was not broken until we drew up in Serpentine Avenue.

events.text_segment:
I slept at Baker Street that night, and we were engaged upon our toast and coffee in the morning when the King of Bohemia rushed into the room.
“You have really got it!” he cried, grasping Sherlock Holmes by either shoulder and looking eagerly into his face.
“Not yet.”
“But you have hopes?”
“I have hopes.”
“Then, come. I am all impatience to be gone.”
“We must have a cab.”
“No, my brougham is waiting.”
“Then that will simplify matters.” We descended and started off once more for Briony Lodge.
“Irene Adler is married,” remarked Holmes.
“Married! When?”
“Yesterday.”
“But to whom?”
“To an English lawyer named Norton.”
“But she could not love him.”
“I am in hopes that she does.”
“And why in hopes?”
“Because it would spare your Majesty all fear of future annoyance. If the lady loves her husband, she does not love your Majesty. If she does not love your Majesty, there is no reason why she should interfere with your Majesty’s plan.”
“It is true. And yet—! Well! I wish she had been of my own station! What a queen she would have made!” He relapsed into a moody silence, which was not broken until we drew up in Serpentine Avenue.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: I slept at Baker Street that night, and we were engaged upon our toast and coffee in the morning when the King of Bohemia rushed into the room. He was a man of imposing appearance, with a face which, even in repose, showed the traces of a life of passion and intrigue. His Majesty's manner was hurried and agitated, and his eyes gleamed with a feverish light as he looked from one to the other of us. 'Have you got it?' he asked, in a voice which was almost a whisper. 'Have you got the photograph?' 'Not yet, sir,' said Holmes, quietly. 'But I have every hope of doing so.' The King gave a groan of despair and flung himself into a chair. 'Time is everything,' he cried. 'Every hour may bring disaster. You must go at once. I have a brougham waiting at the door.' Holmes and I were soon upon the road to Briony Lodge, the King himself driving with a nervous energy which showed the state of his mind. 'You have heard of the marriage of Miss Irene Adler?' said Holmes, as we drove along. 'Yes,' said the King. 'She married an English lawyer, a man named Norton, yesterday.' 'Ah!' said the King, and his face darkened. 'If she loves this man, as I believe she does, then she is no longer a danger to me or to the State.' 'You are right,' said the King, with a sigh. 'She was a queen in every sense of the word. I have loved her with a passion which no man can understand. If she had been my wife, I would have made her the most envied woman in Europe.' He sat in silence for the rest of the journey, his face buried in his hands, and his thoughts far away.

events.title: Irene Adler's Escape Confirmed
detailed_summary: Upon arrival at Briony Lodge, they find the door open and an elderly woman on the steps.
The woman eyes them sardonically and confirms Holmes's identity.
She states that her mistress, Irene, anticipated his visit.
The woman delivers the news that Irene and her husband left for the Continent on the 5:15 train that morning, with no intention of returning.
Holmes reacts with visible shock, surprise, and chagrin.
The King, distressed, asks about the compromising papers, fearing they are lost.
Holmes, determined, says "We shall see" and pushes past the servant into the house.
The King and Watson follow Holmes into the drawing-room.
The room is in disarray, appearing hastily ransacked before Irene's departure.
Holmes quickly goes to the bell-pull, opens a hidden compartment, and retrieves a photograph and a letter.
The photograph shows Irene Adler in evening attire; the letter is addressed to Sherlock Holmes.
Holmes opens the letter, and the three men prepare to read it together.

events.text_segment:
The door of Briony Lodge was open, and an elderly woman stood upon the steps. She watched us with a sardonic eye as we stepped from the brougham.
“Mr. Sherlock Holmes, I believe?” said she.
“I am Mr. Holmes,” answered my companion, looking at her with a questioning and rather startled gaze.
“Indeed! My mistress told me that you were likely to call. She left this morning with her husband by the 5:15 train from Charing Cross for the Continent.”
“What!” Sherlock Holmes staggered back, white with chagrin and surprise. “Do you mean that she has left England?”
“Never to return.”
“And the papers?” asked the King hoarsely. “All is lost.”
“We shall see.” He pushed past the servant and rushed into the drawing-room, followed by the King and myself. The furniture was scattered about in every direction, with dismantled shelves and open drawers, as if the lady had hurriedly ransacked them before her flight. Holmes rushed at the bell-pull, tore back a small sliding shutter, and, plunging in his hand, pulled out a photograph and a letter. The photograph was of Irene Adler herself in evening dress, the letter was superscribed to “Sherlock Holmes, Esq. To be left till called for.” My friend tore it open, and we all three read it together. It was dated at midnight of the preceding night and ran in this way:

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The door of Briony Lodge was open, and an elderly woman stood upon the steps. She was a tall, thin figure, draped in black, with a face as sharp and sardonic as a knife. Her eyes, keen and knowing, fixed upon us with a look of quiet amusement.

"Ah!" she said, with a faint smile. "You are Mr. Sherlock Holmes, I presume?"

"That is my name," I answered for my friend, who had grown pale and silent.

"Your arrival was anticipated," she continued. "My mistress, Miss Irene Adler, has been expecting you. She left for the Continent this morning on the five-fifteen train, and she does not intend to return."

The King of Bohemia, who had been standing behind us, gave a cry of anguish and turned to Holmes. "The papers!" he gasped. "Are they lost?"

Holmes, with a sudden flash of determination, said, "We shall see," and pushed past the servant into the house. The King and I followed him into the drawing-room.

It was a scene of disorder. The furniture had been overturned, the drawers of the writing-table flung open, and the carpet was littered with the fragments of a shattered mirror. It was clear that the place had been ransacked in haste.

Holmes moved quickly to the bell-pull, and with a deft twist of his fingers, he opened a concealed compartment in the wall. From it he drew a photograph and a letter.

The photograph showed Irene Adler in evening dress, her face radiant with beauty and poise. The letter was addressed in a bold hand to Sherlock Holmes. He opened it, and we three stood in silence, waiting for the revelation that was to come.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The door of Briony Lodge was open, and an elderly woman stood upon the steps. She was wrapped in a shawl of black, and her face was drawn and haggard with anxiety. At the sight of us she gave a cry of relief and hurried forward. 

"Oh, sir," she said, "I have been waiting for you. My name is Mrs. Farintosh, and I live at Briony Lodge. Something terrible has happened. My son, Godfrey, has disappeared, and I believe he is in great danger."

"Come in, Mrs. Farintosh," said Holmes, gently. "You are clearly in a state of great distress. Tell me all that you know."

We followed her into a small, dimly lit sitting room. The fire had gone out, and the air was heavy with the scent of lavender. Mrs. Farintosh sat down, trembling, and began to speak in a low, hurried voice. 

"My son has been acting strangely for days," she said. "He has been receiving letters, always in the dead of night, and he has grown pale and distracted. Last night, he left the house and has not returned. I found this," she added, producing a crumpled letter from her pocket. 

Holmes took the letter and examined it carefully. "This is of interest," he said. "We must find your son, Mrs. Farintosh. I believe we are on the edge of a mystery."

With that, he rose and we left the house, stepping into the cold night air, ready to begin our search.

events.title: Irene Adler's Explanatory Letter
detailed_summary: Irene's letter begins by complimenting Holmes on his performance, admitting he completely deceived her initially.
She explains that the alarm of fire made her suspicious and prompted her to reconsider after she revealed the photograph's location.
She reveals she had been warned about Holmes months prior and was given his address.
Despite the warnings, she acknowledges Holmes successfully tricked her.
She notes her difficulty in suspecting the kindly old clergyman Holmes portrayed, but reminds him of her own training as an actress and familiarity with male disguise.
She confesses to sending her coachman to watch Holmes, changing into outdoor clothes, and following him back to Baker Street.
She admits to imprudently wishing him goodnight on the street to confirm his identity.
She explains that after seeing her husband, they decided fleeing was the best option against such a formidable adversary.
She assures Holmes that his client, the King, can be at ease regarding the photograph.
She declares her love for her husband, whom she considers a better man than the King, and states the King is free to act without interference from her.
She clarifies she keeps the original photograph only as a safeguard against any future actions the King might take against her.
She concludes by stating she is leaving behind a different photograph that the King might like to have, signing off as Irene Norton, formerly Adler.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “MY DEAR MR. SHERLOCK HOLMES,—You really did it very well.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence:
“Very truly yours,
“IRENE NORTON, née ADLER.”

events.text_segment:
“MY DEAR MR. SHERLOCK HOLMES,—You really did it very well. You took me in completely. Until after the alarm of fire, I had not a suspicion. But then, when I found how I had betrayed myself, I began to think. I had been warned against you months ago. I had been told that, if the King employed an agent, it would certainly be you. And your address had been given me. Yet, with all this, you made me reveal what you wanted to know. Even after I became suspicious, I found it hard to think evil of such a dear, kind old clergyman. But, you know, I have been trained as an actress myself. Male costume is nothing new to me. I often take advantage of the freedom which it gives. I sent John, the coachman, to watch you, ran upstairs, got into my walking clothes, as I call them, and came down just as you departed.
    “Well, I followed you to your door, and so made sure that I was really an object of interest to the celebrated Mr. Sherlock Holmes. Then I, rather imprudently, wished you good-night, and started for the Temple to see my husband.
    “We both thought the best resource was flight, when pursued by so formidable an antagonist; so you will find the nest empty when you call to-morrow. As to the photograph, your client may rest in peace. I love and am loved by a better man than he. The King may do what he will without hindrance from one whom he has cruelly wronged. I keep it only to safeguard myself, and to preserve a weapon which will always secure me from any steps which he might take in the future. I leave a photograph which he might care to possess; and I remain, dear Mr. Sherlock Holmes,“Very truly yours,
“IRENE NORTON, née ADLER.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: MY DEAR MR. SHERLOCK HOLMES,—You really did it very well. I was completely deceived, and I must confess that I was not a little annoyed at finding myself outwitted by you. It was the alarm of fire which first put me on my guard, and which made me look back upon the whole matter. I had been warned of you months ago, and had even your address, but I had not the least idea that you would take such a line. I must say, however, that I was not a little surprised at the ease with which you assumed the character of the old clergyman. I have had some experience in the matter of disguise myself, and I know how difficult it is to pass for what one is not. I confess that I sent my coachman to watch you, and that I followed you myself in the cab. I even changed into my outdoor clothes and walked behind you as far as Baker Street. I was imprudent enough to say good-night to you on the street, and I thought I had made sure of your identity. But I see now that I was mistaken. I have seen my husband, and we have decided that the best course is to fly. Against such an adversary as you we can do nothing. I have no doubt that my client, the King of Bohemia, may rest in peace as to the photograph. I love my husband, and I think he is a better man than the King. I will not interfere with him in any way. I keep the original only as a safeguard against any future action which the King might take. I leave behind me another photograph, which I think the King might like to have. I remain, dear Mr. Holmes, yours faithfully, IRENE NORTON, formerly ADLER.
