I have been reading your account of the adventure of the Speckled Band, and I must say that I am quite in awe of your powers of observation and deduction. I have always been a great admirer of your methods, and I must confess that I have often tried to emulate them in my own small way. I am a schoolmaster in the village of Leatherhead, and I have recently encountered a mystery that has puzzled me greatly. I have no doubt that you would be able to solve it in a moment, but I thought I would write to you in the hope that you might be able to offer me some guidance. The matter is of a somewhat delicate nature, and I do not wish to alarm the villagers unnecessarily. It concerns one of the schoolgirls, a bright and promising child named Emily Wren. For the past week, she has been acting strangely, and I have noticed that she has been receiving letters from an unknown sender. The letters are always delivered in the same manner, slipped under her door in the dormitory, and they are always written in a very peculiar hand. The content of the letters is also most unusual, and I have reason to believe that they may be of a threatening nature. I have tried to question the child, but she is very evasive and refuses to tell me anything. I have also spoken to the other girls, but they know nothing of the matter. I am at my wits' end, and I do not know what to do. I have no doubt that you would be able to solve this mystery in a moment, and I would be most grateful if you could offer me any advice. I remain, dear Mr. Holmes, your most humble and obedient servant, J. H. WILKINS.”

events.title: Mission Resolved and Holmes's Unique Reward
detailed_summary: After reading the letter, the King exclaims admiration for Irene's quick wit and resolution.
He reiterates his sentiment that she would have made an excellent queen and laments she wasn't his social equal.
Holmes responds coolly, suggesting Irene seems to be on a significantly different, implicitly higher, level than the King.
Holmes formally apologizes for not bringing the King's case to a more successful conclusion.
The King dismisses the apology, declaring the outcome couldn't be more successful, as he trusts Irene's word that the photograph is now safe.
Expressing immense gratitude, the King offers Holmes an emerald snake ring as a reward.
Holmes declines the ring, stating there is something else the King possesses that he would value more.
When invited to name his price, Holmes asks for the photograph of Irene Adler they had just found.
The King stares in astonishment but agrees to Holmes's request.
Holmes thanks the King, declares the matter closed, and bids him good morning.
He bows and leaves with Watson, pointedly ignoring the King's outstretched hand.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “What a woman—oh, what a woman!” cried the King of Bohemia, when we had all three read this epistle.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He bowed, and, turning away without observing the hand which the King had stretched out to him, he set off in my company for his chambers.

events.text_segment:
“What a woman—oh, what a woman!” cried the King of Bohemia, when we had all three read this epistle. “Did I not tell you how quick and resolute she was? Would she not have made an admirable queen? Is it not a pity that she was not on my level?”
“From what I have seen of the lady, she seems, indeed, to be on a very different level to your Majesty,” said Holmes coldly. “I am sorry that I have not been able to bring your Majesty’s business to a more successful conclusion.”
“On the contrary, my dear sir,” cried the King; “nothing could be more successful. I know that her word is inviolate. The photograph is now as safe as if it were in the fire.”
“I am glad to hear your Majesty say so.”
“I am immensely indebted to you. Pray tell me in what way I can reward you. This ring—” He slipped an emerald snake ring from his finger and held it out upon the palm of his hand.
“Your Majesty has something which I should value even more highly,” said Holmes.
“You have but to name it.”
“This photograph!”
The King stared at him in amazement.
“Irene’s photograph!” he cried. “Certainly, if you wish it.”
“I thank your Majesty. Then there is no more to be done in the matter. I have the honour to wish you a very good morning.” He bowed, and, turning away without observing the hand which the King had stretched out to him, he set off in my company for his chambers.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“What a woman—oh, what a woman!” cried the King of Bohemia, when we had all three read this epistle. “She is a marvel, a mystery, a masterpiece of nature. I have known many women, but never one who could so completely baffle and bewilder me. She is a riddle wrapped in an enigma, and I confess I am at my wit’s end to solve it.”

Sherlock Holmes, who had been sitting in his usual attitude of quiet abstraction, now leaned forward and tapped the letter with his finger. “It is a remarkable document,” he remarked. “The writer is a woman of strong will and keen intellect. She is not one to be trifled with, nor to be easily outwitted. She has a mind of her own, and she uses it with great effect. I should say that she is a woman who has made her own way in the world, and not without success.”

The King of Bohemia nodded. “You are right, Mr. Holmes. She is a woman of extraordinary character. I have loved her with all my heart, and yet I do not know her. She is a puzzle to me, and I fear I am not the only one who finds her so. I have tried to win her back, but she has eluded me at every turn. I have followed her to the ends of the earth, and still she remains beyond my reach.”

Holmes smiled. “Then it is time, I think, that we took a more scientific approach to the matter. Let us examine the facts, and see if we cannot unravel the mystery of this remarkable woman.”

events.title: The Enduring Legacy of "The Woman"
detailed_summary: Watson reflects on the conclusion of the affair that threatened the Kingdom of Bohemia.
He highlights that Sherlock Holmes's well-laid plans were ultimately defeated by a woman's intelligence.
Watson notes a change in Holmes: he used to mock the cleverness of women but has ceased doing so since this case.
He concludes by stating that Holmes always refers to Irene Adler, and her photograph, with the distinct and respectful title, "the woman."

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: And that was how a great scandal threatened to affect the kingdom of Bohemia, and how the best plans of Mr. Sherlock Holmes were beaten by a woman’s wit.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And when he speaks of Irene Adler, or when he refers to her photograph, it is always under the honourable title of the woman.

events.text_segment: And that was how a great scandal threatened to affect the kingdom of Bohemia, and how the best plans of Mr. Sherlock Holmes were beaten by a woman’s wit. He used to make merry over the cleverness of women, but I have not heard him do it of late. And when he speaks of Irene Adler, or when he refers to her photograph, it is always under the honourable title of the woman.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: And that was how a great scandal threatened to affect the kingdom of Bohemia, and how the best plans of Mr. Sherlock Holmes were beaten by a woman’s wit. I have heard many people speak of the cleverness of women, but I must confess that I had never before realized the full force of the remark until I saw the way in which this one woman outmanoeuvred the most logical and methodical mind of our time. It was a strange thing to see the great detective, who had always treated the sex with a mixture of indulgence and contempt, suddenly become grave and thoughtful when the name of Irene Adler was mentioned. From that day forward, I noticed a change in him. He no longer made his old jests about the cleverness of women, nor did he treat the subject of their intellect with the same flippancy. He had met his match, and he knew it. And to this day, when he refers to Irene Adler, it is never as 'Miss Adler' or 'Madame'—no, it is always 'the woman,' with a certain tone, a certain intonation, which I have heard in London drawing-rooms when the hostess speaks of the Prime Minister.

events.title: Introduction of the Client and His Singular Case
detailed_summary: Dr. Watson visits Sherlock Holmes and finds him speaking with a client, Mr. Jabez Wilson, notable for his stout build and fiery red hair.
Holmes insists Watson stay, introducing Wilson and highlighting Watson's role as his partner and chronicler.
Wilson acknowledges Watson with a brief greeting.
Holmes invites Watson to sit, noting Watson's appreciation for the unusual and bizarre, which Holmes claims characterizes many of his cases.
Holmes references a previous conversation where he asserted that real life is stranger than fiction, a point Watson had doubted.
He introduces Mr. Wilson's narrative as potentially one of the most singular he has encountered, possibly involving a smaller, unique crime, or perhaps no crime at all.
Holmes requests Wilson to restart his story for Watson's benefit and because the peculiar details warrant careful repetition, admitting the case seems unprecedented in his experience.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I had called upon my friend, Mr. Sherlock Holmes, one day in the autumn of last year and found him in deep conversation with a very stout, florid-faced, elderly gentleman with fiery red hair.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In the present instance I am forced to admit that the facts are, to the best of my belief, unique.”

events.text_segment:
I had called upon my friend, Mr. Sherlock Holmes, one day in the autumn of last year and found him in deep conversation with a very stout, florid-faced, elderly gentleman with fiery red hair. With an apology for my intrusion, I was about to withdraw when Holmes pulled me abruptly into the room and closed the door behind me.
“You could not possibly have come at a better time, my dear Watson,” he said cordially.
“I was afraid that you were engaged.”
“So I am. Very much so.”
“Then I can wait in the next room.”
“Not at all. This gentleman, Mr. Wilson, has been my partner and helper in many of my most successful cases, and I have no doubt that he will be of the utmost use to me in yours also.”
The stout gentleman half rose from his chair and gave a bob of greeting, with a quick little questioning glance from his small fat-encircled eyes.
“Try the settee,” said Holmes, relapsing into his armchair and putting his fingertips together, as was his custom when in judicial moods. “I know, my dear Watson, that you share my love of all that is bizarre and outside the conventions and humdrum routine of everyday life. You have shown your relish for it by the enthusiasm which has prompted you to chronicle, and, if you will excuse my saying so, somewhat to embellish so many of my own little adventures.”
“Your cases have indeed been of the greatest interest to me,” I observed.
“You will remember that I remarked the other day, just before we went into the very simple problem presented by Miss Mary Sutherland, that for strange effects and extraordinary combinations we must go to life itself, which is always far more daring than any effort of the imagination.”
“A proposition which I took the liberty of doubting.”
“You did, Doctor, but none the less you must come round to my view, for otherwise I shall keep on piling fact upon fact on you until your reason breaks down under them and acknowledges me to be right. Now, Mr. Jabez Wilson here has been good enough to call upon me this morning, and to begin a narrative which promises to be one of the most singular which I have listened to for some time. You have heard me remark that the strangest and most unique things are very often connected not with the larger but with the smaller crimes, and occasionally, indeed, where there is room for doubt whether any positive crime has been committed. As far as I have heard, it is impossible for me to say whether the present case is an instance of crime or not, but the course of events is certainly among the most singular that I have ever listened to. Perhaps, Mr. Wilson, you would have the great kindness to recommence your narrative. I ask you not merely because my friend Dr. Watson has not heard the opening part but also because the peculiar nature of the story makes me anxious to have every possible detail from your lips. As a rule, when I have heard some slight indication of the course of events, I am able to guide myself by the thousands of other similar cases which occur to my memory. In the present instance I am forced to admit that the facts are, to the best of my belief, unique.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: I had called upon my friend, Mr. Sherlock Holmes, one day in the autumn of last year and found him in deep conversation with a very stout, florid-faced, elderly gentleman with fiery red hair. 'I have just had a most extraordinary interview, Watson,' he remarked, as I entered. 'This is Mr. Jabez Wilson, who has been good enough to call upon me this morning in reference to a matter which has given him much anxiety.' 'Good morning, sir,' said Wilson, in a slow, heavy voice, and with a grave, solemn manner. 'You are Dr. Watson, if I am not mistaken?' 'Yes, sir,' I answered. 'I have heard your name mentioned by my friend Holmes.' 'Then you will be so good as to remain,' said Holmes. 'This is a case of the greatest interest. I have already made certain notes, but I should like your professional opinion upon it, and also your assistance in the matter of details.' 'I shall be happy to do so,' I answered. 'I have no doubt that it is a case of some importance, judging from the manner in which you speak of it.' 'Indeed, it is of the very greatest importance,' said Holmes, with a grave face. 'It is a case of the most singular character. It is a case which may involve a very small crime, or perhaps no crime at all. But it is a case which has certainly given me more food for thought than any I have yet had.' 'I am sorry to hear that,' said Wilson, with a sigh. 'I have had a very unpleasant time of it.' 'I have no doubt of it,' said Holmes. 'But you will find that I am a very patient man, and that I shall do all that I can for you. In the meantime, perhaps you will be good enough to tell me your story once more, for I think that I may have missed some of the more important details.' 'With pleasure, sir,' said Wilson, and he leaned back in his chair, with a look of relief upon his face.

I had called upon my friend, Mr. Sherlock Holmes, one day in the autumn of last year and found him in deep conversation with a very stout, florid-faced, elderly gentleman with fiery red hair. The moment I entered, the stranger rose to his feet with a somewhat embarrassed air, and, after a few hurried words of explanation, he took his leave. I had often seen Holmes in the midst of his professional labors, but I had never yet had the opportunity of observing the quiet, the almost dreamy abstraction which sat upon his face when unvisited. He lay, as I remember, curled upon the sofa, a heavy shawl across his chest, his bandsome violin resting on his knee, and his eyes fixed upon the fire. I had no idea that he was aware of my entrance. I coughed slightly, and at the sound he turned with a smile.

"Ah, Watson," he said, "I was just thinking of you. You have come at a fortunate moment."

"Indeed?" I remarked, glancing at the closed door through which the stranger had just passed. "I see that you have had a visitor."

"Yes, a most interesting case," said Holmes, lighting a cigarette. "A problem which has been troubling him for some time."

"And what is it?"

"Well, I cannot go into details yet, but I can tell you that it is a case of identity. The man is convinced that he is not who he believes himself to be."

"Not who he believes himself to be?"

"Precisely. He is a retired merchant, as you saw, and he has lived for many years in the same house in the same street. Yet he is convinced that he is not the same man who lived there before."

"That is certainly strange."

"It is more than strange. It is a most singular case. He has a perfect recollection of his past life, but he is convinced that it is not his own. He has examined his papers, his letters, his bank accounts, and everything points to his being the same man. And yet he is convinced that he is an imposter."

"And what do you think, Holmes?"

"I think that there is a very simple explanation. I think that he is suffering from a form of amnesia, and that he has forgotten his true identity."

"But he remembers everything else."

"Yes, but not the key fact. He remembers his name, his address, his business, but he does not remember the events that led him to that position. He is like a man who has woken up in a strange house, with a strange name, and a strange life, and he is trying to piece it together."

"And you are going to help him?"

"I am. I have already made a few inquiries, and I believe that I am on the right track."

"And what is the track?"

"Well, I have discovered that there was a man of the same name and appearance who lived in the same house twenty years ago. He was a merchant, as our friend is now, but he disappeared suddenly and was never heard of again."

"And you think that this man is the same person?"

"I think that it is possible. I think that he may have suffered a complete amnesia, and that he has taken on the identity of the man who lived there before him."

"That is a most extraordinary theory."

"It is not so extraordinary when you consider the facts."

events.title: Holmes Deduces Wilson's Background
detailed_summary: Mr. Wilson proudly retrieves a newspaper from his coat.

While Wilson looks for an advertisement, Watson observes him, noting his appearance as an average, obese, pompous, and slow British tradesman, identifiable primarily by his striking red hair and an expression of discontent.

Holmes observes Watson's scrutiny and smiles, proceeding to list several deductions about Wilson: past manual labor, snuff use, Freemason membership, time spent in China, and recent extensive writing.
Wilson is astonished and asks Holmes how he deduced these facts, starting with the manual labor.
Holmes explains the deduction based on the larger size and developed muscles of Wilson's right hand.
Regarding snuff and Freemasonry, Holmes points to Wilson's arc-and-compass breastpin, a slightly non-standard Masonic symbol.
The writing deduction comes from the worn right cuff and the smooth patch on the left sleeve near the elbow.

The China connection is deduced from a specific type of fish tattoo above Wilson's right wrist, identifiable by the pink staining technique unique to China, further corroborated by a Chinese coin on his watch chain.
Wilson laughs heartily, initially impressed but now believing the deductions were simple observations.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Well, I never!” said he.

events.text_segment:
The portly client puffed out his chest with an appearance of some little pride and pulled a dirty and wrinkled newspaper from the inside pocket of his greatcoat. As he glanced down the advertisement column, with his head thrust forward and the paper flattened out upon his knee, I took a good look at the man and endeavoured, after the fashion of my companion, to read the indications which might be presented by his dress or appearance.
I did not gain very much, however, by my inspection. Our visitor bore every mark of being an average commonplace British tradesman, obese, pompous, and slow. He wore rather baggy grey shepherd’s check trousers, a not over-clean black frock-coat, unbuttoned in the front, and a drab waistcoat with a heavy brassy Albert chain, and a square pierced bit of metal dangling down as an ornament. A frayed top-hat and a faded brown overcoat with a wrinkled velvet collar lay upon a chair beside him. Altogether, look as I would, there was nothing remarkable about the man save his blazing red head, and the expression of extreme chagrin and discontent upon his features.
Sherlock Holmes’ quick eye took in my occupation, and he shook his head with a smile as he noticed my questioning glances. “Beyond the obvious facts that he has at some time done manual labour, that he takes snuff, that he is a Freemason, that he has been in China, and that he has done a considerable amount of writing lately, I can deduce nothing else.”
Mr. Jabez Wilson started up in his chair, with his forefinger upon the paper, but his eyes upon my companion.
“How, in the name of good-fortune, did you know all that, Mr. Holmes?” he asked. “How did you know, for example, that I did manual labour. It’s as true as gospel, for I began as a ship’s carpenter.”
“Your hands, my dear sir. Your right hand is quite a size larger than your left. You have worked with it, and the muscles are more developed.”
“Well, the snuff, then, and the Freemasonry?”
“I won’t insult your intelligence by telling you how I read that, especially as, rather against the strict rules of your order, you use an arc-and-compass breastpin.”
“Ah, of course, I forgot that. But the writing?”
“What else can be indicated by that right cuff so very shiny for five inches, and the left one with the smooth patch near the elbow where you rest it upon the desk?”
“Well, but China?”
“The fish that you have tattooed immediately above your right wrist could only have been done in China. I have made a small study of tattoo marks and have even contributed to the literature of the subject. That trick of staining the fishes’ scales of a delicate pink is quite peculiar to China. When, in addition, I see a Chinese coin hanging from your watch-chain, the matter becomes even more simple.”
Mr. Jabez Wilson laughed heavily. “Well, I never!” said he.

He unfolded it with great care and smoothed it out upon the table. "I wish to call your attention," he said, "to this advertisement, sir. I should like to know what you would make of it." 

I glanced at the paper, but Holmes had already risen from his chair and was looking over the client's shoulder. "It is the Red-Headed League, no doubt," he remarked. "I have heard of it before. It is a very curious institution. But I should like to hear what you have to say about it."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The portly client puffed out his chest with an appearance of some little pride and pulled a dirty and wrinkled newspaper from the inside pocket of his greatcoat. He unfolded it with a great deal of ceremony, as though it were a document of the highest importance, and laid it upon the table between us. I glanced at the date and saw that it was a week old. The article was headed in bold letters: 'The Mysterious Disappearance of the Silver Tea-Set from the Home of Reginald Pym.'

'You see, Mr. Holmes,' said the client, 'I am Mr. Pym himself. That tea-set was a wedding present from my wife's family, and it was of considerable sentimental value. It vanished without a trace, and the police were of no help whatsoever. I have come to you in the hope that you might shed some light on the matter.'

Holmes leaned forward, his keen eyes scanning the article with a mixture of interest and amusement. 'I see that the police have ruled out theft by outsiders, as the windows and doors were all found to be intact. They also dismissed the possibility of a domestic accomplice, as the housemaid and butler were both accounted for at the time of the disappearance. Is this correct?'

'Yes, yes, that is all correct,' replied Mr. Pym, nodding vigorously. 'I have no idea how the set could have vanished. I had it displayed in the drawing-room, and I was certain it was there the night before it disappeared. I even remember serving tea to my guests with it the evening before the theft was discovered.'

Holmes steepled his fingers and gave a thoughtful nod. 'And yet, the set was gone by the morning. No sign of forced entry, no disturbance in the room. It is a curious case, indeed. Tell me, Mr. Pym, did you have any visitors the night before the disappearance?'

'Only my cousin, Mr. Ambrose,' replied Pym. 'He is a bit of a bore, but a harmless man. I do not see how he could have anything to do with the theft.'

'And yet, you say he is a bore,' said Holmes, his voice calm and inquisitive. 'That is an interesting choice of words. You seem to have a certain disdain for your cousin. Perhaps it is not so much that he is a bore, but that he is a man of some means and perhaps a bit too interested in your affairs.'

Mr. Pym looked taken aback. 'I... I suppose he has been a bit inquisitive, but I have no reason to believe he would steal from me.'

Holmes gave a small smile. 'We shall see. I believe I have a plan. If you will excuse me for a moment, I must make a few inquiries of my own. I shall return shortly, and I promise you, Mr. Pym, the mystery of the silver tea-set shall be solved.'

events.title: The Mysterious Advertisement for the Red-Headed League
detailed_summary: Holmes remarks to Watson that explaining his methods diminishes their mystique and potentially harms his reputation.
He asks Wilson if he has located the advertisement.
Wilson confirms, pointing to it in the newspaper column, stating it's the origin of the whole affair.
He hands the paper to Watson.

Watson reads the advertisement aloud: it announces a vacancy in the Red-Headed League, offering £4 per week for nominal services to eligible red-headed men over twenty-one, funded by the late Ezekiah Hopkins. Applicants are directed to apply in person at 7 Pope’s Court, Fleet Street.
Watson expresses bafflement at the strange announcement.
Holmes chuckles, agreeing it's unusual, and prompts Wilson to narrate his story from the beginning, including details about his household and the advertisement's impact.
Holmes instructs Watson to record the newspaper's name and date.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I begin to think, Watson,” said Holmes, “that I make a mistake in explaining.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: You will first make a note, Doctor, of the paper and the date.”

events.text_segment:
“I begin to think, Watson,” said Holmes, “that I make a mistake in explaining. ‘Omne ignotum pro magnifico,’ you know, and my poor little reputation, such as it is, will suffer shipwreck if I am so candid. Can you not find the advertisement, Mr. Wilson?”
“Yes, I have got it now,” he answered with his thick red finger planted halfway down the column. “Here it is. This is what began it all. You just read it for yourself, sir.”
I took the paper from him and read as follows:
“TO THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE: On account of the bequest of the late Ezekiah Hopkins, of Lebanon, Pennsylvania, U.S.A., there is now another vacancy open which entitles a member of the League to a salary of £ 4 a week for purely nominal services. All red-headed men who are sound in body and mind and above the age of twenty-one years, are eligible. Apply in person on Monday, at eleven o’clock, to Duncan Ross, at the offices of the League, 7 Pope’s Court, Fleet Street.”
“What on earth does this mean?” I ejaculated after I had twice read over the extraordinary announcement.
Holmes chuckled and wriggled in his chair, as was his habit when in high spirits. “It is a little off the beaten track, isn’t it?” said he. “And now, Mr. Wilson, off you go at scratch and tell us all about yourself, your household, and the effect which this advertisement had upon your fortunes. You will first make a note, Doctor, of the paper and the date.”

simple_agent_extraction_refined_0.text: I begin to think, Watson,

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: “I begin to think, Watson,” said Holmes, “that I make a mistake in explaining. It is a pity to spoil a good mystery by making it too plain. The art of detection is like the art of the dramatist. You must leave your audience in suspense until the final curtain. I have noticed that you are always impatient to have everything explained at once, but I must confess that I find it more satisfying to let the puzzle unfold gradually. It is the very essence of the game. You see, the thrill lies in the chase, in the deduction, in the moment of revelation. If I were to lay everything bare from the start, it would rob the case of its charm. I have observed that people are more inclined to remember and admire the solution when it is revealed at the proper time, rather than when it is given too soon. It is a question of taste, Watson, and I have always held that the best things in life are those which are earned, not given. I shall continue, then, to let the mystery play out in its own time, and I trust that you will bear with me. After all, you are not only my companion in these adventures, but also my willing pupil. And I must confess, I take a certain pleasure in watching the light of understanding dawn in your eyes at the right moment. So, let us proceed, and I shall allow the facts to speak for themselves, in their own good time.”

events.title: Mr. Wilson Describes His Pawnshop and Assistant
detailed_summary: Watson notes the newspaper is The Morning Chronicle from April 27, 1890, about two months prior.
Wilson begins his narrative, explaining he owns a small pawnbroker's business near the City, which barely provides a living.
He mentions he now employs only one assistant, having previously had two.
The current assistant, Vincent Spaulding, works for half wages to learn the trade.
Holmes inquires about Spaulding.
Wilson describes Spaulding as smart and capable, likely able to earn more elsewhere, but seemingly content.
Holmes remarks on the rarity of finding an employee willing to work below market rate, finding the assistant as noteworthy as the advertisement.
Wilson concedes Spaulding has a fault: an obsession with photography, often developing pictures in the cellar when he should be working, but otherwise considers him a good, vice-free worker.
Wilson confirms Spaulding is still employed.
He adds that his household consists only of himself (a widower with no family), Spaulding, and a young girl who handles cooking and cleaning.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “It is The Morning Chronicle of April 27, 1890.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: We live very quietly, sir, the three of us; and we keep a roof over our heads and pay our debts, if we do nothing more.

events.text_segment:
“It is The Morning Chronicle of April 27, 1890. Just two months ago.”
“Very good. Now, Mr. Wilson?”
“Well, it is just as I have been telling you, Mr. Sherlock Holmes,” said Jabez Wilson, mopping his forehead; “I have a small pawnbroker’s business at Coburg Square, near the City. It’s not a very large affair, and of late years it has not done more than just give me a living. I used to be able to keep two assistants, but now I only keep one; and I would have a job to pay him but that he is willing to come for half wages so as to learn the business.”
“What is the name of this obliging youth?” asked Sherlock Holmes.
“His name is Vincent Spaulding, and he’s not such a youth, either. It’s hard to say his age. I should not wish a smarter assistant, Mr. Holmes; and I know very well that he could better himself and earn twice what I am able to give him. But, after all, if he is satisfied, why should I put ideas in his head?”
“Why, indeed? You seem most fortunate in having an employé who comes under the full market price. It is not a common experience among employers in this age. I don’t know that your assistant is not as remarkable as your advertisement.”
“Oh, he has his faults, too,” said Mr. Wilson. “Never was such a fellow for photography. Snapping away with a camera when he ought to be improving his mind, and then diving down into the cellar like a rabbit into its hole to develop his pictures. That is his main fault, but on the whole he’s a good worker. There’s no vice in him.”
“He is still with you, I presume?”
“Yes, sir. He and a girl of fourteen, who does a bit of simple cooking and keeps the place clean—that’s all I have in the house, for I am a widower and never had any family. We live very quietly, sir, the three of us; and we keep a roof over our heads and pay our debts, if we do nothing more.

I am a pawnbroker in the City, and have done business in the same neighbourhood for the last twenty years. I have a small but profitable trade, and I live very quietly, as you may imagine. I am a widower, with no family, and my only assistant is a young man named Vincent Spaulding, who has been with me for some time. He is a very capable young fellow, and I have every reason to be satisfied with him. He is not a man who would be likely to run away from his post, and yet, as I shall explain, he has done so in a very singular manner. He is a very good workman, and I have no complaint to make of him. He is a little too fond of photography, I think, and he spends a good deal of time in the cellar developing his pictures, but otherwise he is a most trustworthy and industrious young man. He is not a man who would be likely to get into any sort of trouble, and yet, as I shall explain, he has done so in a very singular manner.

The police are baffled, and Scotland Yard has been forced to admit that the case is beyond their current understanding. The public, ever eager for a scandal, is abuzz with speculation. Some claim it was the work of a foreign agent, others whisper of a secret society, and a few, more daring in their theories, suggest the involvement of a master criminal who has eluded the law for years. The article concludes with a call for vigilance and a reminder of the importance of national security. The tone is one of urgency and concern, reflecting the gravity of the situation. The editor's note at the end urges readers to remain calm and to trust in the authorities, though the subtext suggests a lack of confidence in their ability to resolve the matter. The article is written in a formal and measured style, befitting the newspaper's reputation for seriousness and reliability. It is clear that the theft has shaken the public's trust in the security of the nation's most important institutions. The article also mentions that the stolen documents were last seen in the possession of a Mr. James Moriarty, a name that has recently appeared in several other unsolved cases. The connection to Moriarty is not elaborated upon, but it is enough to raise eyebrows and spark further speculation. The article ends with a brief mention of a private detective, Mr. Sherlock Holmes, who has been seen in the vicinity of the bank in recent days. The article is a masterful piece of journalism, capturing the public's imagination while maintaining a veneer of objectivity. events.title: Applying for the Red-Headed League Position
detailed_summary: Wilson recounts how Spaulding brought the newspaper advertisement to his attention eight weeks prior, wishing he were red-headed himself.
Spaulding explained the League offered a fortune for little work and implied vacancies outnumbered qualified applicants.
Wilson, being largely homebound due to his business, was unaware of the League and asked for details.
Spaulding expressed surprise at Wilson's ignorance, pointing out Wilson's own eligibility.
He estimated the position paid a couple hundred pounds a year with minimal interference with other work.
Wilson, whose business was struggling, became interested in the extra income.

Spaulding elaborated, based on the ad, that the League was founded by a peculiar American millionaire, Ezekiah Hopkins, who sympathized with red-headed men and left his fortune to provide them easy jobs.
Wilson worried about immense competition, but Spaulding claimed it was limited to Londoners and men with truly fiery red hair, suggesting Wilson would easily qualify.
Confident in his hair color and spurred by Spaulding's knowledge, Wilson closed his shop for the day and went with Spaulding to the address.
Wilson describes an astonishing scene: Fleet Street packed with red-headed men of every shade responding to the ad.
Despite Wilson's despair at the competition, Spaulding energetically pushed him through the crowd to the office entrance.
They joined the flow of hopeful applicants going up the stairs and dejected ones coming down, eventually reaching the office.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There was a double stream upon the stair, some going up in hope, and some coming back dejected; but we wedged in as well as we could and soon found ourselves in the office.”

events.text_segment:
“The first thing that put us out was that advertisement. Spaulding, he came down into the office just this day eight weeks, with this very paper in his hand, and he says:
“‘I wish to the Lord, Mr. Wilson, that I was a red-headed man.’
“‘Why that?’ I asks.
“‘Why,’ says he, ‘here’s another vacancy on the League of the Red-headed Men. It’s worth quite a little fortune to any man who gets it, and I understand that there are more vacancies than there are men, so that the trustees are at their wits’ end what to do with the money. If my hair would only change colour, here’s a nice little crib all ready for me to step into.’
“‘Why, what is it, then?’ I asked. You see, Mr. Holmes, I am a very stay-at-home man, and as my business came to me instead of my having to go to it, I was often weeks on end without putting my foot over the door-mat. In that way I didn’t know much of what was going on outside, and I was always glad of a bit of news.
“‘Have you never heard of the League of the Red-headed Men?’ he asked with his eyes open.
“‘Never.’
“‘Why, I wonder at that, for you are eligible yourself for one of the vacancies.’
“‘And what are they worth?’ I asked.
“‘Oh, merely a couple of hundred a year, but the work is slight, and it need not interfere very much with one’s other occupations.’
“Well, you can easily think that that made me prick up my ears, for the business has not been over good for some years, and an extra couple of hundred would have been very handy.
“‘Tell me all about it,’ said I.
“‘Well,’ said he, showing me the advertisement, ‘you can see for yourself that the League has a vacancy, and there is the address where you should apply for particulars. As far as I can make out, the League was founded by an American millionaire, Ezekiah Hopkins, who was very peculiar in his ways. He was himself red-headed, and he had a great sympathy for all red-headed men; so, when he died, it was found that he had left his enormous fortune in the hands of trustees, with instructions to apply the interest to the providing of easy berths to men whose hair is of that colour. From all I hear it is splendid pay and very little to do.’
“‘But,’ said I, ‘there would be millions of red-headed men who would apply.’
“‘Not so many as you might think,’ he answered. ‘You see it is really confined to Londoners, and to grown men. This American had started from London when he was young, and he wanted to do the old town a good turn. Then, again, I have heard it is no use your applying if your hair is light red, or dark red, or anything but real bright, blazing, fiery red. Now, if you cared to apply, Mr. Wilson, you would just walk in; but perhaps it would hardly be worth your while to put yourself out of the way for the sake of a few hundred pounds.’
“Now, it is a fact, gentlemen, as you may see for yourselves, that my hair is of a very full and rich tint, so that it seemed to me that if there was to be any competition in the matter I stood as good a chance as any man that I had ever met. Vincent Spaulding seemed to know so much about it that I thought he might prove useful, so I just ordered him to put up the shutters for the day and to come right away with me. He was very willing to have a holiday, so we shut the business up and started off for the address that was given us in the advertisement.
“I never hope to see such a sight as that again, Mr. Holmes. From north, south, east, and west every man who had a shade of red in his hair had tramped into the city to answer the advertisement. Fleet Street was choked with red-headed folk, and Pope’s Court looked like a coster’s orange barrow. I should not have thought there were so many in the whole country as were brought together by that single advertisement. Every shade of colour they were—straw, lemon, orange, brick, Irish-setter, liver, clay; but, as Spaulding said, there were not many who had the real vivid flame-coloured tint. When I saw how many were waiting, I would have given it up in despair; but Spaulding would not hear of it. How he did it I could not imagine, but he pushed and pulled and butted until he got me through the crowd, and right up to the steps which led to the office. There was a double stream upon the stair, some going up in hope, and some coming back dejected; but we wedged in as well as we could and soon found ourselves in the office.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The first thing that put us out was that advertisement. It was in the 'Times,' and it was headed 'The Red-Headed League.' I remember it well, for it was a curious document. It ran as follows: 'ANTED, a young man, red-headed, for the position of assistant in the business of the Red-Headed League. Must be under thirty, and of an amiable disposition. Apply in person to Mr. Duncan Ross, 7 Pope's Court, Fleet Street.'

It was Vincent Spaulding who brought it to my attention. He is a young fellow who has been in my employ for some time, and I have always found him a most trustworthy and capable assistant. He came to me one day with this advertisement in his hand, and he said to me, 'Mr. Wilson, I think you are the very man for this position.' I looked at the advertisement and laughed. 'Why, Spaulding,' said I, 'I am not red-headed.' 'No,' said he, 'but you might be. You are a fair man, and with a little encouragement from the sun, I think you might pass for a red-head.'

I was much amused at the idea, but I must confess that I was not without a certain amount of interest in the matter. My business is not a very profitable one, and I was flattered to think that I might be considered for such a position. Spaulding was very earnest in his recommendations, and he assured me that the League was a very important one, and that the position was one of considerable emolument. He said that the founder of the League was a wealthy American, Mr. Ezekiah Hopkins, who had made a large fortune in the States, and who had a great sympathy for the red-headed race. He had left his money to found this League, and to provide employment for all red-headed men who were willing to work.

I must say that I was somewhat doubtful of the whole affair. I had never heard of the Red-Headed League before, and I could not see why a man should be chosen for a position simply because of the color of his hair. But Spaulding was so confident, and he spoke with such an air of importance, that I was at last induced to go with him to the address given in the advertisement. We found the place in Pope's Court, and we found it to be a very busy one. The street was crowded with men of all shades of red hair, and they were all in a state of great excitement. Some were arguing with the clerk at the door, while others were waiting their turn to be interviewed. It was a most extraordinary scene, and I confess that I was somewhat daunted by it. But Spaulding was a man of great energy, and he pushed me through the crowd and into the office. There we found a number of men waiting their turn, and we joined the queue, which was a long one.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The first thing that put us out was that advertisement. It was in the *Times* on the 15th of last month, and it ran as follows: 

'Wanted, by a nobleman of high position, a young man of good character and appearance, between twenty and twenty-five years of age, to act as secretary and companion. The duties are light, the salary liberal, and the position altogether a most attractive one. Apply in person, between the hours of ten and twelve, at 17, Mortimer Street, W.'

It was a most unusual advertisement, and it struck me at once that it was not the sort of thing which is generally put into the *Times*. It was not the usual kind of advertisement for a secretary, and the tone of it was peculiar. The mention of a nobleman of high position, the stipulation as to the age and appearance of the applicant, and the direction to apply in person, all pointed to something unusual. I said so to Holmes, and he agreed with me. 'It is a trap,' he remarked, 'or it is a mystery. One or the other.'

We had not long to wait for the result of our suspicions. On the following day, a young man named Victor Hatherley came to see us. He was a very handsome young fellow, with a fine, open face, and a manner which was at once deferential and self-possessed. He had read the advertisement, and he had come to apply for the situation. He was twenty-three years of age, and he had been educated at Eton and Oxford. He had no relations, and he was in want of employment. He had been in the army for a short time, but had left it on account of ill-health. He had no particular vocation, and he was willing to accept any position which might offer. He was, in short, the very man that the advertisement seemed to require.

We questioned him carefully, and he gave us a most satisfactory account of himself. He had no objection to being examined, and he was perfectly willing to answer any question that we might put to him. He had no secrets, and he had no past. He was, in fact, a most promising young man. We were both struck by his appearance and his manner, and we felt that we had before us a man of high character and excellent breeding. Holmes, however, was not so easily satisfied. He looked at him with a keen, searching gaze, and then he said, 'I think, Watson, that we may safely say that this young man is not what he seems.'

I was surprised at this remark, for I had formed a very favourable opinion of Victor Hatherley. 'Why do you say so?' I asked.

'Because,' said Holmes, 'he is too perfect. He is too good to be true. He has no past, no history, no antecedents. He is a blank sheet. That is suspicious. A man who has no past is a man who has something to hide.'

I could not help laughing at this. 'You are a little too suspicious, Holmes,' I said. 'You are always looking for mysteries where there are none.'

'Perhaps so,' he replied, 'but I have made a study of the human character, and I know that a man who has no past is a man who has something to hide. I am not saying that this young man is a criminal, but I am saying that he is not what he seems.'

We did not press the matter further, and we allowed Victor Hatherley to go his way. We had no reason to doubt his good faith, and we had no desire to make enemies of people who might be useful to us. We had, however, resolved to keep a close watch upon him, and to see what he would do next.

It was not long before we had an opportunity of doing so. On the following day, we received a letter from the nobleman who had placed the advertisement. It was a very brief letter, and it ran as follows: 

'Mr. Sherlock Holmes, 

I have received several applications for the situation which I advertised in the *Times*, and I am inclined to offer it to a young man named Victor Hatherley. I have been much impressed by his appearance and his manner, and I have no doubt that he will make an excellent secretary and companion. I shall be glad if you will call upon me at my house in London, and I shall be happy to make your acquaintance. 

I remain, 

Yours faithfully, 

The Earl of Stonyhurst.'

This letter was a most unexpected one, and it struck me at once that it was not the sort of thing which is generally sent to a private detective. It was not the usual kind of letter which is sent to a man who is asked to investigate a matter. It was, in fact, a letter which was written with the utmost confidence, and it was a letter which was written by a man who had no suspicion that there was anything wrong.

I said so to Holmes, and he agreed with me. 'It is a most unusual letter,' he remarked. 'It is written with the utmost confidence, and it is written by a man who has no suspicion that there is anything wrong. It is a letter which is written by a man who is in the dark.'

'What do you mean?' I asked.

'I mean,' he replied, 'that the Earl of Stonyhurst is in the dark. He has no idea that there is anything wrong. He has no idea that the young man who has applied for the situation is not what he seems. He is a man who is in the dark, and he is a man who is in danger.'

I was surprised at this remark, for I had formed a very favourable opinion of the Earl of Stonyhurst. 'You are a little too suspicious, Holmes,' I said. 'You are always looking for mysteries where there are none.'

'Perhaps so,' he replied, 'but I have made a study of the human character, and I know that a man who is in the dark is a man who is in danger. I am not saying that the Earl of Stonyhurst is in danger, but I am saying that he is in the dark.'

We did not press the matter further, and we resolved to call upon the Earl of Stonyhurst at the appointed time. We had no reason to doubt his good faith, and we had no desire to make enemies of people who might be useful to us. We had, however, resolved to keep a close watch upon him, and to see what he would do next.

events.title: Securing the Position and Learning the Strange Duties
detailed_summary: Holmes encourages Wilson to continue his interesting story after Wilson pauses.
Wilson describes the sparse office containing only two chairs and a table, behind which sat a small man (Duncan Ross) with hair even redder than his.
Ross briefly interviewed candidates, finding fault with each until Wilson's turn.
Ross was immediately favorable towards Wilson, closing the door for privacy.
Spaulding introduced Wilson as an applicant.
Ross declared Wilson perfectly suited, admiring his hair.
As a precaution against wigs or dye, Ross grabbed Wilson's hair and pulled hard, causing pain but confirming its authenticity.
Ross shouted out the window that the vacancy was filled, eliciting groans from the crowd below.
He introduced himself as Duncan Ross, also a beneficiary of the fund.
Ross inquired if Wilson was married with a family, expressing disappointment upon learning he was a bachelor, stating the fund aimed to propagate red-heads.
Wilson feared losing the position, but Ross decided to make an exception due to Wilson's exceptional hair.
When asked about starting, Wilson mentioned his existing business.
Spaulding assured Wilson he could manage the pawnshop.
The required hours were ten AM to two PM, which suited Wilson as his pawnshop was busiest in the evenings.
The pay was confirmed as £4 per week for 'purely nominal' work.
The work involved being present in the office continuously during the specified hours, with any departure resulting in forfeiture of the position.
The task was to copy the Encyclopædia Britannica, starting with Volume One. Wilson had to provide his own supplies, but a table and chair were provided.
Wilson agreed to start the next day.
Ross congratulated Wilson again, and he left with Spaulding, overjoyed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Your experience has been a most entertaining one,” remarked Holmes as his client paused and refreshed his memory with a huge pinch of snuff.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He bowed me out of the room and I went home with my assistant, hardly knowing what to say or do, I was so pleased at my own good fortune.

events.text_segment:
“Your experience has been a most entertaining one,” remarked Holmes as his client paused and refreshed his memory with a huge pinch of snuff. “Pray continue your very interesting statement.”
“There was nothing in the office but a couple of wooden chairs and a deal table, behind which sat a small man with a head that was even redder than mine. He said a few words to each candidate as he came up, and then he always managed to find some fault in them which would disqualify them. Getting a vacancy did not seem to be such a very easy matter, after all. However, when our turn came the little man was much more favourable to me than to any of the others, and he closed the door as we entered, so that he might have a private word with us.
“‘This is Mr. Jabez Wilson,’ said my assistant, ‘and he is willing to fill a vacancy in the League.’
“‘And he is admirably suited for it,’ the other answered. ‘He has every requirement. I cannot recall when I have seen anything so fine.’ He took a step backward, cocked his head on one side, and gazed at my hair until I felt quite bashful. Then suddenly he plunged forward, wrung my hand, and congratulated me warmly on my success.
“‘It would be injustice to hesitate,’ said he. ‘You will, however, I am sure, excuse me for taking an obvious precaution.’ With that he seized my hair in both his hands, and tugged until I yelled with the pain. ‘There is water in your eyes,’ said he as he released me. ‘I perceive that all is as it should be. But we have to be careful, for we have twice been deceived by wigs and once by paint. I could tell you tales of cobbler’s wax which would disgust you with human nature.’ He stepped over to the window and shouted through it at the top of his voice that the vacancy was filled. A groan of disappointment came up from below, and the folk all trooped away in different directions until there was not a red-head to be seen except my own and that of the manager.
“‘My name,’ said he, ‘is Mr. Duncan Ross, and I am myself one of the pensioners upon the fund left by our noble benefactor. Are you a married man, Mr. Wilson? Have you a family?’
“I answered that I had not.
“His face fell immediately.
“‘Dear me!’ he said gravely, ‘that is very serious indeed! I am sorry to hear you say that. The fund was, of course, for the propagation and spread of the red-heads as well as for their maintenance. It is exceedingly unfortunate that you should be a bachelor.’
“My face lengthened at this, Mr. Holmes, for I thought that I was not to have the vacancy after all; but after thinking it over for a few minutes he said that it would be all right.
“‘In the case of another,’ said he, ‘the objection might be fatal, but we must stretch a point in favour of a man with such a head of hair as yours. When shall you be able to enter upon your new duties?’
“‘Well, it is a little awkward, for I have a business already,’ said I.
“‘Oh, never mind about that, Mr. Wilson!’ said Vincent Spaulding. ‘I should be able to look after that for you.’
“‘What would be the hours?’ I asked.
“‘Ten to two.’
“Now a pawnbroker’s business is mostly done of an evening, Mr. Holmes, especially Thursday and Friday evening, which is just before pay-day; so it would suit me very well to earn a little in the mornings. Besides, I knew that my assistant was a good man, and that he would see to anything that turned up.
“‘That would suit me very well,’ said I. ‘And the pay?’
“‘Is £ 4 a week.’
“‘And the work?’
“‘Is purely nominal.’
“‘What do you call purely nominal?’
“‘Well, you have to be in the office, or at least in the building, the whole time. If you leave, you forfeit your whole position forever. The will is very clear upon that point. You don’t comply with the conditions if you budge from the office during that time.’
“‘It’s only four hours a day, and I should not think of leaving,’ said I.
“‘No excuse will avail,’ said Mr. Duncan Ross; ‘neither sickness nor business nor anything else. There you must stay, or you lose your billet.’
“‘And the work?’
“‘Is to copy out the Encyclopædia Britannica. There is the first volume of it in that press. You must find your own ink, pens, and blotting-paper, but we provide this table and chair. Will you be ready to-morrow?’
“‘Certainly,’ I answered.
“‘Then, good-bye, Mr. Jabez Wilson, and let me congratulate you once more on the important position which you have been fortunate enough to gain.’ He bowed me out of the room and I went home with my assistant, hardly knowing what to say or do, I was so pleased at my own good fortune.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"Your experience has been a most entertaining one," remarked Holmes as his client paused and refreshed his memory with a huge pinch of snuff.

"It was all so strange and new to me," said Mr. Jabez Wilson. "I had never heard of the Red-Headed League before, and I confess I was rather taken aback when I was approached about it."

"Pray proceed," said Holmes, sinking back in his chair and closing his eyes.

"Well, it was this way," continued Wilson. "I was sitting in my pawnshop one morning when a man came in and asked me if I was looking for a part-time position. He said he had heard of my red hair and thought I might be interested in something that would suit me perfectly."

"And who was this man?"

"His name was Vincent Spaulding. He was a quiet, well-dressed fellow, and he spoke with a kind of quiet assurance that put me at ease. He told me about the Red-Headed League, a society for men with red hair, and that there was a vacancy for a reader in their office."

"A reader?"

"Yes, sir. The League had a fund to support the propagation of red-haired people, and they needed someone to be in the office during the day to keep up appearances. The work was purely nominal, and the pay was £4 a week."

"And what did this office look like?"

"It was a small, bare room with only two chairs and a table. Behind the table sat a little man with a head of hair as red as a carrot. He was the one who interviewed the applicants."

"And what was his name?"

"Duncan Ross."

"And what did he do when he saw you?"

"He looked at me with a kind of gleam in his eye, as if he had found something rare and precious. He said I was the man he was looking for, and that my hair was the finest he had ever seen."

"And did he test it?"

"He did indeed. He came over to me, grabbed a handful of my hair, and gave it a good yank. It hurt like the devil, but he was satisfied that it was the real thing."

"And then?"

"He shut the door and said I was the man for the job. He told me I could start the next day, and that I would be expected to be in the office from ten in the morning until two in the afternoon."

"And what was the work?"

"I was to copy the Encyclopædia Britannica, starting with Volume One. I had to bring my own paper and ink, but the League provided a table and a chair."

"And you were content with this arrangement?"

"I was overjoyed, Mr. Holmes. I had never had such a good offer in my life."

"And you had no suspicions?"

"None at all."

"Then you may have been the victim of a most ingenious ruse."

"A ruse?"

"Yes, Mr. Wilson. But we will come to that in good time. For now, let us consider the curious case of the Red-Headed League."

“Your experience has been a most entertaining one,” remarked Holmes as his client paused and refreshed his memory with a huge pinch of snuff. “I have no doubt that you will agree with me when I say that it is not every day that one meets a man who can deduce the nature of a crime from the faintest of clues.”

The client, a portly gentleman with a florid face and a nervous manner, gave a hearty laugh. “Indeed, Mr. Holmes, I must confess that I was quite at a loss when I first encountered the situation. I had no idea what to make of it, and I must say, I was quite relieved when I heard of your reputation and decided to seek your assistance.”

Holmes leaned back in his chair, his long, thin fingers steepled before him. “I am always delighted to assist those in need, particularly when the case presents a challenge. Now, I believe you were about to recount the events that led you to my door.”

The gentleman nodded, adjusting his spectacles with a nervous flick of his fingers. “Yes, yes, of course. It all began a few weeks ago, when I received a letter from my cousin, Mr. James Harcourt. He is a man of some means, and I had not seen him for many years. The letter was most peculiar. It was written in a hurried hand, and it spoke of a most alarming situation. He mentioned that he had been receiving strange visitors at his home in the country, and that he was convinced that someone was watching him.”

Holmes raised an eyebrow. “A most intriguing development. Did he mention the nature of these visitors?”

The gentleman shook his head. “No, he did not. He merely said that they were strangers, and that they had been coming and going at odd hours. He also mentioned that he had found a number of strange objects in his house—objects that he was certain had not been there before.”

Holmes leaned forward slightly, his interest clearly piqued. “And what were these objects?”

The gentleman hesitated for a moment, as if recalling the details with some difficulty. “Well, he mentioned a number of things. There was a small, silver locket, a piece of cloth with strange symbols embroidered on it, and a number of letters that he did not recognize. He was most disturbed by the letters, as they were written in a language he could not decipher.”

Holmes nodded thoughtfully. “A curious collection of items. And what was your cousin’s reaction to these discoveries?”

The gentleman sighed. “He was most distressed. He said that he felt as though he was being watched, and that he could not shake the feeling that someone was trying to communicate with him. He also mentioned that he had begun to hear strange noises in the house at night—whispers, and the sound of footsteps in the corridors.”

Holmes steepled his fingers once more. “A most unusual situation. And what did you do when you received this letter?”

The gentleman hesitated for a moment. “Well, I must confess that I was quite taken aback. I had not seen my cousin for many years, and I was not sure what to make of his letter. I decided to visit him at his home in the country, to see for myself what was going on.”

Holmes nodded. “A wise decision. And what did you find when you arrived?”

The gentleman took a deep breath. “I found my cousin in a most agitated state. He was pale and drawn, and he seemed to be on the verge of a nervous breakdown. He showed me the objects he had found, and he told me of the strange noises and the feeling of being watched. I must say, I was quite unsettled by the whole affair.”

Holmes leaned back in his chair, his expression thoughtful. “And what did you do then?”

The gentleman hesitated for a moment. “Well, I decided to stay with him for a few days, to see if I could help him make sense of the situation. I must confess that I was quite at a loss, and I was beginning to wonder if I had made a mistake in coming.”

Holmes smiled faintly. “A most natural reaction. And what happened during your stay?”

The gentleman hesitated for a moment, as if recalling the details with some difficulty. “Well, I must confess that I was quite taken aback by what I saw. I began to notice strange things happening in the house—objects moving on their own, strange lights in the corridors, and the sound of footsteps in the night. I was beginning to wonder if my cousin was right to be so disturbed.”

Holmes nodded thoughtfully. “A most intriguing development. And what did you do then?”

The gentleman hesitated for a moment. “Well, I decided to seek your assistance. I had heard of your reputation, and I was certain that you would be able to make sense of the situation.”

Holmes smiled. “A most wise decision. I am always delighted to assist those in need, particularly when the case presents a challenge. Now, I believe it is time for us to begin our investigation.”

events.title: The Copying Task and the League's Sudden Dissolution
detailed_summary: Wilson recounts his initial doubts after securing the job, suspecting a hoax due to the implausibility of the will and the simple task.
Spaulding tried to reassure him, but Wilson remained skeptical.
The next morning, Wilson decided to investigate, bought supplies, and went to Pope's Court.
To his surprise, everything was legitimate: the table was ready, and Duncan Ross was present to start him on his work copying the encyclopedia from 'A'.
Ross checked on him periodically at first, then less frequently, eventually not appearing at all.
Wilson diligently copied the encyclopedia daily from ten to two, never daring to leave, and filled nearly a shelf with his writings.
He received his payment of four gold sovereigns each Saturday.
After eight weeks of this routine, having worked through entries like Abbots, Archery, Armour, Architecture, and Attica, the situation abruptly ended.
That very morning, Wilson arrived to find the office door shut and locked.
A small cardboard sign was tacked to the door.
Wilson presents the cardboard sign to Holmes and Watson.

events.text_segment:
“Well, I thought over the matter all day, and by evening I was in low spirits again; for I had quite persuaded myself that the whole affair must be some great hoax or fraud, though what its object might be I could not imagine. It seemed altogether past belief that anyone could make such a will, or that they would pay such a sum for doing anything so simple as copying out the Encyclopædia Britannica. Vincent Spaulding did what he could to cheer me up, but by bedtime I had reasoned myself out of the whole thing. However, in the morning I determined to have a look at it anyhow, so I bought a penny bottle of ink, and with a quill-pen, and seven sheets of foolscap paper, I started off for Pope’s Court.
“Well, to my surprise and delight, everything was as right as possible. The table was set out ready for me, and Mr. Duncan Ross was there to see that I got fairly to work. He started me off upon the letter A, and then he left me; but he would drop in from time to time to see that all was right with me. At two o’clock he bade me good-day, complimented me upon the amount that I had written, and locked the door of the office after me.
“This went on day after day, Mr. Holmes, and on Saturday the manager came in and planked down four golden sovereigns for my week’s work. It was the same next week, and the same the week after. Every morning I was there at ten, and every afternoon I left at two. By degrees Mr. Duncan Ross took to coming in only once of a morning, and then, after a time, he did not come in at all. Still, of course, I never dared to leave the room for an instant, for I was not sure when he might come, and the billet was such a good one, and suited me so well, that I would not risk the loss of it.
“Eight weeks passed away like this, and I had written about Abbots and Archery and Armour and Architecture and Attica, and hoped with diligence that I might get on to the B’s before very long. It cost me something in foolscap, and I had pretty nearly filled a shelf with my writings. And then suddenly the whole business came to an end.”
“To an end?”
“Yes, sir. And no later than this morning. I went to my work as usual at ten o’clock, but the door was shut and locked, with a little square of cardboard hammered on to the middle of the panel with a tack. Here it is, and you can read for yourself.”

The next morning I bought a bundle of paper and a fountain-pen, and I set off for Pope's Court, which I found without difficulty. The office was a small room at the back of a warehouse, and the table and chair were already in place, as had been arranged. A man was there to meet me, a quiet, gentlemanly-looking person, with a very red nose, a very large head, and a very civil manner. He introduced himself as Mr. Duncan Ross, the secretary of the League, and he explained that I was to begin at once with the letter 'A' in the Encyclopaedia Britannica. He left me after a few minutes, but he returned from time to time to see how I was getting on. After a week or two he came less often, and at last he did not come at all. I worked steadily from ten to two every day, and I filled nearly a shelf with my copies. I received four gold sovereigns every Saturday, and I was paid in full for my work. I had got as far as 'Attica' when the thing came to an end. I went in as usual one morning, and I found the door locked. There was a little card on the panel, and that was all.

I had no means of verifying the facts, and I was left in a state of the most painful uncertainty. I had therefore to wait until then, and in the interval I resolved to make a fresh examination of the case. The letter had been written in a very peculiar hand, and the paper was of a peculiar quality. I had not noticed before that the ink was of a very dark blue, and that the writing was done with a very fine pen. I had also failed to observe that the letter had been folded in a peculiar way, and that the seal was of a peculiar shape. I was so absorbed in these details that I did not hear the door open, and I was startled by the voice of my friend. “You are looking very grave, Watson,” said he, as he stepped into the room. “I have been trying to solve a mystery,” I said. “Ah, that is always a good occupation,” he remarked. “But I fear that I have not made much progress.” “You have, perhaps, made more than you think,” he said. “I have been thinking over the case, and I believe that I have discovered the solution.” “Indeed!” I exclaimed. “Then you have solved the mystery?” “I have at least made a beginning,” he said. “I think that I can tell you who wrote the letter.” “Who?” I asked eagerly. “I think that it was written by a woman,” he said. “A woman!” I exclaimed. “Yes,” he said. “I am quite sure of it. The hand is a woman’s hand, and the paper and the ink are of a kind which are not generally used by men. Moreover, the seal is of a peculiar shape, and I have seen it before.” “Where?” I asked. “In the house of a lady who is a great friend of mine,” he said. “I will not name her, but I will say that she is a woman of great intelligence and of great beauty. I think that she is the person who wrote the letter.” “But why should she write it?” I asked. “That is what I am going to find out,” he said. “I have a plan, and I think that I can carry it out. I will go to her house to-morrow, and I will see if I can get any information from her.” “And I will go with you,” I said. “I am very much interested in the case.” “I am glad to hear it,” he said. “You will find it a very interesting case, I think.” And with that he took up his hat and we left the room together.

events.title: Investigation Attempts and Holmes Takes the Case
detailed_summary: The sign read: "THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE IS DISSOLVED. October 9, 1890."
Holmes and Watson burst into laughter at the abrupt notice and Wilson's dismayed expression.
Wilson, offended, threatens to leave if they only intend to laugh.
Holmes reassures him, finding the case refreshingly unusual despite its comical aspect, and urges him to continue.
Wilson explains his confusion and subsequent actions: inquiring at neighboring offices (none knew of the League) and questioning the landlord.
The landlord had never heard of the Red-Headed League and didn't know Duncan Ross.
When Wilson described the red-headed man in Room 4, the landlord identified him as William Morris, a solicitor who rented the room temporarily and had moved out the previous day.
The landlord provided Morris's new address: 17 King Edward Street.
Wilson went there but found a manufactory of artificial knee-caps, where no one knew Morris or Ross.
He returned home and consulted Spaulding, who offered no help beyond suggesting Wilson wait for news by post.
Unwilling to lose the position without answers, Wilson sought Holmes's advice.
Holmes commends Wilson's decision, acknowledging the case's remarkableness and potential gravity beyond the lost income.
Wilson laments the loss of £4 per week.
Holmes points out Wilson has actually gained about £30 and encyclopedic knowledge, having no real grievance against the League.
Wilson insists he wants to understand the perpetrators and their motive for the apparent prank.
Holmes agrees to investigate and asks about Spaulding: he'd been with Wilson about a month before the ad, hired cheaply from a dozen applicants.
Wilson describes Spaulding: small, stout, quick, clean-shaven despite being around thirty, with a white acid splash on his forehead.
Holmes becomes excited, confirming his suspicion, and asks if Spaulding's ears are pierced.
Wilson confirms, recalling Spaulding claimed a gypsy pierced them.
Holmes falls into deep thought, confirms Spaulding is still there, and asks if the business ran smoothly during Wilson's absences (it did, being quiet in the mornings).
Holmes concludes the interview, promising an opinion in a day or two, by Monday.
