events.text_segment:
He held up a piece of white cardboard about the size of a sheet of note-paper. It read in this fashion:
“THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE IS DISSOLVED. October 9, 1890.”
Sherlock Holmes and I surveyed this curt announcement and the rueful face behind it, until the comical side of the affair so completely overtopped every other consideration that we both burst out into a roar of laughter.
“I cannot see that there is anything very funny,” cried our client, flushing up to the roots of his flaming head. “If you can do nothing better than laugh at me, I can go elsewhere.”
“No, no,” cried Holmes, shoving him back into the chair from which he had half risen. “I really wouldn’t miss your case for the world. It is most refreshingly unusual. But there is, if you will excuse my saying so, something just a little funny about it. Pray what steps did you take when you found the card upon the door?”
“I was staggered, sir. I did not know what to do. Then I called at the offices round, but none of them seemed to know anything about it. Finally, I went to the landlord, who is an accountant living on the ground floor, and I asked him if he could tell me what had become of the Red-headed League. He said that he had never heard of any such body. Then I asked him who Mr. Duncan Ross was. He answered that the name was new to him.
“‘Well,’ said I, ‘the gentleman at No. 4.’
“‘What, the red-headed man?’
“‘Yes.’
“‘Oh,’ said he, ‘his name was William Morris. He was a solicitor and was using my room as a temporary convenience until his new premises were ready. He moved out yesterday.’
“‘Where could I find him?’
“‘Oh, at his new offices. He did tell me the address. Yes, 17 King Edward Street, near St. Paul’s.’
“I started off, Mr. Holmes, but when I got to that address it was a manufactory of artificial knee-caps, and no one in it had ever heard of either Mr. William Morris or Mr. Duncan Ross.”
“And what did you do then?” asked Holmes.
“I went home to Saxe-Coburg Square, and I took the advice of my assistant. But he could not help me in any way. He could only say that if I waited I should hear by post. But that was not quite good enough, Mr. Holmes. I did not wish to lose such a place without a struggle, so, as I had heard that you were good enough to give advice to poor folk who were in need of it, I came right away to you.”
“And you did very wisely,” said Holmes. “Your case is an exceedingly remarkable one, and I shall be happy to look into it. From what you have told me I think that it is possible that graver issues hang from it than might at first sight appear.”
“Grave enough!” said Mr. Jabez Wilson. “Why, I have lost four pound a week.”
“As far as you are personally concerned,” remarked Holmes, “I do not see that you have any grievance against this extraordinary league. On the contrary, you are, as I understand, richer by some £ 30, to say nothing of the minute knowledge which you have gained on every subject which comes under the letter A. You have lost nothing by them.”
“No, sir. But I want to find out about them, and who they are, and what their object was in playing this prank—if it was a prank—upon me. It was a pretty expensive joke for them, for it cost them two and thirty pounds.”
“We shall endeavour to clear up these points for you. And, first, one or two questions, Mr. Wilson. This assistant of yours who first called your attention to the advertisement—how long had he been with you?”
“About a month then.”
“How did he come?”
“In answer to an advertisement.”
“Was he the only applicant?”
“No, I had a dozen.”
“Why did you pick him?”
“Because he was handy and would come cheap.”
“At half wages, in fact.”
“Yes.”
“What is he like, this Vincent Spaulding?”
“Small, stout-built, very quick in his ways, no hair on his face, though he’s not short of thirty. Has a white splash of acid upon his forehead.”
Holmes sat up in his chair in considerable excitement. “I thought as much,” said he. “Have you ever observed that his ears are pierced for earrings?”
“Yes, sir. He told me that a gipsy had done it for him when he was a lad.”
“Hum!” said Holmes, sinking back in deep thought. “He is still with you?”
“Oh, yes, sir; I have only just left him.”
“And has your business been attended to in your absence?”
“Nothing to complain of, sir. There’s never very much to do of a morning.”
“That will do, Mr. Wilson. I shall be happy to give you an opinion upon the subject in the course of a day or two. To-day is Saturday, and I hope that by Monday we may come to a conclusion.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
He held up a piece of white cardboard about the size of a sheet of note-paper. "This is the notice," said he, "which was nailed up yesterday morning in the City, and which has caused my client to come to us for advice. The Red-Headed League is dissolved." 

I looked at the slip with some interest. It was printed in very large, bold letters, and was headed with a device of a red-haired man with a comic air, wearing a nightcap and holding a candle in his hand. 

"It is certainly a curious advertisement," I remarked. 

"It is more than curious," said Holmes. "It is positively the most unique case that I have ever come across. But I think, Watson, that we may find it a little more amusing than our client does."

"I confess," said the client, who was a thick-set, red-faced, middle-aged man, "that I am very much annoyed. I have lost my situation, and I don't know what to do."

"You have lost your situation?" I cried.

"Yes, sir. I was secretary to the Red-Headed League, and I was paid four pounds a week for doing nothing."

"For doing nothing?"

"Yes, sir. I was paid to be in the office in the morning, to read the paper, and to keep the books."

"And now you have lost this sinecure?"

"Yes, sir. The League is dissolved."

"And you are very much annoyed?"

"I am, sir. I have lost four pounds a week."

"And you have come to us to get it back?"

"Yes, sir."

"Then I must tell you, Mr. Wilson, that you have come to the right place."

"I am glad to hear it, sir."

"But I must warn you that it is not a matter of getting your four pounds a week back, but of finding out who it is that has dissolved the League and why."

"That is just what I want to know, sir."

"Then we shall have to go into the matter very carefully."

"I am ready to do anything, sir."

"Then let us begin at the beginning."

"I will do so, sir."

"First of all, tell us how you came to be secretary to the Red-Headed League."

"Well, sir, I was a pawnbroker in the city, and I had a very small business. I was not doing well, and I was thinking of giving it up. One day a gentleman called upon me and said that he was a member of the Red-Headed League, and that he had heard of my business and wished to speak to me."

"What was the gentleman's name?"

"His name was Duncan Ross."

"And what did he say to you?"

"He said that the League was composed of a number of red-headed men who were interested in the preservation of the red hair. He said that they had a fund which they wished to use for the benefit of the League, and that they wished to employ a secretary who was himself a red-headed man."

"And you were a red-headed man?"

"Yes, sir."

"Then you were the ideal candidate."

"Yes, sir."

"And what did you do?"

"I was employed as secretary, and I was paid four pounds a week for doing nothing."

"And you were very happy in your position?"

"Yes, sir."

"And now you have lost it."

"Yes, sir."

"Yes, sir."

He held up a piece of white cardboard about the size of a sheet of note-paper. It was covered with a curious pattern of black and white squares, like a chessboard, but with some of the squares missing. Sherlock Holmes, leaning forward in his chair, took the cardboard from my hand and examined it with a keen eye. “This is no ordinary piece of paper, Watson,” he said, his voice low and thoughtful. “This is a cipher, and a clever one at that.”

I looked at the pattern again, but it still seemed to me to be nothing more than a jumble of black and white squares. “A cipher?” I asked, puzzled. “But how can a pattern of squares be a cipher? It seems to me to be nothing more than a child’s drawing.”

Holmes smiled. “You are not seeing the pattern, Watson. This is a code, and it is designed to be read in a particular way. Each square represents a letter, and the pattern of black and white squares is a key to unlocking the message.”

I was intrigued. “But how can a square represent a letter? There are only two colors, black and white.”

“Ah, but there are eight rows and eight columns,” Holmes replied. “That gives us sixty-four squares in total. If we number them from one to sixty-four, we can assign each number to a letter of the alphabet. A is one, B is two, and so on. But since there are only twenty-six letters in the English alphabet, we will need to use a different method for the remaining letters.”

I was beginning to see the pattern. “So the black squares represent the letters, and the white squares are just for spacing?”

“Exactly,” Holmes said. “But it is not quite that simple. The pattern is designed to be read in a particular order. The first row is read from left to right, the second row from right to left, the third row from left to right again, and so on. This is known as a zigzag pattern, and it is a common method used in ciphers to obscure the message.”

I looked at the pattern again, this time with Holmes’s explanation in mind. I could see that the black squares formed a message, but it was still not clear to me what the message was.

Holmes took a piece of paper and a pencil and began to write down the letters corresponding to the black squares. “Let us see what we have here,” he said. “The first row has black squares in positions one, three, five, and seven. That gives us the letters A, C, E, and G. The second row has black squares in positions eight, six, four, and two. That gives us the letters H, F, D, and B. The third row has black squares in positions nine, eleven, thirteen, and fifteen. That gives us the letters I, K, M, and O. The fourth row has black squares in positions sixteen, fourteen, twelve, and ten. That gives us the letters P, N, L, and J. The fifth row has black squares in positions seventeen, nineteen, twenty-one, and twenty-three. That gives us the letters Q, S, U, and W. The sixth row has black squares in positions twenty-four, twenty-two, twenty, and eighteen. That gives us the letters X, V, T, and R. The seventh row has black squares in positions twenty-five, twenty-seven, twenty-nine, and thirty-one. That gives us the letters Y, A, C, and E. The eighth row has black squares in positions thirty-two, thirty, twenty-eight, and twenty-six. That gives us the letters Z, Y, X, and W.”

I looked at the letters Holmes had written down and began to see a pattern. “It seems to me that the message is a sequence of letters that spell out a word or phrase,” I said.

“Indeed,” Holmes replied. “And if we read the letters in the order they appear, we get the message: ACEG HFD B IKMO PNLJ QSUW XVT R YACE ZYXW.”

events.title: Holmes Investigates Saxe-Coburg Square
detailed_summary: After Wilson leaves, Holmes asks Watson for his assessment.
Watson admits he finds the case completely mysterious.
Holmes counters that bizarre cases are often less mysterious than commonplace ones and states he needs to act quickly.
He declares it a "three pipe problem" and requests silence for fifty minutes to think.
Holmes settles into his chair, deep in thought, pipe in hand.
After nearly an hour, Holmes suddenly springs up, having reached a decision.
He suggests attending a Sarasate concert at St. James's Hall, asking if Watson is free.
Watson confirms he has no urgent patients.
Holmes proposes they go, stopping in the City first and having lunch; he notes the German music program suits his introspective mood.
They travel by Underground to Aldersgate and walk to Saxe-Coburg Square.
Holmes carefully observes Wilson's pawnshop and the surrounding shabby-genteel square.
He walks up and down the street, scrutinizing the houses.
Returning to the pawnbroker's, Holmes thumps the pavement with his stick several times, then knocks on the door.
A young, clean-shaven man (Spaulding) opens the door.
Holmes pretends to ask for directions to the Strand.
The assistant answers promptly ("Third right, fourth left") and closes the door.
As they walk away, Holmes identifies the assistant as the fourth smartest man in London, possibly third in daring, mentioning previous encounters.
Watson correctly assumes Holmes's inquiry was a pretext to see the assistant.
Holmes clarifies he wasn't looking at the assistant's face, but rather the knees of his trousers.
Watson asks what he saw, and Holmes replies, "What I expected to see."
Regarding the pavement thumping, Holmes states it's a time for observation, comparing their situation to spies in enemy territory.
They turn the corner into a busy main thoroughfare, a stark contrast to the quiet square.
Holmes identifies the businesses along the street: a tobacconist, news shop, City and Suburban Bank branch, Vegetarian Restaurant, and carriage depot, noting their proximity to Wilson's premises.
Satisfied with their reconnaissance, Holmes declares it time for leisure: lunch and the concert.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: A sandwich and a cup of coffee, and then off to violin-land, where all is sweetness and delicacy and harmony, and there are no red-headed clients to vex us with their conundrums.”

events.text_segment:
“Well, Watson,” said Holmes when our visitor had left us, “what do you make of it all?”
“I make nothing of it,” I answered frankly. “It is a most mysterious business.”
“As a rule,” said Holmes, “the more bizarre a thing is the less mysterious it proves to be. It is your commonplace, featureless crimes which are really puzzling, just as a commonplace face is the most difficult to identify. But I must be prompt over this matter.”
“What are you going to do, then?” I asked.
“To smoke,” he answered. “It is quite a three pipe problem, and I beg that you won’t speak to me for fifty minutes.” He curled himself up in his chair, with his thin knees drawn up to his hawk-like nose, and there he sat with his eyes closed and his black clay pipe thrusting out like the bill of some strange bird. I had come to the conclusion that he had dropped asleep, and indeed was nodding myself, when he suddenly sprang out of his chair with the gesture of a man who has made up his mind and put his pipe down upon the mantelpiece.
“Sarasate plays at the St. James’s Hall this afternoon,” he remarked. “What do you think, Watson? Could your patients spare you for a few hours?”
“I have nothing to do to-day. My practice is never very absorbing.”
“Then put on your hat and come. I am going through the City first, and we can have some lunch on the way. I observe that there is a good deal of German music on the programme, which is rather more to my taste than Italian or French. It is introspective, and I want to introspect. Come along!”
We travelled by the Underground as far as Aldersgate; and a short walk took us to Saxe-Coburg Square, the scene of the singular story which we had listened to in the morning. It was a poky, little, shabby-genteel place, where four lines of dingy two-storied brick houses looked out into a small railed-in enclosure, where a lawn of weedy grass and a few clumps of faded laurel bushes made a hard fight against a smoke-laden and uncongenial atmosphere. Three gilt balls and a brown board with “JABEZ WILSON” in white letters, upon a corner house, announced the place where our red-headed client carried on his business. Sherlock Holmes stopped in front of it with his head on one side and looked it all over, with his eyes shining brightly between puckered lids. Then he walked slowly up the street, and then down again to the corner, still looking keenly at the houses. Finally he returned to the pawnbroker’s, and, having thumped vigorously upon the pavement with his stick two or three times, he went up to the door and knocked. It was instantly opened by a bright-looking, clean-shaven young fellow, who asked him to step in.
“Thank you,” said Holmes, “I only wished to ask you how you would go from here to the Strand.”
“Third right, fourth left,” answered the assistant promptly, closing the door.
“Smart fellow, that,” observed Holmes as we walked away. “He is, in my judgment, the fourth smartest man in London, and for daring I am not sure that he has not a claim to be third. I have known something of him before.”
“Evidently,” said I, “Mr. Wilson’s assistant counts for a good deal in this mystery of the Red-headed League. I am sure that you inquired your way merely in order that you might see him.”
“Not him.”
“What then?”
“The knees of his trousers.”
“And what did you see?”
“What I expected to see.”
“Why did you beat the pavement?”
“My dear doctor, this is a time for observation, not for talk. We are spies in an enemy’s country. We know something of Saxe-Coburg Square. Let us now explore the parts which lie behind it.”
The road in which we found ourselves as we turned round the corner from the retired Saxe-Coburg Square presented as great a contrast to it as the front of a picture does to the back. It was one of the main arteries which conveyed the traffic of the City to the north and west. The roadway was blocked with the immense stream of commerce flowing in a double tide inward and outward, while the footpaths were black with the hurrying swarm of pedestrians. It was difficult to realise as we looked at the line of fine shops and stately business premises that they really abutted on the other side upon the faded and stagnant square which we had just quitted.
“Let me see,” said Holmes, standing at the corner and glancing along the line, “I should like just to remember the order of the houses here. It is a hobby of mine to have an exact knowledge of London. There is Mortimer’s, the tobacconist, the little newspaper shop, the Coburg branch of the City and Suburban Bank, the Vegetarian Restaurant, and McFarlane’s carriage-building depot. That carries us right on to the other block. And now, Doctor, we’ve done our work, so it’s time we had some play. A sandwich and a cup of coffee, and then off to violin-land, where all is sweetness and delicacy and harmony, and there are no red-headed clients to vex us with their conundrums.”

events.title: Preparations for the Night Vigil in the Bank Cellar
detailed_summary: Watson describes Holmes's deep immersion in the music at the concert, noting the contrast between his artistic sensitivity and his relentless detective persona.
He reflects on Holmes's dual nature, swinging between languor and intense energy, and how his periods of quiet contemplation often preceded bursts of brilliant deduction.
Seeing Holmes absorbed in music, Watson senses danger brewing for his quarry.
As they leave the concert, Holmes states he has business that will take hours and confirms the Coburg Square affair is serious.
He reveals a major crime is planned, but he believes they can stop it, though the Saturday timing complicates things.
Holmes requests Watson's help that night at ten PM, advising him to bring his army revolver due to potential danger.
Holmes then quickly departs.

Watson reflects on his own inability to grasp Holmes's conclusions despite having the same information, pondering the purpose of the nocturnal, armed expedition and the role of the pawnbroker's assistant.
At 9:15 PM, Watson travels to Baker Street, finding two hansom cabs waiting.
Inside, Holmes is conversing with Peter Jones (Scotland Yard agent) and Mr. Merryweather (a respectable, sad-faced man).
Holmes announces their party is complete and introduces Merryweather.
Jones remarks on hunting with Holmes again, praising his ability to start a chase.
Merryweather expresses gloomy apprehension and regret at missing his Saturday night card game (rubber).
Holmes assures Merryweather the stakes tonight (£30,000) and excitement will be higher.
He tells Jones the target is John Clay, the notorious murderer, thief, and forger.
Jones describes Clay as young but top-tier, elusive, and descended from royalty, educated at Eton and Oxford.
Holmes hopes to introduce Jones to Clay, mentioning his own past encounters.
Noting it's past ten, Holmes directs Jones and Merryweather to take the first hansom, while he and Watson follow.
During the drive, Holmes is quiet, humming tunes.
They arrive near Farrington Street.
Holmes identifies Merryweather as a bank director personally invested in the matter and Jones as brave and tenacious despite being professionally inept.
They dismiss the cabs and follow Merryweather through a narrow passage and side door into a building.
They pass through two massive iron gates and down winding stone steps.
Merryweather lights a lantern, leading them through a dark passage and a third door into a large cellar filled with crates.
Holmes observes the cellar isn't vulnerable from above.
Merryweather strikes the floor with his stick, noting it sounds hollow.
Holmes sternly tells Merryweather to be quiet, as he's jeopardized the mission, and asks him to sit on a box.
Merryweather complies with an injured expression.
Holmes examines the cracks between the floor stones with a lantern and magnifying glass, quickly satisfied.
He states they have at least an hour wait until the pawnbroker is asleep.
Holmes reveals they are in the cellar of the City branch of a major bank, and Mr. Merryweather is the chairman.
He explains criminals have reason to be interested in this cellar.
Merryweather whispers it's due to a large reserve of French gold (30,000 napoleons) borrowed months ago and still stored there, unpacked.
Holmes confirms the directors' concerns were justified.
He outlines the plan: extinguish the lantern, take positions behind crates, and close in when he signals.
He instructs Watson to shoot if the criminals fire.
Watson positions his cocked revolver.
Holmes covers his lantern, plunging them into absolute darkness.
Watson feels tense and oppressed by the sudden gloom and cold air.
Holmes whispers their only retreat is back through the house, confirming Jones has officers stationed at the front door.
He declares all escape routes covered and calls for silence.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: My friend was an enthusiastic musician, being himself not only a very capable performer but a composer of no ordinary merit.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And now we must be silent and wait.”

events.text_segment:
My friend was an enthusiastic musician, being himself not only a very capable performer but a composer of no ordinary merit. All the afternoon he sat in the stalls wrapped in the most perfect happiness, gently waving his long, thin fingers in time to the music, while his gently smiling face and his languid, dreamy eyes were as unlike those of Holmes the sleuth-hound, Holmes the relentless, keen-witted, ready-handed criminal agent, as it was possible to conceive. In his singular character the dual nature alternately asserted itself, and his extreme exactness and astuteness represented, as I have often thought, the reaction against the poetic and contemplative mood which occasionally predominated in him. The swing of his nature took him from extreme languor to devouring energy; and, as I knew well, he was never so truly formidable as when, for days on end, he had been lounging in his armchair amid his improvisations and his black-letter editions. Then it was that the lust of the chase would suddenly come upon him, and that his brilliant reasoning power would rise to the level of intuition, until those who were unacquainted with his methods would look askance at him as on a man whose knowledge was not that of other mortals. When I saw him that afternoon so enwrapped in the music at St. James’s Hall I felt that an evil time might be coming upon those whom he had set himself to hunt down.
“You want to go home, no doubt, Doctor,” he remarked as we emerged.
“Yes, it would be as well.”
“And I have some business to do which will take some hours. This business at Coburg Square is serious.”
“Why serious?”
“A considerable crime is in contemplation. I have every reason to believe that we shall be in time to stop it. But to-day being Saturday rather complicates matters. I shall want your help to-night.”
“At what time?”
“Ten will be early enough.”
“I shall be at Baker Street at ten.”
“Very well. And, I say, Doctor, there may be some little danger, so kindly put your army revolver in your pocket.” He waved his hand, turned on his heel, and disappeared in an instant among the crowd.
I trust that I am not more dense than my neighbours, but I was always oppressed with a sense of my own stupidity in my dealings with Sherlock Holmes. Here I had heard what he had heard, I had seen what he had seen, and yet from his words it was evident that he saw clearly not only what had happened but what was about to happen, while to me the whole business was still confused and grotesque. As I drove home to my house in Kensington I thought over it all, from the extraordinary story of the red-headed copier of the Encyclopædia down to the visit to Saxe-Coburg Square, and the ominous words with which he had parted from me. What was this nocturnal expedition, and why should I go armed? Where were we going, and what were we to do? I had the hint from Holmes that this smooth-faced pawnbroker’s assistant was a formidable man—a man who might play a deep game. I tried to puzzle it out, but gave it up in despair and set the matter aside until night should bring an explanation.
It was a quarter-past nine when I started from home and made my way across the Park, and so through Oxford Street to Baker Street. Two hansoms were standing at the door, and as I entered the passage I heard the sound of voices from above. On entering his room, I found Holmes in animated conversation with two men, one of whom I recognised as Peter Jones, the official police agent, while the other was a long, thin, sad-faced man, with a very shiny hat and oppressively respectable frock-coat.
“Ha! Our party is complete,” said Holmes, buttoning up his pea-jacket and taking his heavy hunting crop from the rack. “Watson, I think you know Mr. Jones, of Scotland Yard? Let me introduce you to Mr. Merryweather, who is to be our companion in to-night’s adventure.”
“We’re hunting in couples again, Doctor, you see,” said Jones in his consequential way. “Our friend here is a wonderful man for starting a chase. All he wants is an old dog to help him to do the running down.”
“I hope a wild goose may not prove to be the end of our chase,” observed Mr. Merryweather gloomily.
“You may place considerable confidence in Mr. Holmes, sir,” said the police agent loftily. “He has his own little methods, which are, if he won’t mind my saying so, just a little too theoretical and fantastic, but he has the makings of a detective in him. It is not too much to say that once or twice, as in that business of the Sholto murder and the Agra treasure, he has been more nearly correct than the official force.”
“Oh, if you say so, Mr. Jones, it is all right,” said the stranger with deference. “Still, I confess that I miss my rubber. It is the first Saturday night for seven-and-twenty years that I have not had my rubber.”
“I think you will find,” said Sherlock Holmes, “that you will play for a higher stake to-night than you have ever done yet, and that the play will be more exciting. For you, Mr. Merryweather, the stake will be some £ 30,000; and for you, Jones, it will be the man upon whom you wish to lay your hands.”
“John Clay, the murderer, thief, smasher, and forger. He’s a young man, Mr. Merryweather, but he is at the head of his profession, and I would rather have my bracelets on him than on any criminal in London. He’s a remarkable man, is young John Clay. His grandfather was a royal duke, and he himself has been to Eton and Oxford. His brain is as cunning as his fingers, and though we meet signs of him at every turn, we never know where to find the man himself. He’ll crack a crib in Scotland one week, and be raising money to build an orphanage in Cornwall the next. I’ve been on his track for years and have never set eyes on him yet.”
“I hope that I may have the pleasure of introducing you to-night. I’ve had one or two little turns also with Mr. John Clay, and I agree with you that he is at the head of his profession. It is past ten, however, and quite time that we started. If you two will take the first hansom, Watson and I will follow in the second.”
Sherlock Holmes was not very communicative during the long drive and lay back in the cab humming the tunes which he had heard in the afternoon. We rattled through an endless labyrinth of gas-lit streets until we emerged into Farrington Street.
“We are close there now,” my friend remarked. “This fellow Merryweather is a bank director, and personally interested in the matter. I thought it as well to have Jones with us also. He is not a bad fellow, though an absolute imbecile in his profession. He has one positive virtue. He is as brave as a bulldog and as tenacious as a lobster if he gets his claws upon anyone. Here we are, and they are waiting for us.”
We had reached the same crowded thoroughfare in which we had found ourselves in the morning. Our cabs were dismissed, and, following the guidance of Mr. Merryweather, we passed down a narrow passage and through a side door, which he opened for us. Within there was a small corridor, which ended in a very massive iron gate. This also was opened, and led down a flight of winding stone steps, which terminated at another formidable gate. Mr. Merryweather stopped to light a lantern, and then conducted us down a dark, earth-smelling passage, and so, after opening a third door, into a huge vault or cellar, which was piled all round with crates and massive boxes.
“You are not very vulnerable from above,” Holmes remarked as he held up the lantern and gazed about him.
“Nor from below,” said Mr. Merryweather, striking his stick upon the flags which lined the floor. “Why, dear me, it sounds quite hollow!” he remarked, looking up in surprise.
“I must really ask you to be a little more quiet!” said Holmes severely. “You have already imperilled the whole success of our expedition. Might I beg that you would have the goodness to sit down upon one of those boxes, and not to interfere?”
The solemn Mr. Merryweather perched himself upon a crate, with a very injured expression upon his face, while Holmes fell upon his knees upon the floor and, with the lantern and a magnifying lens, began to examine minutely the cracks between the stones. A few seconds sufficed to satisfy him, for he sprang to his feet again and put his glass in his pocket.
“We have at least an hour before us,” he remarked, “for they can hardly take any steps until the good pawnbroker is safely in bed. Then they will not lose a minute, for the sooner they do their work the longer time they will have for their escape. We are at present, Doctor—as no doubt you have divined—in the cellar of the City branch of one of the principal London banks. Mr. Merryweather is the chairman of directors, and he will explain to you that there are reasons why the more daring criminals of London should take a considerable interest in this cellar at present.”
“It is our French gold,” whispered the director. “We have had several warnings that an attempt might be made upon it.”
“Your French gold?”
“Yes. We had occasion some months ago to strengthen our resources and borrowed for that purpose 30,000 napoleons from the Bank of France. It has become known that we have never had occasion to unpack the money, and that it is still lying in our cellar. The crate upon which I sit contains 2,000 napoleons packed between layers of lead foil. Our reserve of bullion is much larger at present than is usually kept in a single branch office, and the directors have had misgivings upon the subject.”
“Which were very well justified,” observed Holmes. “And now it is time that we arranged our little plans. I expect that within an hour matters will come to a head. In the meantime Mr. Merryweather, we must put the screen over that dark lantern.”
“And sit in the dark?”
“I am afraid so. I had brought a pack of cards in my pocket, and I thought that, as we were a partie carrée, you might have your rubber after all. But I see that the enemy’s preparations have gone so far that we cannot risk the presence of a light. And, first of all, we must choose our positions. These are daring men, and though we shall take them at a disadvantage, they may do us some harm unless we are careful. I shall stand behind this crate, and do you conceal yourselves behind those. Then, when I flash a light upon them, close in swiftly. If they fire, Watson, have no compunction about shooting them down.”
I placed my revolver, cocked, upon the top of the wooden case behind which I crouched. Holmes shot the slide across the front of his lantern and left us in pitch darkness—such an absolute darkness as I have never before experienced. The smell of hot metal remained to assure us that the light was still there, ready to flash out at a moment’s notice. To me, with my nerves worked up to a pitch of expectancy, there was something depressing and subduing in the sudden gloom, and in the cold dank air of the vault.
“They have but one retreat,” whispered Holmes. “That is back through the house into Saxe-Coburg Square. I hope that you have done what I asked you, Jones?”
“I have an inspector and two officers waiting at the front door.”
“Then we have stopped all the holes. And now we must be silent and wait.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: My friend was an enthusiastic musician, being himself not only a very capable performer but a composer of no ordinary merit. He was a frequent patron of the concert-rooms, and I have often accompanied him to them. On the present occasion, however, I found him in a mood of singular abstraction. He sat in the gallery, his long, thin fingers idly tapping the arm of his chair, his eyes fixed upon the stage, yet with a vacant, dreamy expression which told me that his thoughts were far away. I had often observed this dual nature in him—the capacity for intense concentration and the power to withdraw into a world of his own. At times he would lie for days in a condition bordering on lethargy, and then, with a sudden spring of energy, he would burst forth into action with a force that was almost startling. It was this very contrast that made him so fascinating to me, and it was this same contrast that I now saw reflected in his face. As the music swelled and the orchestra played with increasing fervor, I could not help but feel that some great and terrible event was looming in the distance, and that my friend was already in the thick of it. When the concert ended, we walked out into the cool night air. Holmes paused for a moment, his eyes scanning the street with a sharp, calculating gaze. 'I have business that will take me some hours,' he said at last. 'The matter at Coburg Square is serious, and I believe a major crime is about to be committed. I can stop it, but the timing—Saturday—complicates things.' He looked at me with a strange, almost mischievous glint in his eyes. 'I shall need your help tonight at ten o'clock. Bring your army revolver, for there may be danger.' With that, he turned and strode away, leaving me to ponder the meaning of his words. I could not fathom how he had deduced so much from so little, nor could I grasp the full significance of the expedition he had planned. But I knew that whatever it was, it would be extraordinary. At half-past nine that evening, I made my way to Baker Street. As I approached, I saw two hansom cabs waiting at the curb. Inside the flat, Holmes was deep in conversation with two men: one was Peter Jones, the stalwart agent of Scotland Yard, and the other was Mr. Merryweather, a man of middle age, with a grave and melancholy countenance. 'Our party is complete,' Holmes announced, as I entered. 'This is Mr. Merryweather.' Jones, who had been standing with his hands in his pockets, turned to me with a grin. 'Well, I'm glad to be hunting with you again, Mr. Holmes,' he said. 'You always know how to start a chase.' Mr. Merryweather, on the other hand, looked more somber. 'I wish I were at home playing my rubber,' he muttered. 'This is no way to spend a Saturday night.' 'The stakes are higher than a rubber, Mr. Merryweather,' Holmes replied. 'And the excitement, I daresay, will be greater.' He turned to Jones. 'This is John Clay, the notorious murderer, thief, and forger. You know his reputation.' Jones nodded. 'A young man, but one of the top tier. Elusive, too. He's got a bit of a pedigree, you know—descended from royalty, educated at Eton and Oxford.' 'I have had the pleasure of meeting him before,' Holmes said. 'I hope tonight I may have the pleasure of introducing you to him.' As the clock struck ten, Holmes gave a signal, and we all stepped into the cabs. During the drive, he was quiet, humming a tune under his breath. We arrived near Farrington Street, and Holmes, with a quick glance at his companions, led the way into a narrow passage and through a side door. We passed through two massive iron gates and down a winding stone staircase. Mr. Merryweather, who had been carrying a lantern, lit it and led us through a dark passage and into a large cellar filled with crates. Holmes examined the floor with a careful eye. 'This place is not vulnerable from above,' he said. Mr. Merryweather struck the floor with his stick. 'It's hollow,' he said. 'There's something beneath it.' Holmes turned sharply on him. 'You have jeopardized the whole affair,' he said. 'Sit down.' Mr. Merryweather complied, looking as if he had been struck. Holmes then took out his magnifying glass and examined the cracks between the stones. 'We have at least an hour before the pawnbroker is asleep,' he said. 'We are in the cellar of the City branch of a major bank, and Mr. Merryweather is the chairman.' He turned to me. 'The criminals have reason to be interested in this cellar.' Mr. Merryweather whispered that it was due to a large reserve of French gold—30,000 napoleons—that had been borrowed months ago and was still stored there, unpacked. Holmes nodded. 'The directors were right to be concerned.' He outlined the plan: we were to extinguish the lantern, take positions behind the crates, and close in when he gave the signal. I cocked my revolver, ready for action. Holmes covered his lantern, and we were plunged into absolute darkness. The cold air pressed in on me, and I felt a deep sense of tension. Holmes whispered that our only retreat was back through the house, and that Jones had stationed officers at the front door. 'All escape routes are covered,' he said. 'Now, silence.'

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
My friend was an enthusiastic musician, being himself not only a very capable performer but a composer of no ordinary merit. He had a fine ear and a quick hand, and his compositions, though not numerous, were marked by a certain originality and charm which won him many admirers. I remember once, when we were staying together at a country house, he played a new piece to me which he had written during the evening. It was a nocturne, full of the quiet beauty of the night, and as I listened I could almost see the moonlight on the lake and the whisper of the wind among the trees. It was a rare gift, and I was proud to call him my friend.

It was in the spring of the year 1894 that I found myself once more in the company of my friend, this time in the city of London. We had been invited to a small gathering at the home of a mutual acquaintance, a wealthy collector of rare books and curiosities. The evening was pleasant, and the company was agreeable, but it was not until the following morning that I became aware of the peculiar circumstances which were to lead us into a most singular and perplexing case.

It was about ten o’clock when I was summoned to my friend’s room by a most unusual sound. It was a low, monotonous hum, such as one might hear from a tuning fork held near the ear. I knocked at the door, but there was no answer. I turned the handle and found the room empty, the window open, and the curtains fluttering in the breeze. On the table lay a sheet of music, half-written, and a single violin string, which had been cut with a sharp instrument. I looked around, but there was no sign of my friend. The room was in perfect order, and yet something in the air of the place told me that something was amiss.

I went in search of the host of the gathering, a Mr. Jameson, and found him in the library. He was a tall, thin man, with a pale face and a nervous manner. He greeted me with a start, as if he had been expecting someone else.

"I am sorry to trouble you, Mr. Jameson," I said, "but I have just discovered that my friend, Mr. Holmes, is missing. His room is empty, and there are signs that he has been taken away."

Mr. Jameson’s face paled still further, and he looked at me with a mixture of alarm and curiosity.

"I am afraid I cannot help you, sir," he said. "I have not seen Mr. Holmes since last night. He was in excellent spirits, and I believe he retired early."

I was not satisfied with this answer, and I pressed him for more information. He finally admitted that he had heard a strange noise during the night, something like the sound of a violin being played in a high key, but he had paid no attention to it, thinking it to be the wind. I was convinced that this was no ordinary disappearance, and I resolved to investigate further.

The first thing I did was to examine the room more carefully. I found that the window had been opened from the inside, and the latch was still warm, as if it had been recently touched. The sheet of music on the table was a fragment of a nocturne, and the cut violin string was of a peculiar type, not commonly used by musicians. I took these items with me and set out to find my friend.

I began my search in the city, visiting the usual haunts of musicians and composers. I asked about the cut string, and it was not long before I found a luthier who recognized it. He told me that it was a rare type, used only by a few virtuoso players, and that it was made by a firm in the city of Paris. This was a curious piece of information, and I resolved to follow it up.

I next visited the music shops in London, hoping to find some trace of my friend. I was told that he had not been seen in any of them, and that no one had heard of his disappearance. I was beginning to feel that I was on the wrong track, when I received a message from a colleague of my friend, a Mr. Lestrade, who was a detective in the Metropolitan Police.

"I have heard of your friend’s disappearance," he said, "and I have a few questions to ask you. I believe he may have been involved in a case of some importance."

I was surprised to hear this, and I agreed to meet him at his office. He was a stout, red-faced man, with a manner that was both genial and professional. He listened to my account of the events and then asked me about the cut violin string.

"That is a curious thing," he said. "I have seen something like it before. It was in a case involving a French violinist who was murdered in his hotel room. The string was cut in the same manner, and the room was left in perfect order."

This was a most unexpected revelation, and I was filled with a sense of foreboding. I asked him if he had any idea who might be responsible for the disappearance of my friend.

"I have a theory," he said, "but it is only a theory. I believe that your friend may have been taken by a group of musicians who are involved in a secret society. They are known to be very secretive, and they have a reputation for taking those who they consider to be rivals or threats to their art."

This was a most extraordinary suggestion, and I was not sure whether to believe it or not. I decided to investigate further, and I set out to find more information about this secret society.

I began by visiting the music halls and concert halls of London, hoping to find some trace of the society. I asked about the French violinist and the cut string, and I was told that there was a group of musicians who were known to be very exclusive and very secretive. They were called the Society of the Silver String, and they were said to be composed of the most talented musicians in the city.

I was told that they met in a private club in the city, and that they were known to be very protective of their members. I decided to visit this club and see if I could find any information about my friend.

The club was a small, unassuming building in a quiet street. I was met at the door by a tall, thin man with a monocle and a very formal manner. He asked me my business, and I told him that I was looking for my friend, Mr. Holmes.

"I am sorry, sir," he said, "but we do not admit visitors without an invitation."

I was not to be deterred so easily, and I asked if I could speak to the manager of the club. He looked at me with a mixture of curiosity and suspicion, but he finally agreed to take me to the manager.

The manager was a portly man with a round face and a genial smile. He greeted me with a nod and asked me what I wanted.

"I am looking for my friend, Mr. Holmes," I said. "He has disappeared, and I believe he may have been taken by your society."

The manager’s smile faded, and he looked at me with a grave expression.

"I cannot confirm or deny that," he said. "But I can tell you that Mr. Holmes was a member of our society, and that he was last seen here a few days ago."

I was surprised to hear this, and I asked him if he knew where my friend might be.

"I am afraid I cannot say," he said. "But I can tell you that he was last seen in the company of a French violinist, and that he was very interested in the cut string."

This was a most curious piece of information, and I was determined to find out more. I asked the manager if I could see the French violinist, and he agreed to arrange a meeting.

The French violinist was a tall, dark man with a melancholic expression. He greeted me with a nod and asked me what I wanted.

"I am looking for my friend, Mr. Holmes," I said. "He has disappeared, and I believe he may have been taken by your society."

The violinist looked at me with a mixture of surprise and concern.

"I cannot confirm or deny that," he said. "But I can tell you that Mr. Holmes was very interested in the cut string, and that he was working on a new composition."

I was beginning to feel that I was getting somewhere, and I asked him if he knew where my friend might be.

"I am afraid I cannot say," he said. "But I can tell you that he was last seen in the company of a man who was not a member of the society."

This was a most unexpected revelation, and I was filled with a sense of urgency. I asked him if he could describe this man, and he agreed to do so.

"He was a tall, thin man with a pale face and a nervous manner," he said. "He was not a musician, but he was very interested in the cut string."

This was a most curious description, and I was convinced that this man was the key to my friend’s disappearance. I thanked the violinist and set out to find this man.

I began my search in the city, visiting the usual haunts of men of this description. I asked about the pale, thin man, and it was not long before I found a man who matched the description. He was a bookseller, and he was known to have a collection of rare books and curiosities. I visited his shop and asked him if he had seen my friend.

"I have not seen him," he said, "but I have heard of him. He was a most unusual man, and he was very interested in the cut string."

events.title: The Capture and Holmes's Explanation
detailed_summary: The wait feels interminable to Watson (later confirmed as an hour and a quarter).
Watson's senses are heightened; he can distinguish the breathing patterns of his companions.
He sees a spark of light on the floor, which expands into a line.
A section of the floor opens, and a white hand feels around.
The hand withdraws, then a large stone slab turns over, revealing a square hole and lantern light.
A young, clean-cut face (John Clay) peers out, then climbs out of the hole.
Clay helps his smaller companion (Archie, the red-headed assistant) out.
Clay whispers "It's all clear" and asks for tools.
Holmes springs out and grabs Clay.
Archie dives back into the hole; Jones grabs his coat-tails but he escapes.
Clay draws a revolver, but Holmes strikes his wrist with a crop, disarming him.
Holmes tells Clay he has no chance.
Clay calmly accepts capture but hopes his accomplice is safe.
Holmes informs him three men are waiting at the door.
Clay acknowledges Holmes's thoroughness and compliments him.
Holmes compliments Clay's novel red-headed scheme.
Jones handcuffs Clay, who protests being touched by 'filthy hands' and demands to be addressed respectfully due to his 'royal blood'.
Jones mockingly agrees and leads Clay away.
Mr. Merryweather profusely thanks Holmes for foiling a major bank robbery.
Holmes states he had personal scores to settle with Clay and expects the bank to cover his expenses, but feels repaid by the unique experience and Wilson's narrative.
Later, at Baker Street, Holmes explains his deductions to Watson.
The Red-Headed League's purpose was clearly to get Wilson out of his shop for hours daily.
The method, suggested by the accomplice's hair color, was elaborate but effective; the salary was bait.
Spaulding's willingness to work for half wages signaled a strong hidden motive.
Holmes ruled out intrigue (no women) and robbery at the small pawnshop.
The motive had to be outside the house; Spaulding's cellar activity (photography) was the key clue.
Inquiries revealed the assistant was a known dangerous criminal (John Clay).
The cellar activity, taking hours daily for months, suggested tunneling.
Visiting the square, Holmes confirmed the cellar didn't extend forward by thumping the pavement.
Seeing the assistant (Clay) confirmed his identity; the worn knees of his trousers evidenced digging.
Observing the adjacent bank provided the objective: the tunnel led to the bank vault.
Holmes then contacted Scotland Yard and the bank chairman.
The dissolution of the League signaled the tunnel's completion.
They needed to act quickly before discovery or bullion removal.
Saturday was chosen for the attempt to allow two days for escape.
Watson expresses admiration for Holmes's reasoning.
Holmes yawns, stating the case saved him from boredom, which is already returning.
He sees his work as an escape from mundane existence.
When Watson calls him a benefactor, Holmes shrugs, quoting Flaubert: "Man is nothing—work is everything."

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: What a time it seemed!
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “‘L’homme c’est rien—l’œuvre c’est tout,’ as Gustave Flaubert wrote to George Sand.”

events.text_segment:
What a time it seemed! From comparing notes afterwards it was but an hour and a quarter, yet it appeared to me that the night must have almost gone, and the dawn be breaking above us. My limbs were weary and stiff, for I feared to change my position; yet my nerves were worked up to the highest pitch of tension, and my hearing was so acute that I could not only hear the gentle breathing of my companions, but I could distinguish the deeper, heavier in-breath of the bulky Jones from the thin, sighing note of the bank director. From my position I could look over the case in the direction of the floor. Suddenly my eyes caught the glint of a light.
At first it was but a lurid spark upon the stone pavement. Then it lengthened out until it became a yellow line, and then, without any warning or sound, a gash seemed to open and a hand appeared, a white, almost womanly hand, which felt about in the centre of the little area of light. For a minute or more the hand, with its writhing fingers, protruded out of the floor. Then it was withdrawn as suddenly as it appeared, and all was dark again save the single lurid spark which marked a chink between the stones.
Its disappearance, however, was but momentary. With a rending, tearing sound, one of the broad, white stones turned over upon its side and left a square, gaping hole, through which streamed the light of a lantern. Over the edge there peeped a clean-cut, boyish face, which looked keenly about it, and then, with a hand on either side of the aperture, drew itself shoulder-high and waist-high, until one knee rested upon the edge. In another instant he stood at the side of the hole and was hauling after him a companion, lithe and small like himself, with a pale face and a shock of very red hair.
“It’s all clear,” he whispered. “Have you the chisel and the bags? Great Scott! Jump, Archie, jump, and I’ll swing for it!”
Sherlock Holmes had sprung out and seized the intruder by the collar. The other dived down the hole, and I heard the sound of rending cloth as Jones clutched at his skirts. The light flashed upon the barrel of a revolver, but Holmes’ hunting crop came down on the man’s wrist, and the pistol clinked upon the stone floor.
“It’s no use, John Clay,” said Holmes blandly. “You have no chance at all.”
“So I see,” the other answered with the utmost coolness. “I fancy that my pal is all right, though I see you have got his coat-tails.”
“There are three men waiting for him at the door,” said Holmes.
“Oh, indeed! You seem to have done the thing very completely. I must compliment you.”
“And I you,” Holmes answered. “Your red-headed idea was very new and effective.”
“You’ll see your pal again presently,” said Jones. “He’s quicker at climbing down holes than I am. Just hold out while I fix the derbies.”
“I beg that you will not touch me with your filthy hands,” remarked our prisoner as the handcuffs clattered upon his wrists. “You may not be aware that I have royal blood in my veins. Have the goodness, also, when you address me always to say ‘sir’ and ‘please.’”
“All right,” said Jones with a stare and a snigger. “Well, would you please, sir, march upstairs, where we can get a cab to carry your Highness to the police-station?”
“That is better,” said John Clay serenely. He made a sweeping bow to the three of us and walked quietly off in the custody of the detective.
“Really, Mr. Holmes,” said Mr. Merryweather as we followed them from the cellar, “I do not know how the bank can thank you or repay you. There is no doubt that you have detected and defeated in the most complete manner one of the most determined attempts at bank robbery that have ever come within my experience.”
“I have had one or two little scores of my own to settle with Mr. John Clay,” said Holmes. “I have been at some small expense over this matter, which I shall expect the bank to refund, but beyond that I am amply repaid by having had an experience which is in many ways unique, and by hearing the very remarkable narrative of the Red-headed League.”
“You see, Watson,” he explained in the early hours of the morning as we sat over a glass of whisky and soda in Baker Street, “it was perfectly obvious from the first that the only possible object of this rather fantastic business of the advertisement of the League, and the copying of the Encyclopædia, must be to get this not over-bright pawnbroker out of the way for a number of hours every day. It was a curious way of managing it, but, really, it would be difficult to suggest a better. The method was no doubt suggested to Clay’s ingenious mind by the colour of his accomplice’s hair. The £ 4 a week was a lure which must draw him, and what was it to them, who were playing for thousands? They put in the advertisement, one rogue has the temporary office, the other rogue incites the man to apply for it, and together they manage to secure his absence every morning in the week. From the time that I heard of the assistant having come for half wages, it was obvious to me that he had some strong motive for securing the situation.”
“But how could you guess what the motive was?”
“Had there been women in the house, I should have suspected a mere vulgar intrigue. That, however, was out of the question. The man’s business was a small one, and there was nothing in his house which could account for such elaborate preparations, and such an expenditure as they were at. It must, then, be something out of the house. What could it be? I thought of the assistant’s fondness for photography, and his trick of vanishing into the cellar. The cellar! There was the end of this tangled clue. Then I made inquiries as to this mysterious assistant and found that I had to deal with one of the coolest and most daring criminals in London. He was doing something in the cellar—something which took many hours a day for months on end. What could it be, once more? I could think of nothing save that he was running a tunnel to some other building.
“So far I had got when we went to visit the scene of action. I surprised you by beating upon the pavement with my stick. I was ascertaining whether the cellar stretched out in front or behind. It was not in front. Then I rang the bell, and, as I hoped, the assistant answered it. We have had some skirmishes, but we had never set eyes upon each other before. I hardly looked at his face. His knees were what I wished to see. You must yourself have remarked how worn, wrinkled, and stained they were. They spoke of those hours of burrowing. The only remaining point was what they were burrowing for. I walked round the corner, saw the City and Suburban Bank abutted on our friend’s premises, and felt that I had solved my problem. When you drove home after the concert I called upon Scotland Yard and upon the chairman of the bank directors, with the result that you have seen.”
“And how could you tell that they would make their attempt to-night?” I asked.
“Well, when they closed their League offices that was a sign that they cared no longer about Mr. Jabez Wilson’s presence—in other words, that they had completed their tunnel. But it was essential that they should use it soon, as it might be discovered, or the bullion might be removed. Saturday would suit them better than any other day, as it would give them two days for their escape. For all these reasons I expected them to come to-night.”
“You reasoned it out beautifully,” I exclaimed in unfeigned admiration. “It is so long a chain, and yet every link rings true.”
“It saved me from ennui,” he answered, yawning. “Alas! I already feel it closing in upon me. My life is spent in one long effort to escape from the commonplaces of existence. These little problems help me to do so.”
“And you are a benefactor of the race,” said I.
He shrugged his shoulders. “Well, perhaps, after all, it is of some little use,” he remarked. “‘L’homme c’est rien—l’œuvre c’est tout,’ as Gustave Flaubert wrote to George Sand.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: What a time it seemed! To me, at any rate, it was interminable. I had never realized before how full of sound and substance the world is. I heard the creak of the floorboards, the rustle of the curtains, the faint breathing of my companions. I could even distinguish the different rhythms of their respiration. Holmes, with his head in his hands, seemed to be in a state of profound meditation. Dr. Watson, who sat near the fire, was breathing slowly and regularly, while Peter Jones, the detective, snored softly in his chair. Mr. Merryweather, the bank official, was restless and kept shifting his position. I was on the edge of my seat, my nerves taut as a bowstring. Suddenly, a faint glimmer of light caught my eye. It was a spark, no larger than a pin's head, flickering on the floor. I blinked, and it had grown into a line of light, running diagonally across the room. Then, with a faint creak, a section of the floor gave way. A white hand, pale and delicate, emerged from the darkness and felt its way along the edge of the opening. It withdrew, and then a great stone slab, which had been lying flat, turned slowly upon its hinges. A square hole was revealed, and from it came the glow of a lantern. A young, clean-cut face peered out, with a look of alert intelligence in its eyes. He was dressed in a neat suit, and his hair was dark and well-kept. He was John Clay, the infamous criminal. He looked around, then turned back into the hole and helped out a smaller figure, who was his assistant, Archie, the red-headed man. Clay whispered, 'It's all clear,' and reached for the tools that had been left for him. But before he could take them, Holmes sprang from his chair and seized him by the collar. Archie, startled, turned and tried to dive back into the hole, but Peter Jones was already on him, grabbing his coat-tails. Archie wriggled free and vanished into the darkness. Clay, however, was not so fortunate. He drew a revolver, but Holmes struck his wrist with a crop, sending the weapon clattering to the floor. 'You have no chance,' said Holmes, his voice calm and cold. Clay, though taken by surprise, did not show fear. 'I accept my fate,' he said, 'but I hope my friend is safe.' 'Three men are waiting at the door,' said Holmes. 'You have been very thorough,' Clay admitted. 'You have a mind like a steel trap.' 'And you have a scheme as clever as it is dangerous,' Holmes replied. Jones, who had been watching the exchange, now stepped forward and fastened the handcuffs on Clay. 'You may call me Mr. Jones,' he said, 'but I must warn you, I have no patience for your royal blood nonsense.' Clay, who had been boasting of his noble lineage, merely shrugged. 'Very well, Mr. Jones,' he said, and allowed himself to be led away. Mr. Merryweather, who had been watching the whole thing in stunned silence, now came forward and thanked Holmes profusely. 'You have saved the bank from a disaster,' he said. 'I am merely doing my duty,' Holmes replied. 'I had a personal score to settle with Mr. Clay, but I am glad to have been of service.' Later, at Baker Street, Holmes explained the case to Watson. 'The Red-Headed League was a clever ruse,' he said. 'Its purpose was to get Wilson out of his shop for hours each day. The method, suggested by the red hair of the assistant, was elaborate but effective. The salary was the bait. Spaulding's willingness to work for half wages was the first clue. I ruled out intrigue—there were no women involved—and robbery at the pawnshop itself. The motive had to be elsewhere. Spaulding's activity in the cellar, which he described as photography, was the key. Inquiries revealed that the assistant was a known criminal, John Clay. The fact that he spent hours in the cellar for months suggested something more than mere photography. I visited the square and confirmed that the cellar did not extend forward by thumping the pavement. Seeing the assistant, I recognized him as Clay. The worn knees of his trousers showed that he had been digging. Observing the adjacent bank, I saw the objective: the tunnel led to the vault. I then contacted Scotland Yard and the bank chairman. The dissolution of the League signaled the tunnel's completion. We needed to act quickly, before the bullion was removed. Saturday was chosen for the attempt, allowing two days for escape. Watson, who had been listening with rapt attention, now expressed his admiration. 'You have a mind like a machine,' he said. 'I am merely a man,' Holmes replied, yawning. 'This case has saved me from the boredom of inaction. It is already returning.' He looked out of the window, his eyes distant. 'I see my work as an escape from the mundane. When you call me a benefactor, I must quote Flaubert: 'Man is nothing—work is everything.'

events.title: Holmes and Watson Debate Reality vs. Fiction
detailed_summary: Sitting by the fire, Sherlock Holmes posits that real life is far stranger than any fictional narrative man could invent.
He suggests that observing the hidden complexities, coincidences, and long-term consequences unfolding in London homes would make conventional fiction seem dull.
Dr. Watson expresses skepticism, arguing that newspaper reports and police records, while realistic, are often bald and unartistic.
Holmes counters that police reports lack the necessary selection and discretion, focusing on superficialities rather than the vital details an observer needs.
He asserts that the truly commonplace is often the most unnatural.
Watson, unconvinced, picks up a newspaper, pointing to a typical 'husband's cruelty' story as an example of predictable, crude reality.
Holmes refutes Watson's example, revealing he worked on the specific case mentioned (the Dundas separation).
He clarifies that the husband was a teetotaler with no mistress; the cruelty involved habitually throwing his false teeth at his wife after meals—an act unlikely to be invented.
Holmes playfully claims victory in their argument, offering Watson snuff.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “My dear fellow,” said Sherlock Holmes as we sat on either side of the fire in his lodgings at Baker Street, “life is infinitely stranger than anything which the mind of man could invent.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Take a pinch of snuff, Doctor, and acknowledge that I have scored over you in your example.”

events.text_segment:
“My dear fellow,” said Sherlock Holmes as we sat on either side of the fire in his lodgings at Baker Street, “life is infinitely stranger than anything which the mind of man could invent. We would not dare to conceive the things which are really mere commonplaces of existence. If we could fly out of that window hand in hand, hover over this great city, gently remove the roofs, and peep in at the queer things which are going on, the strange coincidences, the plannings, the cross-purposes, the wonderful chains of events, working through generations, and leading to the most outré results, it would make all fiction with its conventionalities and foreseen conclusions most stale and unprofitable.”
“And yet I am not convinced of it,” I answered. “The cases which come to light in the papers are, as a rule, bald enough, and vulgar enough. We have in our police reports realism pushed to its extreme limits, and yet the result is, it must be confessed, neither fascinating nor artistic.”
“A certain selection and discretion must be used in producing a realistic effect,” remarked Holmes. “This is wanting in the police report, where more stress is laid, perhaps, upon the platitudes of the magistrate than upon the details, which to an observer contain the vital essence of the whole matter. Depend upon it, there is nothing so unnatural as the commonplace.”
I smiled and shook my head. “I can quite understand your thinking so,” I said. “Of course, in your position of unofficial adviser and helper to everybody who is absolutely puzzled, throughout three continents, you are brought in contact with all that is strange and bizarre. But here”—I picked up the morning paper from the ground—“let us put it to a practical test. Here is the first heading upon which I come. ‘A husband’s cruelty to his wife.’ There is half a column of print, but I know without reading it that it is all perfectly familiar to me. There is, of course, the other woman, the drink, the push, the blow, the bruise, the sympathetic sister or landlady. The crudest of writers could invent nothing more crude.”
“Indeed, your example is an unfortunate one for your argument,” said Holmes, taking the paper and glancing his eye down it. “This is the Dundas separation case, and, as it happens, I was engaged in clearing up some small points in connection with it. The husband was a teetotaler, there was no other woman, and the conduct complained of was that he had drifted into the habit of winding up every meal by taking out his false teeth and hurling them at his wife, which, you will allow, is not an action likely to occur to the imagination of the average story-teller. Take a pinch of snuff, Doctor, and acknowledge that I have scored over you in your example.”

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
My dear fellow," said Sherlock Holmes as we sat on either side of the fire in his lodgings at Baker Street, "life is infinitely stranger than anything which the mind of man could invent. I wish I could force you to accept my views. On sin, on crime, on human degradation, the newspapers are saturated with details which would make even the imagination of the most vivid novelist recoil. But it is not the terrible things that are done, it is the terrible things that are done and left unexplained, the things that are done and then forgotten, that are the most interesting of all."

"I am not sure that I follow you," I remarked.

"You do not," he said, with a smile. "You see, the police records are very bald and unartistic. They give you the skeleton of the thing, but not the flesh and blood. They tell you that a man was found dead in a field, but they do not tell you how he got there, or why, or by whom. They do not tell you the little points, the tiny details which are the very soul of the whole matter."

"But surely," I said, "the police have to be practical. They cannot be expected to record every detail."

"No, they cannot," he said, "but I can. And I do."

"But what of the ordinary cases? The ones that are reported in the newspapers?"

"Ah!" he said, "there you have it. Take, for instance, the case of the Dundas separation. You remember it?"

"I remember the name," I said.

"It was a case of the most extraordinary cruelty. The husband was a teetotaler, and he had no mistress. His cruelty was of a very peculiar kind. He used to throw his false teeth at his wife after dinner."

"Good heavens!"

"Yes, that was the nature of his cruelty. He would sit at the table, and after dinner, he would take his false teeth and throw them at her."

"But why?"

"That is the question, is it not? Why? That is the whole problem."

He leaned back in his chair and took a pinch of snuff. "You see, my dear Watson, I have won my point. The real life is far stranger than any fiction."

1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion only includes the opening address and omits the entire dialogue and narrative that follows. This results in the absence of all major sections, including the philosophical discussion, the exchange of opinions, the practical test with the newspaper, and the specific case example.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The initial setting and context are not established beyond the first words.
- The philosophical reflection on the strangeness of real life compared to fiction is missing.
- The back-and-forth conversation between the two characters, including their differing perspectives, is absent.
- The practical demonstration involving the newspaper and the specific case discussed are not present.
- The humorous and unexpected details about the case are not included.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- There are no inaccurate elements present, as the completion does not attempt to recreate any of the content beyond the initial address. However, the lack of content means that the sequence of events and the logical flow of the original passage are entirely missing.

events.title: Souvenirs, Past Cases, and the Nature of Investigations
detailed_summary: Watson admires Holmes's ornate gold snuffbox with an amethyst.
Holmes explains it's a souvenir from the King of Bohemia for his help regarding Irene Adler.
Watson inquires about a brilliant ring on Holmes's finger.
Holmes reveals it's from the Dutch royal family for a confidential matter.
Watson asks if Holmes has any interesting cases currently.
Holmes mentions having ten or twelve cases, but deems them important rather than interesting.
He elaborates on his theory that seemingly unimportant matters often provide the best field for observation and deduction, as larger crimes usually have more obvious motives.
He notes an exception: one intricate case referred from Marseilles.
Holmes anticipates a potential new client arriving shortly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He held out his snuffbox of old gold, with a great amethyst in the centre of the lid.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It is possible, however, that I may have something better before very many minutes are over, for this is one of my clients, or I am much mistaken.”

events.text_segment:
He held out his snuffbox of old gold, with a great amethyst in the centre of the lid. Its splendour was in such contrast to his homely ways and simple life that I could not help commenting upon it.
“Ah,” said he, “I forgot that I had not seen you for some weeks. It is a little souvenir from the King of Bohemia in return for my assistance in the case of the Irene Adler papers.”
“And the ring?” I asked, glancing at a remarkable brilliant which sparkled upon his finger.
“It was from the reigning family of Holland, though the matter in which I served them was of such delicacy that I cannot confide it even to you, who have been good enough to chronicle one or two of my little problems.”
“And have you any on hand just now?” I asked with interest.
“Some ten or twelve, but none which present any feature of interest. They are important, you understand, without being interesting. Indeed, I have found that it is usually in unimportant matters that there is a field for the observation, and for the quick analysis of cause and effect which gives the charm to an investigation. The larger crimes are apt to be the simpler, for the bigger the crime the more obvious, as a rule, is the motive. In these cases, save for one rather intricate matter which has been referred to me from Marseilles, there is nothing which presents any features of interest. It is possible, however, that I may have something better before very many minutes are over, for this is one of my clients, or I am much mistaken.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: He held out his snuffbox of old gold, with a great amethyst in the centre of the lid. "It is a trifle," said he, "but it is a trifle which has a history. It was a present from the King of Bohemia, in recognition of my services in the matter of the Irene Adler business." I had heard of Irene Adler, the celebrated opera singer, and I had imagined that she was a woman of some importance in the world of music. "She is more than that," said Holmes. "She is a woman who has played a part in the affairs of Europe. But I have no time to dwell upon her now. You asked me if I had any interesting cases at present. I have ten or twelve, but they are not of the kind that would interest you. They are all of them of a professional nature, and of a very important character. The most interesting of them is a case which has been referred to me from Marseilles. It is a case of identity, and I think that it may prove to be one of the most remarkable that I have ever handled. But I anticipate. The client will be here shortly, and we shall hear the details from his own lips."
