"She is a woman who has played a part in the affairs of Europe. But I have no time to dwell upon her now. You asked me if I had any interesting cases at present. I have ten or twelve, but they are not of the kind that would interest you. They are all of them of a professional nature, and of a very important character. The most interesting of them is a case which has been referred to me from Marseilles. It is a case of identity, and I think that it may prove to be one of the most remarkable that I have ever handled. But I anticipate. The client will be here shortly, and we shall hear the details from his own lips."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: He held out his snuffbox of old gold, with a great amethyst in the centre of the lid. "I have a small quantity of the finest Spanish snuff in the world," said he. "It is a gift from a friend in Seville, and I should be delighted to share it with you, Mr. Holmes. You will find it most invigorating." I took the box with a polite nod, though I must confess that I had little interest in the contents. My attention was drawn more to the peculiar expression on the gentleman's face—half amusement, half calculation—as he watched me. "You are a man of observation, I believe," he continued, "and perhaps you have already noted the peculiarities of this box. The gold is not merely ornamental, but of considerable value. The amethyst, too, is a gem of some rarity. I have no doubt that you have already deduced the reason for my bringing it to your attention." I looked up sharply. "Indeed, sir, I have noted the box, and I have formed a few tentative conclusions regarding its significance. However, I should be most obliged if you would enlighten me as to the nature of the matter in which you require my assistance." He smiled, a slow, deliberate smile. "You are as sharp as I have heard, Mr. Holmes. Very well, let us proceed. There is a mystery that has long perplexed me, and I believe that your talents may be of considerable use in its resolution. But first, I should like to see if you can tell me the history of this snuffbox." I examined it carefully, turning it over in my hands. "This is no ordinary snuffbox," I said. "It is a relic of some importance, and I suspect that it has passed through many hands before coming into yours. But I shall say no more until you have explained the nature of your inquiry."

events.title: Observation and Arrival of Miss Sutherland
detailed_summary: Holmes stands and observes a woman pacing nervously on the street below.
Watson looks over his shoulder and sees a large woman, elaborately dressed with a fur boa and feathered hat, peering anxiously at their windows.
Her body language shows hesitation and fidgeting.
Suddenly, she rushes across the road, and they hear the bell clang sharply.
Holmes interprets her
based on past experience.
He deduces she seeks advice on a delicate love matter, differentiating her hesitation from the behavior of a woman seeking retribution for a serious wrong (who would likely break the bell wire).
He concludes she is more perplexed or grieved than angry.
A tap sounds, and the pageboy announces Miss Mary Sutherland.
The lady enters, appearing large and imposing behind the small boy.
Holmes greets her courteously, shows her to a chair, and observes her closely.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He had risen from his chair and was standing between the parted blinds gazing down into the dull neutral-tinted London street.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Do you not find,” he said, “that with your short sight it is a little trying to do so much typewriting?”

events.text_segment:
He had risen from his chair and was standing between the parted blinds gazing down into the dull neutral-tinted London street. Looking over his shoulder, I saw that on the pavement opposite there stood a large woman with a heavy fur boa round her neck, and a large curling red feather in a broad-brimmed hat which was tilted in a coquettish Duchess of Devonshire fashion over her ear. From under this great panoply she peeped up in a nervous, hesitating fashion at our windows, while her body oscillated backward and forward, and her fingers fidgeted with her glove buttons. Suddenly, with a plunge, as of the swimmer who leaves the bank, she hurried across the road, and we heard the sharp clang of the bell.
“I have seen those symptoms before,” said Holmes, throwing his cigarette into the fire. “Oscillation upon the pavement always means an affaire de cœur. She would like advice, but is not sure that the matter is not too delicate for communication. And yet even here we may discriminate. When a woman has been seriously wronged by a man she no longer oscillates, and the usual symptom is a broken bell wire. Here we may take it that there is a love matter, but that the maiden is not so much angry as perplexed, or grieved. But here she comes in person to resolve our doubts.”
As he spoke there was a tap at the door, and the boy in buttons entered to announce Miss Mary Sutherland, while the lady herself loomed behind his small black figure like a full-sailed merchant-man behind a tiny pilot boat. Sherlock Holmes welcomed her with the easy courtesy for which he was remarkable, and, having closed the door and bowed her into an armchair, he looked her over in the minute and yet abstracted fashion which was peculiar to him.
“Do you not find,” he said, “that with your short sight it is a little trying to do so much typewriting?”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: He had risen from his chair and was standing between the parted blinds gazing down into the dull neutral-tinted London street. I looked up from my book and saw the figure of a very large woman, elaborately dressed, with a fur boa and a hat decorated with plumes, who was walking slowly up and down the opposite side. Her manner was one of the utmost hesitation and indecision, and she kept pausing and looking up at our windows as though she were in doubt whether to come on or to go back. Suddenly she quickened her pace, and with a sharp clang the bell below proclaimed her arrival. "She is a woman who wants advice, not vengeance," said Holmes, with a smile. "If she had come to denounce a wrong, she would have broken the wire instead of ringing it." He leaned forward and looked out again. "She is more perplexed than angry. She is a woman who has a heavy heart, not a vengeful one." A tap came at the door, and the pageboy announced Miss Mary Sutherland. The lady entered, and I confess that I was surprised at her appearance. She was a very large and imposing woman, and she looked all the larger as she followed the small boy in buttons who had ushered her in. Holmes rose and greeted her with his usual urbanity, and then, with a slight bow, he motioned her to a chair, his keen eyes never leaving her face as she sat down.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He had risen from his chair and was standing between the parted blinds gazing down into the dull neutral-tinted London street. The fog was rolling in from the river, curling its damp tendrils around the lamp-posts and muffling the sound of the distant hansom cabs. Sherlock Holmes stood motionless, his long, thin fingers resting lightly on the windowsill, his keen eyes fixed on some point in the distance. I had seen him in many moods, but never before had I seen him so still, so absorbed. There was a strange, almost solemn expression on his face, as though he were listening not to the sounds of the street, but to something far more intangible—perhaps the whisper of a thought, or the echo of a memory.

I rose from my chair and approached him, my footsteps muffled by the thick carpet. He did not turn, but I could see the faintest twitch of his lips, as if he were suppressing a smile. 'You are watching for something, Holmes,' I said quietly. 'Or perhaps someone.'

He turned then, his eyes gleaming with a sudden light. 'You are quick, Watson,' he said, his voice low and thoughtful. 'Yes, I am watching for someone. A man who will be here within the hour. He is not a man of great importance, but he carries a message that may prove most interesting.'

'And what makes you so certain of this?' I asked, intrigued.

'Because,' he said, turning back to the window, 'I have seen the same man twice this week, always at the same hour, always in the same place. He is not a man of habit, but he is a man of purpose. And purpose, my dear Watson, is a most revealing thing.'

I stood beside him, watching the fog roll in, the city hushed beneath its grey shroud. The mystery was unfolding, and I could feel the familiar thrill of anticipation rising in my chest. Something was about to happen—something that would test not only Holmes's keen mind, but my own as well.

events.title: Miss Sutherland's Predicament and Initial Interview
detailed_summary: Miss Sutherland acknowledges the initial difficulty of typewriting with short sight but confirms she now types by touch.
Realizing Holmes deduced this without prior knowledge, she reacts with shock and asks how he knew.
Holmes dismisses her question, stating it's his business to observe overlooked details.
Miss Sutherland explains she was referred by Mrs. Etherege, whose husband Holmes had found.
She pleads for Holmes's help regarding a Mr. Hosmer Angel, offering her modest income as payment.
Holmes asks why she left home so abruptly to consult him.
Startled again, she confirms she left angrily due to her stepfather's (Mr. Windibank) dismissive attitude and refusal to involve Holmes or the police.
Holmes clarifies that Windibank is her stepfather, noting the different name.
She confirms, adding he is only five years older than her.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I did at first,” she answered, “but now I know where the letters are without looking.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I call him father, though it sounds funny, too, for he is only five years and two months older than myself.”

events.text_segment:
“I did at first,” she answered, “but now I know where the letters are without looking.” Then, suddenly realising the full purport of his words, she gave a violent start and looked up, with fear and astonishment upon her broad, good-humoured face. “You’ve heard about me, Mr. Holmes,” she cried, “else how could you know all that?”
“Never mind,” said Holmes, laughing; “it is my business to know things. Perhaps I have trained myself to see what others overlook. If not, why should you come to consult me?”
“I came to you, sir, because I heard of you from Mrs. Etherege, whose husband you found so easy when the police and everyone had given him up for dead. Oh, Mr. Holmes, I wish you would do as much for me. I’m not rich, but still I have a hundred a year in my own right, besides the little that I make by the machine, and I would give it all to know what has become of Mr. Hosmer Angel.”
“Why did you come away to consult me in such a hurry?” asked Sherlock Holmes, with his finger-tips together and his eyes to the ceiling.
Again a startled look came over the somewhat vacuous face of Miss Mary Sutherland. “Yes, I did bang out of the house,” she said, “for it made me angry to see the easy way in which Mr. Windibank—that is, my father—took it all. He would not go to the police, and he would not go to you, and so at last, as he would do nothing and kept on saying that there was no harm done, it made me mad, and I just on with my things and came right away to you.”
“Your father,” said Holmes, “your stepfather, surely, since the name is different.”
“Yes, my stepfather. I call him father, though it sounds funny, too, for he is only five years and two months older than myself.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“I did at first,” she answered, “but now I know where the letters are without looking.”

“Indeed!” said Holmes. “That is a very useful accomplishment for a young lady in your profession.”

She smiled faintly. “I have had to make the best of it, you see. I have been obliged to do a good deal of typewriting.”

“Ah, I see. You have short sight, then?”

She gave a startled look at him. “How did you know?”

“Because you have a pair of pince-nez in your pocket, and you have been using them. You have also a very slight squint when you are not looking at anything in particular. These are all signs of defective vision.”

She looked at him with a mingled expression of admiration and alarm. “You are very clever, Mr. Holmes. But I had no idea—”

“Ah, but it is my business to notice these things. You seem surprised that I should have observed them.”

“I was indeed. I had not thought of them myself.”

“I am glad to hear it. It is always a comfort to know that one is not entirely out of one’s depth.”

She hesitated a moment, then said: “I was sent to you by Mrs. Etherege. Her husband was missing, and you found him for her. She said you were the only man who could help me.”

“Indeed! And who is it that you wish me to find for you?”

She hesitated again, and then, with a sudden rush of words, she said: “It is Mr. Hosmer Angel. I have heard nothing of him for weeks, and I am afraid something has happened to him.”

“Why should you suppose that?”

“Because he promised to marry me, and he has not come back.”

“Why did you not go to the police?”

She looked at him with a startled expression. “I could not. My stepfather would never have allowed it. He is a very proud man, and he would not have listened to me.”

“Your stepfather?”

“Yes. Mr. Windibank.”

“Ah! I see. And is he your guardian?”

“No, he is not. But he has always treated me as if I were a child. He would never have believed me. He would have said I was fanciful and romantic.”

“Is he a man of means?”

“He is very rich. He is a manufacturer of some sort. I have a small income of my own, but it is nothing compared to his.”

“Then why did you come to me so suddenly? Why not wait until you could consult him?”

She looked at him with a startled expression. “Because I was angry. I was so angry that I could not bear to stay in the house any longer. I could not bear to see his sneering face. I could not bear to hear him say that I was a fool for thinking of Mr. Hosmer Angel.”

“Ah! I see. And you have come to me in a state of some excitement. You are not quite yourself.”

She looked at him with a startled expression. “How did you know?”

“Because you have not taken the precaution of removing your hat and gloves. You have come in with the air of a woman who has made a sudden and impulsive decision. You have also a slight tremor in your hands, which is not due to cold.”

She looked at him with a mingled expression of admiration and alarm. “You are very clever, Mr. Holmes. But I had no idea—”

“Ah, but it is my business to notice these things. You seem surprised that I should have observed them.”

events.title: Family Background and Financial Arrangements
detailed_summary: Miss Sutherland confirms her mother is alive and well.
She expresses disapproval of her mother's remarriage soon after her father's death to Mr. Windibank, a man nearly fifteen years younger.
She explains her father was a plumber who left a good business, initially run by her mother and the foreman, Mr. Hardy.
Mr. Windibank, a wine traveller, persuaded her mother to sell the business for £4700, less than her father would have received.
Watson expects Holmes to be impatient, but Holmes listens intently.
Holmes inquires about her personal income.
She clarifies it's separate, inherited from her Uncle Ned in Auckland—£2500 in New Zealand stock yielding £100 per year (4.5% interest).
She states she can only access the interest.
Holmes expresses interest, suggesting she must travel and indulge herself with such an income combined with her earnings.
Miss Sutherland explains that while living at home, she allows her mother and stepfather use of her interest money to avoid being a burden.
She states Mr. Windibank collects the interest quarterly and gives it to her mother.
She manages adequately on her typewriting earnings (two pence per sheet, often 15-20 sheets daily).
Holmes acknowledges her clear explanation and introduces Dr. Watson, assuring her she can speak freely before him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “And your mother is alive?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Kindly tell us now all about your connection with Mr. Hosmer Angel.”

events.text_segment:
“And your mother is alive?”
“Oh, yes, mother is alive and well. I wasn’t best pleased, Mr. Holmes, when she married again so soon after father’s death, and a man who was nearly fifteen years younger than herself. Father was a plumber in the Tottenham Court Road, and he left a tidy business behind him, which mother carried on with Mr. Hardy, the foreman; but when Mr. Windibank came he made her sell the business, for he was very superior, being a traveller in wines. They got £ 4700 for the goodwill and interest, which wasn’t near as much as father could have got if he had been alive.”
I had expected to see Sherlock Holmes impatient under this rambling and inconsequential narrative, but, on the contrary, he had listened with the greatest concentration of attention.
“Your own little income,” he asked, “does it come out of the business?”
“Oh, no, sir. It is quite separate and was left me by my uncle Ned in Auckland. It is in New Zealand stock, paying 4½ per cent. Two thousand five hundred pounds was the amount, but I can only touch the interest.”
“You interest me extremely,” said Holmes. “And since you draw so large a sum as a hundred a year, with what you earn into the bargain, you no doubt travel a little and indulge yourself in every way. I believe that a single lady can get on very nicely upon an income of about £ 60.”
“I could do with much less than that, Mr. Holmes, but you understand that as long as I live at home I don’t wish to be a burden to them, and so they have the use of the money just while I am staying with them. Of course, that is only just for the time. Mr. Windibank draws my interest every quarter and pays it over to mother, and I find that I can do pretty well with what I earn at typewriting. It brings me twopence a sheet, and I can often do from fifteen to twenty sheets in a day.”
“You have made your position very clear to me,” said Holmes. “This is my friend, Dr. Watson, before whom you can speak as freely as before myself. Kindly tell us now all about your connection with Mr. Hosmer Angel.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
And your mother is alive?"

"Yes, sir, and in very good health."

"And where does she reside?"

"At 23, Lower Wimpole Street."

"I am glad to hear it. I understand that you have some family matters upon which you desire my advice."

"Yes, Mr. Holmes. I have come to you because I am in a very difficult position."

"I shall do my best to help you."

Miss Sutherland hesitated a moment, then said: "My mother is a very kind and affectionate woman, but she has made a second marriage, and I am afraid that I cannot regard my stepfather with any feelings of affection."

"Indeed?"

"Yes, sir. My father was a plumber, and he left a very good business. After his death, my mother and Mr. Hardy, the foreman, managed it. But Mr. Windibank, a wine traveller, came into our lives, and he persuaded my mother to sell the business for £4700, which was less than my father would have received."

"I see. And you disapprove of this arrangement?"

"I do, Mr. Holmes. Mr. Windibank is nearly fifteen years younger than my mother, and I cannot help feeling that she was not entirely free in her choice."

"You are a young lady of independent means, I presume?"

"Yes, sir. I have an income of £100 a year from New Zealand stock, which I inherited from my Uncle Ned."

"Ah, that is a very useful sum."

"It is, sir, but I can only touch the interest."

"I understand. And you live at home with your mother and stepfather?"

"Yes, sir. I allow them the use of my interest to avoid being a burden."

"And you earn your own living?"

"Yes, sir. I am a typist, and I earn two pence a sheet. I do about fifteen to twenty sheets a day."

"That is a very modest income."

"It is, sir, but I manage."

"You have explained your position very clearly, Miss Sutherland. I am much obliged to you. This is Dr. Watson, my colleague. You may speak freely before him."

"I am very glad to meet you, Dr. Watson."

"The pleasure is all mine, Miss Sutherland. I am sure that Mr. Holmes will do all in his power to assist you."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“And your mother is alive?”

The young man nodded, his face pale and drawn. “Yes, she is. But she is not well. That is why I have come to you, Mr. Holmes. I have heard of your abilities, and I am desperate for your help.”

Sherlock Holmes leaned back in his chair, his long, thin fingers steepled before his lips. His keen eyes studied the young man with an intensity that made the latter shift uncomfortably in his seat.

“Pray continue,” said Holmes. “I am always interested in the unusual.”

“My name is James Harcourt,” the young man said. “I am the only son of Sir Reginald Harcourt, of Harcourt Manor in the county of Wiltshire. My mother, Lady Harcourt, has been in a state of great distress for some time now. She refuses to speak of the cause, but I have noticed that she is often seen in the garden at night, alone, and in a state of great agitation.”

Holmes raised an eyebrow. “A garden at night? That is certainly unusual for a lady of her station. And you have not been able to learn the cause of her distress?”

“I have tried, Mr. Holmes. I have asked her, I have questioned the servants, but no one will speak of it. And then, last night, something happened that has left me in a state of great alarm. I found a letter in my mother’s room, addressed to her, but written in a hand I do not recognize. It was not delivered by the post, but left on her desk. The letter contained only a single sentence: 'You cannot hide from me forever.'”

Holmes leaned forward, his interest clearly piqued. “'You cannot hide from me forever.' That is certainly ominous. And what did you do upon reading this?”

“I did what any son would do in such a situation. I came to London, to seek your help. I have heard of your work, Mr. Holmes, and I believe that if anyone can uncover the truth, it is you.”

Holmes was silent for a moment, his mind clearly at work. Then he said, “Very well, Mr. Harcourt. I shall take your case. But I must warn you, I am not a man of sentiment. I shall pursue the truth, no matter where it leads.”

James Harcourt nodded, his eyes filled with hope and fear. “I understand, Mr. Holmes. I only ask that you help me to find the truth, and to protect my mother from whatever it is that haunts her.”

Holmes rose from his chair and began to pace the room. “Very well. We shall begin our investigation at once. I shall require you to remain in London for the time being, and I shall send for Dr. Watson to assist me. In the meantime, I suggest you write to your father and inform him of the situation. He must know what is happening.”

James Harcourt nodded again, his hands trembling slightly. “Yes, Mr. Holmes. I shall do as you say.”

Holmes turned to him, his expression grave. “Then let us begin, Mr. Harcourt. The truth, as you shall soon discover, is often far more complicated than we imagine.”

events.text_segment:
A flush stole over Miss Sutherland’s face, and she picked nervously at the fringe of her jacket. “I met him first at the gasfitters’ ball,” she said. “They used to send father tickets when he was alive, and then afterwards they remembered us, and sent them to mother. Mr. Windibank did not wish us to go. He never did wish us to go anywhere. He would get quite mad if I wanted so much as to join a Sunday-school treat. But this time I was set on going, and I would go; for what right had he to prevent? He said the folk were not fit for us to know, when all father’s friends were to be there. And he said that I had nothing fit to wear, when I had my purple plush that I had never so much as taken out of the drawer. At last, when nothing else would do, he went off to France upon the business of the firm, but we went, mother and I, with Mr. Hardy, who used to be our foreman, and it was there I met Mr. Hosmer Angel.”
“I suppose,” said Holmes, “that when Mr. Windibank came back from France he was very annoyed at your having gone to the ball.”
“Oh, well, he was very good about it. He laughed, I remember, and shrugged his shoulders, and said there was no use denying anything to a woman, for she would have her way.”
“I see. Then at the gasfitters’ ball you met, as I understand, a gentleman called Mr. Hosmer Angel.”
“Yes, sir. I met him that night, and he called next day to ask if we had got home all safe, and after that we met him—that is to say, Mr. Holmes, I met him twice for walks, but after that father came back again, and Mr. Hosmer Angel could not come to the house any more.”
“No?”
“Well, you know father didn’t like anything of the sort. He wouldn’t have any visitors if he could help it, and he used to say that a woman should be happy in her own family circle. But then, as I used to say to mother, a woman wants her own circle to begin with, and I had not got mine yet.”
“But how about Mr. Hosmer Angel? Did he make no attempt to see you?”
“Well, father was going off to France again in a week, and Hosmer wrote and said that it would be safer and better not to see each other until he had gone. We could write in the meantime, and he used to write every day. I took the letters in in the morning, so there was no need for father to know.”
“Were you engaged to the gentleman at this time?”
“Oh, yes, Mr. Holmes. We were engaged after the first walk that we took. Hosmer—Mr. Angel—was a cashier in an office in Leadenhall Street—and—”
“What office?”
“That’s the worst of it, Mr. Holmes, I don’t know.”
“Where did he live, then?”
“He slept on the premises.”
“And you don’t know his address?”
“No—except that it was Leadenhall Street.”
“Where did you address your letters, then?”
“To the Leadenhall Street Post Office, to be left till called for. He said that if they were sent to the office he would be chaffed by all the other clerks about having letters from a lady, so I offered to typewrite them, like he did his, but he wouldn’t have that, for he said that when I wrote them they seemed to come from me, but when they were typewritten he always felt that the machine had come between us. That will just show you how fond he was of me, Mr. Holmes, and the little things that he would think of.”
“It was most suggestive,” said Holmes. “It has long been an axiom of mine that the little things are infinitely the most important. Can you remember any other little things about Mr. Hosmer Angel?”
“He was a very shy man, Mr. Holmes. He would rather walk with me in the evening than in the daylight, for he said that he hated to be conspicuous. Very retiring and gentlemanly he was. Even his voice was gentle. He’d had the quinsy and swollen glands when he was young, he told me, and it had left him with a weak throat, and a hesitating, whispering fashion of speech. He was always well dressed, very neat and plain, but his eyes were weak, just as mine are, and he wore tinted glasses against the glare.”

**Chapter III. A Case of Identity**

*A flush stole over Miss Sutherland’s face, and she picked nervously at the fringe of her jacket.*

“I met Mr. Hosmer Angel at the gasfitters’ ball,” she began, her voice barely above a whisper. “It was my first time attending such an event, and I confess I was quite overwhelmed. My late father had been a valued customer of the firm, and they sent us tickets as a gesture of goodwill. But my stepfather, Mr. Windibank, was most opposed to the idea. He rarely allowed me to attend any sort of social gathering, and when he learned of the invitation, he was quite adamant.”

Holmes leaned forward slightly, his keen eyes fixed on the young woman. “You insisted on going, I presume?”

“Yes,” she replied, her fingers still fidgeting with the jacket’s fringe. “I had an old purple plush dress that had never been worn, and I thought it would be a shame to let it gather dust. Mr. Windibank was not pleased, but he had business in France and left just before the event. My mother and I went with the former foreman, Mr. Hardy, and it was there that I met Mr. Angel.”

Dr. Watson, who had been listening intently, exchanged a glance with Holmes. The detective, however, remained silent, his expression unreadable.

“Did your stepfather express any displeasure upon his return?” Holmes asked.

“No, he was quite good-natured about it,” she replied. “He never said a word. But I know he disapproved of Mr. Angel. He believed that women should remain within the family circle, and he was not fond of visitors.”

Holmes nodded slowly. “And Mr. Angel—what was your impression of him?”

Miss Sutherland hesitated. “He was very shy, but kind. He preferred to walk in the evenings, and he always spoke in a quiet voice. I believe he had some childhood illness that affected his throat, for his voice was rather soft. He was always neatly dressed, and he wore tinted glasses, much like I do.”

“Did he visit you at home?” Holmes inquired.

“Only twice,” she said. “After my stepfather returned, he stopped coming. But we corresponded. Mr. Angel wrote to me every day, and I collected the letters from the Leadenhall Street Post Office. He insisted they be addressed there, so as not to be teased at the office where he worked.”

“And what was his profession?” Holmes asked.

“He is a cashier,” she replied. “He works in an office on Leadenhall Street, and he sleeps on the premises. I never knew the exact address, only that he worked there.”

Holmes tapped his fingers lightly on the armrest of his chair. “And what of your letters to him? Did you write them in the same manner?”

“I offered to typewrite them, as he did, but he refused. He said he wanted the personal touch of handwriting. I took it as a sign of affection.”

Holmes smiled faintly. “Most suggestive, indeed. The little things are often the most telling.”

---

**End of Segment**

---

**Chapter III. A Case of Identity**  

*A flush stole over Miss Sutherland’s face, and she picked nervously at the fringe of her jacket.*  

“I met Mr. Hosmer Angel at the gasfitters’ ball,” she began, her voice barely above a whisper. “It was my first time attending such an event. The tickets were sent originally to my late father, as a gesture of goodwill from the firm. After his passing, they were forwarded to my mother. Mr. Windibank—my stepfather—was most opposed to the idea. He rarely allowed me to attend any sort of social gathering, and when he learned of the invitation, he was quite adamant. He objected not only to the company but to the dress I intended to wear—a purple plush gown I had never worn before. He called it ‘imprudent’ and insisted I remain at home.”  

Holmes leaned forward slightly, his keen eyes fixed on the young woman. “You insisted on going, I presume?”  

“Yes,” she replied, her fingers still fidgeting with the jacket’s fringe. “I thought it would be a shame to let the dress gather dust. Mr. Windibank left for France on business just before the event, and my mother and I went with the former foreman, Mr. Hardy. It was there that I met Mr. Angel.”  

“Did your stepfather express any displeasure upon his return?” Holmes asked.  

“No, he was quite good-natured about it,” she replied. “He never said a word. But I know he disapproved of Mr. Angel. He believed that women should remain within the family circle, and he was not fond of visitors.”  

Holmes nodded slowly. “And Mr. Angel—what was your impression of him?”  

Miss Sutherland hesitated. “He was very shy, but kind. He preferred to walk in the evenings, and he always spoke in a quiet voice. I believe he had some childhood illness that affected his throat, for his voice was rather soft. He was always neatly dressed, and he wore tinted glasses, much like I do.”  

“Did he visit you at home?” Holmes inquired.  

“Only twice,” she said. “After my stepfather returned, he stopped coming. But we corresponded. Mr. Angel wrote to me every day, and I collected the letters from the Leadenhall Street Post Office. He insisted they be addressed there, so as not to be teased at the office where he worked. He is a cashier there, and he sleeps on the premises. I never knew the exact address, only that he worked in the office.”  

“An interesting precaution,” Holmes remarked. “And what of your letters to him? Did you write them in the same manner?”  

“I offered to typewrite them, as he did, but he refused. He said he wanted the personal touch of handwriting. I took it as a sign of affection.”  

Holmes smiled faintly. “Most suggestive, indeed. The little things are often the most telling. Tell me, were there any other little things about Mr. Angel that struck you?”  

Miss Sutherland nodded. “He was very particular about the time of our meetings. He never arrived before dusk, and he always carried a small notebook. He said it was for his work, but I never saw him write in it. And… he never mentioned his family or where he came from. He spoke only of his job and his desire to marry me.”  

Holmes steepled his fingers. “And the engagement—how did it come about?”  

“After our first walk, he proposed. He said he had no fortune, but he would work hard to provide for me. I believed him. I believed in him.”  

The room fell silent, save for the ticking of the clock. Holmes’s gaze lingered on the young woman, his mind already unraveling the threads of her story.  

---

events.text_segment:
“Well, and what happened when Mr. Windibank, your stepfather, returned to France?”
“Mr. Hosmer Angel came to the house again and proposed that we should marry before father came back. He was in dreadful earnest and made me swear, with my hands on the Testament, that whatever happened I would always be true to him. Mother said he was quite right to make me swear, and that it was a sign of his passion. Mother was all in his favour from the first and was even fonder of him than I was. Then, when they talked of marrying within the week, I began to ask about father; but they both said never to mind about father, but just to tell him afterwards, and mother said she would make it all right with him. I didn’t quite like that, Mr. Holmes. It seemed funny that I should ask his leave, as he was only a few years older than me; but I didn’t want to do anything on the sly, so I wrote to father at Bordeaux, where the company has its French offices, but the letter came back to me on the very morning of the wedding.”
“It missed him, then?”
“Yes, sir; for he had started to England just before it arrived.”
“Ha! that was unfortunate. Your wedding was arranged, then, for the Friday. Was it to be in church?”
“Yes, sir, but very quietly. It was to be at St. Saviour’s, near King’s Cross, and we were to have breakfast afterwards at the St. Pancras Hotel. Hosmer came for us in a hansom, but as there were two of us he put us both into it and stepped himself into a four-wheeler, which happened to be the only other cab in the street. We got to the church first, and when the four-wheeler drove up we waited for him to step out, but he never did, and when the cabman got down from the box and looked there was no one there! The cabman said that he could not imagine what had become of him, for he had seen him get in with his own eyes. That was last Friday, Mr. Holmes, and I have never seen or heard anything since then to throw any light upon what became of him.”
“It seems to me that you have been very shamefully treated,” said Holmes.
“Oh, no, sir! He was too good and kind to leave me so. Why, all the morning he was saying to me that, whatever happened, I was to be true; and that even if something quite unforeseen occurred to separate us, I was always to remember that I was pledged to him, and that he would claim his pledge sooner or later. It seemed strange talk for a wedding-morning, but what has happened since gives a meaning to it.”
“Most certainly it does. Your own opinion is, then, that some unforeseen catastrophe has occurred to him?”
“Yes, sir. I believe that he foresaw some danger, or else he would not have talked so. And then I think that what he foresaw happened.”
“But you have no notion as to what it could have been?”
“None.”
“One more question. How did your mother take the matter?”
“She was angry, and said that I was never to speak of the matter again.”
“And your father? Did you tell him?”
“Yes; and he seemed to think, with me, that something had happened, and that I should hear of Hosmer again. As he said, what interest could anyone have in bringing me to the doors of the church, and then leaving me? Now, if he had borrowed my money, or if he had married me and got my money settled on him, there might be some reason, but Hosmer was very independent about money and never would look at a shilling of mine. And yet, what could have happened? And why could he not write? Oh, it drives me half-mad to think of it, and I can’t sleep a wink at night.” She pulled a little handkerchief out of her muff and began to sob heavily into it.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Well, and what happened when Mr. Windibank, your stepfather, returned to France?"

"He came back, as I have said, and found that Hosmer Angel had been here. He was very angry, and accused me of having been foolish and imprudent. But I told him the whole story, and he could not deny that Hosmer had behaved with the greatest delicacy and consideration. He had urged us to marry before Mr. Windibank's return, and had made me swear on the Testament to be always true to him, whatever happened. My mother, who was very fond of Hosmer, supported me, and said that this was the best proof of his passion. When the question of marriage within the week was raised, I was afraid of my stepfather's anger, but both my mother and Hosmer told me not to worry, and to inform him afterwards. My mother promised to manage it all.

"I felt uneasy about not asking his leave, though the difference in our ages was not so great as to make it unreasonable. But I did not wish to act in secrecy. I wrote to Mr. Windibank in Bordeaux, but the letter was returned to me on my wedding morning, having missed him by only a day. The quiet wedding was to take place on Friday at St. Saviour's, King's Cross, and we were to have breakfast afterwards at the St. Pancras Hotel. Hosmer came for me and my mother in a hansom cab. Since the hansom was small, he put us both inside and took a separate four-wheeler himself. We arrived at the church first; when the four-wheeler arrived, Hosmer never emerged. The cabman was quite certain that he had seen him get in. This occurred last Friday, and I have had no word since."

"You seem to have been shamefully treated," said Holmes.

"No, no, Mr. Holmes!" she cried, with a sudden burst of feeling. "Hosmer was too kind, too noble. His words before, about unforeseen events, now make sense. He must have foreseen some danger, and this danger has come upon us. I do not know what it is, but I feel it in my heart."

"And your mother?"

"She was angry, and forbade me to speak of it again."

"And your stepfather?"

"He seemed to agree with me that something had happened, and that Hosmer would reappear. He asked me what motive anyone could have for abandoning you at the church door without financial gain."

Miss Sutherland sat in silence for a moment, her face pale and drawn. Then she began to sob softly, her hands clasped in her lap, her shoulders trembling with the weight of her grief.

events.title: Holmes Takes the Case and Assesses the Client
detailed_summary: Holmes rises, assures Miss Sutherland he will investigate and likely find a definite result.
He advises her to stop dwelling on it and try to let Hosmer Angel vanish from her memory.
She asks if he thinks she won't see Angel again; Holmes confirms he fears not.
She asks what happened to him; Holmes asks her to leave the question to him.
He requests an accurate description of Angel and any letters.
She provides an advertisement slip from the Chronicle and four letters from Angel.
She gives her address as No. 31 Lyon Place, Camberwell.
Holmes confirms she never had Angel's specific address and asks for her stepfather's business.

Holmes thanks her for her clear statement, advises her again to put the incident behind her.

events.text_segment:
“I shall glance into the case for you,” said Holmes, rising, “and I have no doubt that we shall reach some definite result. Let the weight of the matter rest upon me now, and do not let your mind dwell upon it further. Above all, try to let Mr. Hosmer Angel vanish from your memory, as he has done from your life.”
“Then you don’t think I’ll see him again?”
“I fear not.”
“Then what has happened to him?”
“You will leave that question in my hands. I should like an accurate description of him and any letters of his which you can spare.”
“I advertised for him in last Saturday’s Chronicle,” said she. “Here is the slip and here are four letters from him.”
“Thank you. And your address?”
“No. 31 Lyon Place, Camberwell.”
“Mr. Angel’s address you never had, I understand. Where is your father’s place of business?”
“He travels for Westhouse & Marbank, the great claret importers of Fenchurch Street.”
“Thank you. You have made your statement very clearly. You will leave the papers here, and remember the advice which I have given you. Let the whole incident be a sealed book, and do not allow it to affect your life.”
“You are very kind, Mr. Holmes, but I cannot do that. I shall be true to Hosmer. He shall find me ready when he comes back.”
For all the preposterous hat and the vacuous face, there was something noble in the simple faith of our visitor which compelled our respect. She laid her little bundle of papers upon the table and went her way, with a promise to come again whenever she might be summoned.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"I shall glance into the case for you," said Holmes, rising, "and I have no doubt that we shall reach some definite result. In the meantime, I should advise you to try to forget it, and to let Hosmer Angel vanish from your memory." 

"But you think I shall never see him again?" she asked, with a paling face.

"I fear not," said Holmes, coldly.

"Then what has become of him?" she cried.

"That is a question which I must leave to myself," he answered. "I shall be very glad if you will give me an accurate description of the man, and also any letters which may have passed between you."

She drew a slip of paper from her pocket, and handed it to him. It was an advertisement from the Chronicle, offering a reward for information respecting a missing man named Hosmer Angel. She also produced four letters, all in a firm, business-like hand, which had been written by the missing man. 

"You will find my address at No. 31, Lyon Place, Camberwell," she said.

"You never had his address?"

"No, indeed."

"And your stepfather's business?"

"Westhouse & Marbank, claret importers, Fenchurch Street."

"Thank you. You have given me a very clear statement. I can only repeat my advice, that you should put the whole affair from your mind."

She looked at him with a wistful, appealing gaze. "But if he should return?"

"If he should return, you will hear of it."

She rose, and with a little sigh, she left the room, carrying with her the bundle of letters. As she passed me, I caught a glimpse of her face, and I could not but admire the quiet dignity and simple faith which shone in her features. She was a woman who, though she had been through a bitter experience, had not lost her trust in the man she loved. And yet, I could not help feeling that there was something strange and even sinister in the whole affair.

“I shall glance into the case for you,” said Holmes, rising, “and I have no doubt that we shall reach some definite result.”

I was delighted at his readiness to assist, for the case had already taken on a most singular and intriguing aspect. “You are very good, Mr. Holmes,” I said. “I am sure that your keen insight will bring the matter to light.”

Holmes smiled faintly, his eyes gleaming with the anticipation of a puzzle to be solved. “It is always a pleasure to assist a fellow man in distress, Watson. And this case, I must confess, does appear to be of some interest. I nodded, recalling the details I had shared with him. “The butler, Mr. Lestrade, is most perplexed. He swears that the silver was locked in the cabinet, and yet it vanished overnight. The housemaid, too, is convinced that no one entered the room.”

Holmes leaned back in his chair, steepling his fingers beneath his chin. “Indeed. A locked room mystery, perhaps. Or perhaps not. There is always a method to the madness, Watson. We shall soon see.”

With that, he rose and, after a brief pause to don his coat, we set out for the address I had provided. The fog was thick upon the streets of London, and the gas lamps flickered in the damp air, casting long shadows that seemed to stretch and twist like the very mysteries we were about to unravel.

events.text_segment:
Sherlock Holmes sat silent for a few minutes with his fingertips still pressed together, his legs stretched out in front of him, and his gaze directed upward to the ceiling. Then he took down from the rack the old and oily clay pipe, which was to him as a counsellor, and, having lit it, he leaned back in his chair, with the thick blue cloud-wreaths spinning up from him, and a look of infinite languor in his face.
“Quite an interesting study, that maiden,” he observed. “I found her more interesting than her little problem, which, by the way, is rather a trite one. You will find parallel cases, if you consult my index, in Andover in ’77, and there was something of the sort at The Hague last year. Old as is the idea, however, there were one or two details which were new to me. But the maiden herself was most instructive.”
“You appeared to read a good deal upon her which was quite invisible to me,” I remarked.
“Not invisible but unnoticed, Watson. You did not know where to look, and so you missed all that was important. I can never bring you to realise the importance of sleeves, the suggestiveness of thumb-nails, or the great issues that may hang from a boot-lace. Now, what did you gather from that woman’s appearance? Describe it.”
“Well, she had a slate-coloured, broad-brimmed straw hat, with a feather of a brickish red. Her jacket was black, with black beads sewn upon it, and a fringe of little black jet ornaments. Her dress was brown, rather darker than coffee colour, with a little purple plush at the neck and sleeves. Her gloves were greyish and were worn through at the right forefinger. Her boots I didn’t observe. She had small round, hanging gold earrings, and a general air of being fairly well-to-do in a vulgar, comfortable, easy-going way.”
Sherlock Holmes clapped his hands softly together and chuckled.
“’Pon my word, Watson, you are coming along wonderfully. You have really done very well indeed. It is true that you have missed everything of importance, but you have hit upon the method, and you have a quick eye for colour. Never trust to general impressions, my boy, but concentrate yourself upon details. My first glance is always at a woman’s sleeve. In a man it is perhaps better first to take the knee of the trouser. As you observe, this woman had plush upon her sleeves, which is a most useful material for showing traces. The double line a little above the wrist, where the typewritist presses against the table, was beautifully defined. The sewing-machine, of the hand type, leaves a similar mark, but only on the left arm, and on the side of it farthest from the thumb, instead of being right across the broadest part, as this was. I then glanced at her face, and, observing the dint of a pince-nez at either side of her nose, I ventured a remark upon short sight and typewriting, which seemed to surprise her.”
“It surprised me.”
“But, surely, it was obvious. I was then much surprised and interested on glancing down to observe that, though the boots which she was wearing were not unlike each other, they were really odd ones; the one having a slightly decorated toe-cap, and the other a plain one. One was buttoned only in the two lower buttons out of five, and the other at the first, third, and fifth. Now, when you see that a young lady, otherwise neatly dressed, has come away from home with odd boots, half-buttoned, it is no great deduction to say that she came away in a hurry.”
“And what else?” I asked, keenly interested, as I always was, by my friend’s incisive reasoning.
“I noted, in passing, that she had written a note before leaving home but after being fully dressed. You observed that her right glove was torn at the forefinger, but you did not apparently see that both glove and finger were stained with violet ink. She had written in a hurry and dipped her pen too deep. It must have been this morning, or the mark would not remain clear upon the finger. All this is amusing, though rather elementary, but I must go back to business, Watson. Would you mind reading me the advertised description of Mr. Hosmer Angel?”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Sherlock Holmes sat silent for a few minutes with his fingertips still pressed together, his legs stretched out in front of him, and his gaze directed upward to the ceiling. Then he lit his clay pipe, and, as the smoke curled up between his brows, he remarked: 'You have some interesting studies in your case, Miss Sutherland, but the problem itself is, I confess, a trite one. I have had a good many similar ones in my time. I remember one in Andover in '77, and another in The Hague last year.'

'You mean the case of the missing husband?' I asked.

'Precisely. But I must say that the woman herself is more interesting than the problem. You have observed her, no doubt.'

'Yes, I have had a good look at her.'

'And what did you see?'

'I saw a very plain woman, with a vulgar dress, a loud feather in her hat, and a general air of the well-to-do lower middle class.'

'Ah, you see what you expect to see. The signs were not invisible, but you did not see them. You have not yet begun to look with your eyes. You trust too much to your general impressions and not enough to your specific observations.'

'What, then, did you see, Holmes?'

'First, I observed that her sleeves were of plush, and that there were faint traces of a double line near the wrist. That, as you know, is the mark of a typewritist, and not of a sewing machine. Then I noticed the indentation on her nose from the pince-nez, which told me that she was short-sighted and used the instrument constantly. I also remarked that her boots were odd, one with a different toe-cap and half-buttoned in a different way. That told me that she had dressed in a hurry, and had not the time to match them properly. And finally, I saw that she had written a note after she had dressed, for there was a stain of violet ink on her right glove and on her forefinger, and it was applied too deeply to be accidental.'

'You are a marvel, Holmes!' I exclaimed.

'Elementary, my dear Watson. Now, if you will kindly read the advertisement of Hosmer Angel, we may proceed with the case.'

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Sherlock Holmes sat silent for a few minutes with his fingertips still pressed together, his legs stretched out in front of him, and his gaze directed upward to the ceiling. Dr. Watson, who had been watching his friend intently, could see the wheels of his mind turning, the great detective's thoughts racing through a labyrinth of facts and deductions. The room was quiet, save for the occasional ticking of the clock on the wall and the faint crackle of the fire in the hearth. It was one of those rare moments when even the ever-attentive Dr. Watson could not fathom the direction of Holmes' thoughts.

At last, Holmes broke the silence with a soft sigh, his fingers parting as he leaned forward slightly. "It is a curious case, Watson," he said, his voice low and contemplative. "The details are so peculiar, so seemingly insignificant, yet they all point to something far more complex than they appear. The man who came to see me this morning, the one with the red beard and the nervous manner, he is not the criminal, but he is certainly connected to the crime in a most unusual way."

Dr. Watson raised an eyebrow. "Connected, but not the criminal? That is an odd distinction."

"Indeed," Holmes replied, his eyes gleaming with the thrill of the mystery. "You see, Watson, the man is a pawn in a much larger game. He was sent to me by someone else, someone who is far more intelligent and calculating. The red beard is a disguise, the nervous manner a performance. He is not the mastermind, but he is a vital piece of the puzzle."

Watson leaned back in his chair, intrigued. "And what of the crime itself? You have not yet mentioned the details."

Holmes smiled faintly. "Ah, yes. The theft of the Crown Jewels. A most audacious act, and one that has left the authorities baffled. The jewels were taken from the Tower of London, yet there is no sign of forced entry, no indication of how they were removed. The only clue is a single red hair found at the scene, and that is where our friend with the red beard comes in."

Watson's eyes widened. "A red hair? You think he was there?"

"Not he, Watson, but the person who sent him. The red hair is a clue, but it is also a red herring. The real criminal is someone who has gone to great lengths to mislead us. The red beard is a false trail, a distraction from the true mastermind."

Dr. Watson nodded slowly, beginning to grasp the complexity of the case. "And what of the method? How could the jewels be taken without a trace?"

Holmes leaned back, his fingers once again pressed together. "That is the most fascinating part, Watson. I believe the thief used a method that is both simple and brilliant. The Tower is a place of great security, but it is also a place of routine. The guards follow the same patterns, the same procedures, day after day. The thief exploited this predictability."

"How?" Watson asked, his curiosity piqued.

"By becoming a part of the routine," Holmes replied. "The thief was not an outsider, but someone who had access to the Tower. Someone who knew the guards, their schedules, their blind spots. The jewels were not taken by force, but by deception. The thief simply walked out with them, unnoticed."

Watson shook his head in amazement. "That is incredible. But who could it be?"

Holmes smiled. "That is the next step, Watson. We must find out who has the knowledge, the opportunity, and the motive. And I believe I have a suspect in mind."

With that, Holmes rose from his chair, his long coat rustling as he moved. "Come, Watson. We have much to do. The game is afoot."

And with that, the great detective was off, leaving Dr. Watson to follow in his wake, eager to see how the mystery would unfold.

events.title: Analyzing the Evidence and Planning the Next Steps
detailed_summary: Watson reads the newspaper description of Hosmer Angel: physical details, clothing, tinted glasses, speech infirmity, employed in Leadenhall Street.
Holmes stops Watson, finding the description sufficient.
He glances over the letters, calling them commonplace, offering no clue except a Balzac quote.
He points out one 'remarkable' and 'suggestive' point for Watson to notice.
Watson correctly identifies that the letters are typewritten.
Holmes clarifies the key point is not just that they are typewritten, but that the *signature* ('Hosmer Angel') is also typewritten.
He notes the vague Leadenhall Street address and date, but emphasizes the signature as conclusive.
Watson fails to grasp the significance, speculating it might be to deny the signature later.
Holmes dismisses this, stating he will write two letters to settle the matter.
One letter is to a firm in the City (presumably Angel's supposed employer or Windibank's actual employer).

events.text_segment:
I held the little printed slip to the light. “Missing,” it said, “on the morning of the fourteenth, a gentleman named Hosmer Angel. About five ft. seven in. in height; strongly built, sallow complexion, black hair, a little bald in the centre, bushy, black side-whiskers and moustache; tinted glasses, slight infirmity of speech. Was dressed, when last seen, in black frock-coat faced with silk, black waistcoat, gold Albert chain, and grey Harris tweed trousers, with brown gaiters over elastic-sided boots. Known to have been employed in an office in Leadenhall Street. Anybody bringing,” &c, &c.
“That will do,” said Holmes. “As to the letters,” he continued, glancing over them, “they are very commonplace. Absolutely no clue in them to Mr. Angel, save that he quotes Balzac once. There is one remarkable point, however, which will no doubt strike you.”
“They are typewritten,” I remarked.
“Not only that, but the signature is typewritten. Look at the neat little ‘Hosmer Angel’ at the bottom. There is a date, you see, but no superscription except Leadenhall Street, which is rather vague. The point about the signature is very suggestive—in fact, we may call it conclusive.”
“Of what?”
“My dear fellow, is it possible you do not see how strongly it bears upon the case?”
“I cannot say that I do unless it were that he wished to be able to deny his signature if an action for breach of promise were instituted.”
“No, that was not the point. However, I shall write two letters, which should settle the matter. One is to a firm in the City, the other is to the young lady’s stepfather, Mr. Windibank, asking him whether he could meet us here at six o’clock to-morrow evening. It is just as well that we should do business with the male relatives. And now, Doctor, we can do nothing until the answers to those letters come, so we may put our little problem upon the shelf for the interim.”

**Chapter III. A CASE OF IDENTITY**

"I held the little printed slip to the light. It was a small advertisement, no more, yet it seemed to me to contain the germs of a mystery which might well prove to be of absorbing interest. The name of the firm was printed in bold type at the top, and beneath it ran the description of a young man named Hosmer Angel. He was to be engaged for a position in Leadenhall Street, and the advertisement gave a detailed account of his appearance: a tall, fair-haired man with a slight impediment in his speech, who wore tinted glasses and dressed with a certain fastidiousness.

I read the description aloud to Holmes, who sat with his long, thin fingers interlaced and his eyes fixed upon the ceiling. 'That is sufficient,' he said, with a wave of his hand. 'The rest is mere embroidery. The letters themselves are of no particular interest, save for a quotation from Balzac, which is as common as it is meaningless.'

He glanced over the letters I had brought, his keen eyes missing nothing. 'There is one point, however, which is both remarkable and suggestive,' he remarked, tapping the paper with a finger. I looked at him in surprise. 'What is it?' I asked.

'Observe,' he said, handing me the letter. I took it and saw at once what he meant. The body of the letter was typewritten, but so was the signature—*Hosmer Angel*. 'That is the key,' he said. 'If the name is typewritten, it is not written by the hand of the supposed Hosmer Angel. It is a forgery, or at the very least, a deception.'

I was puzzled. 'But why would they go to such trouble? Surely it would be easier to sign the name by hand.'

'Perhaps,' Holmes mused, 'but the typewritten signature is more convincing. It suggests a level of sophistication, a desire to appear legitimate. No, the real question is: who is behind this? And why?'

He was already writing. One letter was addressed to a firm in the City, the other to Mr. Windibank. 'We shall hear from them tomorrow evening,' he said. 'Until then, there is nothing more to be done. I prefer dealing with male relatives—they are more direct, more to the point.'

I sat in silence, watching him as he returned to his contemplative pose. The case of Hosmer Angel had begun, and I could not yet see where it would lead."

"I held the little printed slip to the light. It was a small advertisement, no more, yet it seemed to me to contain the germs of a mystery which might well prove to be of absorbing interest. The name of the firm was printed in bold type at the top, and beneath it ran the description of a young man named Hosmer Angel. He was to be engaged for a position in Leadenhall Street, and the advertisement gave a detailed account of his appearance: a tall, fair-haired man with a slight impediment in his speech, who wore tinted glasses and dressed with a certain fastidiousness.

I read the description aloud to Holmes, who sat with his long, thin fingers interlaced and his eyes fixed upon the ceiling. 'That is sufficient,' he said, with a wave of his hand. 'The rest is mere embroidery. The letters themselves are of no particular interest, save for a quotation from Balzac, which is as common as it is meaningless.'

He glanced over the letters I had brought, his keen eyes missing nothing. 'There is one point, however, which is both remarkable and suggestive,' he remarked, tapping the paper with a finger. I looked at him in surprise. 'What is it?' I asked.

'Observe,' he said, handing me the letter. I took it and saw at once what he meant. The body of the letter was typewritten, but so was the signature—*Hosmer Angel*. 'That is the key,' he said. 'If the name is typewritten, it is not written by the hand of the supposed Hosmer Angel. It is a forgery, or at the very least, a deception.'

I was puzzled. 'But why would they go to such trouble? Surely it would be easier to sign the name by hand.'

'Perhaps,' Holmes mused, 'but the typewritten signature is more convincing. It suggests a level of sophistication, a desire to appear legitimate. No, the real question is: who is behind this? And why?'

He was already writing. One letter was addressed to a firm in the City, the other to Mr. Windibank. 'We shall hear from them tomorrow evening,' he said. 'Until then, there is nothing more to be done. I prefer dealing with male relatives—they are more direct, more to the point.'

I sat in silence, watching him as he returned to his contemplative pose. The case of Hosmer Angel had begun, and I could not yet see where it would lead."

--- 

**End of Simulated Output**

The words were printed in a bold, block style, and the whole thing had the appearance of being hastily produced. I read it again carefully, for it was of the utmost importance that I should not misinterpret a single word. The slip bore the heading of a well-known London newspaper, and beneath it was a short paragraph, which ran as follows: 'A most singular and inexplicable occurrence took place at the house of Mr. James Mortimer, of Barbury Castle, yesterday evening. A large, black hound was seen by several persons in the grounds of the property, and it is said to have howled in a most unearthly manner. The animal, which is supposed to have belonged to the late Mr. Charles Baskerville, was last seen some years ago. The circumstances are regarded with the greatest alarm by the inhabitants of the village, and it is feared that the old legend may be about to be fulfilled. We shall report further developments in our next issue.' I turned the slip over, but there was nothing more upon it. I had read the paragraph with the keenest interest, for I had already heard of the Baskerville family and their strange history. The name of the hound was one that had long been associated with mystery and terror, and I could not help feeling a thrill of excitement as I considered the implications of the report. I had been asked by Mr. Sherlock Holmes to keep my eyes open for any unusual occurrences, and this certainly seemed to be one. I resolved at once to communicate the matter to him without delay. I folded the slip carefully and placed it in my pocket, then I rose from my chair and made my way to the door. The night was dark and still, and as I stepped out into the street, I could not help but feel that I was on the threshold of something strange and perhaps dangerous. I had no doubt that Mr. Holmes would be deeply interested in the case, and I was eager to see what his reaction would be when I presented him with the evidence I had just acquired.

events.title: Interim and Watson's Confidence in Holmes
detailed_summary: Watson reflects on his strong belief in Holmes's reasoning and energy.
He feels Holmes must have solid grounds for his confident handling of the mystery.
He recalls Holmes's rare failure in the Irene Adler case but contrasts it with successes like the Sign of Four and A Study in Scarlet.
Watson feels confident Holmes can unravel this tangle.
He leaves Holmes smoking his pipe, expecting the case to be solved by the next evening.
Watson is occupied with a serious professional case the entire next day.
He arrives at Baker Street near six o'clock, fearing he missed the conclusion.
He finds Holmes alone, drowsy in his armchair, surrounded by chemical apparatus, indicating he spent the day on experiments.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I had had so many reasons to believe in my friend’s subtle powers of reasoning and extraordinary energy in action that I felt that he must have some solid grounds for the assured and easy demeanour with which he treated the singular mystery which he had been called upon to fathom.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: A formidable array of bottles and test-tubes, with the pungent cleanly smell of hydrochloric acid, told me that he had spent his day in the chemical work which was so dear to him.

events.text_segment:
I had had so many reasons to believe in my friend’s subtle powers of reasoning and extraordinary energy in action that I felt that he must have some solid grounds for the assured and easy demeanour with which he treated the singular mystery which he had been called upon to fathom. Once only had I known him to fail, in the case of the King of Bohemia and of the Irene Adler photograph; but when I looked back to the weird business of the Sign of Four, and the extraordinary circumstances connected with the Study in Scarlet, I felt that it would be a strange tangle indeed which he could not unravel.
I left him then, still puffing at his black clay pipe, with the conviction that when I came again on the next evening I would find that he held in his hands all the clues which would lead up to the identity of the disappearing bridegroom of Miss Mary Sutherland.
A professional case of great gravity was engaging my own attention at the time, and the whole of next day I was busy at the bedside of the sufferer. It was not until close upon six o’clock that I found myself free and was able to spring into a hansom and drive to Baker Street, half afraid that I might be too late to assist at the dénouement of the little mystery. I found Sherlock Holmes alone, however, half asleep, with his long, thin form curled up in the recesses of his armchair. A formidable array of bottles and test-tubes, with the pungent cleanly smell of hydrochloric acid, told me that he had spent his day in the chemical work which was so dear to him.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: I had had so many reasons to believe in my friend’s subtle powers of reasoning and extraordinary energy in action that I felt that he must have some solid grounds for the assured and easy demeanour with which he treated the singular mystery which he had been called upon to fathom. I had already observed how his mind worked, and I knew that when he made a statement it was not in the nature of a guess, but as the logical outcome of a series of careful deductions. I had, indeed, so much confidence in him that I was not surprised when he told me that the case was already solved. I had, however, a recollection of one or two cases in which he had been at fault, and I could not help thinking of the Irene Adler affair, which had shaken my faith in his infallibility. But then I remembered the triumphs of the Sign of Four and A Study in Scarlet, and I felt that this was but a small matter compared with the great successes which had already crowned his career. I left him to his own devices, with his pipe in his mouth and his eyes fixed upon the ceiling, and I went out to attend to my own professional duties. The next day was one of the busiest I had ever spent in my practice, and I did not return to Baker Street until nearly six o'clock in the evening. I was afraid that I might have missed the solution of the mystery, and that Holmes might have already gone to his client with the result of his investigations. I found him, however, still in his armchair, with his feet upon the table, and a long trail of smoke curling from his pipe. He was surrounded by a number of chemical apparatus, and the air was heavy with the smell of strong acids. He looked up as I entered, and smiled at me with the air of a man who has finished his work and is now at leisure to enjoy the fruits of his labours.

'Then you know that the will was found in the drawer of the dead man's desk, and that it was not there when he was alive?' 'That is what I understand.' 'Precisely. They assume that the will was placed there after his death, and that the drawer was opened after his death. But I have reason to believe that the will was placed there before his death, and that the drawer was opened before his death. The key was in the dead man's pocket, but it was not the key to the drawer. It was the key to the room in which the drawer was kept. The drawer was opened before his death, and the will was placed there before his death. The man was murdered after the will was placed there, and the drawer was locked after his death. The key was in his pocket, but it was not the key to the drawer. It was the key to the room. That is my theory, and I have reason to believe that it is correct.'

events.title: The Solution Revealed and Windibank's Arrival
detailed_summary: Watson enters and asks if Holmes has solved the mystery.
Holmes initially responds absently about a chemical result ('bisulphate of baryta').
Clarifying Watson meant the case, Holmes confirms it's solved, stating there was never really a mystery, though some details were interesting.
He expresses frustration that the law likely cannot punish the culprit.
As Watson asks who the culprit was and his motive, they hear heavy footsteps and a tap at the door.
Holmes identifies the visitor as the stepfather, Mr. James Windibank, confirming he'd written to expect him at six.
Holmes invites him in.
A sturdy, middle-sized man of about thirty enters, clean-shaven with sharp grey eyes and an insinuating manner.
He glances sharply at Holmes and Watson, places his hat down, and takes a chair.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Well, have you solved it?” I asked as I entered.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Come in!”

events.text_segment:
“Well, have you solved it?” I asked as I entered.
“Yes. It was the bisulphate of baryta.”
“No, no, the mystery!” I cried.
“Oh, that! I thought of the salt that I have been working upon. There was never any mystery in the matter, though, as I said yesterday, some of the details are of interest. The only drawback is that there is no law, I fear, that can touch the scoundrel.”
“Who was he, then, and what was his object in deserting Miss Sutherland?”
The question was hardly out of my mouth, and Holmes had not yet opened his lips to reply, when we heard a heavy footfall in the passage and a tap at the door.
“This is the girl’s stepfather, Mr. James Windibank,” said Holmes. “He has written to me to say that he would be here at six. Come in!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Well, have you solved it?” I asked as I entered.

Holmes looked up from his microscope with a weary air. “The bisulphate of baryta is quite precipitated,” he remarked.

I laughed. “I mean the mystery, of course.”

He leaned back in his chair and smiled. “Ah, that! Yes, I have solved it. There was never really a mystery, though there were one or two points of interest. I confess, however, that I feel some sympathy for the young lady, and some admiration for the man who did the trick.”

“Who was it, then?” I asked eagerly.

He was about to answer when a heavy footstep and a tap at the door interrupted us. “That must be Mr. James Windibank,” said Holmes. “I expected him at six.”

He rang the bell, and the servant admitted a stout, middle-sized man of about thirty, clean-shaven, with sharp grey eyes and an insinuating manner. He glanced keenly at both of us, set his hat down on the table, and took a chair.

events.title: Confronting Windibank with Typewriter Evidence
detailed_summary: Holmes greets Mr. Windibank and confirms a typewritten letter arranging the appointment is from him.
Windibank apologizes for being slightly late, blaming work constraints.
He expresses annoyance that Miss Sutherland troubled Holmes, preferring not to air family matters publicly.
He mentions her impulsive nature and that her visit was against his wishes, though he minds less since Holmes isn't official police.
He dismisses the investigation as a useless expense, questioning how Holmes could possibly find Hosmer Angel.
Holmes calmly states he has every reason to believe he *will* succeed in discovering Mr. Hosmer Angel.
Windibank starts violently, drops his gloves, and claims to be delighted.
Holmes remarks on the individuality of typewriters, noting that older machines develop unique characteristics.
He points out specific flaws in Windibank's appointment letter: a slurred 'e' and defective 'r' tail, among fourteen other characteristics.
Windibank, eyeing Holmes keenly, attributes this to wear on the office machine.
Holmes announces he will show Windibank an interesting study, mentioning his intention to write a monograph on typewriters and crime.
He presents the four letters purportedly from Hosmer Angel, all typewritten.

He invites Windibank to use a magnifying lens to observe that the same distinctive flaws, including the slurred 'e's, tailless 'r's, and the other fourteen characteristics, are present in Angel's letters as well.
