events.text_segment:
The man who entered was a sturdy, middle-sized fellow, some thirty years of age, clean-shaven, and sallow-skinned, with a bland, insinuating manner, and a pair of wonderfully sharp and penetrating grey eyes. He shot a questioning glance at each of us, placed his shiny top-hat upon the sideboard, and with a slight bow sidled down into the nearest chair.
“Good-evening, Mr. James Windibank,” said Holmes. “I think that this typewritten letter is from you, in which you made an appointment with me for six o’clock?”
“Yes, sir. I am afraid that I am a little late, but I am not quite my own master, you know. I am sorry that Miss Sutherland has troubled you about this little matter, for I think it is far better not to wash linen of the sort in public. It was quite against my wishes that she came, but she is a very excitable, impulsive girl, as you may have noticed, and she is not easily controlled when she has made up her mind on a point. Of course, I did not mind you so much, as you are not connected with the official police, but it is not pleasant to have a family misfortune like this noised abroad. Besides, it is a useless expense, for how could you possibly find this Hosmer Angel?”
“On the contrary,” said Holmes quietly; “I have every reason to believe that I will succeed in discovering Mr. Hosmer Angel.”
Mr. Windibank gave a violent start and dropped his gloves. “I am delighted to hear it,” he said.
“It is a curious thing,” remarked Holmes, “that a typewriter has really quite as much individuality as a man’s handwriting. Unless they are quite new, no two of them write exactly alike. Some letters get more worn than others, and some wear only on one side. Now, you remark in this note of yours, Mr. Windibank, that in every case there is some little slurring over of the ‘e,’ and a slight defect in the tail of the ‘r.’ There are fourteen other characteristics, but those are the more obvious.”
“We do all our correspondence with this machine at the office, and no doubt it is a little worn,” our visitor answered, glancing keenly at Holmes with his bright little eyes.
“And now I will show you what is really a very interesting study, Mr. Windibank,” Holmes continued. “I think of writing another little monograph some of these days on the typewriter and its relation to crime. It is a subject to which I have devoted some little attention. I have here four letters which purport to come from the missing man. They are all typewritten. In each case, not only are the ‘e’s’ slurred and the ‘r’s’ tailless, but you will observe, if you care to use my magnifying lens, that the fourteen other characteristics to which I have alluded are there as well.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The man who entered was a sturdy, middle-sized fellow, some thirty years of age, clean-shaven, and sallow-skinned, with a bland, insinuating manner, and a pair of wonderfully sharp and penetrating grey eyes. He bowed with a slight, formal inclination of the head, and seated himself with the air of a man who is accustomed to getting his own way.

"Mr. James Windibank, I believe," said Holmes.

"That is my name, sir. I have had the pleasure of hearing of you, and I have no doubt that Miss Sutherland has also spoken of you. I must apologize for being a little late, but business has been very pressing."

"I have no doubt that it has," said Holmes, with a smile. "But I trust that it was not so pressing as to prevent you from coming at all."

"Certainly not. I was very much annoyed when I heard that Miss Sutherland had troubled you. I had hoped that the matter could be settled quietly within the family."

"I understand that she is a very impulsive young lady."

"She is, indeed. She has a way of doing things her own way, and I confess that I was not at all pleased when I heard of her visit to you. But, of course, I mind it less now that I know it was not the police who were involved."

"I am afraid that I cannot promise you much success in your search for Mr. Hosmer Angel," said Windibank, with a faint smile. "I should think it very difficult to find a man who does not exist."

"On the contrary," said Holmes, "I have every reason to believe that I shall succeed in discovering Mr. Hosmer Angel."

Windibank started violently, and his hand dropped from the table, scattering his gloves. "You are a very remarkable man," he said, with a forced laugh. "I am delighted to hear it."

"I have been looking at the typewritten letter which brought you here," said Holmes. "It is a very interesting document. You see, the individuality of a typewriter is as marked as that of a human being. The older the machine, the more peculiar are its characteristics."

"I should imagine that the office machine would show some wear," said Windibank, glancing keenly at Holmes. "It is a very old machine, and it has been used a great deal."

"Precisely," said Holmes. "And it is precisely because of that wear that I am able to tell you that the four letters which I have here, purporting to be from Mr. Hosmer Angel, were also written upon the same machine."

He laid the letters upon the table and handed Windibank a magnifying lens. "You will observe, if you look carefully, that the same peculiarities which you have just mentioned—the slurred 'e' and the defective 'r'—are to be found in these letters as well. In fact, there are fourteen other characteristics which are identical."

Windibank took the lens and examined the letters with a face which grew paler and paler as he did so. "I am very much obliged to you, Mr. Holmes," he said at last, with a forced smile. "I think I shall find your monograph on typewriters and crime very interesting indeed."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The man who entered was a sturdy, middle-sized fellow, some thirty years of age, clean-shaven, and sallow-skinned, with a bland, insinuating manner, and a pair of wonderfully sharp and penetrating grey eyes. He was dressed in a dark suit of good but unostentatious cut, and his manner, though quiet, was not without a certain air of assurance. He carried himself with a quiet confidence, and yet there was something in his bearing that suggested caution, as though he were accustomed to watching and waiting. He looked about the room with a quick, appraising glance, and then, with a slight nod of recognition, he advanced towards the fireplace, where he stood for a moment, his hands behind his back, his gaze fixed upon the glowing embers.

Holmes, who had been reclining in his chair with his eyes closed, opened them now and regarded the newcomer with a faint smile. "You are not a man to be easily surprised," he remarked, "but I fancy that you are not quite sure of your ground. You have come to consult me, no doubt, but I fancy that you are not quite certain whether I am the man to consult."

The stranger smiled, a little wearily. "You are very shrewd, sir," he said. "I have heard of you, and I have come to you because I have a problem that I cannot solve alone."

"Then sit down," said Holmes, "and let us hear what it is that puzzles you."

The man took a seat, and for a moment he sat in silence, his fingers drumming lightly on the arm of the chair. Then he looked up, and his grey eyes met Holmes's with a steady gaze. "I am a merchant," he said. "I deal in rare and valuable goods, and I have recently found myself in possession of a piece of jewelry that I believe to be of considerable value. But I have also found myself in possession of a mystery."

"A mystery, you say?" Holmes leaned forward slightly, his interest clearly piqued.

"Yes," the man replied. "The jewelry was given to me by a client, a man of considerable means and influence. He was a stranger to me, and yet he insisted upon the transaction being conducted in the utmost secrecy. I have no idea where he obtained the piece, but I have reason to believe that it may be connected to a crime."

"A crime?" I interjected, my curiosity now fully engaged.

The man nodded. "Yes, Mr. Watson. I believe that the jewelry may have been stolen, and that the man who gave it to me may have been involved in its theft. I have no proof, but I have a feeling, and I have learned to trust my feelings."

Holmes was silent for a moment, his eyes fixed upon the man before him. Then he said, "Very well. Let us hear more. Tell me everything you know, and we shall see what we can make of it."

events.title: The Accusation and Windibank's Collapse
detailed_summary: Windibank jumps up, grabs his hat, and dismisses Holmes's talk as fantastic, demanding Holmes catch the man if he can and inform him when done.
Holmes steps to the door, locks it, and suavely tells Windibank he *has* caught him.
Windibank turns pale and looks around frantically like a trapped rat.
Holmes tells him escape is impossible and the deception is transparent, chiding him for underestimating the simplicity of the case.
He instructs Windibank to sit down.
Windibank collapses into the chair, looking ghastly and sweating.
He stammers that his actions are not legally actionable.
Holmes agrees but condemns the act as exceptionally cruel, selfish, and heartless.
He proposes to recount the sequence of events for Windibank to correct if wrong.
Windibank sits huddled and crushed as Holmes begins his explanation.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Windibank sprang out of his chair and picked up his hat.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Now, let me just run over the course of events, and you will contradict me if I go wrong.”

events.text_segment:
Mr. Windibank sprang out of his chair and picked up his hat. “I cannot waste time over this sort of fantastic talk, Mr. Holmes,” he said. “If you can catch the man, catch him, and let me know when you have done it.”
“Certainly,” said Holmes, stepping over and turning the key in the door. “I let you know, then, that I have caught him!”
“What! where?” shouted Mr. Windibank, turning white to his lips and glancing about him like a rat in a trap.
“Oh, it won’t do—really it won’t,” said Holmes suavely. “There is no possible getting out of it, Mr. Windibank. It is quite too transparent, and it was a very bad compliment when you said that it was impossible for me to solve so simple a question. That’s right! Sit down and let us talk it over.”
Our visitor collapsed into a chair, with a ghastly face and a glitter of moisture on his brow. “It—it’s not actionable,” he stammered.
“I am very much afraid that it is not. But between ourselves, Windibank, it was as cruel and selfish and heartless a trick in a petty way as ever came before me. Now, let me just run over the course of events, and you will contradict me if I go wrong.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Mr. Windibank sprang out of his chair and picked up his hat. 'I have no patience with all this talk,' he said. 'You may call it fantastic, but I tell you I will have the man if I can, and I will let you know when I have done so.' He turned to go, but Holmes stepped to the door, locked it, and turned back with a suave smile. 'You have the man now,' he said. Windibank turned as pale as a sheet and looked wildly around the room like a rat in a trap. 'There is no escape for you,' said Holmes. 'The whole thing is as plain as day. You have underestimated the simplicity of the case.' He gestured to the chair. 'Sit down, Mr. Windibank.' The man obeyed, his face ghastly and his hands trembling. LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Mr. Windibank sprang out of his chair and picked up his hat. “I must be going,” he said, his voice trembling. “I have a train to catch.”

Sherlock Holmes leaned back in his chair, his eyes fixed on the man with a calculating gaze. “You are in a great hurry, Mr. Windibank,” he remarked. “But I wonder if you are running from something—or to it.”

Mr. Windibank hesitated, his hand tightening around the brim of his hat. “I have no idea what you mean, Mr. Holmes,” he replied, though his voice lacked conviction.

Holmes rose to his feet and walked slowly around the room, his fingers steepled behind his back. “You have been in London for some time now, yet you have not once visited your daughter. A man of your means and position would not neglect such a duty without reason.”

Mr. Windibank turned pale. “I have my reasons,” he muttered.

Holmes stepped closer. “Then let us find out what they are,” he said. “For I have a feeling that your daughter’s recent illness is not the only matter at hand.”

The man’s composure cracked, and he let out a sharp breath. “You know too much,” he said, his voice barely above a whisper.

Holmes smiled faintly. “I know just enough to make you talk, Mr. Windibank. Sit down, and let us have a little chat.”

With a reluctant sigh, Mr. Windibank lowered himself back into his chair, the tension in the room thickening as the game of wits began.

events.text_segment:
The man sat huddled up in his chair, with his head sunk upon his breast, like one who is utterly crushed. Holmes stuck his feet up on the corner of the mantelpiece and, leaning back with his hands in his pockets, began talking, rather to himself, as it seemed, than to us.
“The man married a woman very much older than himself for her money,” said he, “and he enjoyed the use of the money of the daughter as long as she lived with them. It was a considerable sum, for people in their position, and the loss of it would have made a serious difference. It was worth an effort to preserve it. The daughter was of a good, amiable disposition, but affectionate and warm-hearted in her ways, so that it was evident that with her fair personal advantages, and her little income, she would not be allowed to remain single long. Now her marriage would mean, of course, the loss of a hundred a year, so what does her stepfather do to prevent it? He takes the obvious course of keeping her at home and forbidding her to seek the company of people of her own age. But soon he found that that would not answer forever. She became restive, insisted upon her rights, and finally announced her positive intention of going to a certain ball. What does her clever stepfather do then? He conceives an idea more creditable to his head than to his heart. With the connivance and assistance of his wife he disguised himself, covered those keen eyes with tinted glasses, masked the face with a moustache and a pair of bushy whiskers, sunk that clear voice into an insinuating whisper, and doubly secure on account of the girl’s short sight, he appears as Mr. Hosmer Angel, and keeps off other lovers by making love himself.”
“It was only a joke at first,” groaned our visitor. “We never thought that she would have been so carried away.”
“Very likely not. However that may be, the young lady was very decidedly carried away, and, having quite made up her mind that her stepfather was in France, the suspicion of treachery never for an instant entered her mind. She was flattered by the gentleman’s attentions, and the effect was increased by the loudly expressed admiration of her mother. Then Mr. Angel began to call, for it was obvious that the matter should be pushed as far as it would go if a real effect were to be produced. There were meetings, and an engagement, which would finally secure the girl’s affections from turning towards anyone else. But the deception could not be kept up forever. These pretended journeys to France were rather cumbrous. The thing to do was clearly to bring the business to an end in such a dramatic manner that it would leave a permanent impression upon the young lady’s mind and prevent her from looking upon any other suitor for some time to come. Hence those vows of fidelity exacted upon a Testament, and hence also the allusions to a possibility of something happening on the very morning of the wedding. James Windibank wished Miss Sutherland to be so bound to Hosmer Angel, and so uncertain as to his fate, that for ten years to come, at any rate, she would not listen to another man. As far as the church door he brought her, and then, as he could go no farther, he conveniently vanished away by the old trick of stepping in at one door of a four-wheeler and out at the other. I think that was the chain of events, Mr. Windibank!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The man sat huddled up in his chair, with his head sunk upon his breast, like one who is utterly crushed. His face was deathly pale, and his hands trembled as he twisted and untwisted a small piece of paper in his grasp. I glanced at Sherlock Holmes, who, leaning back in his armchair, was whirling a match between his fingers and looking at our visitor with the most perfect indifference.

"You have come to us, Mr. Windibank," said he, "because you are in trouble."

The man gave a low groan and pressed his hands to his temples.

"I have," he said. "I have come because I have no one else to go to."

"You have come to the right place," said Holmes. "We are always ready to help those who are in trouble. But I must warn you that we are not always ready to condone those who are in the wrong."

"I am not in the wrong," said Mr. Windibank, with a sudden burst of energy. "I am not. I have done nothing but what I thought was right."

"Ah!" said Holmes, with a smile. "That is a very common delusion. But let us hear your story."

Mr. Windibank looked at us with a hunted, despairing look, and then, with a deep sigh, he began to speak. He told us how he had married an older woman for her money, and how he had benefited from her daughter's income as long as she lived at home. He told us how the loss of this income would be a serious matter, and how he had done everything in his power to retain it. He told us how the daughter was a most amiable and affectionate girl, and how her advantages in person and manner made it likely that she would not remain long in the single state. He told us how her marriage would mean the loss of the income, and how he had tried to keep her isolated from the world. He told us how, when she insisted upon her rights, and upon going to the ball, he had devised a plan with the help of his wife. He told us how he had disguised himself as Hosmer Angel, with tinted glasses, whiskers, and an altered voice, and how he had wooed her himself to prevent other suitors. He told us how the scheme had started as a joke, and how he had not expected her to be so taken with him. He told us how Miss Sutherland, believing her stepfather was in France, had never suspected treachery, and had been flattered by 'Angel's' attention and her mother's vocal approval. He told us how Angel had begun to call, and how the meetings had led to an engagement to secure her affections. He told us how the deception could not last, and how the fake trips to France had become cumbersome. He told us how the goal had become to end the affair dramatically, to leave a lasting impression, and to prevent her from considering other suitors for years. He told us how this explained the vows of fidelity and the hints of catastrophe on the wedding morning. He told us how he had aimed to bind her to Angel's memory and uncertain fate. He told us how he had accompanied her to the church door, and then had vanished using the trick of entering one door of a four-wheeler cab and exiting the other. And then, with a final groan, he collapsed into his chair, his story told.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The man sat huddled up in his chair, with his head sunk upon his breast, like one who is utterly crushed. His clothes were in disorder, his face was haggard and worn, and his hands trembled as he sat there. I had seen many men in my time, but never one who gave so plainly the impression of a soul in torment. I turned to Sherlock Holmes, who was standing by the window, and I saw that his keen eyes were fixed upon the stranger with the same intensity of interest which I had observed so often in the past. 

"What do you make of him, Holmes?" I asked in a low voice. 

"He is a man who has been through a terrible ordeal," Holmes replied, "and one which has left its mark upon him. His manner is that of a man who is afraid, yet he is not afraid of the man who sits opposite to him. No, he is afraid of something else. Something which has followed him here."

I looked at the other man, who was now sitting upright, his eyes fixed upon the stranger with a look of cold and calculating interest. He was a tall, thin man, with a pale face and a sharp, aquiline nose. His clothes were of the best quality, and his manner was that of a man of position and breeding. Yet there was something in his bearing which suggested that he was not to be trifled with. 

"And who is he?" I asked. 

"That is a question which I am about to ask him," Holmes replied, stepping forward and taking a seat at the table. "Mr. James Mortimer, I believe?"

The tall man nodded. 

"And you are the gentleman who has sent for us, I presume?"

"That is correct," said Mr. Mortimer. "I have sent for you, Mr. Holmes, because I have a case which I believe to be of some interest to you."

"Indeed?" Holmes leaned forward slightly. "I am always interested in cases of a peculiar nature."

"This is peculiar, I can assure you," said Mr. Mortimer. "It concerns a man named Charles Augustus Milverton."

Holmes's eyes gleamed with interest. 

"Milverton," he said. "A name which I have heard before. A man of some notoriety, I believe."

"He is a man of considerable notoriety," said Mr. Mortimer. "A man who has made a fortune by the sale of other people's secrets."

"Ah!" said Holmes. "A most unscrupulous profession."

"It is a profession which has brought him into conflict with many people," said Mr. Mortimer. "And it is a profession which has now brought him into conflict with me."

"Indeed?" said Holmes. "And what is it that he has done to you?"

"He has threatened to publish a letter which would bring me into great discredit," said Mr. Mortimer. "A letter which I had written to a lady of high position, in which I expressed my admiration for her."

"Ah!" said Holmes. "A love letter, then."

"It was not a love letter," said Mr. Mortimer. "It was a letter of apology."

"I see," said Holmes. "And what is it that you wish me to do?"

"I wish you to prevent the letter from being published," said Mr. Mortimer. "And I wish you to bring Milverton to justice."

"A most interesting case," said Holmes. "I shall be happy to assist you, Mr. Mortimer."

"I am glad to hear it," said Mr. Mortimer. "I have no doubt that you will be able to do what I have been unable to do."

"I shall do my best," said Holmes. "And I shall not rest until the matter is resolved."

With that, the meeting was concluded, and Mr. Mortimer left the room, leaving behind him the man who had sat huddled up in his chair, still trembling with fear and despair.

events.title: Windibank's Defiance, Escape, and Holmes's Final Thoughts
detailed_summary: Windibank regains some composure and rises with a sneer.
He tells Holmes that if he's so sharp, he should realize Holmes is now breaking the law by locking the door (assault and illegal constraint), while Windibank himself has done nothing actionable.
Holmes unlocks and opens the door, agreeing the law can't touch Windibank but asserting he deserves punishment more than anyone.
He suggests if Miss Sutherland had a brother or friend, they should whip Windibank.
Seeing Windibank's sneer, Holmes flushes with anger, notes a nearby hunting crop, and moves towards it, intending to use it.
Before Holmes can grab it, Windibank bolts, clattering down the stairs and banging the hall door.
They see him running away at top speed.
Holmes laughs, calls Windibank a cold-blooded scoundrel destined for the gallows, and remarks the case had interesting aspects.
Watson asks for clarification on Holmes's reasoning.
Holmes explains it was obvious Angel needed a strong motive and the stepfather was the sole beneficiary.
The fact that one man was always present when the other was absent was suggestive.
The disguise elements (glasses, voice, whiskers) and the typewritten signature (implying familiar handwriting) confirmed his suspicions.
These facts all pointed in one direction.
To verify, he contacted Windibank's firm (Westhouse & Marbank), sending them Angel's description stripped of disguise elements.
He wrote to Windibank at his business address, ensuring the reply would be typewritten.
Windibank's typewritten reply matched the flaws in Angel's letters.
The firm confirmed the description matched their employee, James Windibank.
Asked about Miss Sutherland, Holmes states he won't tell her the truth, quoting a Persian saying (attributed to Hafiz) about the danger of snatching a delusion from a woman.

events.text_segment:
Our visitor had recovered something of his assurance while Holmes had been talking, and he rose from his chair now with a cold sneer upon his pale face.
“It may be so, or it may not, Mr. Holmes,” said he, “but if you are so very sharp you ought to be sharp enough to know that it is you who are breaking the law now, and not me. I have done nothing actionable from the first, but as long as you keep that door locked you lay yourself open to an action for assault and illegal constraint.”
“The law cannot, as you say, touch you,” said Holmes, unlocking and throwing open the door, “yet there never was a man who deserved punishment more. If the young lady has a brother or a friend, he ought to lay a whip across your shoulders. By Jove!” he continued, flushing up at the sight of the bitter sneer upon the man’s face, “it is not part of my duties to my client, but here’s a hunting crop handy, and I think I shall just treat myself to—” He took two swift steps to the whip, but before he could grasp it there was a wild clatter of steps upon the stairs, the heavy hall door banged, and from the window we could see Mr. James Windibank running at the top of his speed down the road.
“There’s a cold-blooded scoundrel!” said Holmes, laughing, as he threw himself down into his chair once more. “That fellow will rise from crime to crime until he does something very bad, and ends on a gallows. The case has, in some respects, been not entirely devoid of interest.”
“I cannot now entirely see all the steps of your reasoning,” I remarked.
“Well, of course it was obvious from the first that this Mr. Hosmer Angel must have some strong object for his curious conduct, and it was equally clear that the only man who really profited by the incident, as far as we could see, was the stepfather. Then the fact that the two men were never together, but that the one always appeared when the other was away, was suggestive. So were the tinted spectacles and the curious voice, which both hinted at a disguise, as did the bushy whiskers. My suspicions were all confirmed by his peculiar action in typewriting his signature, which, of course, inferred that his handwriting was so familiar to her that she would recognise even the smallest sample of it. You see all these isolated facts, together with many minor ones, all pointed in the same direction.”
“And how did you verify them?”
“Having once spotted my man, it was easy to get corroboration. I knew the firm for which this man worked. Having taken the printed description. I eliminated everything from it which could be the result of a disguise—the whiskers, the glasses, the voice, and I sent it to the firm, with a request that they would inform me whether it answered to the description of any of their travellers. I had already noticed the peculiarities of the typewriter, and I wrote to the man himself at his business address asking him if he would come here. As I expected, his reply was typewritten and revealed the same trivial but characteristic defects. The same post brought me a letter from Westhouse & Marbank, of Fenchurch Street, to say that the description tallied in every respect with that of their employé, James Windibank. Voilà tout!”
“And Miss Sutherland?”
“If I tell her she will not believe me. You may remember the old Persian saying, ‘There is danger for him who taketh the tiger cub, and danger also for whoso snatches a delusion from a woman.’ There is as much sense in Hafiz as in Horace, and as much knowledge of the world.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Our visitor had recovered something of his assurance while Holmes had been talking, and he rose from his chair now with a cold sneer upon his pale face. 

"If you are so sharp," he said, "you should know that you are now breaking the law by locking the door. You are committing an assault and an illegal constraint, while I have done nothing which can be made actionable."

Holmes slowly turned the key in the lock and flung the door open. 

"The law may not touch you," he said, "but I think that you deserve punishment more than any man I have met. If Miss Sutherland had a brother or a friend, I should say that they had a right to whip you."

He stepped forward, his face flushed with anger, and his eyes fixed upon a hunting-crop which lay across the back of a chair. 

But before he could reach it, Windibank had darted past him, clattered down the stairs, and banged the hall door behind him. We heard his heavy boots upon the pavement and the rattle of a carriage as he drove away at top speed.

"A cold-blooded scoundrel, and one who will swing yet," said Holmes, laughing. "This case has had some interesting points, has it not?"

"Indeed," I answered, "but I should be glad to know how you arrived at your conclusion."

"Well, I will tell you. It was obvious from the first that the stepfather was the only possible motive. The man was the sole beneficiary. The fact that one was always present when the other was absent was suggestive. The disguise, the glasses, the voice, the whiskers, and the typewritten signature, which showed that the hand was familiar with the machine, all pointed in one direction. I sent to Westhouse & Marbank, the firm with which he is connected, a description of the man who had called as Angel, but with the disguise removed. I wrote to Windibank himself at his business address, and I took care that the reply should be typewritten. The reply was in the same hand as the letters. The firm confirmed that the description was of their clerk, James Windibank."

"And Miss Sutherland?"

"I shall not tell her the truth," said Holmes. "There is a Persian saying which runs, 'The bird of the desert is the gazelle, but the bird of the soul is the delusion.' I have no wish to snatch the gazelle from her, even though it may be a delusion."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Our visitor had recovered something of his assurance while Holmes had been talking, and he rose from his chair now with a cold sneer upon his pale face. He was a tall, thin man, with a long, angular face and a pair of keen, restless eyes that seemed to take in everything at once. His manner was haughty, and there was a certain air of defiance in his bearing which suggested that he was not a man to be easily cowed. He stood for a moment, his hand resting on the back of the chair, and then turned to Holmes with a slight inclination of the head.

"I have said all that I have to say, Mr. Holmes," he remarked. "I trust that you will find my statement of sufficient interest to warrant your attention."

"Indeed, I do," said Holmes, rising to his feet and lighting a fresh cigar. "You have given us a most singular narrative, and I confess that I am much intrigued. I should be very glad to know the outcome of your little mystery."

The man looked at him for a moment in silence, and then with a sudden movement he turned and walked to the door. "I have no more to say," he repeated. "I have given you the facts as I know them. What you make of them is your affair."

"One moment," said Holmes, stepping forward. "There is one point which I should like to clear up before you go. You spoke of a letter which was delivered to you last night. Might I ask what it contained?"

The man hesitated for a moment, and then with a shrug of his shoulders he turned and walked out of the room. The door closed behind him with a sharp snap, and we were left alone together.

"Well, Watson," said Holmes, seating himself once more and taking up his pipe, "what do you make of that?"

I looked at him in some surprise. "I confess that I am at a loss," I said. "The man is clearly in some trouble, but I cannot see what it is."

"Nor I," said Holmes, "but I have no doubt that we shall soon find out. The letter which he received last night is obviously of the greatest importance. I have a feeling that it will lead us to some very strange and unexpected developments."

"And the man himself?" I asked. "He is certainly a singular character."

"Yes, he is. He is a man of action, and a man of mystery. He is not the sort of man to come to a consulting room unless he is driven to it by necessity. And yet, he has come, and he has told us something of his story. That is a beginning."

"But what is the story?" I asked. "He has given us a few facts, but they seem to me to be disconnected and without meaning."

"Precisely," said Holmes. "That is the art of the thing. He has given us the facts, but he has not given us the interpretation. That is what we must supply."

I looked at him in some surprise. "You mean to say that you think he is deliberately withholding something from us?"

"I think that he is not telling us the whole truth," said Holmes. "He is a man of caution, and he is not likely to reveal all his cards at once. But I have no doubt that we shall soon have the opportunity to test his story."

"And how do you propose to do that?" I asked.

"By following the trail of the letter," said Holmes. "If we can find out what it contained, we shall be in a position to understand the whole mystery."

"And if we cannot?" I asked.

"Then we shall have to find another way," said Holmes. "But I have no doubt that we shall succeed."

He rose to his feet and walked to the window, looking out into the street. "The man is gone," he said. "But he will return. I have no doubt of that. And when he does, we shall have the opportunity to ask him a few more questions."

I looked at him in some surprise. "You are very confident, Holmes," I said. "But I must confess that I am not so sure."

"Ah, but you are not a detective, Watson," said Holmes. "You do not see the signs as I do. The man is not finished with us. He will return, and when he does, we shall have the opportunity to learn the truth."

I could not help but smile at his confidence. "Very well, Holmes," I said. "Let us hope that you are right."

"I always am," said Holmes, with a smile. "And now, Watson, I think we had better go out and take a little walk. There is a certain post office which I should like to visit."

"And what do you hope to find there?" I asked.

"The letter, of course," said Holmes. "And perhaps the man who delivered it."

"And if we find neither?"

"Then we shall have to find another way," said Holmes. "But I have no doubt that we shall succeed."

And with that, he turned and walked out of the room, leaving me to follow in his wake.

events.title: Summons to Boscombe Valley
detailed_summary: Watson and his wife receive a telegram from Sherlock Holmes during breakfast.
Holmes requests Watson's company for a couple of days to investigate the Boscombe Valley tragedy in the west of England, departing from Paddington.
Watson expresses hesitation due to his patient list, but his wife encourages him to go for a change of scenery and because of his interest in Holmes's cases.
Reminded of the benefits gained from a previous case, Watson agrees and rushes to pack.
Leveraging his past military experience, Watson packs quickly and arrives at Paddington Station within half an hour.
He finds Holmes already there, identifiable by his distinctive tall figure, grey cloak, and cap.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We were seated at breakfast one morning, my wife and I, when the maid brought in a telegram.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Sherlock Holmes was pacing up and down the platform, his tall, gaunt figure made even gaunter and taller by his long grey travelling-cloak and close-fitting cloth cap.

events.text_segment:
We were seated at breakfast one morning, my wife and I, when the maid brought in a telegram. It was from Sherlock Holmes and ran in this way:
“Have you a couple of days to spare? Have just been wired for from the west of England in connection with Boscombe Valley tragedy. Shall be glad if you will come with me. Air and scenery perfect. Leave Paddington by the 11:15.”
“What do you say, dear?” said my wife, looking across at me. “Will you go?”
“I really don’t know what to say. I have a fairly long list at present.”
“Oh, Anstruther would do your work for you. You have been looking a little pale lately. I think that the change would do you good, and you are always so interested in Mr. Sherlock Holmes’ cases.”
“I should be ungrateful if I were not, seeing what I gained through one of them,” I answered. “But if I am to go, I must pack at once, for I have only half an hour.”
My experience of camp life in Afghanistan had at least had the effect of making me a prompt and ready traveller. My wants were few and simple, so that in less than the time stated I was in a cab with my valise, rattling away to Paddington Station. Sherlock Holmes was pacing up and down the platform, his tall, gaunt figure made even gaunter and taller by his long grey travelling-cloak and close-fitting cloth cap.

Important case. Boscombe Valley tragedy. Shall want your help." That was all. I read it over and over, for it seemed to me that the very brevity of the message conveyed a weight of meaning. My wife, glancing at it over my shoulder, said, "You had better go, my dear. You have been cooped up here for weeks, and it will do you good to have a change. Besides, you know how interested you always are in Mr. Holmes's cases." I was about to make some demur, for I had a long list of patients and a heavy round to make, but the thought of the Boscombe Valley mystery, and the certainty that I should be in the company of the keenest brain in Europe, carried all before it. I had, in fact, already made up my mind. I rose at once, and with the rapidity of a soldier who has learned to pack under pressure, I had my bag ready within half an hour. I found Holmes already at Paddington Station, lounging on a bench, his tall figure wrapped in a grey cloak, a cap pulled down over his brows, and a newspaper in his hand. He looked up as I approached, and his keen eyes sparkled with their usual animation."}

Holmes has summoned me for a matter of some importance.' 'You always go to him,' she said with a smile. 'I suppose it is the nature of your friendship.' I kissed her and hurried out, taking the hansom that waited at the door. The Northumberland Hotel was not far from Baker Street, and I arrived within ten minutes. Holmes was pacing the small sitting room, his long, thin frame moving with restless energy. 'You are just in time, Watson,' he said, not pausing in his stride. 'A most peculiar case has presented itself. A man was found this morning in a locked room, dead, with no sign of forced entry or exit. The only clue is a single playing card, the ace of hearts, placed on his chest.' I looked at the card in his hand. 'A locked room mystery, then?' 'Indeed,' he said, his eyes gleaming. 'And I suspect it will prove most intriguing.'

events.title: Holmes Briefs Watson on the Train
detailed_summary: Holmes expresses gratitude for Watson's presence, valuing his reliability over potentially biased local help, and asks him to secure seats while he gets tickets.
They share a carriage filled with Holmes's papers, which he studies intensely until past Reading.
Holmes gathers the papers and asks Watson if he knows about the case.
Watson admits ignorance, having not seen newspapers recently.
Holmes explains the London press coverage is limited and he's reviewed recent papers.
He describes the case as deceptively simple yet extremely difficult, noting that singularity is usually a clue, while featureless crimes are harder to solve.
Holmes confirms it's considered a murder and a strong case exists against the victim's son, though he reserves judgment.

He provides background: Boscombe Valley is near Ross, Herefordshire. Mr. John Turner, wealthy from Australia, owns the land. Mr. Charles McCarthy, also ex-Australian and known to Turner from the colonies, rents Hatherley farm from him.

The two men, both widowers with a child of similar age (an 18-year-old son for McCarthy, a daughter for Turner), maintained equality despite the landlord-tenant relationship and led retired lives, avoiding local society but enjoying racing.
Holmes details the events of Monday, June 3rd: McCarthy left home around 3 PM for Boscombe Pool after telling his servant he had an important appointment.
Two witnesses, an unnamed old woman and Turner's gamekeeper William Crowder, saw McCarthy walking alone towards the Pool.
Crowder also saw McCarthy's son, James, following with a gun shortly after.

Patience Moran, a 14-year-old girl picking flowers near the wooded pool, saw McCarthy and his son engaged in a violent quarrel; she heard shouting and saw the son raise his hand as if to strike, prompting her to flee.
Shortly after she told her mother, young McCarthy arrived at the lodge, agitated, missing his gun and hat, with blood on his hand and sleeve, reporting his father's death.
The body was found by the pool with severe head injuries consistent with blows from the butt-end of James's gun, which lay nearby.
James was arrested, an inquest returned a 'wilful murder' verdict, and magistrates referred the case to the Assizes.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “It is really very good of you to come, Watson,” said he.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Those are the main facts of the case as they came out before the coroner and the police-court.”

events.text_segment:
“It is really very good of you to come, Watson,” said he. “It makes a considerable difference to me, having someone with me on whom I can thoroughly rely. Local aid is always either worthless or else biassed. If you will keep the two corner seats I shall get the tickets.”
We had the carriage to ourselves save for an immense litter of papers which Holmes had brought with him. Among these he rummaged and read, with intervals of note-taking and of meditation, until we were past Reading. Then he suddenly rolled them all into a gigantic ball and tossed them up onto the rack.
“Have you heard anything of the case?” he asked.
“Not a word. I have not seen a paper for some days.”
“The London press has not had very full accounts. I have just been looking through all the recent papers in order to master the particulars. It seems, from what I gather, to be one of those simple cases which are so extremely difficult.”
“That sounds a little paradoxical.”
“But it is profoundly true. Singularity is almost invariably a clue. The more featureless and commonplace a crime is, the more difficult it is to bring it home. In this case, however, they have established a very serious case against the son of the murdered man.”
“It is a murder, then?”
“Well, it is conjectured to be so. I shall take nothing for granted until I have the opportunity of looking personally into it. I will explain the state of things to you, as far as I have been able to understand it, in a very few words.
“Boscombe Valley is a country district not very far from Ross, in Herefordshire. The largest landed proprietor in that part is a Mr. John Turner, who made his money in Australia and returned some years ago to the old country. One of the farms which he held, that of Hatherley, was let to Mr. Charles McCarthy, who was also an ex-Australian. The men had known each other in the colonies, so that it was not unnatural that when they came to settle down they should do so as near each other as possible. Turner was apparently the richer man, so McCarthy became his tenant but still remained, it seems, upon terms of perfect equality, as they were frequently together. McCarthy had one son, a lad of eighteen, and Turner had an only daughter of the same age, but neither of them had wives living. They appear to have avoided the society of the neighbouring English families and to have led retired lives, though both the McCarthys were fond of sport and were frequently seen at the race-meetings of the neighbourhood. McCarthy kept two servants—a man and a girl. Turner had a considerable household, some half-dozen at the least. That is as much as I have been able to gather about the families. Now for the facts.
“On June 3rd, that is, on Monday last, McCarthy left his house at Hatherley about three in the afternoon and walked down to the Boscombe Pool, which is a small lake formed by the spreading out of the stream which runs down the Boscombe Valley. He had been out with his serving-man in the morning at Ross, and he had told the man that he must hurry, as he had an appointment of importance to keep at three. From that appointment he never came back alive.
“From Hatherley Farmhouse to the Boscombe Pool is a quarter of a mile, and two people saw him as he passed over this ground. One was an old woman, whose name is not mentioned, and the other was William Crowder, a game-keeper in the employ of Mr. Turner. Both these witnesses depose that Mr. McCarthy was walking alone. The game-keeper adds that within a few minutes of his seeing Mr. McCarthy pass he had seen his son, Mr. James McCarthy, going the same way with a gun under his arm. To the best of his belief, the father was actually in sight at the time, and the son was following him. He thought no more of the matter until he heard in the evening of the tragedy that had occurred.
“The two McCarthys were seen after the time when William Crowder, the game-keeper, lost sight of them. The Boscombe Pool is thickly wooded round, with just a fringe of grass and of reeds round the edge. A girl of fourteen, Patience Moran, who is the daughter of the lodge-keeper of the Boscombe Valley estate, was in one of the woods picking flowers. She states that while she was there she saw, at the border of the wood and close by the lake, Mr. McCarthy and his son, and that they appeared to be having a violent quarrel. She heard Mr. McCarthy the elder using very strong language to his son, and she saw the latter raise up his hand as if to strike his father. She was so frightened by their violence that she ran away and told her mother when she reached home that she had left the two McCarthys quarrelling near Boscombe Pool, and that she was afraid that they were going to fight. She had hardly said the words when young Mr. McCarthy came running up to the lodge to say that he had found his father dead in the wood, and to ask for the help of the lodge-keeper. He was much excited, without either his gun or his hat, and his right hand and sleeve were observed to be stained with fresh blood. On following him they found the dead body stretched out upon the grass beside the pool. The head had been beaten in by repeated blows of some heavy and blunt weapon. The injuries were such as might very well have been inflicted by the butt-end of his son’s gun, which was found lying on the grass within a few paces of the body. Under these circumstances the young man was instantly arrested, and a verdict of ‘wilful murder’ having been returned at the inquest on Tuesday, he was on Wednesday brought before the magistrates at Ross, who have referred the case to the next Assizes. Those are the main facts of the case as they came out before the coroner and the police-court.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“It is really very good of you to come, Watson,” said he.

I looked at my friend with some surprise, for I had not expected to be summoned so suddenly. The room was in its usual state of disorder, with papers and books scattered about, and the scent of tobacco still lingering in the air. Sherlock Holmes sat in his armchair, his long, thin fingers steepled before his face, his eyes fixed upon the fire with an expression of deep thought.

“I received a telegram this morning,” he said, “from a gentleman named Mr. James Harcourt. He is a wealthy industrialist from the north of England, and he is in a state of considerable distress. He has asked for my assistance in a matter of the utmost urgency. I thought you might care to accompany me, as I believe you will find the case of some interest.”

I was always ready to accompany my friend on his investigations, and I readily assented. Within an hour we were on our way to the station, and by the evening we were in the city of Leeds, where Mr. Harcourt awaited us.

He was a man of about fifty, with a pale, anxious face and a manner that betrayed his unease. He greeted us with a nervous smile and led us into a private room at the hotel where he was staying.

“I am in a most peculiar and alarming situation,” he said, as he poured out a glass of brandy for each of us. “I have been receiving a series of letters, each more threatening than the last. The first was merely a warning, but the last contained a photograph of my daughter, Miss Harcourt, and a demand for a large sum of money. I have not yet sent the money, but I am afraid that if I do not act quickly, something terrible may happen.”

Holmes leaned forward, his eyes gleaming with interest. “You have not yet sent the money, then?”

“No,” said Mr. Harcourt. “I have been trying to find out who is behind this. I have made inquiries, but I have found nothing. The letters were all written in a different hand, and the postmarks were from various parts of the country. I have no idea who is responsible.”

Holmes was silent for a moment, then he said, “And the photograph? What did it show?”

Mr. Harcourt hesitated, then handed him a small envelope. Holmes took it and opened it, glancing at the contents before passing it to me. It was a photograph of a young woman, dressed in a simple black dress, standing in a garden. Her face was pale and drawn, and there was a look of fear in her eyes.

“This is my daughter,” said Mr. Harcourt. “She is twenty-two years old, and she has been missing for nearly a week. I have searched everywhere for her, but I have found no trace of her. I am afraid that she has been taken by the same person who is sending me these letters.”

Holmes was silent for a moment, then he said, “And what is your daughter like? What is her character?”

“She is a quiet, reserved girl,” said Mr. Harcourt. “She has always been a little shy, but she is intelligent and well-educated. She has no friends outside of the family, and she has never been known to associate with anyone who might have a grudge against me.”

Holmes nodded. “And what is your business, Mr. Harcourt?”

“I am a manufacturer of textiles,” said Mr. Harcourt. “I have a large factory in Leeds, and I have been in business for many years. I have no enemies, as far as I know.”

Holmes was silent for a moment, then he said, “I think I may be able to help you, Mr. Harcourt. I will need to make a few inquiries, and I will also need to speak to your daughter, if she is still alive.”

Mr. Harcourt looked at him with a mixture of hope and fear. “If she is still alive,” he said. “But what if she is not?”

Holmes looked at him steadily. “Then we must do all we can to find out what has happened to her.”

The next morning, Holmes and I set out to visit the Harcourt factory. It was a large, imposing building, with a long row of windows that looked out over the city. The workers were already at their posts, and the air was filled with the sound of machinery and the scent of cotton and dye.

Mr. Harcourt introduced us to his foreman, a gruff, middle-aged man named Mr. Simpson, who showed us around the factory. As we walked through the various departments, Holmes was clearly making mental notes of everything he saw. He asked questions about the workers, the machinery, and the production process, and he seemed particularly interested in the security measures in place.

After the tour, we returned to the office, where Holmes asked to see the books and records. He spent several hours poring over them, occasionally making notes in a small notebook. I watched him with some amusement, for I had seen him do this many times before, and I knew that he was searching for some clue that would lead him to the truth.

That evening, we returned to the hotel, and Holmes was in a state of deep thought. I asked him what he had discovered, but he merely smiled and said, “I have a theory, Watson, but I must test it before I can be certain.”

The next day, we visited the Harcourt home in the suburbs of Leeds. It was a large, stately house, with a well-kept garden and a view of the countryside. The servants were polite but reserved, and the atmosphere was one of quiet tension.

Miss Harcourt was not at home, but her mother, a tall, elegant woman with a pale, anxious face, received us in the drawing room. She was clearly distressed, and she spoke in a low, trembling voice.

“My daughter has always been a quiet girl,” she said. “She has never been known to associate with anyone outside of the family. I cannot imagine who would want to harm her.”

Holmes was silent for a moment, then he said, “And what is your daughter’s opinion of her father’s business?”

“She is very proud of it,” said Mrs. Harcourt. “She has always admired her father’s success, and she has often spoken of the importance of hard work and honesty.”

Holmes nodded. “And what is your opinion of the business?”

“I think it is a great success,” said Mrs. Harcourt. “But I must confess that I have never been particularly interested in the details of it.”

Holmes was silent for a moment, then he said, “I think I may be able to help you, Mrs. Harcourt. I will need to make a few inquiries, and I will also need to speak to your daughter, if she is still alive.”

Mrs. Harcourt looked at him with a mixture of hope and fear. “If she is still alive,” she said. “But what if she is not?”

Holmes looked at her steadily. “Then we must do all we can to find out what has happened to her.”

The next day, Holmes and I set out to visit the Harcourt factory again. This time, we were accompanied by a constable, who had been sent by the local police. Holmes had requested his presence, and I suspected that he was about to make an arrest.

As we entered the factory, Holmes led us to a small room at the back of the building. The door was locked, but Holmes produced a small key from his pocket and opened it. Inside, we found a young woman, Miss Harcourt, who was clearly in a state of shock. She was pale and trembling, but she was alive.

Holmes turned to the constable. “This is the girl,” he said. “She has been held here for nearly a week, and she has been threatened with death if her father did not send the money.”

The constable looked at her in astonishment. “Who did this?” he asked.

Holmes turned to a man who was standing in the doorway. “This is Mr. Simpson, the foreman,” he said. “He is the one who has been sending the letters and holding your daughter captive.”

Mr. Simpson looked at us in disbelief. “I don’t know what you are talking about,” he said. “I have done nothing wrong.”

Holmes stepped forward. “You have been sending threatening letters to your employer, demanding money under the threat of harm to his daughter. You have been holding her here in this room, and you have been using her as a pawn in your scheme.”

Mr. Simpson looked at us in horror. “I would never do such a thing,” he said. “I have always been loyal to Mr. Harcourt.”

Holmes looked at him steadily. “You have been trying to blackmail your employer, Mr. Simpson. You have been using your position of trust to gain access to the factory and to the family home. You have been using your knowledge of the business to threaten Mr. Harcourt with ruin if he did not pay you the money you demanded.”

Mr. Simpson looked at us in disbelief. “I would never do such a thing,” he said. “I have always been loyal to Mr. Harcourt.”

Holmes

events.title: Holmes on Evidence and Observation
detailed_summary: Watson remarks on the seemingly conclusive circumstantial evidence against James McCarthy.
Holmes cautions that circumstantial evidence can be deceptive, appearing different depending on one's perspective, but concedes the case looks grave for the young man.
He mentions that some locals, including Miss Turner, believe in James's innocence and have hired Lestrade, who, finding the case puzzling, referred it to Holmes.
Watson expresses concern that the case's obviousness offers little chance for Holmes to gain credit.
Holmes counters that obvious facts are often deceptive and hopes to uncover facts missed by Lestrade.
He asserts his unique methods will either confirm or destroy Lestrade's theory.

As an example of his observation and inference, Holmes deduces that Watson's bedroom window is on the right side based on the unevenness of his shave, concluding Watson shaves by sunlight which illuminates one side of his face more than the other.
Holmes states this method is his specialty and might prove useful in the current investigation.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I could hardly imagine a more damning case,” I remarked.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Therein lies my métier, and it is just possible that it may be of some service in the investigation which lies before us.

events.text_segment:
“I could hardly imagine a more damning case,” I remarked. “If ever circumstantial evidence pointed to a criminal it does so here.”
“Circumstantial evidence is a very tricky thing,” answered Holmes thoughtfully. “It may seem to point very straight to one thing, but if you shift your own point of view a little, you may find it pointing in an equally uncompromising manner to something entirely different. It must be confessed, however, that the case looks exceedingly grave against the young man, and it is very possible that he is indeed the culprit. There are several people in the neighbourhood, however, and among them Miss Turner, the daughter of the neighbouring landowner, who believe in his innocence, and who have retained Lestrade, whom you may recollect in connection with the Study in Scarlet, to work out the case in his interest. Lestrade, being rather puzzled, has referred the case to me, and hence it is that two middle-aged gentlemen are flying westward at fifty miles an hour instead of quietly digesting their breakfasts at home.”
“I am afraid,” said I, “that the facts are so obvious that you will find little credit to be gained out of this case.”
“There is nothing more deceptive than an obvious fact,” he answered, laughing. “Besides, we may chance to hit upon some other obvious facts which may have been by no means obvious to Mr. Lestrade. You know me too well to think that I am boasting when I say that I shall either confirm or destroy his theory by means which he is quite incapable of employing, or even of understanding. To take the first example to hand, I very clearly perceive that in your bedroom the window is upon the right-hand side, and yet I question whether Mr. Lestrade would have noted even so self-evident a thing as that.”
“How on earth—”
“My dear fellow, I know you well. I know the military neatness which characterises you. You shave every morning, and in this season you shave by the sunlight; but since your shaving is less and less complete as we get farther back on the left side, until it becomes positively slovenly as we get round the angle of the jaw, it is surely very clear that that side is less illuminated than the other. I could not imagine a man of your habits looking at himself in an equal light and being satisfied with such a result. I only quote this as a trivial example of observation and inference. Therein lies my métier, and it is just possible that it may be of some service in the investigation which lies before us.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
I could hardly imagine a more damning case," I remarked. "The evidence is all against the young man. The murder was committed in his own house, the weapon is his, the motive is there, and the opportunity was perfect."

"Circumstantial evidence, my dear Watson," said Holmes, "is a very tricky thing. It may seem to point very straight to one thing, but if your own mind is biased, it may suggest something else. The truth may lie in a different direction entirely. Still, I must confess that the case does look very grave for James McCarthy."

"But surely, Holmes, you do not mean to say that he is not guilty?"

"I say nothing of the kind. I merely observe that the case is not yet closed. There are some people in the village, and notably Miss Turner, who have a strong belief in McCarthy's innocence. They have taken the matter up with Lestrade, who, finding it a most perplexing one, has referred it to me."

"Then you will take it up?"

"I shall do so with the greatest interest. I confess that I am not so sure as you seem to be that the case is so clear-cut. The more obvious the facts, the more likely they are to be misleading."

"But if the facts are so plain, what can you do?"

"I may be able to do a great deal. I may be able to show that the facts are not so plain as they seem. I may be able to show that the man is not guilty after all."

"But how?"

"By the use of my own peculiar methods. I shall either confirm or destroy Lestrade's theory."

"And what are these peculiar methods?"

"They are methods of observation and deduction. For example, I have just deduced that your bedroom window is on the right-hand side."

"How?"

"By the unevenness of your shave. You have shaved in the morning, and the light has been on your left cheek. You have not shaved as carefully on the right side."

"That is true."

"And that is how I know."

"But what has that to do with the case?"

"It is merely an example of the kind of observation which may be of use to us in the present inquiry."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“I could hardly imagine a more damning case,” I remarked. “The evidence is overwhelming, and the motive is clear. I fail to see how the accused could possibly escape the consequences of his actions.”

Sherlock Holmes leaned back in his chair, his long, thin fingers steepled before his lips. The firelight flickered across his sharp features, casting deep shadows in the dimly lit room. For a moment, he said nothing, his gaze fixed on the ceiling as if lost in thought. Then, with a sudden movement, he turned to me, his eyes alight with the spark of a new idea.

“Watson, my dear fellow, you are far too hasty in your conclusions. The case is not as clear-cut as it seems. You have assumed guilt, but I have only observed facts. Let me remind you of a few details that may have escaped your notice.”

He rose from his chair and began to pace the room, his long strides echoing against the wooden floor. “First, the time of the murder. The victim was found at precisely 10:15 in the evening, but the alibi of the accused places him at a public house at that very hour. A man of his character would not be likely to leave such a place to commit a crime, would he? And yet, the murder was committed with a weapon that he is known to carry at all times—a stiletto, which he claims he left at home that evening.”

I frowned, recalling the details of the case. “But the weapon was found at the scene, and the accused’s fingerprints were on it.”

“Ah, but the fingerprints,” Holmes said, pausing in his pacing. “You assume that the presence of the accused’s fingerprints proves his guilt. But what if they were planted? What if someone wished to frame him? And what of the wound itself? The blow was delivered with precision, from behind. A man in a public house, surrounded by strangers, would not be likely to commit such a calculated act.”

I was beginning to see the flaw in my reasoning. “Then who could have done it?”

Holmes smiled, a glimmer of triumph in his eyes. “That, my dear Watson, is the question. But I suspect the answer lies not in the public house, but in the quiet, unassuming home of the victim’s brother. A man with a grudge, a hidden motive, and a knowledge of the accused’s habits. He may have taken the opportunity to frame the wrong man and escape unnoticed.”

I sat in silence, the weight of Holmes’s words settling over me. “You always see what others miss, Holmes. I must admit, I was blinded by the obvious.”

“Obvious, yes,” he replied, “but not always true. The truth, as you know, is often far more complex than it appears.”

events.title: James's Reaction and Testimony Analysis
detailed_summary: Holmes brings up minor points from the inquest.
He notes James McCarthy wasn't arrested immediately but later at the farm.
Upon being informed he was a prisoner, James remarked he wasn't surprised and deserved it, which solidified the coroner's jury's doubts.
Watson calls it a confession, but Holmes corrects him, noting it was followed by a declaration of innocence.
Watson finds the remark highly suspicious given the circumstances.
Holmes disagrees, seeing it as the 'brightest rift' – a natural reaction for an innocent man overwhelmed by damning evidence, arguing feigned surprise would be more suspicious.
He interprets the 'deserts' remark as natural self-reproach from a son who had just quarreled violently with his now-deceased father, suggesting a healthy rather than guilty mind.
Watson remains skeptical, pointing out men have been hanged on less evidence; Holmes acknowledges wrongful hangings occur.
Asked about James's own account, Holmes finds it unencouraging but with suggestive points, handing Watson a local newspaper containing the testimony.
Watson reads James McCarthy's statement: James returned from Bristol on Monday morning, saw his father leave, then went towards Boscombe Pool with his gun intending to hunt rabbits.
He saw Crowder but denies following his father, claiming he didn't know his father was ahead.
Near the pool, he heard the signal 'Cooee!', hurried forward, found his father surprised to see him, and they argued violently.
James left due to his father's temper but returned upon hearing a 'hideous outcry' 150 yards away.
He found his father dying, held him, dropped his gun, and ran for help at the nearest lodge after his father expired.
He claims ignorance of the attacker and denies his father had active enemies.
Under questioning, James says his father mumbled words, mentioning 'a rat,' which James dismissed as delirium.
He refuses to state the cause of their quarrel, despite the Coroner's warning it would prejudice his case.
He confirms 'Cooee' was their signal but is confused why his father used it before seeing him or knowing he'd returned.

When asked about suspicions upon returning, James mentions a vague impression of something grey, like a coat or plaid, lying on the ground to his left, about a dozen yards from the body and the wood's edge, which was gone when he looked again after rising from his father.
Watson notes the coroner's concluding remarks were severe, highlighting discrepancies (the signal, the refusal to explain the quarrel, the 'rat' reference) as points against James.

Holmes softly laughs, arguing Watson and the coroner focus on points favoring James – his lack of imagination (not inventing a sympathetic quarrel reason) contrasts with too much imagination (inventing the 'rat' and vanishing cloth).
Holmes declares he will assume James's statement is true and see where it leads.
He then proposes silence on the case until they reach the scene, turning his attention to a book.

events.text_segment:
There are one or two minor points which were brought out in the inquest, and which are worth considering.”
“What are they?”
“It appears that his arrest did not take place at once, but after the return to Hatherley Farm. On the inspector of constabulary informing him that he was a prisoner, he remarked that he was not surprised to hear it, and that it was no more than his deserts. This observation of his had the natural effect of removing any traces of doubt which might have remained in the minds of the coroner’s jury.”
“It was a confession,” I ejaculated.
“No, for it was followed by a protestation of innocence.”
“Coming on the top of such a damning series of events, it was at least a most suspicious remark.”
“On the contrary,” said Holmes, “it is the brightest rift which I can at present see in the clouds. However innocent he might be, he could not be such an absolute imbecile as not to see that the circumstances were very black against him. Had he appeared surprised at his own arrest, or feigned indignation at it, I should have looked upon it as highly suspicious, because such surprise or anger would not be natural under the circumstances, and yet might appear to be the best policy to a scheming man. His frank acceptance of the situation marks him as either an innocent man, or else as a man of considerable self-restraint and firmness. As to his remark about his deserts, it was also not unnatural if you consider that he stood beside the dead body of his father, and that there is no doubt that he had that very day so far forgotten his filial duty as to bandy words with him, and even, according to the little girl whose evidence is so important, to raise his hand as if to strike him. The self-reproach and contrition which are displayed in his remark appear to me to be the signs of a healthy mind rather than of a guilty one.”
I shook my head. “Many men have been hanged on far slighter evidence,” I remarked.
“So they have. And many men have been wrongfully hanged.”
“What is the young man’s own account of the matter?”
“It is, I am afraid, not very encouraging to his supporters, though there are one or two points in it which are suggestive. You will find it here, and may read it for yourself.”
He picked out from his bundle a copy of the local Herefordshire paper, and having turned down the sheet he pointed out the paragraph in which the unfortunate young man had given his own statement of what had occurred. I settled myself down in the corner of the carriage and read it very carefully. It ran in this way:
“Mr. James McCarthy, the only son of the deceased, was then called and gave evidence as follows: ‘I had been away from home for three days at Bristol, and had only just returned upon the morning of last Monday, the 3rd. My father was absent from home at the time of my arrival, and I was informed by the maid that he had driven over to Ross with John Cobb, the groom. Shortly after my return I heard the wheels of his trap in the yard, and, looking out of my window, I saw him get out and walk rapidly out of the yard, though I was not aware in which direction he was going. I then took my gun and strolled out in the direction of the Boscombe Pool, with the intention of visiting the rabbit warren which is upon the other side. On my way I saw William Crowder, the game-keeper, as he had stated in his evidence; but he is mistaken in thinking that I was following my father. I had no idea that he was in front of me. When about a hundred yards from the pool I heard a cry of “Cooee!” which was a usual signal between my father and myself. I then hurried forward, and found him standing by the pool. He appeared to be much surprised at seeing me and asked me rather roughly what I was doing there. A conversation ensued which led to high words and almost to blows, for my father was a man of a very violent temper. Seeing that his passion was becoming ungovernable, I left him and returned towards Hatherley Farm. I had not gone more than 150 yards, however, when I heard a hideous outcry behind me, which caused me to run back again. I found my father expiring upon the ground, with his head terribly injured. I dropped my gun and held him in my arms, but he almost instantly expired. I knelt beside him for some minutes, and then made my way to Mr. Turner’s lodge-keeper, his house being the nearest, to ask for assistance. I saw no one near my father when I returned, and I have no idea how he came by his injuries. He was not a popular man, being somewhat cold and forbidding in his manners, but he had, as far as I know, no active enemies. I know nothing further of the matter.’
“The Coroner: Did your father make any statement to you before he died?
“Witness: He mumbled a few words, but I could only catch some allusion to a rat.
“The Coroner: What did you understand by that?
“Witness: It conveyed no meaning to me. I thought that he was delirious.
“The Coroner: What was the point upon which you and your father had this final quarrel?
“Witness: I should prefer not to answer.
“The Coroner: I am afraid that I must press it.
“Witness: It is really impossible for me to tell you. I can assure you that it has nothing to do with the sad tragedy which followed.
“The Coroner: That is for the court to decide. I need not point out to you that your refusal to answer will prejudice your case considerably in any future proceedings which may arise.
“Witness: I must still refuse.
“The Coroner: I understand that the cry of ‘Cooee’ was a common signal between you and your father?
“Witness: It was.
“The Coroner: How was it, then, that he uttered it before he saw you, and before he even knew that you had returned from Bristol?
“Witness (with considerable confusion): I do not know.
“A Juryman: Did you see nothing which aroused your suspicions when you returned on hearing the cry and found your father fatally injured?
“Witness: Nothing definite.
“The Coroner: What do you mean?
“Witness: I was so disturbed and excited as I rushed out into the open, that I could think of nothing except of my father. Yet I have a vague impression that as I ran forward something lay upon the ground to the left of me. It seemed to me to be something grey in colour, a coat of some sort, or a plaid perhaps. When I rose from my father I looked round for it, but it was gone.
“‘Do you mean that it disappeared before you went for help?’
“‘Yes, it was gone.’
“ ‘You cannot say what it was?’
“‘No, I had a feeling something was there.’
“‘How far from the body?’
“‘A dozen yards or so.’
“‘And how far from the edge of the wood?’
“‘About the same.’
“‘Then if it was removed it was while you were within a dozen yards of it?’
“‘Yes, but with my back towards it.’
“This concluded the examination of the witness.”
“I see,” said I as I glanced down the column, “that the coroner in his concluding remarks was rather severe upon young McCarthy. He calls attention, and with reason, to the discrepancy about his father having signalled to him before seeing him, also to his refusal to give details of his conversation with his father, and his singular account of his father’s dying words. They are all, as he remarks, very much against the son.”
Holmes laughed softly to himself and stretched himself out upon the cushioned seat. “Both you and the coroner have been at some pains,” said he, “to single out the very strongest points in the young man’s favour. Don’t you see that you alternately give him credit for having too much imagination and too little? Too little, if he could not invent a cause of quarrel which would give him the sympathy of the jury; too much, if he evolved from his own inner consciousness anything so outré as a dying reference to a rat, and the incident of the vanishing cloth. No, sir, I shall approach this case from the point of view that what this young man says is true, and we shall see whither that hypothesis will lead us. And now here is my pocket Petrarch, and not another word shall I say of this case until we are on the scene of action. We lunch at Swindon, and I see that we shall be there in twenty minutes.”
