simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: There are one or two minor points which were brought out in the inquest, and which are worth considering. You remember that James McCarthy was not arrested at the time of the discovery, but some hours later at his father's farm. When he was informed that he was a prisoner, he remarked that he was not surprised, and that he deserved it. This remark, as you may remember, had a very serious effect upon the coroner's jury. You would call it a confession, I suppose?" "To me it seems so," I answered. "It is followed, however, by a declaration of innocence, which is equally explicit. He says that he did not do it, and that he knows nothing of the matter." "Precisely," said Holmes. "And that is what makes it suspicious to you. But to me it is the very reverse. It is the brightest rift in the whole case. A man who has done a deed of that sort would not be likely to make such a remark. He would be surprised, he would be indignant. But a man who is innocent, who is suddenly overwhelmed with the weight of evidence against him, may well say that he deserves it. It is the natural reaction of a healthy mind. But if he had feigned surprise, that would have been more suspicious than if he had shown no surprise at all. "I see your point," I said. "But still, it is a very serious charge against him." "Yes, but it is not a conclusive one. You must remember that men have been hanged on less. But I do not think that this is a case where the law would be so unjust. "And what of his own account?" I asked. "It is not encouraging," said Holmes, "but there are one or two suggestive points in it. I have here a copy of the local newspaper, which contains the full statement of the young man. You can read it for yourself." I took the paper and read the following: "James McCarthy was examined by the Coroner. He said that he had returned from Bristol on Monday morning, and that he had seen his father leave the house about half-past ten. He had then gone towards Boscombe Pool with his gun, intending to shoot some rabbits. He had seen Crowder, the gamekeeper, but had not followed him, as he did not know that his father was ahead of him. He had heard the signal 'Cooee!' and had hurried forward, finding his father surprised to see him. They had quarrelled violently, and he had left him. But he had returned upon hearing a 'hideous outcry' about a hundred and fifty yards away. He had found his father dying, had held him, had dropped his gun, and had run for help to the nearest lodge. He had no idea who had attacked him, and denied that his father had any active enemies. When asked if he had noticed anything unusual at the time, he said that his father had mumbled some words, which he had dismissed as delirium. He had refused to state the cause of the quarrel, though the Coroner had warned him that it would prejudice his case. He had confirmed that 'Cooee' was their signal, but was puzzled as to why his father had used it before he had seen him or known that he had returned. When asked if he had any suspicions upon returning, he said that he had a vague impression of something grey, like a coat or a plaid, lying on the ground to his left, about a dozen yards from the body and the edge of the wood. But when he looked again after rising from his father, it was gone. "The Coroner's concluding remarks were very severe. He pointed out the discrepancies in the young man's statement, the refusal to explain the quarrel, the mention of the 'rat,' and the vanishing grey object as points against him. "Holmes laughed softly. "You and the Coroner are both looking at the wrong side of the case. You are both looking for points which would incriminate him. But I am looking for points which would exculpate him. You see, the young man has not the imagination to invent a reason for the quarrel. He is too straightforward for that. But he has too much imagination to invent the 'rat' and the vanishing grey cloth. It is the very fact that he does not know the cause of the quarrel which makes me think that he is telling the truth. And it is the very fact that he does mention the 'rat' and the vanishing cloth which makes me think that he is not. "I was silent, for I could not follow his reasoning. "I shall assume for the present that the young man's statement is true," said Holmes, "and see where it leads us. Until we reach the scene of the crime, I think that we had better say nothing more upon the subject." He took up a book and began to read, leaving me to my own reflections.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
There are one or two minor points which were brought out in the inquest, and which are worth considering.”

Holmes leaned back in his chair, his long, thin fingers steepled before his lips, his eyes fixed in thought upon the ceiling. The room was dimly lit, the fire in the grate casting flickering shadows across the walls. I sat opposite him, my notebook open on my knee, ready to record whatever insights he might offer. The case of the mysterious death at the manor of Baskerville had already taken on a life of its own in the public imagination, but Holmes, as always, was more interested in the details than the drama.

“You mean the peculiarities of the scene, the lack of a clear motive, and the curious behavior of the servants?” I asked, recalling the inquest’s proceedings.

Holmes nodded. “Precisely. The coroner was a man of some experience, and he did not miss the oddities. First, the position of the body—found in the library, slumped over the desk, with the candle still burning. The candle, by the way, was of a peculiar type, not commonly found in the area. Second, the absence of any signs of struggle or forced entry. Third, the curious note found in the dead man’s hand, written in a hurried and disjointed manner, which the coroner dismissed as the ramblings of a man in a state of terror.

“I have examined the note myself,” I said. “It read: 'The hound is loose. It is not of this world. I have seen it. I have heard it. It is coming for me.' It was unsigned, but the handwriting was unmistakably that of the deceased, Sir Henry Baskerville.”

Holmes gave a small, grim smile. “Yes, and that is precisely what makes it so interesting. A man of sound mind and considerable education, writing as if he were in the grip of a nightmare. Now, Watson, what do you make of that?”

I considered for a moment. “It suggests that he was either the victim of some supernatural terror or that he was suffering from a sudden and severe mental breakdown. But the latter seems unlikely, given his otherwise stable character and the lack of any prior history of illness.”

“Exactly,” said Holmes. “And yet, the coroner was content to rule it a case of natural causes, citing the man’s heart condition. But I have seen enough to know that when a man dies in such circumstances, it is rarely as simple as it seems. There is always a thread to be pulled, a clue to be found.”

I looked at him, intrigued. “And what thread do you propose to pull in this case?”

Holmes rose from his chair and began to pace the room, his long strides echoing in the quiet. “The candle, for one. The type of candle used in the library was not the same as those found elsewhere in the house. It was a beeswax candle, of a very fine quality, and it was purchased from a shop in London, not the local village. That is an unusual choice for a manor house in the country, where tallow or paraffin would be more common. Why would Sir Henry choose such a candle for his private study?”

I frowned. “Perhaps he had a preference for the light it produced, or perhaps it was a gift from a friend.”

“Possibly,” said Holmes. “But I have a feeling that there is more to it than that. Beeswax candles burn with a very clean flame, producing little smoke and no soot. That is a curious choice for a man who was supposedly in a state of terror. If he were truly afraid, would he not have wanted to light as many candles as possible, to drive away the darkness? And yet, there was only one candle burning, and it was of a type that would not have provided much light in a large room.”

I was beginning to see where Holmes was going with this. “You think the candle was placed there deliberately, perhaps to create a certain effect?”

“Precisely,” said Holmes. “And that effect may have been to make the room appear more sinister, more foreboding. Perhaps to create the illusion of a ghostly presence, or to heighten the sense of fear in the mind of the deceased.”

I considered this for a moment. “But why would someone go to such lengths to frighten Sir Henry Baskerville?”

Holmes turned to me, his eyes gleaming with the light of a man on the verge of a discovery. “That is the question, is it not? And the answer may lie in the second point I mentioned—the lack of signs of struggle or forced entry. A man who is truly in fear for his life would not sit calmly at his desk, writing a note and then slumping over it as if he had simply fallen asleep. He would have tried to escape, to call for help, to defend himself. And yet, there was no sign of any of these things.”

I was beginning to feel the weight of the mystery. “So you are suggesting that Sir Henry was not the victim of a supernatural terror, but of a carefully orchestrated deception?”

“Not necessarily a deception,” said Holmes. “But a manipulation of the environment to create the illusion of one. The candle, the note, the position of the body—all of these elements were arranged with a purpose. And that purpose was to make it appear as though the man had died of fear, perhaps at the hands of some unseen force.”

I was beginning to see the pattern. “And the third point—the servants’ behavior?”

Holmes nodded. “Ah, yes. The servants were all very cooperative at the inquest, but I noticed that they were strangely reluctant to speak about the events of the night in question. When asked about the library, they all gave vague answers, and when pressed, they seemed to become uneasy. One of the maids, in particular, a young woman named Mary, was visibly shaken when the subject of the candle was raised.”

I recalled the inquest. “Yes, I remember. She said that she had seen the candle burning when she passed the library on her way to the kitchen, but she did not go in because she thought it was unusual for Sir Henry to be up at that hour.”

“Exactly,” said Holmes. “And yet, she did not report it to anyone. That is strange, is it not? If she had seen something unusual, would she not have gone to the housekeeper or the butler? And yet, she did not. She simply continued on her way, as if she had seen nothing at all.”

I was beginning to see the implications. “You think she was involved in some way?”

“Not necessarily,” said Holmes. “But I think she may have known something that she was not willing to share. And that is always a red flag in a case like this.”

I was beginning to feel the weight of the mystery. “So what do you propose we do next?”

Holmes turned to me, his eyes gleaming with the light of a man on the verge of a discovery. “We go back to the manor. I would like to speak with the servants again, to see if we can get a clearer picture of what happened that night. And I would also like to examine the candle more closely. I have a feeling that it may hold the key to this mystery.”

I nodded. “And what of the note? Do you think it was written by Sir Henry?”

Holmes gave a small, enigmatic smile. “That is the question, is it not? And the answer may lie in the ink. I have a friend in the city who is an expert in the analysis of inks and papers. If we can determine the age of the ink and the type of pen used, we may be able to determine whether the note was written at the time of the death or at some other time.”

I was beginning to see the pattern. “And if it was written at some other time?”

“Then we may have a case of forgery,” said Holmes. “And that would suggest that someone went to great lengths to make it appear as though Sir Henry had died of fear. And that, my dear Watson, is a very dangerous game to play.”

I was beginning to feel the weight of the mystery. “And what of the hound? Do you think it was real?”

Holmes gave a small, grim smile. “That is the question, is it not? And the answer may lie in the shadows of the manor. But for now, let us focus on the candle, the note, and the servants. For in those minor points, I believe we will find the key to the mystery.”

And with that, Holmes rose from his chair and began to prepare for our journey to the manor of Baskerville, where the shadows of the past were about to be brought into the light.}{

events.title: Arrival in Ross and Miss Turner's Plea
detailed_summary: Holmes and Watson arrive in Ross around 4 PM.
They are met by Lestrade, disguised in country attire.
They proceed to the Hereford Arms hotel.
Lestrade mentions he ordered a carriage, expecting Holmes's eagerness to visit the crime scene immediately.
Holmes declines, citing the favorable barometric pressure (implying good weather for preservation of clues) and his preference to rest and smoke rather than rush.
Lestrade assumes Holmes has already solved the case from newspapers, calling it 'plain as a pikestaff,' but acknowledges Miss Turner insisted on Holmes's involvement.
Miss Turner arrives unexpectedly, rushing into the room in great distress.
Identifying Holmes, she expresses gladness at his arrival and passionately asserts James McCarthy's innocence, urging Holmes to believe it implicitly.
She states that knowing James since childhood, she's aware of his faults but insists he is too kind-hearted to commit such a crime.
Holmes promises to do all he can.
Miss Turner asks if Holmes sees any flaws in the evidence or thinks James is innocent; Holmes replies it's 'very probable.'
She reacts triumphantly towards Lestrade, who cautions Holmes against forming conclusions too quickly.
Miss Turner insists Holmes is right and reveals the quarrel between James and his father likely involved her.
She explains Mr. McCarthy desperately wanted her to marry James, but both she and James viewed each other as siblings, and James wasn't ready for marriage.
She confirms her own father, Mr. Turner, was also against the union.
Holmes inquires about seeing Mr. Turner, but Miss Turner says he is gravely ill, broken down by the tragedy, confined to bed with a shattered nervous system.
She adds that Mr. McCarthy was the only living person who knew her father from his time in Victoria.
Holmes seizes on the Victoria connection, confirming Mr. Turner made his money there, specifically at the gold mines.
Miss Turner thanks Holmes, asks for news, and requests he tell James she believes in his innocence.
She departs quickly to care for her ill father.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was nearly four o’clock when we at last, after passing through the beautiful Stroud Valley, and over the broad gleaming Severn, found ourselves at the pretty little country-town of Ross.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She hurried from the room as impulsively as she had entered, and we heard the wheels of her carriage rattle off down the street.

events.text_segment:
It was nearly four o’clock when we at last, after passing through the beautiful Stroud Valley, and over the broad gleaming Severn, found ourselves at the pretty little country-town of Ross. A lean, ferret-like man, furtive and sly-looking, was waiting for us upon the platform. In spite of the light brown dustcoat and leather-leggings which he wore in deference to his rustic surroundings, I had no difficulty in recognising Lestrade, of Scotland Yard. With him we drove to the Hereford Arms where a room had already been engaged for us.
“I have ordered a carriage,” said Lestrade as we sat over a cup of tea. “I knew your energetic nature, and that you would not be happy until you had been on the scene of the crime.”
“It was very nice and complimentary of you,” Holmes answered. “It is entirely a question of barometric pressure.”
Lestrade looked startled. “I do not quite follow,” he said.
“How is the glass? Twenty-nine, I see. No wind, and not a cloud in the sky. I have a caseful of cigarettes here which need smoking, and the sofa is very much superior to the usual country hotel abomination. I do not think that it is probable that I shall use the carriage to-night.”
Lestrade laughed indulgently. “You have, no doubt, already formed your conclusions from the newspapers,” he said. “The case is as plain as a pikestaff, and the more one goes into it the plainer it becomes. Still, of course, one can’t refuse a lady, and such a very positive one, too. She has heard of you, and would have your opinion, though I repeatedly told her that there was nothing which you could do which I had not already done. Why, bless my soul! here is her carriage at the door.”
He had hardly spoken before there rushed into the room one of the most lovely young women that I have ever seen in my life. Her violet eyes shining, her lips parted, a pink flush upon her cheeks, all thought of her natural reserve lost in her overpowering excitement and concern.
“Oh, Mr. Sherlock Holmes!” she cried, glancing from one to the other of us, and finally, with a woman’s quick intuition, fastening upon my companion, “I am so glad that you have come. I have driven down to tell you so. I know that James didn’t do it. I know it, and I want you to start upon your work knowing it, too. Never let yourself doubt upon that point. We have known each other since we were little children, and I know his faults as no one else does; but he is too tender-hearted to hurt a fly. Such a charge is absurd to anyone who really knows him.”
“I hope we may clear him, Miss Turner,” said Sherlock Holmes. “You may rely upon my doing all that I can.”
“But you have read the evidence. You have formed some conclusion? Do you not see some loophole, some flaw? Do you not yourself think that he is innocent?”
“I think that it is very probable.”
“There, now!” she cried, throwing back her head and looking defiantly at Lestrade. “You hear! He gives me hopes.”
Lestrade shrugged his shoulders. “I am afraid that my colleague has been a little quick in forming his conclusions,” he said.
“But he is right. Oh! I know that he is right. James never did it. And about his quarrel with his father, I am sure that the reason why he would not speak about it to the coroner was because I was concerned in it.”
“In what way?” asked Holmes.
“It is no time for me to hide anything. James and his father had many disagreements about me. Mr. McCarthy was very anxious that there should be a marriage between us. James and I have always loved each other as brother and sister; but of course he is young and has seen very little of life yet, and—and—well, he naturally did not wish to do anything like that yet. So there were quarrels, and this, I am sure, was one of them.”
“And your father?” asked Holmes. “Was he in favour of such a union?”
“No, he was averse to it also. No one but Mr. McCarthy was in favour of it.” A quick blush passed over her fresh young face as Holmes shot one of his keen, questioning glances at her.
“Thank you for this information,” said he. “May I see your father if I call to-morrow?”
“I am afraid the doctor won’t allow it.”
“The doctor?”
“Yes, have you not heard? Poor father has never been strong for years back, but this has broken him down completely. He has taken to his bed, and Dr. Willows says that he is a wreck and that his nervous system is shattered. Mr. McCarthy was the only man alive who had known dad in the old days in Victoria.”
“Ha! In Victoria! That is important.”
“Yes, at the mines.”
“Quite so; at the gold-mines, where, as I understand, Mr. Turner made his money.”
“Yes, certainly.”
“Thank you, Miss Turner. You have been of material assistance to me.”
“You will tell me if you have any news to-morrow. No doubt you will go to the prison to see James. Oh, if you do, Mr. Holmes, do tell him that I know him to be innocent.”
“I will, Miss Turner.”
“I must go home now, for dad is very ill, and he misses me so if I leave him. Good-bye, and God help you in your undertaking.” She hurried from the room as impulsively as she had entered, and we heard the wheels of her carriage rattle off down the street.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
It was nearly four o’clock when we at last, after passing through the beautiful Stroud Valley, and over the broad gleaming Severn, found ourselves at the pretty little country-town of Ross. The streets were already in shadow, and the air was cool and fresh with the scent of the hills. We had been driven some miles from the station, and as we passed through the narrow lanes and by the red-tiled roofs of the town, I could see that we were entering a region of quiet and seclusion. 

We were met at the door of the Hereford Arms by Lestrade, who, to my surprise, was dressed in a rough country suit, with a broad-brimmed hat and a stick in his hand. He greeted us with a nod, and led the way into the hotel. 

"I thought you would be in a hurry to see the scene of the crime," he remarked, as he ordered a carriage. 

"I have no doubt that the barometer is in your favor," said Holmes, lighting a cigarette. "But I prefer to rest and smoke before I begin my investigations. The mind, like the body, needs its due measure of repose." 

Lestrade shrugged. "Well, I suppose you have read the papers, and the case is as plain as a pikestaff to you. But Miss Turner insisted upon your coming, and I had no choice but to comply." 

He had scarcely finished speaking when the door flew open and a young woman rushed into the room. She was pale, with a frightened look in her eyes, and her dress was disordered as though she had run. 

"Mr. Holmes!" she cried, and came forward with outstretched hands. "Oh, I am so glad you have come!" 

Holmes rose and bowed. "Miss Turner, I believe?" 

"Yes, sir. I have heard so much of you. I have come to beg you to believe in James’s innocence. I know it in my heart, and I know you will see it too." 

"I shall do all I can," said Holmes quietly. 

"But do you think he is innocent?" she asked, her voice trembling. 

"It is very probable," said Holmes. 

She turned to Lestrade with a look of triumph. 

"You see!" she said. 

"I hope you are not forming conclusions too quickly," said Lestrade, with a frown. 

"No, no, I am merely stating the facts as they appear to me," said Holmes. 

Miss Turner turned back to him. "The quarrel between James and his father was about me, Mr. Holmes. Mr. McCarthy wished me to marry James, but we are only like brother and sister. James is not ready for marriage, and I—my father was also against the match." 

"Your father is Mr. Turner, I believe?" 

"Yes, sir. He is very ill, broken by this tragedy. He lies in bed, a shattered nervous system. But Mr. McCarthy was the only man who knew my father from his time in Victoria. He was the only one who could tell the story of his past." 

Holmes leaned forward slightly. "And your father made his money in Victoria, was it not?" 

"Yes, in the gold mines. That is why Mr. McCarthy was so important to us." 

"Then I think we may have a clue," said Holmes. 

Miss Turner looked at him with a mixture of hope and fear. "You think you can help him?" 

"I shall do all I can," said Holmes. 

She pressed his hand. "Then I shall wait for your news. And tell James that I believe in him. I must go now. My father is waiting." 

And with a last, anxious glance at Holmes, she hurried from the room.

The day had been warm and bright, and the scenery, though not dramatic, was of a quiet and unassuming charm. The trees were just beginning to show the first signs of autumn, and the golden light of the late afternoon gave a soft, mellow glow to the landscape. I looked about me with interest, for I had heard that Ross was a place of some antiquity and peculiar character, and I was curious to see what it might hold for us in our present inquiry.

We had been sent for by telegram from London, and the case which had brought us to this remote corner of the country was one of some mystery. A local magistrate, Mr. James Holder, had written to my friend Sherlock Holmes, requesting his assistance in a matter which had puzzled the local authorities. The letter had been brief, but it had contained enough to suggest that the case was not one of the ordinary run. There was something about the tone of the message which suggested urgency, and perhaps even a touch of fear.

As we alighted from the carriage at the station, we were met by a man who introduced himself as Mr. Holder. He was a tall, thin man, with a pale, anxious face and a manner that was both courteous and nervous. He greeted us with a certain degree of relief, as though he had been expecting us for some time and was glad to see us arrive.

"I am very glad to see you, Mr. Holmes," he said, shaking my friend's hand. "I trust you will find the journey has not been in vain. I have been most anxious about the matter, and I fear that time is of the essence."

"I trust that you have not exaggerated the gravity of the situation," Holmes replied, with a slight smile. "I have no doubt that we shall find the matter to be of some interest, but I must confess that I have not yet formed any opinion as to its nature."

"I fear that it is of a most unusual nature," Mr. Holder replied. "It concerns a young woman who has disappeared under most peculiar circumstances. Her name is Miss Alice Dunbar, and she is the daughter of a well-known and respected family in the district."

"I see," said Holmes. "And what are these peculiar circumstances?"

"Well, to begin with, she was last seen on the evening of the 12th, when she left her father's house in the village of Wotton, which is about five miles from here. She was expected to return the following day, but she did not. Her father, Mr. Dunbar, is a retired schoolmaster, and a man of some learning and quiet disposition. He is most distressed by the disappearance of his daughter."

"And what was the nature of her business on that evening?" Holmes asked.

"She was going to visit a friend, Miss Emily Carter, who lives in the village of Wotton. The two young ladies are great friends, and it was not unusual for them to visit each other."

"And Miss Carter?" Holmes asked.

"She is quite well, and has no knowledge of what happened to Miss Dunbar. She says that she was alone with her that evening, and that they parted at about ten o'clock."

"And what is it that has brought you to consult me?" Holmes asked.

events.title: Lestrade's Rebuke and Watson's Pondering
detailed_summary: Lestrade criticizes Holmes for giving Miss Turner false hope, calling it cruel.
Holmes confidently states he sees a way to clear James McCarthy and asks Lestrade if he has an order to visit the prison.
Learning the order is only for them, Holmes decides to go immediately, asking Watson to wait.
Watson accompanies them to the station, then returns to the hotel.
Unable to focus on a novel due to the real-life mystery, Watson contemplates the case, assuming James's story is true.
He wonders what terrible event occurred between James leaving his father and returning upon hearing the screams.
Considering the medical evidence from the inquest report (obtained from a local paper), he notes the fatal blow shattered the back-left portion of the skull, implying it came from behind.
This seems slightly favorable to James, who was seen face-to-face with his father, though the father could have turned.
Watson puzzles over the dying reference to 'a rat,' reasoning it wasn't delirium from a sudden blow but likely an attempt to name the cause of death.
He also considers the mysterious grey cloth, noting the killer must have dropped it, then daringly retrieved it while James knelt nearby.
Watson acknowledges the complexity and Lestrade's skepticism but retains faith in Holmes's insight, especially as new facts seem to reinforce Holmes's belief in James's innocence.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I could not lose hope as long as every fresh fact seemed to strengthen his conviction of young McCarthy’s innocence.

events.text_segment:
“I am ashamed of you, Holmes,” said Lestrade with dignity after a few minutes’ silence. “Why should you raise up hopes which you are bound to disappoint? I am not over-tender of heart, but I call it cruel.”
“I think that I see my way to clearing James McCarthy,” said Holmes. “Have you an order to see him in prison?”
“Yes, but only for you and me.”
“Then I shall reconsider my resolution about going out. We have still time to take a train to Hereford and see him to-night?”
“Ample.”
“Then let us do so. Watson, I fear that you will find it very slow, but I shall only be away a couple of hours.”
I walked down to the station with them, and then wandered through the streets of the little town, finally returning to the hotel, where I lay upon the sofa and tried to interest myself in a yellow-backed novel. The puny plot of the story was so thin, however, when compared to the deep mystery through which we were groping, and I found my attention wander so continually from the action to the fact, that I at last flung it across the room and gave myself up entirely to a consideration of the events of the day. Supposing that this unhappy young man’s story were absolutely true, then what hellish thing, what absolutely unforeseen and extraordinary calamity could have occurred between the time when he parted from his father, and the moment when, drawn back by his screams, he rushed into the glade? It was something terrible and deadly. What could it be? Might not the nature of the injuries reveal something to my medical instincts? I rang the bell and called for the weekly county paper, which contained a verbatim account of the inquest. In the surgeon’s deposition it was stated that the posterior third of the left parietal bone and the left half of the occipital bone had been shattered by a heavy blow from a blunt weapon. I marked the spot upon my own head. Clearly such a blow must have been struck from behind. That was to some extent in favour of the accused, as when seen quarrelling he was face to face with his father. Still, it did not go for very much, for the older man might have turned his back before the blow fell. Still, it might be worth while to call Holmes’ attention to it. Then there was the peculiar dying reference to a rat. What could that mean? It could not be delirium. A man dying from a sudden blow does not commonly become delirious. No, it was more likely to be an attempt to explain how he met his fate. But what could it indicate? I cudgelled my brains to find some possible explanation. And then the incident of the grey cloth seen by young McCarthy. If that were true the murderer must have dropped some part of his dress, presumably his overcoat, in his flight, and must have had the hardihood to return and to carry it away at the instant when the son was kneeling with his back turned not a dozen paces off. What a tissue of mysteries and improbabilities the whole thing was! I did not wonder at Lestrade’s opinion, and yet I had so much faith in Sherlock Holmes’ insight that I could not lose hope as long as every fresh fact seemed to strengthen his conviction of young McCarthy’s innocence.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“I am ashamed of you, Holmes,” said Lestrade with dignity after a few minutes’ silence.

Holmes leaned back in his chair, his long, thin fingers steepled before his lips. His eyes, sharp and unyielding, fixed upon the inspector with a mixture of amusement and disdain.

“Ah, Lestrade,” he said, his voice smooth and deliberate, “you are a man of principle, I know. But principles, like facts, must be tempered with reason. You accuse me of shame, but I ask you—what is it that you are truly ashamed of? That I have uncovered the truth, or that you were not the first to do so?”

Lestrade’s face flushed with anger. “You know very well what I mean, Holmes. You have gone too far this time. You have not only interfered in a matter that was well within the jurisdiction of the Metropolitan Police, but you have done so in a manner that has brought the matter into public view. The press is already speculating wildly. The public is in an uproar. And for what? A few stolen trinkets and a missing maid?”

Holmes smiled faintly. “A missing maid, yes. And a mystery that you, with all your experience, have failed to solve. I have not brought the matter into the public view, Lestrade. I have merely drawn attention to the facts that you have overlooked. The maid is not missing—she is in hiding. And the trinkets? They are not stolen, but pawned. A most curious set of circumstances, if you ask me.”

Lestrade shook his head. “You are playing with fire, Holmes. You may think yourself above the law, but the law is not amused. The commissioner is not amused.”

Holmes chuckled. “The law is a curious thing, Lestrade. It is not a man, nor a thing. It is a principle. And I have always served it, even when it has not served me. You, on the other hand, seem to serve only your own pride.”

Lestrade’s jaw tightened. “I serve the people of London. I serve justice. And I will not be outdone by a man who plays detective in his spare time.”

Holmes rose from his chair and walked to the window. The fog of London clung to the glass, thick and grey. “Then I suppose we are at an impasse, Lestrade. You may go your way, and I mine. But I warn you—this case is not as simple as it seems. There is more to it than a missing maid and a few stolen trinkets. There is a pattern, a design. And I intend to follow it to its end.”

Lestrade stood for a moment, his face a mask of frustration. Then, with a curt nod, he turned and left the room, the door closing behind him with a soft click.

Holmes turned back to his desk, where a letter lay waiting. He picked it up and read it once more, his brow furrowing slightly. Watson, who had been listening in silence, now spoke.

“Well,” he said, “that was a most unusual exchange. I must say, I have never seen Lestrade so ruffled.”

Holmes smiled. “Nor I, Watson. But I suspect that this is only the beginning. The game is afoot, my dear fellow. And I have no intention of letting it end until the truth is revealed.”

events.text_segment:
It was late before Sherlock Holmes returned. He came back alone, for Lestrade was staying in lodgings in the town.
“The glass still keeps very high,” he remarked as he sat down. “It is of importance that it should not rain before we are able to go over the ground. On the other hand, a man should be at his very best and keenest for such nice work as that, and I did not wish to do it when fagged by a long journey. I have seen young McCarthy.”
“And what did you learn from him?”
“Nothing.”
“Could he throw no light?”
“None at all. I was inclined to think at one time that he knew who had done it and was screening him or her, but I am convinced now that he is as puzzled as everyone else. He is not a very quick-witted youth, though comely to look at and, I should think, sound at heart.”
“I cannot admire his taste,” I remarked, “if it is indeed a fact that he was averse to a marriage with so charming a young lady as this Miss Turner.”
“Ah, thereby hangs a rather painful tale. This fellow is madly, insanely, in love with her, but some two years ago, when he was only a lad, and before he really knew her, for she had been away five years at a boarding-school, what does the idiot do but get into the clutches of a barmaid in Bristol and marry her at a registry office? No one knows a word of the matter, but you can imagine how maddening it must be to him to be upbraided for not doing what he would give his very eyes to do, but what he knows to be absolutely impossible. It was sheer frenzy of this sort which made him throw his hands up into the air when his father, at their last interview, was goading him on to propose to Miss Turner. On the other hand, he had no means of supporting himself, and his father, who was by all accounts a very hard man, would have thrown him over utterly had he known the truth. It was with his barmaid wife that he had spent the last three days in Bristol, and his father did not know where he was. Mark that point. It is of importance. Good has come out of evil, however, for the barmaid, finding from the papers that he is in serious trouble and likely to be hanged, has thrown him over utterly and has written to him to say that she has a husband already in the Bermuda Dockyard, so that there is really no tie between them. I think that that bit of news has consoled young McCarthy for all that he has suffered.”
“But if he is innocent, who has done it?”
“Ah! who? I would call your attention very particularly to two points. One is that the murdered man had an appointment with someone at the pool, and that the someone could not have been his son, for his son was away, and he did not know when he would return. The second is that the murdered man was heard to cry ‘Cooee!’ before he knew that his son had returned. Those are the crucial points upon which the case depends. And now let us talk about George Meredith, if you please, and we shall leave all minor matters until to-morrow.”

**Chapter IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY**

It was late before Sherlock Holmes returned. He came in alone, his long, lank figure wrapped in a heavy coat, the damp air of the evening clinging to him like a second skin. The weather had held firm—no rain, no mist—leaving the ground in perfect condition for the investigation the next day. I watched him closely, noting the quiet satisfaction in his eyes as he removed his hat and gloves.

“I didn’t want to examine the scene while fatigued,” he said, settling into his chair with a sigh. “The mind must be sharp, and the body must be rested. The Boscombe Valley mystery is not one to be solved in haste.”

I nodded, sipping my tea. “And what of young McCarthy? Did he yield any new information?”

Holmes shook his head. “No, nothing new about the crime itself. But I did confirm one thing—James is not the man I once suspected. At first, I thought he might be shielding someone, but now I believe he is genuinely puzzled by the events that transpired.”

I raised an eyebrow. “You think him innocent?”

“Not entirely innocent, but certainly not the villain I once imagined. James is not a man of great intellect, but he is good-looking and, at heart, decent. His actions, however, were driven by a most painful tale.”

He leaned forward, his eyes alight with the thrill of the revelation. “James is madly in love with Miss Turner. But there is a secret in his past. Two years ago, before he truly knew Miss Turner—while she was away at school—he married a barmaid in Bristol. A young, impulsive act, and one that has haunted him ever since.”

I frowned. “But how does that tie into the murder?”

“His father, a man of rigid principles and financial control, insisted on a proposal to Miss Turner. James, bound by his secret and his dependence on his father, could not refuse. The tension between them reached a breaking point during their final argument, witnessed by many. James, unable to confess the truth, was left in a position of unbearable pressure.”

“And the three days in Bristol?” I asked.

“Ah, yes. James had gone to visit his barmaid wife, a fact unknown to his father. This absence, I believe, is of great importance. But there is a twist—his wife, upon reading of his troubles in the papers, wrote to him. She revealed that she had already married another man. Their union was null and void. This news has greatly consoled James.”

I sat in silence, absorbing the weight of the revelation. “Then who is the culprit, if not James?”

Holmes smiled, a glimmer of triumph in his gaze. “Two facts are crucial. First, the murdered man had an appointment with someone other than his son. Second, he cried out 'Cooee!' before realizing his son was present. These are the pivotal points.”

He rose, pacing the room. “The case is nearly solved, but I shall not speak of it further tonight. There is time enough for that tomorrow.”

And with that, he turned to the window, the night air stirring the curtains as the mystery of the Boscombe Valley lingered in the silence between us.

--- 

**End of Segment**

**Chapter IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY**

It was late before Sherlock Holmes returned. He came in alone, his long, lank figure wrapped in a heavy coat, the damp air of the evening clinging to him like a second skin. The weather had held firm—no rain, no mist—leaving the ground in perfect condition for the investigation the next day. I watched him closely, noting the quiet satisfaction in his eyes as he removed his hat and gloves.

“I didn’t want to examine the scene while fatigued,” he said, settling into his chair with a sigh. “The mind must be sharp, and the body must be rested. The Boscombe Valley mystery is not one to be solved in haste.”

I nodded, sipping my tea. “And what of young McCarthy? Did he yield any new information?”

Holmes shook his head. “No, nothing new about the crime itself. But I did confirm one thing—James is not the man I once suspected. At first, I thought he might be shielding someone, but now I believe he is genuinely puzzled by the events that transpired.”

I raised an eyebrow. “You think him innocent?”

“Not entirely innocent, but certainly not the villain I once imagined. James is not a man of great intellect, but he is good-looking and, at heart, decent. His actions, however, were driven by a most painful tale.”

He leaned forward, his eyes alight with the thrill of the revelation. “James is madly in love with Miss Turner. But there is a secret in his past. Two years ago, before he truly knew Miss Turner—while she was away at school—he married a barmaid in Bristol. A young, impulsive act, and one that has haunted him ever since.”

I frowned. “But how does that tie into the murder?”

“His father, a man of rigid principles and financial control, insisted on a proposal to Miss Turner. James, bound by his secret and his dependence on his father, could not refuse. The tension between them reached a breaking point during their final argument, witnessed by many. James, unable to confess the truth, was left in a position of unbearable pressure.”

“And the three days in Bristol?” I asked.

“Ah, yes. James had gone to visit his barmaid wife, a fact unknown to his father. This absence, I believe, is of great importance. But there is a twist—his wife, upon reading of his troubles in the papers, wrote to him. She revealed that she had already married another man. Their union was null and void. This news has greatly consoled James.”

I sat in silence, absorbing the weight of the revelation. “Then who is the culprit, if not James?”

Holmes smiled, a glimmer of triumph in his gaze. “Two facts are crucial. First, the murdered man had an appointment with someone other than his son. Second, he cried out 'Cooee!' before realizing his son was present. These are the pivotal points.”

He rose, pacing the room. “The case is nearly solved, but I shall not speak of it further tonight. There is time enough for that tomorrow.”

And with that, he turned to the window, the night air stirring the curtains as the mystery of the Boscombe Valley lingered in the silence between us.

--- 

**End of Segment**

It was late before Sherlock Holmes returned. I had been sitting in the dimly lit sitting room of our Baker Street lodgings, the fire having long since died down to a faint glow. The night was cold and still, and the silence of the room was broken only by the occasional creak of the old house settling. I had been reading, but my thoughts kept drifting to the case Holmes had taken on that morning. It was a peculiar one, involving a missing heirloom and a series of strange letters sent to a client of his, each more cryptic than the last. I had offered to accompany him, but he had waved me off with a smile and a promise that he would return soon. Now, as the clock struck ten, I was beginning to wonder if I had been left alone for longer than expected.

The door creaked open, and Holmes stepped inside, his coat dusted with snow and his face drawn with exhaustion. He removed his hat and gloves with a weary motion, then turned to me with a faint smile. "I trust you haven't been waiting long, Watson," he said, his voice low and hoarse.

"Not long at all," I replied, rising to my feet. "But I must say, I was beginning to think you had been detained by the case."

He chuckled, though there was little mirth in it. "Detained is the word. The matter is more complicated than I first believed."

I watched as he removed his coat and hung it on the back of a chair. He looked older than usual, the lines on his face more pronounced in the dim light. "Shall I fetch you a glass of brandy?" I asked.

"Yes, that would be most welcome," he said, sinking into the armchair by the fire. "And perhaps a bit of supper as well. I have not had the time for either."

I went to the kitchen and returned with a tray of food and a glass of brandy. As I set it before him, I could not help but notice the look of deep thought on his face. "Well?" I asked, after a moment. "What have you discovered?"

He took a sip of the brandy and exhaled slowly. "It is a most curious case, Watson. The letters, as you know, were written in a cipher of some sort. I have spent the evening deciphering them, and I believe I have found the key."

"And what does it reveal?"

He leaned forward, his eyes gleaming with the excitement of a puzzle solved. "The heirloom is not lost, but hidden. And the person who sent the letters is not the thief, but the one who has been trying to protect the heirloom from the true villain."

I sat down, intrigued. "That is most unexpected."

"Indeed," he said, his voice low. "And it is only the beginning."

As the night wore on, Holmes filled me in on the details of his investigation, his mind working at a feverish pace as he pieced together the clues. I listened in silence, my admiration for my friend growing with each revelation. And as the fire burned low and the snow continued to fall outside, I knew that another mystery had been solved, and that the night was far from over.

Lestrade arrives with a carriage at 9 AM.
Lestrade shares news that Mr. Turner is critically ill.
Holmes inquires about Turner's age (around sixty) and learns his health has been poor due to his life abroad, and McCarthy's death worsened his condition.
Lestrade reveals Turner was a great benefactor to McCarthy, even giving him Hatherley Farm rent-free and helping in many other ways.
Holmes finds it peculiar that McCarthy, so indebted to Turner, would push for his son to marry Turner's heiress daughter, especially since Turner himself opposed the match.
Lestrade dismisses Holmes's 'deductions and inferences,' preferring 'facts.'
Holmes retorts that Lestrade finds tackling facts hard.
Lestrade insists the fact is McCarthy Jr. killed McCarthy Sr.
Holmes compares Lestrade's certainty to 'fog' and his own theories to 'moonshine,' then identifies Hatherley Farm.
At the farm, Holmes examines the boots worn by McCarthy Sr. at death and a pair of his son's boots, taking careful measurements.
They follow the path to Boscombe Pool.
Holmes transforms into an intensely focused investigator, his demeanor becoming predatory and concentrated.
He moves swiftly along the path, examining the damp ground, occasionally stopping or making detours, ignoring questions.
At Boscombe Pool, Lestrade points out the body's location, where traces are still visible.
Holmes intently reads many more details from the trampled grass.
He questions Lestrade about disturbing the pool bed with a rake.
Holmes identifies Lestrade's footprints and complains about the scene being trampled.
He identifies three sets of tracks belonging to James McCarthy (walking twice, running once), confirming his story.
He finds the father's footprints and marks from the gun butt where James stood.
He discovers unusual, square-toed boot prints ('Tiptoes!') coming and going, deducing this was for retrieving the dropped cloak.
Following these tracks into the woods under a large beech tree, Holmes examines the ground, leaves, bark, and collects dust.
He finds a jagged stone among the moss, examines it carefully, and keeps it.
He follows the tracks to the high road where they disappear.
Returning to his normal manner, Holmes states the case is interesting and decides to speak with Moran at the lodge before returning for lunch.

events.text_segment:
There was no rain, as Holmes had foretold, and the morning broke bright and cloudless. At nine o’clock Lestrade called for us with the carriage, and we set off for Hatherley Farm and the Boscombe Pool.
“There is serious news this morning,” Lestrade observed. “It is said that Mr. Turner, of the Hall, is so ill that his life is despaired of.”
“An elderly man, I presume?” said Holmes.
“About sixty; but his constitution has been shattered by his life abroad, and he has been in failing health for some time. This business has had a very bad effect upon him. He was an old friend of McCarthy’s, and, I may add, a great benefactor to him, for I have learned that he gave him Hatherley Farm rent free.”
“Indeed! That is interesting,” said Holmes.
“Oh, yes! In a hundred other ways he has helped him. Everybody about here speaks of his kindness to him.”
“Really! Does it not strike you as a little singular that this McCarthy, who appears to have had little of his own, and to have been under such obligations to Turner, should still talk of marrying his son to Turner’s daughter, who is, presumably, heiress to the estate, and that in such a very cocksure manner, as if it were merely a case of a proposal and all else would follow? It is the more strange, since we know that Turner himself was averse to the idea. The daughter told us as much. Do you not deduce something from that?”
“We have got to the deductions and the inferences,” said Lestrade, winking at me. “I find it hard enough to tackle facts, Holmes, without flying away after theories and fancies.”
“You are right,” said Holmes demurely; “you do find it very hard to tackle the facts.”
“Anyhow, I have grasped one fact which you seem to find it difficult to get hold of,” replied Lestrade with some warmth.
“And that is—”
“That McCarthy senior met his death from McCarthy junior and that all theories to the contrary are the merest moonshine.”
“Well, moonshine is a brighter thing than fog,” said Holmes, laughing. “But I am very much mistaken if this is not Hatherley Farm upon the left.”
“Yes, that is it.” It was a widespread, comfortable-looking building, two-storied, slate-roofed, with great yellow blotches of lichen upon the grey walls. The drawn blinds and the smokeless chimneys, however, gave it a stricken look, as though the weight of this horror still lay heavy upon it. We called at the door, when the maid, at Holmes’ request, showed us the boots which her master wore at the time of his death, and also a pair of the son’s, though not the pair which he had then had. Having measured these very carefully from seven or eight different points, Holmes desired to be led to the court-yard, from which we all followed the winding track which led to Boscombe Pool.
Sherlock Holmes was transformed when he was hot upon such a scent as this. Men who had only known the quiet thinker and logician of Baker Street would have failed to recognise him. His face flushed and darkened. His brows were drawn into two hard black lines, while his eyes shone out from beneath them with a steely glitter. His face was bent downward, his shoulders bowed, his lips compressed, and the veins stood out like whipcord in his long, sinewy neck. His nostrils seemed to dilate with a purely animal lust for the chase, and his mind was so absolutely concentrated upon the matter before him that a question or remark fell unheeded upon his ears, or, at the most, only provoked a quick, impatient snarl in reply. Swiftly and silently he made his way along the track which ran through the meadows, and so by way of the woods to the Boscombe Pool. It was damp, marshy ground, as is all that district, and there were marks of many feet, both upon the path and amid the short grass which bounded it on either side. Sometimes Holmes would hurry on, sometimes stop dead, and once he made quite a little detour into the meadow. Lestrade and I walked behind him, the detective indifferent and contemptuous, while I watched my friend with the interest which sprang from the conviction that every one of his actions was directed towards a definite end.
The Boscombe Pool, which is a little reed-girt sheet of water some fifty yards across, is situated at the boundary between the Hatherley Farm and the private park of the wealthy Mr. Turner. Above the woods which lined it upon the farther side we could see the red, jutting pinnacles which marked the site of the rich landowner’s dwelling. On the Hatherley side of the pool the woods grew very thick, and there was a narrow belt of sodden grass twenty paces across between the edge of the trees and the reeds which lined the lake. Lestrade showed us the exact spot at which the body had been found, and, indeed, so moist was the ground, that I could plainly see the traces which had been left by the fall of the stricken man. To Holmes, as I could see by his eager face and peering eyes, very many other things were to be read upon the trampled grass. He ran round, like a dog who is picking up a scent, and then turned upon my companion.
“What did you go into the pool for?” he asked.
“I fished about with a rake. I thought there might be some weapon or other trace. But how on earth—”
“Oh, tut, tut! I have no time! That left foot of yours with its inward twist is all over the place. A mole could trace it, and there it vanishes among the reeds. Oh, how simple it would all have been had I been here before they came like a herd of buffalo and wallowed all over it. Here is where the party with the lodge-keeper came, and they have covered all tracks for six or eight feet round the body. But here are three separate tracks of the same feet.” He drew out a lens and lay down upon his waterproof to have a better view, talking all the time rather to himself than to us. “These are young McCarthy’s feet. Twice he was walking, and once he ran swiftly, so that the soles are deeply marked and the heels hardly visible. That bears out his story. He ran when he saw his father on the ground. Then here are the father’s feet as he paced up and down. What is this, then? It is the butt-end of the gun as the son stood listening. And this? Ha, ha! What have we here? Tiptoes! tiptoes! Square, too, quite unusual boots! They come, they go, they come again—of course that was for the cloak. Now where did they come from?” He ran up and down, sometimes losing, sometimes finding the track until we were well within the edge of the wood and under the shadow of a great beech, the largest tree in the neighbourhood. Holmes traced his way to the farther side of this and lay down once more upon his face with a little cry of satisfaction. For a long time he remained there, turning over the leaves and dried sticks, gathering up what seemed to me to be dust into an envelope and examining with his lens not only the ground but even the bark of the tree as far as he could reach. A jagged stone was lying among the moss, and this also he carefully examined and retained. Then he followed a pathway through the wood until he came to the high road, where all traces were lost.
“It has been a case of considerable interest,” he remarked, returning to his natural manner. “I fancy that this grey house on the right must be the lodge. I think that I will go in and have a word with Moran, and perhaps write a little note. Having done that, we may drive back to our luncheon. You may walk to the cab, and I shall be with you presently.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
There was no rain, as Holmes had foretold, and the morning broke bright and cloudless. At half-past eight we were astir, and by nine o’clock Lestrade had driven up in his brougham, a portly, red-faced man, with a very official air, and a manner which suggested that he was not accustomed to be contradicted. He had, he said, brought with him the most recent news from the coroner’s court. “Mr. Turner is very ill,” he remarked, as he handed me a telegram. “The shock has been too much for him. He is a man of sixty, and his health has never been good since his years in the East. McCarthy’s death has been the last straw.”

Holmes read the telegram with a frown. “And yet,” he mused, “McCarthy was a man who owed everything to Turner. The farm, the money, the position—Turner gave it all to him. And yet he was pushing his son to marry Turner’s daughter. That seems strange, does it not?”

Lestrade sniffed. “You are always for your deductions and inferences, Mr. Holmes. I prefer facts.”

“Ah, but you find facts hard to tackle, Lestrade,” Holmes replied with a smile. “You prefer to wrap yourself in the fog of certainty. I, on the other hand, am content to work with the moonshine of theory.”

Lestrade bristled. “The fact is, Mr. Holmes, that James McCarthy killed his father.”

“Perhaps,” said Holmes, “but I should like to see the scene of the crime first.”

We set out for Hatherley Farm, where the elder McCarthy had lived. Holmes was particularly interested in the boots that the dead man had been wearing, and he took careful measurements of them, as well as of a pair belonging to his son. Then, with a sudden decision, he set off along the path that led to Boscombe Pool.

He moved with a strange intensity, his eyes fixed on the ground, his body tense and alert, like a man hunting. He would stop suddenly, crouch, and examine the trampled grass, then move on again with the same relentless purpose. Lestrade and I followed in silence, watching the transformation of our companion into a creature of pure instinct and purpose.

At the pool, Lestrade pointed out the spot where the body had been found. “You can still see the marks,” he said. Holmes knelt and studied them for a long time. “You have been raking the bed of the pool, I see,” he remarked. “And you have left your own footprints all over the scene. A most unfortunate proceeding, Lestrade.”

Lestrade reddened. “I was trying to find the murder weapon.”

“Ah, but you have destroyed the very evidence you sought,” said Holmes. “However, there is still much to be learned from the ground.”

He traced the footprints of James McCarthy, who had walked twice and run once, just as the young man had claimed. Then he found the prints of the elder McCarthy, and the mark of the gun butt where he had stood. But there was something else—something strange. A set of square-toed boot prints, going and coming, as if someone had tiptoed to retrieve something. “Tiptoes!” Holmes exclaimed. “That is most interesting.”

He followed the tracks into the woods, where they led to a large beech tree. He examined the ground, the leaves, the bark, and finally picked up a small amount of dust. “This is not from the farm,” he said. “It is from the high road.”

He found a jagged stone among the moss and examined it carefully. “This may be the murder weapon,” he said. “Or it may not. We shall see.”

The tracks led to the high road, where they disappeared. Holmes stood for a moment, then turned to us with a smile. “The case is most interesting,” he said. “I think I shall call upon Moran at the lodge before we return for lunch.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
There was no rain, as Holmes had foretold, and the morning broke bright and cloudless. The sun, rising in a clear sky, cast long shadows across the dewy grass of the garden, and the air was fresh with the scent of spring. I had risen early, for I had been unable to sleep, and I stood at the window of our Baker Street lodgings, watching the world stir to life. My companion, still wrapped in his dressing gown, sat in his armchair, his long, thin fingers steepled before his lips, his eyes fixed upon the horizon as though he were reading the future in the light of the sun.

"You are early, Watson," he remarked, without turning his head.

"I could not sleep," I replied. "The case has been too much for me. I have been turning it over in my mind all night."

"Ah, yes, the case of the missing will," he said, with a faint smile. "A most singular affair, is it not?"

"Singular, indeed," I said. "And yet, I confess I am at a loss to see how you can have solved it so quickly."

"It was not so very difficult," he replied. "The clues were all there, if one had the eyes to see them."

"But the will was destroyed, was it not?"

"Destroyed, yes, but not before it had been copied."

"Copied!"

"Yes, by the very man who destroyed it."

"But why?"

"Because he wished to make it appear that the will had been lost, and that the property would pass to the nearest heir. But in reality, he had already secured the original, and he intended to produce it at the appropriate moment."

"But who is this man?"

"That is what we are about to find out," said Holmes, rising from his chair. "Come, Watson, we have no time to lose."

I followed him into the street, where a hansom cab was waiting. We drove rapidly through the morning traffic, and soon found ourselves at the gates of a large and imposing house in the suburbs. The butler, a tall, thin man with a face like a parchment, opened the door for us.

"Mr. Holmes," he said, with a bow. "I was not expecting you."

"Nor were you, I imagine," said Holmes. "But I have come to see Mr. James Morstan."

"Mr. Morstan is not at home," said the butler. "He has gone out for the day."

"Then I shall wait for him," said Holmes. "I have no doubt he will return before long."

The butler looked at me, and then at Holmes, and then at the clock on the wall. "Very well, sir," he said. "I will show you to the drawing-room."

We were shown into a large and well-furnished room, where we found a number of other visitors already assembled. There was a man in a military uniform, a woman in a black dress, and a young man with a book in his hand. They all looked up as we entered, and I could see that they were watching us with interest.

"I see we are not the only ones who have come to call upon Mr. Morstan," said Holmes, with a smile. "It seems that the matter of the will has attracted a good deal of attention."

"Indeed," I said. "It is a most unusual case."

"Unusual, yes," said Holmes. "But not without precedent."

We took our seats, and I could see that Holmes was already at work, his eyes scanning the room with the keenness of a hawk. He was watching the other visitors, noting their manner, their dress, their bearing. I could see that he was forming a picture in his mind, and I could not help but wonder what conclusions he was drawing.

At length, the door opened, and Mr. James Morstan entered. He was a tall, thin man, with a pale face and a nervous manner. He looked at us with a start, and then with a look of relief.

"Mr. Holmes," he said. "I was not expecting you."

"Nor were you, I imagine," said Holmes. "But I have come to see you about the matter of the will."

"The will," said Morstan, with a start. "Yes, I suppose that is what you are here about."

"I understand that you are the executor of the late Mr. Morstan's will," said Holmes. "And that the will has been destroyed."

"Yes," said Morstan. "It was destroyed by my father, just before he died."

"And yet," said Holmes, "I understand that there was a copy of the will made."

Morstan's face paled. "How do you know that?"

"Because it is the only explanation that makes sense," said Holmes. "The will was destroyed, but the property did not pass to the nearest heir. It passed to you."

"That is true," said Morstan. "But I did not know that there was a copy."

"You did not know," said Holmes. "But you suspected."

"I suspected nothing," said Morstan. "I was simply the executor of the will."

"And yet," said Holmes, "you have been in communication with the other visitors here."

Morstan looked at the others, and then back at Holmes. "I have not," he said. "I have not spoken to any of them."

"Then why are they here?" said Holmes. "Why have they come to see you?"

Morstan looked at the others, and then at Holmes. "I do not know," he said. "I have no idea why they are here."

"I think you do," said Holmes. "I think you know that they are here because they suspect that you have the original will."

Morstan's face turned ashen. "I do not have the original will," he said. "I swear it."

"Then where is it?" said Holmes. "For I have no doubt that it is somewhere in this house."

Morstan looked at the others, and then at Holmes. "I do not know," he said. "I swear I do not know."

"Then I shall have to search for it," said Holmes. "And I shall find it."

With that, Holmes rose from his chair and walked out of the room. I followed him, and we found ourselves in the hall. The butler was waiting for us.

"Mr. Holmes," he said. "I was not expecting you to leave so soon."

"I am not leaving," said Holmes. "I am merely going to search the house."

"But Mr. Morstan has not given you permission to do that," said the butler.

"No," said Holmes. "But I have given myself permission."

With that, Holmes walked past the butler and into the house. I followed him, and we found ourselves in a long corridor, lined with doors. Holmes walked along it, opening each door in turn, and looking inside. I could see that he was searching for something, and I could not help but wonder what it was.

At length, he came to a door at the end of the corridor. He opened it, and we found ourselves in a small room, lined with bookshelves. On the shelves were books, and on the floor was a small table, on which was a lamp and a number of papers. Holmes walked to the table, and began to look through the papers.

"What are you looking for?" I asked.

"The will," said Holmes. "Or rather, a copy of it."

He looked through the papers, and then, with a sudden movement, he pulled out a small, leather-bound book. He opened it, and I could see that it was a copy of the will.

"There," he said. "The missing will."

"But how did it get here?" I asked.

"That is what we must now discover," said Holmes. "And I have a feeling that we shall find the answer in the next room."

He walked out of the room, and I followed him. We found ourselves in a large, well-furnished room, where we found Mr. James Morstan, the military man, the woman in black, and the young man with the book. They all looked up as we entered, and I could see that they were watching us with interest.

"I see you have found the will," said Morstan. "I congratulate you, Mr. Holmes."

"I thank you," said Holmes. "But I must now ask you a few questions."

"By all means," said Morstan. "I am at your service."

"First, I must ask you why you destroyed the original will."

"I did not destroy it," said Morstan. "I swear I did not."

"Then who did?"

"I do not know," said Morstan. "I swear I do not know."

"Then I must ask you why you have been in communication with these other people."

"I have not," said Morstan. "I have not spoken to any of them."

"Then why are they here?" said Holmes. "Why have they come to see you?"

Morstan looked at the others, and then at Holmes. "I do not know," he said. "I have no idea why they are here."

"I think you do," said Holmes. "I think you know that they are here because they suspect that you have the original will."

Morstan's face turned ashen. "I do not have the original will," he said. "I swear it."

"Then where is it?" said Holmes. "For I have no doubt that it is somewhere in this house."

Morstan looked at the others, and then at Holmes. "I do not know," he said. "I swear I do not know."

"Then I shall have to search for it," said Holmes. "And I shall find it."

With that, Holmes walked out of the room, and I followed him. We found ourselves in the hall, and the butler was waiting for us.

"Mr. Holmes," he said. "I was not expecting you to leave so soon."

"I am not leaving," said Holmes. "I am merely going to search the house

events.title: Revealing the Murder Weapon and Killer Profile
detailed_summary: Returning to Ross in the cab, Holmes presents the stone to Lestrade.
He declares it the murder weapon.
Lestrade sees no marks, but Holmes explains the grass growing under it showed it was recently placed there, no source was nearby, and it matched the injuries, with no other weapon found.
Holmes describes the murderer: tall, left-handed, limps with the right leg, wears thick-soled shooting boots and a grey cloak, smokes Indian cigars using a holder, and carries a blunt pen-knife.
Lestrade remains skeptical, prioritizing hard evidence for a jury over Holmes's theories.
Holmes calmly states they will see ('Nous verrons') and that he will work his way while Lestrade works his.
Holmes announces he'll be busy that afternoon and likely return to London that evening, claiming the case is finished and solved.
He identifies the criminal only as 'The gentleman I describe,' suggesting Lestrade should be able to find him in the sparsely populated area.
Lestrade dismisses the task of finding a left-handed man with a limp as impractical and likely to make him a laughing-stock.
Holmes quietly accepts Lestrade's refusal, drops him at his lodgings, and says he'll send a note before leaving.
Back at the hotel, Holmes is silent and thoughtful during lunch, appearing perplexed.
After the meal, Holmes asks Watson to listen as he needs advice and wants to explain his reasoning.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Light a cigar and let me expound.”

events.text_segment:
It was about ten minutes before we regained our cab and drove back into Ross, Holmes still carrying with him the stone which he had picked up in the wood.
“This may interest you, Lestrade,” he remarked, holding it out. “The murder was done with it.”
“I see no marks.”
“There are none.”
“How do you know, then?”
“The grass was growing under it. It had only lain there a few days. There was no sign of a place whence it had been taken. It corresponds with the injuries. There is no sign of any other weapon.”
“And the murderer?”
“Is a tall man, left-handed, limps with the right leg, wears thick-soled shooting-boots and a grey cloak, smokes Indian cigars, uses a cigar-holder, and carries a blunt pen-knife in his pocket. There are several other indications, but these may be enough to aid us in our search.”
Lestrade laughed. “I am afraid that I am still a sceptic,” he said. “Theories are all very well, but we have to deal with a hard-headed British jury.”
“Nous verrons,” answered Holmes calmly. “You work your own method, and I shall work mine. I shall be busy this afternoon, and shall probably return to London by the evening train.”
“And leave your case unfinished?”
“No, finished.”
“But the mystery?”
“It is solved.”
“Who was the criminal, then?”
“The gentleman I describe.”
“But who is he?”
“Surely it would not be difficult to find out. This is not such a populous neighbourhood.”
Lestrade shrugged his shoulders. “I am a practical man,” he said, “and I really cannot undertake to go about the country looking for a left-handed gentleman with a game leg. I should become the laughing-stock of Scotland Yard.”
“All right,” said Holmes quietly. “I have given you the chance. Here are your lodgings. Good-bye. I shall drop you a line before I leave.”
Having left Lestrade at his rooms, we drove to our hotel, where we found lunch upon the table. Holmes was silent and buried in thought with a pained expression upon his face, as one who finds himself in a perplexing position.
“Look here, Watson,” he said when the cloth was cleared “just sit down in this chair and let me preach to you for a little. I don’t know quite what to do, and I should value your advice. Light a cigar and let me expound.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: It was about ten minutes before we regained our cab and drove back into Ross, Holmes still carrying with him the stone which he had picked up in the wood. "I think that this will serve as a link in the chain," he remarked, as he handed it to Lestrade. The inspector turned it over carefully in his hand. "There is no mark upon it," he said. "No, but there is the fresh imprint of the grass which grew beneath it. It was placed there recently, for there is no other stone of the kind in the neighbourhood, and it exactly corresponds to the injuries. There is no other weapon to be found." "You are very clever, Mr. Holmes," said Lestrade, with a touch of impatience, "but I must have something more tangible for the jury than these deductions of yours." "Nous verrons," said Holmes quietly. "You work your way and I will work mine." He looked at his watch. "I shall be very busy this afternoon, and I may return to London to-night. The case is complete, and I have no doubt as to the result." "And who is the criminal?" asked Lestrade. "The gentleman I describe," said Holmes. "In such a sparsely populated district as this, you should have no difficulty in finding him." "A left-handed man with a limp," murmured Lestrade, "and a grey cloak and thick-soled shooting boots. It is a very interesting problem, but I fear it would make me a laughing-stock if I were to set about it." Holmes smiled faintly. "Very well, Inspector, I shall not trouble you further. I will drop you at your lodgings on the way." As we drove back, Holmes was silent and thoughtful, his brow furrowed in deep concentration. At the hotel, he was still preoccupied during lunch, and I saw that his mind was far away. After the meal, he turned to me with a sudden decision. "Watson," he said, "I must have your advice. I want to explain my reasoning to you."
