events.title: The Second Warning and Joseph Openshaw's Death
detailed_summary: At John's request, his father examined the locked attic room upon inheriting the Horsham property.
They found the empty brass box with the K.K.K. initials and a label inside indicating 'Letters, memoranda, receipts, and a register' had been destroyed.
Other papers related to the uncle's time in America, including his creditable war service and involvement in opposing post-war politicians in the South.
John's father moved to Horsham in early 1884, and life proceeded normally until January 1885.
On January 4th, while at breakfast, John's father cried out in surprise, holding a newly opened envelope and five orange pips.
Despite having previously dismissed John's story about the Colonel, he now looked frightened.
John identified the envelope's contents as 'K. K. K.'
His father read an additional message above the initials: 'Put the papers on the sundial'.
Confused about which papers and sundial were meant, John suggested the sundial in the garden and the destroyed papers.
His father dismissed the message as 'tomfoolery' from Dundee, refusing to involve the police for fear of ridicule.
He forbade John from contacting the police either.
John remained deeply worried.
Three days later, his father visited Major Freebody at Portsdown Hill.
John felt relief thinking his father was safer away from home, but this proved wrong.
On the second day of his father's absence, John received a telegram from the Major urging him to come at once.
His father had fallen into a deep, unfenced chalk pit near Fareham while returning in the twilight and was found unconscious with a shattered skull.
He died without regaining consciousness.
The jury ruled it 'death from accidental causes' due to the unfamiliar and unfenced terrain.
Despite a careful examination, John found no evidence of murder (no violence, footprints, robbery, or strangers reported).
Nevertheless, John remained convinced his father was a victim of a foul plot.
John thus inherited the sinister estate, keeping it because he believed the danger stemmed from his uncle's past and would follow him regardless of location.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “When my father took over the Horsham property, he, at my request, made a careful examination of the attic, which had been always locked up.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “In this sinister way I came into my inheritance. You will ask me why I did not dispose of it? I answer, because I was well convinced that our troubles were in some way dependent upon an incident in my uncle’s life, and that the danger would be as pressing in one house as in another.

events.text_segment:
“When my father took over the Horsham property, he, at my request, made a careful examination of the attic, which had been always locked up. We found the brass box there, although its contents had been destroyed. On the inside of the cover was a paper label, with the initials of K. K. K. repeated upon it, and ‘Letters, memoranda, receipts, and a register’ written beneath. These, we presume, indicated the nature of the papers which had been destroyed by Colonel Openshaw. For the rest, there was nothing of much importance in the attic save a great many scattered papers and note-books bearing upon my uncle’s life in America. Some of them were of the war time and showed that he had done his duty well and had borne the repute of a brave soldier. Others were of a date during the reconstruction of the Southern states, and were mostly concerned with politics, for he had evidently taken a strong part in opposing the carpet-bag politicians who had been sent down from the North.
“Well, it was the beginning of ’84 when my father came to live at Horsham, and all went as well as possible with us until the January of ’85. On the fourth day after the new year I heard my father give a sharp cry of surprise as we sat together at the breakfast-table. There he was, sitting with a newly opened envelope in one hand and five dried orange pips in the outstretched palm of the other one. He had always laughed at what he called my cock-and-bull story about the colonel, but he looked very scared and puzzled now that the same thing had come upon himself.
“‘Why, what on earth does this mean, John?’ he stammered.
“My heart had turned to lead. ‘It is K. K. K.,’ said I.
“He looked inside the envelope. ‘So it is,’ he cried. ‘Here are the very letters. But what is this written above them?’
“‘Put the papers on the sundial,’ I read, peeping over his shoulder.
“‘What papers? What sundial?’ he asked.
“‘The sundial in the garden. There is no other,’ said I; ‘but the papers must be those that are destroyed.’
“‘Pooh!’ said he, gripping hard at his courage. ‘We are in a civilised land here, and we can’t have tomfoolery of this kind. Where does the thing come from?’
“‘From Dundee,’ I answered, glancing at the postmark.
“‘Some preposterous practical joke,’ said he. ‘What have I to do with sundials and papers? I shall take no notice of such nonsense.’
“‘I should certainly speak to the police,’ I said.
“‘And be laughed at for my pains. Nothing of the sort.’
“‘Then let me do so?’
“‘No, I forbid you. I won’t have a fuss made about such nonsense.’
“It was in vain to argue with him, for he was a very obstinate man. I went about, however, with a heart which was full of forebodings.
“On the third day after the coming of the letter my father went from home to visit an old friend of his, Major Freebody, who is in command of one of the forts upon Portsdown Hill. I was glad that he should go, for it seemed to me that he was farther from danger when he was away from home. In that, however, I was in error. Upon the second day of his absence I received a telegram from the major, imploring me to come at once. My father had fallen over one of the deep chalk-pits which abound in the neighbourhood, and was lying senseless, with a shattered skull. I hurried to him, but he passed away without having ever recovered his consciousness. He had, as it appears, been returning from Fareham in the twilight, and as the country was unknown to him, and the chalk-pit unfenced, the jury had no hesitation in bringing in a verdict of ‘death from accidental causes.’ Carefully as I examined every fact connected with his death, I was unable to find anything which could suggest the idea of murder. There were no signs of violence, no footmarks, no robbery, no record of strangers having been seen upon the roads. And yet I need not tell you that my mind was far from at ease, and that I was well-nigh certain that some foul plot had been woven round him.
“In this sinister way I came into my inheritance. You will ask me why I did not dispose of it? I answer, because I was well convinced that our troubles were in some way dependent upon an incident in my uncle’s life, and that the danger would be as pressing in one house as in another.

The key had been handed down in the family, and the place had never been entered since the death of my uncle, who had left it in such a condition. The room was small and square, with a sloping ceiling, and the air was heavy with the smell of mildew and decay. In one corner stood a large, brass-bound box, which was locked, and on the lid was the inscription 'K.K.K.' I had heard of this box before, for my uncle had once mentioned it in a letter, and had spoken of it with a kind of grim satisfaction. My father, with some difficulty, forced the lid open, and we found inside a number of papers, all of which had been burned and the ashes carefully preserved. There was also a label, which stated that the contents had been destroyed by my uncle himself, and that they consisted of 'Letters, memoranda, receipts, and a register.' My father was a man of some education, and he was able to make out from the fragments of the papers that my uncle had been a man of some importance in the South during the war, and that he had been engaged in some political work after the war. LLM_completions.prefix-probing: When my father took over the Horsham property, he, at my request, made a careful examination of the attic, which had been always locked up. The key had been lost for many years, and the door was forced open with some difficulty. Inside, the place was in a state of complete disarray, with dust-covered furniture, broken windowpanes, and a general air of neglect. My father, with the help of a local carpenter, managed to clear a space and began to search through the debris. It was during this search that he discovered a small, hidden compartment in the wall behind a loose panel. Inside the compartment was a bundle of old letters tied with a faded ribbon. The letters were addressed to my great-grandmother, and the handwriting was unmistakably that of my great-grandfather, who had died under mysterious circumstances many years ago. The contents of the letters were most peculiar. They spoke of a secret meeting, a hidden treasure, and a curse that had befallen the family. My father, being a man of science and reason, dismissed the idea of a curse as mere superstition, but the mention of a hidden treasure intrigued him. He continued his search and found a small, rusted key among the other items in the compartment. The key was inscribed with the initials 'J.H.' and a date that corresponded to the time of my great-grandfather's death. My father, now thoroughly engrossed in the mystery, began to investigate the history of the Horsham property and the family's past. He consulted old records, spoke to the village elders, and even visited the local library to uncover any references to the family's history. What he found was both fascinating and disturbing. The Horsham family had a long and storied past, filled with both triumph and tragedy. There were tales of a great fortune that had once been amassed through trade and industry, but also of a series of untimely deaths and disappearances that had plagued the family for generations. My father, now convinced that there was more to the story than mere coincidence, began to piece together the events that had led to the family's decline. He discovered that my great-grandfather had been a man of considerable intellect and ambition, but also of great secrecy. He had been involved in a number of business ventures, some of which had ended in failure, and others of which had been shrouded in mystery. The letters he had written to my great-grandmother hinted at a secret society, a hidden knowledge, and a treasure that had been lost to time. My father, now fully immersed in the mystery, began to suspect that the treasure was not merely a physical object, but something more intangible—a secret that had been passed down through the generations. He began to search for any clues that might lead him to the truth, and it was during this search that he discovered a hidden room beneath the house. The room had been sealed off for many years, and the entrance was concealed behind a false wall in the library. Inside the room, he found a number of old books, maps, and documents that provided further insight into the family's past. Among these items was a journal that belonged to my great-grandfather, which detailed his final days and the events that had led to his death. The society was said to have been a group of scholars and mystics who had sought to uncover the secrets of the universe, but who had also been involved in a number of dark and dangerous experiments. events.title: John Openshaw Receives the Third Warning and Presents a Clue
detailed_summary: John explains that two years and eight months passed peacefully after his father's death in January 1885.
He had started to hope the family curse had ended.
However, yesterday morning, the threat reappeared in the same form.
He produces a crumpled envelope and shakes five dried orange pips onto the table.
He shows the envelope, postmarked London eastern division, containing the message 'K. K. K.' and 'Put the papers on the sundial'.
When Holmes asks what he has done, Openshaw admits 'Nothing'.
He confesses feeling helpless, like prey cornered by an inescapable evil.
Holmes sharply admonishes him, urging immediate action to avoid being lost.
Openshaw reveals he went to the police, but they dismissed his story as practical jokes and considered his relatives' deaths accidents.
Holmes reacts with frustration at the police's 'incredible imbecility'.
Openshaw mentions the police assigned an officer to stay at his house, but he didn't accompany him to London.
Holmes again shows exasperation and asks why Openshaw didn't come to him immediately.
Openshaw explains he only spoke to Major Prendergast today, who advised consulting Holmes.
Holmes notes two days have passed since the letter arrived, emphasizing the lost time.
He asks if Openshaw has any further suggestive details.
Openshaw remembers something: on the day his uncle burned the papers, he noticed the unburned edges were of a particular blue tint.
He produces a single sheet of discolored, blue-tinted paper found on the floor of his uncle's room, possibly escaped from the fire.
He believes it might be a page from his uncle's private diary, written in his hand, though unsure of its helpfulness beyond mentioning pips.

Holmes examines the torn page, headed 'March, 1869,' which contains cryptic entries: '4th. Hudson came. Same old platform.', '7th. Set the pips on McCauley, Paramore, and John Swain of St. Augustine.', '9th. McCauley cleared.', '10th. John Swain cleared.', '12th. Visited Paramore. All well.'

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “It was in January, ’85, that my poor father met his end, and two years and eight months have elapsed since then.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “12th. Visited Paramore. All well.”

events.text_segment:
“It was in January, ’85, that my poor father met his end, and two years and eight months have elapsed since then. During that time I have lived happily at Horsham, and I had begun to hope that this curse had passed away from the family, and that it had ended with the last generation. I had begun to take comfort too soon, however; yesterday morning the blow fell in the very shape in which it had come upon my father.”
The young man took from his waistcoat a crumpled envelope, and turning to the table he shook out upon it five little dried orange pips.
“This is the envelope,” he continued. “The postmark is London—eastern division. Within are the very words which were upon my father’s last message: ‘K. K. K.’; and then ‘Put the papers on the sundial.’”
“What have you done?” asked Holmes.
“Nothing.”
“Nothing?”
“To tell the truth”—he sank his face into his thin, white hands—“I have felt helpless. I have felt like one of those poor rabbits when the snake is writhing towards it. I seem to be in the grasp of some resistless, inexorable evil, which no foresight and no precautions can guard against.”
“Tut! tut!” cried Sherlock Holmes. “You must act, man, or you are lost. Nothing but energy can save you. This is no time for despair.”
“I have seen the police.”
“Ah!”
“But they listened to my story with a smile. I am convinced that the inspector has formed the opinion that the letters are all practical jokes, and that the deaths of my relations were really accidents, as the jury stated, and were not to be connected with the warnings.”
Holmes shook his clenched hands in the air. “Incredible imbecility!” he cried.
“They have, however, allowed me a policeman, who may remain in the house with me.”
“Has he come with you to-night?”
“No. His orders were to stay in the house.”
Again Holmes raved in the air.
“Why did you come to me?” he said, “and, above all, why did you not come at once?”
“I did not know. It was only to-day that I spoke to Major Prendergast about my troubles and was advised by him to come to you.”
“It is really two days since you had the letter. We should have acted before this. You have no further evidence, I suppose, than that which you have placed before us—no suggestive detail which might help us?”
“There is one thing,” said John Openshaw. He rummaged in his coat pocket, and, drawing out a piece of discoloured, blue-tinted paper, he laid it out upon the table. “I have some remembrance,” said he, “that on the day when my uncle burned the papers I observed that the small, unburned margins which lay amid the ashes were of this particular colour. I found this single sheet upon the floor of his room, and I am inclined to think that it may be one of the papers which has, perhaps, fluttered out from among the others, and in that way has escaped destruction. Beyond the mention of pips, I do not see that it helps us much. I think myself that it is a page from some private diary. The writing is undoubtedly my uncle’s.”
Holmes moved the lamp, and we both bent over the sheet of paper, which showed by its ragged edge that it had indeed been torn from a book. It was headed, “March, 1869,” and beneath were the following enigmatical notices:
“4th. Hudson came. Same old platform.
“7th. Set the pips on McCauley, Paramore, and John Swain of St. Augustine.
“9th. McCauley cleared.
“10th. John Swain cleared.
“12th. Visited Paramore. All well.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: It was in January, ’85, that my poor father met his end, and two years and eight months have elapsed since then. I have never been able to forget the tragedy, nor to understand the circumstances which led to it. My father, Mr. John Hargrave, was a man of some standing in the city of London, a respected solicitor with a large practice. He was a man of quiet habits, of few friends, and of even fewer enemies. Yet, on that fateful night, he was found dead in his study, the room locked from within, and no sign of violence upon his person. The police were baffled, and the matter was closed with the verdict of 'death by natural causes.' But I know better. I have always known better. My father was not a man given to sudden illness, and the manner of his death was too strange to be dismissed so easily. I have spent the past two years and eight months trying to uncover the truth, and I have come to believe that my father was the victim of a most cunning and deliberate crime. I have followed every lead, consulted every expert, and yet I have found no one who can explain the mystery. It was in the hope of finding some clue that I came to Baker Street, for I have heard of the great detective, Sherlock Holmes, and I have heard of his remarkable ability to solve the most perplexing of cases. I have heard, too, of his companion, Dr. Watson, and I have heard of the many cases in which they have worked together. I have come to you, Mr. Holmes, in the hope that you may be able to shed some light upon the matter. I have come to you because I believe that no one else can help me. I have come to you because I believe that you are the only man in London who can solve the mystery of my father's death. I have come to you because I believe that you are the only man in London who can bring the murderer to justice.

events.title: Holmes Gives Urgent Instructions and Warnings
detailed_summary: Holmes quickly returns the diary page to Openshaw, stressing the need for immediate action without further discussion.
He instructs Openshaw to return home instantly.
The plan: place the diary page into the brass box along with a convincing note stating all other papers were burned by his uncle and this is the sole remaining one.
This box must then be placed immediately on the sundial as directed.
Holmes advises against seeking revenge for now, focusing first on removing the immediate danger to Openshaw.
The secondary goals are solving the mystery and punishing the culprits.
Openshaw, revitalized with hope, agrees to follow the advice precisely.
Holmes reiterates the urgency and warns Openshaw to be extremely careful, as he is undoubtedly in real and imminent danger.
Openshaw confirms he will travel back by train from Waterloo and that he is armed.
Holmes notes the streets will be crowded before 9 PM, offering some safety, but urges extreme caution.
Holmes states he will begin working on the case tomorrow, investigating in London, not Horsham, as the secret lies there.
Openshaw promises to report back in a day or two about the box and papers.
He shakes hands and departs into the stormy night.
Watson reflects on the wild story feeling as if it blew in with the storm and was reabsorbed by it.
Holmes sits silently by the fire for some time.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Thank you!” said Holmes, folding up the paper and returning it to our visitor.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: This strange, wild story seemed to have come to us from amid the mad elements—blown in upon us like a sheet of sea-weed in a gale—and now to have been reabsorbed by them once more.

events.text_segment:
“Thank you!” said Holmes, folding up the paper and returning it to our visitor. “And now you must on no account lose another instant. We cannot spare time even to discuss what you have told me. You must get home instantly and act.”
“What shall I do?”
“There is but one thing to do. It must be done at once. You must put this piece of paper which you have shown us into the brass box which you have described. You must also put in a note to say that all the other papers were burned by your uncle, and that this is the only one which remains. You must assert that in such words as will carry conviction with them. Having done this, you must at once put the box out upon the sundial, as directed. Do you understand?”
“Entirely.”
“Do not think of revenge, or anything of the sort, at present. I think that we may gain that by means of the law; but we have our web to weave, while theirs is already woven. The first consideration is to remove the pressing danger which threatens you. The second is to clear up the mystery and to punish the guilty parties.”
“I thank you,” said the young man, rising and pulling on his overcoat. “You have given me fresh life and hope. I shall certainly do as you advise.”
“Do not lose an instant. And, above all, take care of yourself in the meanwhile, for I do not think that there can be a doubt that you are threatened by a very real and imminent danger. How do you go back?”
“By train from Waterloo.”
“It is not yet nine. The streets will be crowded, so I trust that you may be in safety. And yet you cannot guard yourself too closely.”
“I am armed.”
“That is well. To-morrow I shall set to work upon your case.”
“I shall see you at Horsham, then?”
“No, your secret lies in London. It is there that I shall seek it.”
“Then I shall call upon you in a day, or in two days, with news as to the box and the papers. I shall take your advice in every particular.” He shook hands with us and took his leave. Outside the wind still screamed and the rain splashed and pattered against the windows. This strange, wild story seemed to have come to us from amid the mad elements—blown in upon us like a sheet of sea-weed in a gale—and now to have been reabsorbed by them once more.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"Thank you!" said Holmes, folding up the paper and returning it to our visitor. "I think that we had better say no more at present. You must go home at once, and you must do exactly as I tell you."

"But what about the men?" cried Openshaw, his face working with passion.

"Revenge comes afterwards, if it comes at all. First, you must be safe. You are in imminent danger."

"But what can I do?"

"You will do as I direct. Take this paper and put it into the brass box with a note to the effect that all the other papers were burned by your uncle, and that this is the only one which remains. Then place the box at once upon the sundial in the garden, as I have directed."

"But why the sundial?"

"Because it is the only place where it can be found by those who are watching."

"And then?"

"Then you must be careful. You are in danger, and you must be very careful."

"I will be. I will do exactly as you say."

"Good. You will go by the train from Waterloo, and you will be armed."

"I am."

"The streets will be full before nine, and that is some protection. But be careful."

"I will."

"I shall begin my inquiries to-morrow. I shall not go to Horsham, for the secret lies in London."

"And you think that the men will come?"

"I think that they will."

"Then I shall be ready."

"Good. And if you hear anything, you will let me know."

"I will."

He rose and shook hands with us, and then, with a last glance at the storm-lashed window, he passed out into the night.

Watson and I sat in silence for a while, the firelight flickering upon the walls. It was a wild story, this, which had blown in with the storm and was now to be reabsorbed by it. But Holmes, with his quiet, iron will, had already set the wheels in motion, and I knew that the mystery of the five orange pips was about to be solved."}

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Thank you!” said Holmes, folding up the paper and returning it to our visitor. “I think I have all the information I need. I shall be in touch if there is anything further required.”

Our visitor, a tall, thin man with a nervous manner, rose from his chair and bowed slightly. “I am most grateful, Mr. Holmes. I shall await your call with the utmost anticipation.” He turned and left, closing the door behind him with a soft click.

I looked at Holmes, who was already deep in thought, his long fingers steepled beneath his chin. “Well, Watson,” he said, without looking up, “what do you make of it?”

I hesitated. “I confess I am at a loss. The man was clearly agitated, but I could not discern the nature of his trouble. He spoke of a letter, a missing heirloom, and a shadowy figure who had been watching him for some time.”

Holmes gave a faint smile. “Ah, yes. The letter is the key. It is not the letter itself that is important, but the contents. The heirloom is a red herring, though it may yet prove useful. And the shadowy figure—ah, now that is more intriguing. A man who watches without being seen is a man with a purpose.”

I leaned forward. “And what is that purpose, Holmes?”

He looked at me then, his eyes sharp and bright. “That is what I intend to discover. The man is afraid, Watson. He is afraid of something—or someone. And he has come to me because he believes I can help him.”

I nodded. “And you believe you can?”

Holmes rose from his chair and began to pace the room. “I believe I can, yes. The case is not without precedent. There are those who would use fear as a weapon, and there are those who would use it as a shield. I must determine which this man is.”

I watched him as he moved, his mind clearly already at work. “And what of the letter?” I asked. “You said it was the key.”

Holmes stopped and turned to me. “Yes. The letter is the key. It is the only thing that connects the man to the mystery. If I can find the letter, I can find the truth.”

I was about to ask more when the door opened and Mrs. Hudson entered with tea. Holmes accepted the tray with a nod and poured us each a cup. “We shall speak more of this later, Watson,” he said, sipping his tea. “For now, I must make a few inquiries. I have a feeling this case will prove most interesting.”

events.title: Holmes Deduces the K.K.K.'s Identity and Method
detailed_summary: After Openshaw leaves, Holmes lights his pipe and reflects, remarking to Watson that this case is among their most fantastic, possibly rivaling the Sign of Four.
He feels Openshaw is in even greater peril than the Sholtos.
When Watson asks about the nature of the perils and the identity of K.K.K., Holmes explains his method of reasoning.
He states an ideal reasoner could deduce entire chains of events from a single fact, like Cuvier reconstructing an animal from one bone.
Achieving this requires utilizing all relevant knowledge, which Holmes has endeavored to acquire for his work.

Watson recalls his earlier analysis of Holmes's knowledge limitations (zero in philosophy, astronomy, politics; variable botany; profound geology of local mud; eccentric chemistry; unsystematic anatomy; unique crime/sensational lit; skilled violinist, boxer, swordsman, lawyer, self-poisoner).
Holmes reaffirms his principle of keeping only useful knowledge readily accessible.
Turning to the case, Holmes requests the 'K' volume of the American Encyclopædia.
He posits Colonel Openshaw must have had a strong reason to leave America and his Florida life for seclusion in England, suggesting fear.
The threatening letters confirm this fear.
Holmes notes the postmarks: Pondicherry, Dundee, East London – all seaports.
Watson deduces the writer was likely on a ship.
Holmes agrees, calling it a clue.
He then analyzes the time lapse between warning and action: seven weeks from Pondicherry, only days from Dundee.
He dismisses Watson's suggestion of distance alone, pointing out the letter also traveled faster.

Holmes presumes the perpetrators are on a sailing ship, sending the warning ahead; the seven weeks from Pondicherry represented the time difference between the faster mail boat carrying the letter and the slower sailing vessel carrying the senders.
This makes the London postmark critically urgent, implying the senders are already present and no delay can be expected.
Watson exclaims in horror.
Holmes concludes the papers are vital to the K.K.K., which must be a society, not an individual, given the complexity of the two deaths that fooled coroners.
He identifies K.K.K. by asking Watson if he's heard of the Ku Klux Klan.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Sherlock Holmes sat for some time in silence, with his head sunk forward and his eyes bent upon the red glow of the fire.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Have you never—” said Sherlock Holmes, bending forward and sinking his voice—“have you never heard of the Ku Klux Klan?”

events.text_segment:
Sherlock Holmes sat for some time in silence, with his head sunk forward and his eyes bent upon the red glow of the fire. Then he lit his pipe, and leaning back in his chair he watched the blue smoke-rings as they chased each other up to the ceiling.
“I think, Watson,” he remarked at last, “that of all our cases we have had none more fantastic than this.”
“Save, perhaps, the Sign of Four.”
“Well, yes. Save, perhaps, that. And yet this John Openshaw seems to me to be walking amid even greater perils than did the Sholtos.”
“But have you,” I asked, “formed any definite conception as to what these perils are?”
“There can be no question as to their nature,” he answered.
“Then what are they? Who is this K. K. K., and why does he pursue this unhappy family?”
Sherlock Holmes closed his eyes and placed his elbows upon the arms of his chair, with his finger-tips together. “The ideal reasoner,” he remarked, “would, when he had once been shown a single fact in all its bearings, deduce from it not only all the chain of events which led up to it but also all the results which would follow from it. As Cuvier could correctly describe a whole animal by the contemplation of a single bone, so the observer who has thoroughly understood one link in a series of incidents should be able to accurately state all the other ones, both before and after. We have not yet grasped the results which the reason alone can attain to. Problems may be solved in the study which have baffled all those who have sought a solution by the aid of their senses. To carry the art, however, to its highest pitch, it is necessary that the reasoner should be able to utilise all the facts which have come to his knowledge; and this in itself implies, as you will readily see, a possession of all knowledge, which, even in these days of free education and encyclopædias, is a somewhat rare accomplishment. It is not so impossible, however, that a man should possess all knowledge which is likely to be useful to him in his work, and this I have endeavoured in my case to do. If I remember rightly, you on one occasion, in the early days of our friendship, defined my limits in a very precise fashion.”
“Yes,” I answered, laughing. “It was a singular document. Philosophy, astronomy, and politics were marked at zero, I remember. Botany variable, geology profound as regards the mud-stains from any region within fifty miles of town, chemistry eccentric, anatomy unsystematic, sensational literature and crime records unique, violin-player, boxer, swordsman, lawyer, and self-poisoner by cocaine and tobacco. Those, I think, were the main points of my analysis.”
Holmes grinned at the last item. “Well,” he said, “I say now, as I said then, that a man should keep his little brain-attic stocked with all the furniture that he is likely to use, and the rest he can put away in the lumber-room of his library, where he can get it if he wants it. Now, for such a case as the one which has been submitted to us to-night, we need certainly to muster all our resources. Kindly hand me down the letter K of the American Encyclopædia which stands upon the shelf beside you. Thank you. Now let us consider the situation and see what may be deduced from it. In the first place, we may start with a strong presumption that Colonel Openshaw had some very strong reason for leaving America. Men at his time of life do not change all their habits and exchange willingly the charming climate of Florida for the lonely life of an English provincial town. His extreme love of solitude in England suggests the idea that he was in fear of someone or something, so we may assume as a working hypothesis that it was fear of someone or something which drove him from America. As to what it was he feared, we can only deduce that by considering the formidable letters which were received by himself and his successors. Did you remark the postmarks of those letters?”
“The first was from Pondicherry, the second from Dundee, and the third from London.”
“From East London. What do you deduce from that?”
“They are all seaports. That the writer was on board of a ship.”
“Excellent. We have already a clue. There can be no doubt that the probability—the strong probability—is that the writer was on board of a ship. And now let us consider another point. In the case of Pondicherry, seven weeks elapsed between the threat and its fulfilment, in Dundee it was only some three or four days. Does that suggest anything?”
“A greater distance to travel.”
“But the letter had also a greater distance to come.”
“Then I do not see the point.”
“There is at least a presumption that the vessel in which the man or men are is a sailing-ship. It looks as if they always send their singular warning or token before them when starting upon their mission. You see how quickly the deed followed the sign when it came from Dundee. If they had come from Pondicherry in a steamer they would have arrived almost as soon as their letter. But, as a matter of fact, seven weeks elapsed. I think that those seven weeks represented the difference between the mail-boat which brought the letter and the sailing vessel which brought the writer.”
“It is possible.”
“More than that. It is probable. And now you see the deadly urgency of this new case, and why I urged young Openshaw to caution. The blow has always fallen at the end of the time which it would take the senders to travel the distance. But this one comes from London, and therefore we cannot count upon delay.”
“Good God!” I cried. “What can it mean, this relentless persecution?”
“The papers which Openshaw carried are obviously of vital importance to the person or persons in the sailing-ship. I think that it is quite clear that there must be more than one of them. A single man could not have carried out two deaths in such a way as to deceive a coroner’s jury. There must have been several in it, and they must have been men of resource and determination. Their papers they mean to have, be the holder of them who it may. In this way you see K. K. K. ceases to be the initials of an individual and becomes the badge of a society.”
“But of what society?”
“Have you never—” said Sherlock Holmes, bending forward and sinking his voice—“have you never heard of the Ku Klux Klan?”

Sherlock Holmes sat for some time in silence, with his head sunk forward and his eyes bent upon the red glow of the fire. At last he leaned back with a sigh, and lit his pipe with a hand that I noted was a little unsteady. "This is a case," he remarked, "which will rank, I think, among the most singular that we have ever handled. It has some points in common with the Sign of Four, but I fancy that it will prove even more complex." I had heard him use the same phrase before, and I knew that it was a sign of his keenest interest. "The man is in greater danger than the Sholtos," he continued, "for he is not only threatened, but he is being watched. The letters are not the work of a madman, but of a secret society, and that society is the K.K.K." I started at the words. "The K.K.K.!", I cried. "The Ku Klux Klan?" "Precisely," said Holmes. "You have heard of them, no doubt. They are a secret organization in the United States, formed after the war, and devoted to the suppression of the freedmen. They have been responsible for many outrages, and they have always been a terror to the negro population. But they are not merely a local organization. They have branches in many parts of the world, and they are not to be despised. The initials K.K.K. stand for the Ku Klux Klan, and it is they who are behind these letters."

"But how do you know this?" I asked. "I have not yet told you," said Holmes, "how I arrived at this conclusion. It is by the same method which I have always used, and which I have explained to you before. An ideal reasoner would, if he allowed his mind to work unhampered by prejudice or tradition, be like Cuvier in reconstructing an animal from a single bone. He would take the facts, and from them deduce the whole. I have endeavoured to do this in my own small way."

"But you have told me before," I said, "that you have no knowledge of philosophy, and that you are ignorant of astronomy, and that you know nothing of politics."

"That is true," said Holmes. "I have no knowledge which is not useful. I have no hobby-horse. My brain is like a little empty attic, and I must be careful to keep it stocked with useful knowledge only."

"But you have a vast amount of knowledge," I said.

"Yes," said Holmes, "but it is all useful. I know the number of steps which lead down to the cellar of the hotel in which we are now sitting. I know the exact number of the carriages in the London and North Western Railway. I know the number of the houses in Baker Street. I know the number of the books in the British Museum. I know the number of the volumes in the American Encyclopædia."

"But what use is all this?" I asked.

"It is useful," said Holmes, "when I want to find out something about the K.K.K."

He rose and walked to the bookcase, and took down the volume which I had just mentioned. "I think," he said, "that we shall find something of interest in this book."

It is a secret society, formed in the United States after the war, and devoted to the suppression of the freedmen. They have been responsible for many outrages, and they have always been a terror to the negro population. But they are not merely a local organization. They have branches in many parts of the world, and they are not to be despised."

"But what has this to do with our case?" I asked.

"Everything," said Holmes. "The man who sent these letters is a member of the K.K.K. He is a white man, and he is a southerner. He is a man of education, and he is a man of courage. He is a man who is not afraid to do what he thinks right, and he is a man who is not afraid to die. He is a man who is not afraid to kill."

"But why should he send these letters?" I asked.

"Because he is a man of principle," said Holmes. "He is a man who believes in the supremacy of the white race, and he is a man who believes in the subjugation of the negro. events.title: The Ku Klux Klan Connection Revealed
detailed_summary: Watson admits he has never heard of the Ku Klux Klan.
Holmes finds the entry in the American Encyclopædia he requested earlier.
He reads aloud the description: a terrible secret society formed by ex-Confederate soldiers post-Civil War, using terror for political ends, particularly against Black voters and opponents.
Their outrages were often preceded by symbolic warnings (oak leaves, melon seeds, orange pips).
Victims could recant or flee; defiance meant certain death, often in strange ways.
The organization was highly effective and elusive, flourishing for years despite government efforts.
It suddenly collapsed around 1869, though sporadic incidents continued.
Holmes points out the collapse coincided with Colonel Openshaw's departure from America with 'their papers', suggesting cause and effect.
He explains this makes it understandable why implacable members are tracking the family, as the register and diary likely implicate prominent Southern figures who want the documents destroyed.
He interprets the diary page Watson saw: 'sent the pips' meant sending the Klan warning; 'cleared' meant the targets left the country; 'visited' implied a sinister outcome for Paramore.
Holmes believes they can shed light on the matter and that Openshaw's only current chance is following his instructions.
Concluding the discussion for the night, Holmes asks for his violin to distract from the grim weather and human behavior.

events.text_segment:
“I never have.”
Holmes turned over the leaves of the book upon his knee. “Here it is,” said he presently:
“‘Ku Klux Klan. A name derived from the fanciful resemblance to the sound produced by cocking a rifle. This terrible secret society was formed by some ex-Confederate soldiers in the Southern states after the Civil War, and it rapidly formed local branches in different parts of the country, notably in Tennessee, Louisiana, the Carolinas, Georgia, and Florida. Its power was used for political purposes, principally for the terrorising of the negro voters and the murdering and driving from the country of those who were opposed to its views. Its outrages were usually preceded by a warning sent to the marked man in some fantastic but generally recognised shape—a sprig of oak-leaves in some parts, melon seeds or orange pips in others. On receiving this the victim might either openly abjure his former ways, or might fly from the country. If he braved the matter out, death would unfailingly come upon him, and usually in some strange and unforeseen manner. So perfect was the organisation of the society, and so systematic its methods, that there is hardly a case upon record where any man succeeded in braving it with impunity, or in which any of its outrages were traced home to the perpetrators. For some years the organisation flourished in spite of the efforts of the United States government and of the better classes of the community in the South. Eventually, in the year 1869, the movement rather suddenly collapsed, although there have been sporadic outbreaks of the same sort since that date.’
“You will observe,” said Holmes, laying down the volume, “that the sudden breaking up of the society was coincident with the disappearance of Openshaw from America with their papers. It may well have been cause and effect. It is no wonder that he and his family have some of the more implacable spirits upon their track. You can understand that this register and diary may implicate some of the first men in the South, and that there may be many who will not sleep easy at night until it is recovered.”
“Then the page we have seen—”
“Is such as we might expect. It ran, if I remember right, ‘sent the pips to A, B, and C’—that is, sent the society’s warning to them. Then there are successive entries that A and B cleared, or left the country, and finally that C was visited, with, I fear, a sinister result for C. Well, I think, Doctor, that we may let some light into this dark place, and I believe that the only chance young Openshaw has in the meantime is to do what I have told him. There is nothing more to be said or to be done to-night, so hand me over my violin and let us try to forget for half an hour the miserable weather and the still more miserable ways of our fellow men.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
I never have."

"You have never heard of the Ku Klux Klan?"

"No, I confess it."

"Then I will read you an extract from the American Encyclopædia, which I have just fetched. It is a curious and terrible record. Here it is: 'The Ku Klux Klan was a secret organization formed by ex-Confederate soldiers after the American Civil War, with the object of restoring the supremacy of the Southern whites by means of terrorism. Their outrages were preceded by the distribution of symbolic warnings—white crows, black cats, and, in particular, orange pips. Any victim who recanted or fled was safe, but if he defied them, he was sure to meet with a strange and terrible end. The organization was so effective and elusive that it flourished for years in spite of the efforts of the Federal Government. It suddenly collapsed about the year 1869, though there were sporadic outbreaks afterwards.'"

"And you think that this has some bearing upon our case?"

"I do. Note that the collapse of the Klan coincided with Colonel Openshaw's return to England with 'their papers,' as he mentioned. That, I think, is no coincidence. The register and the diary which he took with him must have contained some damning evidence against the most prominent men of the South. It is for that reason that the descendants of the Klan are now tracking the family, and it is for that reason that the pips have been sent."

"But what of the diary page which I saw?"

"Ah, that is the key. 'Sent the pips' means that the warning was given. 'Cleared' means that the man left the country. 'Visited' means that the man was visited by the agents of the Klan. As for Paramore, I fear that his case is the worst of all."

"Then what do you propose to do?"

"I propose to do nothing rash. I think that we can yet throw some light upon the matter. As for Openshaw, his only chance is to follow my instructions."

He rose and took up his violin. The storm had died down, but the night was still grim and cheerless. He played a quiet, melancholy air, and I sat in silence, watching the flickering lamplight and thinking of the strange and terrible things which we had discussed.

“I never have.”

Holmes leaned back in his chair, his long, thin fingers steepled before his lips, his eyes fixed upon me with a look of quiet amusement. I had expected a different answer, for the question had been put with some urgency, and the matter at hand was of no small importance. Yet, as was so often the case, my friend’s calm and deliberate manner served only to heighten the tension in the room.

“You never have,” he repeated, as if savoring the words. “And yet, I have reason to believe that you have been in the company of a certain gentleman who has recently been the subject of some rather unpleasant inquiries. A Mr. James Moriaty, if I am not mistaken.”

I started at the name. “Moriarty?” I echoed. “Surely you do not mean the professor of mathematics at the university?”

“Indeed, I do,” said Holmes. “And I am afraid that his recent activities have taken a rather more sinister turn. I have reason to believe that he is involved in a series of crimes that have baffled the police and that he is, in fact, the mastermind behind a network of criminals operating in the city.”

I was taken aback. “But how can you be sure of this?” I asked. “Surely you do not base such a serious accusation on mere suspicion?”

Holmes smiled. “No, my dear Watson, I do not. I have followed the trail of evidence with the same care and precision that I would apply to a mathematical proof. The connections are there, if one knows where to look. And I have found them.”

I was silent for a moment, considering the gravity of what he had just said. “And what of the gentleman in question?” I asked at last. “Have you any idea where he might be found?”

Holmes nodded. “I have a fair idea. He is a man of great intellect, and I suspect that he is aware of the danger he is in. He will not remain in one place for long, but I believe that he will make his move soon. And when he does, I shall be ready.”

I looked at him with admiration. “You are a remarkable man, Holmes,” I said. “I can only hope that you are right in your suspicions and that you are able to bring this man to justice.”

Holmes smiled again, a faint, enigmatic smile. “I have no doubt that I shall,” he said. “But for now, I must ask you to keep this matter to yourself. The fewer people who know of it, the better. Moriarty is a dangerous man, and I would not wish to see you drawn into his web.”

I nodded. “You may count on my discretion,” I said. “But I must ask you one more question. If you are so certain of his guilt, why not go to the police?”

Holmes shook his head. “Because the police are not yet ready to believe in the existence of a criminal mind as brilliant as Moriarty’s. They would dismiss the idea as fanciful. And I cannot afford to wait for them to come around. The game is afoot, my dear Watson, and I must play it my way.”

I could only nod in agreement. The game was indeed afoot, and I was once again at the side of the greatest detective of our time, ready to face whatever dangers lay ahead.

events.title: Tragic News: John Openshaw Found Dead
detailed_summary: The following morning is clear and sunny.
Watson finds Holmes already at breakfast, anticipating a busy day investigating Openshaw's case.
Holmes plans to start his inquiries in the City, possibly going to Horsham later if needed.
While waiting for coffee, Watson glances at the newspaper and sees a headline that chills him.
He cries out to Holmes that he is too late.
Holmes, fearing the worst, calmly asks how it happened, though Watson sees he is deeply moved.
Watson reads the account titled 'Tragedy Near Waterloo Bridge': between 9 and 10 PM the previous night, a police constable heard a cry for help and a splash near the bridge.
Due to the dark and stormy conditions, rescue attempts by the constable and passers-by failed.
The water-police later recovered the body, identified via an envelope in his pocket as John Openshaw of Horsham.
The newspaper conjectures he was rushing for the last train, missed his path in the dark, and fell from a steamboat landing stage.
The report states no signs of violence were found, concluding it was an unfortunate accident and highlighting the poor condition of riverside landings.
Holmes and Watson sit in silence; Holmes appears more shaken than Watson has ever seen him.
Holmes admits his pride is hurt, calling it a petty feeling but stating the case has become personal.
He vows, health permitting, to bring the gang to justice, lamenting that Openshaw came for help only to be sent to his death.
He paces the room agitatedly, wondering how the 'cunning devils' lured Openshaw to the Embankment, which wasn't on his direct route to Waterloo station.
He resolves to win in the long run and declares he is going out, intending to be his own police force and only involving them once his 'web' is spun.

events.text_segment:
It had cleared in the morning, and the sun was shining with a subdued brightness through the dim veil which hangs over the great city. Sherlock Holmes was already at breakfast when I came down.
“You will excuse me for not waiting for you,” said he; “I have, I foresee, a very busy day before me in looking into this case of young Openshaw’s.”
“What steps will you take?” I asked.
“It will very much depend upon the results of my first inquiries. I may have to go down to Horsham, after all.”
“You will not go there first?”
“No, I shall commence with the City. Just ring the bell and the maid will bring up your coffee.”
As I waited, I lifted the unopened newspaper from the table and glanced my eye over it. It rested upon a heading which sent a chill to my heart.
“Holmes,” I cried, “you are too late.”
“Ah!” said he, laying down his cup, “I feared as much. How was it done?” He spoke calmly, but I could see that he was deeply moved.
“My eye caught the name of Openshaw, and the heading ‘Tragedy Near Waterloo Bridge.’ Here is the account:
“‘Between nine and ten last night Police-Constable Cook, of the H Division, on duty near Waterloo Bridge, heard a cry for help and a splash in the water. The night, however, was extremely dark and stormy, so that, in spite of the help of several passers-by, it was quite impossible to effect a rescue. The alarm, however, was given, and, by the aid of the water-police, the body was eventually recovered. It proved to be that of a young gentleman whose name, as it appears from an envelope which was found in his pocket, was John Openshaw, and whose residence is near Horsham. It is conjectured that he may have been hurrying down to catch the last train from Waterloo Station, and that in his haste and the extreme darkness he missed his path and walked over the edge of one of the small landing-places for river steamboats. The body exhibited no traces of violence, and there can be no doubt that the deceased had been the victim of an unfortunate accident, which should have the effect of calling the attention of the authorities to the condition of the riverside landing-stages.’”
We sat in silence for some minutes, Holmes more depressed and shaken than I had ever seen him.
“That hurts my pride, Watson,” he said at last. “It is a petty feeling, no doubt, but it hurts my pride. It becomes a personal matter with me now, and, if God sends me health, I shall set my hand upon this gang. That he should come to me for help, and that I should send him away to his death—!” He sprang from his chair and paced about the room in uncontrollable agitation, with a flush upon his sallow cheeks and a nervous clasping and unclasping of his long thin hands.
“They must be cunning devils,” he exclaimed at last. “How could they have decoyed him down there? The Embankment is not on the direct line to the station. The bridge, no doubt, was too crowded, even on such a night, for their purpose. Well, Watson, we shall see who will win in the long run. I am going out now!”
“To the police?”
“No; I shall be my own police. When I have spun the web they may take the flies, but not before.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: It had cleared in the morning, and the sun was shining with a subdued brightness through the dim veil which hangs over the great city. I found Holmes already at breakfast, and I could see from his face that he had passed a sleepless night. "I have a busy day before me," he remarked, pushing back his plate. "I shall begin my inquiries in the City, and if I find it necessary I shall go down to Horsham this afternoon." As he spoke he rang the bell, and a moment later the coffee was brought in. I glanced at the paper which lay upon the table, and suddenly I gave a cry and sprang to my feet. Holmes looked up with a startled expression. "What is it?" he asked. "It is too late," I gasped. "He is dead." The look of anxiety which came into his face was so sudden and so deep that I could see that he feared the worst. "How?" he asked, in a quiet voice. "Read this," I said, pointing to the heading of a paragraph which ran across the page: 'Tragedy Near Waterloo Bridge.' The account was brief and to the point. Between the hours of nine and ten last night a police constable, who was on his beat, heard a cry for help and a splash in the water. He rushed to the spot, but the darkness and the storm had already swallowed up the unhappy man. A number of passers-by had also heard the cry, and they had all rushed to the spot, but the water was too deep and the current too strong. The body was not recovered until the morning, when the water-police found it floating near the bridge. A card in the man's pocket identified him as John Openshaw of Horsham. The newspaper conjectured that he had been hurrying for the last train, had lost his way in the dark, and had fallen from a steamboat landing stage. There were no signs of violence, and the report concluded that it was an unfortunate accident, and that the poor condition of the riverside landings was to blame. Holmes and I sat in silence for some time, and I could see that he was more shaken than I had ever seen him. "It is my fault," he said at last. "I have been too proud, too confident. I have allowed my own feelings to blind me to the facts. But I will not rest until I have brought these men to justice. I will not rest until I have avenged the death of this poor fellow, who came to me for help and was sent to his death instead." He rose and began to pace the room, his face set and his eyes burning with a fierce determination. "I wonder how they lured him to the Embankment," he muttered. "It was not on his direct route to Waterloo station. They must have known something that I did not. But I will find out. I will win in the long run. I am going out now. I shall be my own police force, and I shall not involve them until my web is spun."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
It had cleared in the morning, and the sun was shining with a subdued brightness through the dim veil which hangs over the great city. The streets were still damp from the night's rain, and the air was fresh and invigorating. I had just finished my breakfast and was preparing to go out when a knock came at the door. It was my friend Sherlock Holmes, his face drawn and pale, his eyes gleaming with a strange intensity. He had not slept, I could see, and his clothes were disheveled as if he had been in a hurry or had not changed them for some time.

"You must come with me, Watson," he said, his voice low and urgent. "There is a case that has come to my attention, one that is most peculiar and, I believe, of the utmost importance."

I quickly put on my coat and followed him out into the streets. We hailed a cab and drove through the city, the morning bustle beginning to stir as the shops opened and the people began their daily routines. Holmes was silent during the journey, his eyes fixed on the passing scenery, his mind clearly elsewhere. When we arrived at our destination, a modest house in a quiet street, he led me inside without a word.

The house was in a state of disarray. Papers were scattered across the floor, and the furniture was overturned. A woman sat in the corner, her face pale and drawn, her eyes red from crying. She looked up as we entered, and I could see the fear in her expression.

"This is Mrs. Hudson," Holmes said. "She is the landlady of the house and has been the victim of a most unusual and disturbing series of events."

Mrs. Hudson rose to her feet and spoke in a trembling voice. "I have been followed, Mr. Holmes. I have seen the same man watching me for days now. He is always just out of sight, but I know he is there. I have tried to ignore it, but it is becoming unbearable."

Holmes listened intently, his eyes narrowing as he took in every detail. "And what does this man look like?"

"He is tall and thin, with a long, angular face and a dark coat. He always wears a hat, and I have never seen his eyes."

Holmes nodded. "And when did you first notice him?"

"Three days ago. I was returning from the market when I saw him standing near the corner. I thought nothing of it at first, but he has been there every day since."

Holmes turned to me. "Watson, I believe we have a case of surveillance. The man is watching Mrs. Hudson for a reason, and I intend to find out why."

We spent the next few hours investigating the house and the surrounding area. Holmes was tireless, his mind working at a pace that was almost impossible to follow. He questioned the neighbors, examined the windows and doors, and even took a look at the rooftops. Finally, as the sun began to set, he called me to his side.

"I believe I have found the answer," he said. "The man is not following Mrs. Hudson for her own sake, but for something she possesses."

"What do you mean?" I asked.

"There is a letter in her possession, Watson. A letter that contains information of great value. And the man is determined to obtain it."

With that, Holmes turned to Mrs. Hudson. "You must be careful, madam. The man will not stop until he has what he wants."

Mrs. Hudson nodded, her face pale with fear. "I will do as you say, Mr. Holmes."

And with that, we left the house, the sun setting behind us as we made our way back to Baker Street, the mystery of the case still unsolved, but the first step taken toward its resolution.

events.title: Holmes Investigates and Targets the Killers
detailed_summary: Watson spends the day on his own work, returning late to find Holmes still out.
Holmes returns near 10 PM, looking pale and worn.
He immediately goes to the sideboard, tears off a piece of bread, eats it ravenously, and drinks a large amount of water.
He explains he is starving, having forgotten to eat since breakfast due to his investigation.
When Watson asks about his success, Holmes replies 'Well'.
He claims to have the culprits 'in the hollow of my hand' and declares Openshaw will be avenged.
He gets an idea to use the killers' own 'devilish trade-mark' against them.
He takes an orange, squeezes out five pips, and puts them in an envelope.
Inside the flap, he writes 'S. H. for J. O.' (Sherlock Holmes for John Openshaw).
He seals and addresses it to 'Captain James Calhoun, Barque Lone Star, Savannah, Georgia'.
Holmes chuckles, anticipating the letter awaiting Calhoun in port will give him a sleepless night, serving as a precursor to his fate just as the pips were for Openshaw.
He identifies Calhoun as the gang leader, stating he'll get the others too, but Calhoun first.
Holmes explains his method: he spent the day checking Lloyd's registers and old newspapers.
He tracked every ship that was in Pondicherry in Jan/Feb 1883.
One ship, the Lone Star, stood out because, though cleared from London, its name suggested an American origin (Texas).
He checked Dundee records and found the Lone Star was there in January 1885, confirming his suspicion.
Inquiring about ships currently in London, he found the Lone Star had arrived last week.
He went to the Albert Dock and discovered the ship had left that morning, bound for Savannah.
A wire to Gravesend confirmed it had passed some time ago.
With an easterly wind, Holmes believes the ship is now past the Goodwin Sands and near the Isle of Wight.
His plan: Calhoun and his two mates (the only Americans on board, the rest being Finns and Germans) were confirmed ashore last night by the stevedore.

By the time their sailing ship reaches Savannah, the faster mail boat will deliver Holmes's envelope with the pips, and a cablegram will inform Savannah police that the three men are wanted in London for murder.

events.text_segment:
All day I was engaged in my professional work, and it was late in the evening before I returned to Baker Street. Sherlock Holmes had not come back yet. It was nearly ten o’clock before he entered, looking pale and worn. He walked up to the sideboard, and tearing a piece from the loaf he devoured it voraciously, washing it down with a long draught of water.
“You are hungry,” I remarked.
“Starving. It had escaped my memory. I have had nothing since breakfast.”
“Nothing?”
“Not a bite. I had no time to think of it.”
“And how have you succeeded?”
“Well.”
“You have a clue?”
“I have them in the hollow of my hand. Young Openshaw shall not long remain unavenged. Why, Watson, let us put their own devilish trade-mark upon them. It is well thought of!”
“What do you mean?”
He took an orange from the cupboard, and tearing it to pieces he squeezed out the pips upon the table. Of these he took five and thrust them into an envelope. On the inside of the flap he wrote “S. H. for J. O.” Then he sealed it and addressed it to “Captain James Calhoun, Barque Lone Star, Savannah, Georgia.”
“That will await him when he enters port,” said he, chuckling. “It may give him a sleepless night. He will find it as sure a precursor of his fate as Openshaw did before him.”
“And who is this Captain Calhoun?”
“The leader of the gang. I shall have the others, but he first.”
“How did you trace it, then?”
He took a large sheet of paper from his pocket, all covered with dates and names.
“I have spent the whole day,” said he, “over Lloyd’s registers and files of the old papers, following the future career of every vessel which touched at Pondicherry in January and February in ’83. There were thirty-six ships of fair tonnage which were reported there during those months. Of these, one, the Lone Star, instantly attracted my attention, since, although it was reported as having cleared from London, the name is that which is given to one of the states of the Union.”
“Texas, I think.”
“I was not and am not sure which; but I knew that the ship must have an American origin.”
“What then?”
“I searched the Dundee records, and when I found that the barque Lone Star was there in January, ’85, my suspicion became a certainty. I then inquired as to the vessels which lay at present in the port of London.”
“Yes?”
“The Lone Star had arrived here last week. I went down to the Albert Dock and found that she had been taken down the river by the early tide this morning, homeward bound to Savannah. I wired to Gravesend and learned that she had passed some time ago, and as the wind is easterly I have no doubt that she is now past the Goodwins and not very far from the Isle of Wight.”
“What will you do, then?”
“Oh, I have my hand upon him. He and the two mates, are as I learn, the only native-born Americans in the ship. The others are Finns and Germans. I know, also, that they were all three away from the ship last night. I had it from the stevedore who has been loading their cargo. By the time that their sailing-ship reaches Savannah the mail-boat will have carried this letter, and the cable will have informed the police of Savannah that these three gentlemen are badly wanted here upon a charge of murder.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
All day I was engaged in my professional work, and it was late in the evening before I returned to Baker Street. I found my friend still in his dressing-gown, his face pale and haggard, his eyes red from the long strain of thought. He had not dined, and with a ravenous appetite he devoured a piece of bread which he tore from the sideboard, and then drank a tumbler of water. 

"You are looking very tired," I remarked.

"I have been at it all day," he said, "and I have had no time to think of food. But I have done it, Watson. I have them in the hollow of my hand. John Openshaw shall be avenged."

"And you are sure of this?"

"Well," he said, with a quiet smile, "I think I have made a fair beginning."

He took up an orange, squeezed out five of the pips, and placed them in an envelope. On the flap he wrote 'S. H. for J. O.' and then he sealed and addressed it to 'Captain James Calhoun, Barque Lone Star, Savannah, Georgia.'

"This will give him a sleepless night," he remarked, chuckling. "It is the same old devilish trade-mark which has been his undoing. He will know what it means, and he will know that I am on his track."

"But how have you found him?"

"By the same methods which have served me so often before. I have spent the day in the British Museum, poring over the old newspapers and the Lloyd's registers. I have traced every vessel which was in Pondicherry during the months of January and February, 1883. One of them, the Lone Star, stands out from the rest. She was cleared from London, but her name and her origin are American. I have checked the Dundee records, and I find that she was there in January, 1885. That confirms my suspicions."

"And now?"

"The Lone Star is in London. I have ascertained that she arrived last week. I went to the Albert Dock this morning, but I found that she had already left, bound for Savannah. A wire to Gravesend confirmed that she had passed some time ago. With the easterly wind, I should say that she is now past the Goodwin Sands, and not far from the Isle of Wight."

"And Calhoun?"

"He is the ringleader. I have no doubt that he and his two mates are ashore. The rest of the crew are Finns and Germans. I have ascertained from the stevedore that the three Americans were seen on the quay last night. By the time the Lone Star reaches Savannah, my envelope with the five pips will be in the captain's hands, and a cablegram will have informed the police that the three men are wanted in London for murder."}

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
All day I was engaged in my professional work, and it was late in the evening before I returned to Baker Street. As I entered the door, I found my friend, Dr. Watson, in the sitting-room, with a candle upon the table, and a letter in his hand. He looked up as I came in, and I saw at once by his face that something unusual had occurred.

"You have had a long day," he said, rising to his feet. "I trust you have not overtaxed yourself."

"I have had a busy day," I answered, throwing my overcoat upon the sofa. "But I am not tired. What is it that has so interested you?"

He handed me the letter, and I glanced at the address. It was written in a bold, angular hand, and the paper was of a peculiar quality. The envelope was unsealed, and the letter within was brief and to the point.

"I have been followed," it ran. "I am in great danger. I have heard of your methods, and I have come to you for help. I cannot trust anyone else. I am at the Hotel Cosmopolitan, Room 12. Please come at once."

"Who is it?" I asked, as I handed the letter back to Watson.

"I do not know," he answered. "It was brought by a boy, and he said nothing. I have been trying to find out who it is, but I have not succeeded."

I took up my hat and stick, and I was about to go out when I paused and looked at my friend.

"You have not told me everything," I said. "There is something more that you wish to say."

He hesitated for a moment, and then he spoke.

"I have been watching you," he said. "I have noticed that you have been very quiet and preoccupied of late. I have thought that perhaps you were not well. I have also noticed that you have been receiving a number of letters, and that you have been making inquiries in various parts of the city. I have not said anything before, but I have been watching you."

I looked at him in astonishment.

"You have been watching me?"

"Yes," he answered. "I have been watching you for some time. I have been afraid that you were not well."

I laughed, and I patted him on the shoulder.

"You are a good fellow, Watson," I said. "You have been very kind to me. But I am quite well. I have been working on a case, and I have been keeping it to myself."

"A case?"

"Yes. A very interesting case. I have been following a man who has been suspected of a number of crimes. I have been trying to find out who he is, and what he is doing."

"And this letter?"

"This letter is from him. He has been following me, and he has been trying to find out what I am doing. He is in great danger, and he has come to me for help."

"And you are going to help him?"

"Yes. I am going to the Hotel Cosmopolitan at once."

"And I am going with you," said Watson, rising to his feet.

I looked at him for a moment, and then I nodded.

"Very well," I said. "But you must promise me that you will not interfere."

"I promise," he answered. "I will do as you say."

We took a hansom to the Hotel Cosmopolitan, and we found the man in Room 12. He was a tall, thin man, with a pale face and a nervous manner. He looked at us with a mixture of fear and hope, and he told us his story. It was a strange and complicated tale, and I shall not relate it here. But I will say that it was one of the most difficult cases I have ever undertaken, and that it was only by the most careful and patient investigation that I was able to solve it. And I will also say that it was my friend, Dr. Watson, who was the first to notice that something was wrong, and who was the first to offer his help. And for that, I shall always be grateful.

events.title: Nature's Justice: The Fate of the Lone Star
detailed_summary: Watson reflects that even the best human plans can have flaws.
The murderers of John Openshaw were destined never to receive the warning pips sent by Holmes.
The equinoctial gales that year were exceptionally long and severe.
Despite waiting, no news of the Lone Star reaching Savannah ever arrived.
Eventually, word came of a sighting far out in the Atlantic: a shattered stern-post, marked with the letters 'L. S.', was seen drifting in the waves.
Watson concludes that this fragment is the only information ever obtained regarding the final fate of the Lone Star and its crew.

chapters.chapter_title: VI. THE MAN WITH THE TWISTED LIP

events.title: A Distressed Wife's Plea and Watson's Mission
detailed_summary: The narrative introduces Isa Whitney, detailing his long-standing opium addiction originating from a college experiment.
His addiction has reduced him to a pitiable state, a stark contrast to his former self.
One June evening in 1889, Dr. Watson's late-night peace is disturbed by a ring at the bell.
Watson and his wife anticipate a patient.
A veiled woman enters abruptly.
The woman reveals herself in distress, seeking help, and embraces Watson's wife.
Watson's wife recognizes her as Kate Whitney.
Kate explains she sought them out due to overwhelming trouble.
Watson's wife offers comfort and hospitality.
Kate reveals her husband, Isa, has been missing for two days, causing her great fear.
This isn't the first time Kate has confided in the Watsons about Isa's addiction.
They attempt to soothe her and inquire about Isa's possible whereabouts.
Kate believes Isa is at a specific opium den in the East End, the Bar of Gold in Upper Swandam Lane, a place he frequents during his binges.
His current absence of 48 hours is unusually long.
She feels helpless, unable to enter such a place herself to retrieve him.
Watson realizes he must escort her, but then decides it's better for him, as Isa's doctor, to go alone.
He promises Kate he will find Isa if he's at the given address and send him home within two hours.
Watson quickly departs in a cab, embarking on what seems merely a strange errand at the time.
