events.text_segment:
“Hum! So much for the police-court,” said Holmes thoughtfully, tossing aside the paper. “The question for us now to solve is the sequence of events leading from a rifled jewel-case at one end to the crop of a goose in Tottenham Court Road at the other. You see, Watson, our little deductions have suddenly assumed a much more important and less innocent aspect. Here is the stone; the stone came from the goose, and the goose came from Mr. Henry Baker, the gentleman with the bad hat and all the other characteristics with which I have bored you. So now we must set ourselves very seriously to finding this gentleman and ascertaining what part he has played in this little mystery. To do this, we must try the simplest means first, and these lie undoubtedly in an advertisement in all the evening papers. If this fail, I shall have recourse to other methods.”
“What will you say?”
“Give me a pencil and that slip of paper. Now, then: ‘Found at the corner of Goodge Street, a goose and a black felt hat. Mr. Henry Baker can have the same by applying at 6:30 this evening at 221B, Baker Street.’ That is clear and concise.”
“Very. But will he see it?”
“Well, he is sure to keep an eye on the papers, since, to a poor man, the loss was a heavy one. He was clearly so scared by his mischance in breaking the window and by the approach of Peterson that he thought of nothing but flight, but since then he must have bitterly regretted the impulse which caused him to drop his bird. Then, again, the introduction of his name will cause him to see it, for everyone who knows him will direct his attention to it. Here you are, Peterson, run down to the advertising agency and have this put in the evening papers.”
“In which, sir?”
“Oh, in the Globe, Star, Pall Mall, St. James’s Gazette, Evening News, Standard, Echo, and any others that occur to you.”
“Very well, sir. And this stone?”
“Ah, yes, I shall keep the stone. Thank you. And, I say, Peterson, just buy a goose on your way back and leave it here with me, for we must have one to give to this gentleman in place of the one which your family is now devouring.”
When the commissionaire had gone, Holmes took up the stone and held it against the light. “It’s a bonny thing,” said he. “Just see how it glints and sparkles. Of course it is a nucleus and focus of crime. Every good stone is. They are the devil’s pet baits. In the larger and older jewels every facet may stand for a bloody deed. This stone is not yet twenty years old. It was found in the banks of the Amoy River in southern China and is remarkable in having every characteristic of the carbuncle, save that it is blue in shade instead of ruby red. In spite of its youth, it has already a sinister history. There have been two murders, a vitriol-throwing, a suicide, and several robberies brought about for the sake of this forty-grain weight of crystallised charcoal. Who would think that so pretty a toy would be a purveyor to the gallows and the prison? I’ll lock it up in my strong box now and drop a line to the Countess to say that we have it.”
“Do you think that this man Horner is innocent?”
“I cannot tell.”
“Well, then, do you imagine that this other one, Henry Baker, had anything to do with the matter?”
“It is, I think, much more likely that Henry Baker is an absolutely innocent man, who had no idea that the bird which he was carrying was of considerably more value than if it were made of solid gold. That, however, I shall determine by a very simple test if we have an answer to our advertisement.”
“And you can do nothing until then?”
“Nothing.”
“In that case I shall continue my professional round. But I shall come back in the evening at the hour you have mentioned, for I should like to see the solution of so tangled a business.”
“Very glad to see you. I dine at seven. There is a woodcock, I believe. By the way, in view of recent occurrences, perhaps I ought to ask Mrs. Hudson to examine its crop.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Hum! So much for the police-court," said Holmes thoughtfully, tossing aside the paper. "The problem now is to trace the events from the jewel theft to the goose's crop. You remember, Watson, our deductions about the hat owner, which we dismissed as trivial? Well, they now take on a serious, criminal dimension. This stone is linked to the goose, and the goose to Henry Baker. Our priority is to find Henry Baker and determine his role in this affair. The simplest approach, I think, is to advertise in the evening newspapers. I shall dictate an advertisement asking 'Mr. Henry Baker' to collect his found goose and hat at 221B Baker Street this evening. I believe he will see it, for the loss was significant for a poor man, and acquaintances would point it out."

He then dispatched Peterson to place the ad in multiple papers. Holmes kept the carbuncle and asked Peterson to buy a replacement goose for Mr. Baker. After Peterson left, Holmes reflected on the stone's allure and criminal history, calling such gems 'the devil's pet baits.' He recounted the blue carbuncle's specific history: found in China, under 20 years old, yet already linked to murders, assaults, and robberies. He decided to lock the stone away and inform the Countess.

"Do you think," asked Watson, "that Horner is innocent or that Baker is involved?"

"I suspect Baker is entirely innocent and unaware of the goose's valuable contents," said Holmes. "I have a simple test in mind when he responds to the ad. Until then, there is nothing more to do."

Watson decided to leave for his professional rounds but promised to return that evening for the conclusion. Holmes invited Watson to dinner and humorously suggested checking their own dinner bird's crop.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Hum! So much for the police-court,” said Holmes thoughtfully, tossing aside the paper. “It is a curious thing, Watson, how the public always seems to expect the impossible. They demand miracles, and yet when they are performed, they are only too ready to dismiss them as commonplace. I have no doubt that the police have done their best in this matter, but they are not trained to see the subtle threads which bind the case together. It is the little things, the trifles, which are the true clues to the mystery.”

I looked at my friend with admiration. There was a gleam of excitement in his eyes, and his fingers were twitching with the restless energy that always accompanied the approach of a new problem. He had been in a somewhat despondent mood for some days, and I was glad to see that the case had stirred him from his lethargy.

“What is the nature of the case, then?” I asked.

Holmes leaned back in his chair and lit a cigarette. “It is a case of attempted murder,” he said. “A man named James Morley was found in a state of collapse in a small flat in Whitechapel. He had been struck on the head with a heavy object, and there were signs of a struggle. The police have arrested a man named Thomas Hargreaves, who was seen in the neighborhood shortly before the attack. He is a known criminal, and the evidence against him is circumstantial, but not conclusive. The case is being tried at the police-court, and the verdict will be given in the morning.”

I was surprised. “But if the evidence is not conclusive, why is the man being tried at all?”

“Because the police are under pressure to make an arrest,” Holmes replied. “They have a suspect, and they are determined to secure a conviction. But I have no doubt that Hargreaves is innocent. The clues point in a different direction.”

I was intrigued. “Then you believe that the real criminal is still at large?”

“I do,” said Holmes. “And I believe that the key to the case lies in the details that the police have overlooked. For instance, the wound on the victim’s head was not caused by a heavy object, but by a lighter one. The blow was delivered with precision, not with the clumsy force that one would expect from a man like Hargreaves. Moreover, the victim had been poisoned.”

I was astonished. “Poisoned? But the police report said nothing of that.”

“Because they did not look for it,” said Holmes. “The symptoms of the poisoning were masked by the effects of the blow to the head. But I have examined the man’s body, and I can tell you that he was given a dose of strychnine shortly before the attack. The poison was administered in a glass of brandy, and the glass was found in the flat. It was not broken, and the liquid had not been disturbed. That suggests that the glass was not used in the struggle, but that it was left there deliberately.”

I was beginning to see the pattern. “So the killer gave the man the poisoned brandy, and then struck him on the head to make it look like an accident or a robbery gone wrong?”

“Precisely,” said Holmes. “But there is more to it than that. The killer was not a stranger to the victim. The glass was a gift, and it was engraved with the initials J.M. That suggests that the killer was someone who had access to the victim’s home, and who was known to him. Moreover, the poison was not obtained from a chemist, but from a private collection. That suggests that the killer was a man of some means and knowledge.”

I was fascinated. “Then who do you think the killer is?”

Holmes smiled. “That is the question, is it not? I believe that the killer is a man named Reginald Ashford, a former business partner of the victim. The two men had a falling out some years ago, and Ashford had threatened to kill Morley if he ever found out about a certain business deal. I believe that Morley discovered the truth, and that Ashford decided to silence him.”

I was impressed. “Then you will go to the police-court and tell them the truth?”

Holmes shook his head. “No, Watson. I will not. The police are not ready to listen to me. They have made up their minds, and they will not change them. I will go to the trial and observe. If the evidence is as weak as I believe it to be, I will make my case known to the public. The truth will come out, one way or another.”

I was proud of my friend. He was always the same—uncompromising, brilliant, and utterly certain of his own abilities. I knew that he would not rest until the case was solved, and that the innocent man would be cleared of the charge. And so, with a sense of anticipation, I prepared to accompany him to the police-court the next day, ready to witness the unfolding of another of his great adventures.

events.title: Henry Baker Claims His Hat and Goose
detailed_summary: Watson returns to Baker Street slightly after 6:30 PM.
He sees a tall man waiting outside, who is admitted along with him.
Holmes greets the visitor as Mr. Henry Baker and offers him a seat by the fire.
Holmes confirms the battered hat belongs to Baker.
Baker is described as large, with rounded shoulders, an intelligent face, grizzled beard, signs of drinking, and shabbily dressed but with the air of an educated man down on his luck.
Holmes explains they kept the items hoping Baker would advertise.
Baker explains he couldn't afford an ad and assumed the roughs had taken both items.
Holmes informs Baker they had to eat the original goose.
Baker reacts with surprise but readily accepts the fresh replacement goose Holmes offers.
When Holmes jokingly offers the remains (feathers, crop etc.) of the original bird, Baker laughs heartily, declining them as useless relics.
This reaction, observed by Holmes with a glance at Watson, confirms Baker's ignorance about the gem.
Holmes gives Baker the hat and replacement goose.
He casually asks Baker where he obtained the original goose, feigning interest as a 'fowl fancier'.
Baker explains he belongs to a goose club at the Alpha Inn, run by a Mr. Windigate, where members pay weekly for a Christmas bird.
Baker thanks Holmes, puts on his old hat (joking about the unsuitability of his temporary Scotch bonnet), and leaves.
Once Baker is gone, Holmes confirms to Watson that Baker knows nothing about the jewel.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I had been delayed at a case, and it was a little after half-past six when I found myself in Baker Street once more.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Are you hungry, Watson?”

events.text_segment:
I had been delayed at a case, and it was a little after half-past six when I found myself in Baker Street once more. As I approached the house I saw a tall man in a Scotch bonnet with a coat which was buttoned up to his chin waiting outside in the bright semicircle which was thrown from the fanlight. Just as I arrived the door was opened, and we were shown up together to Holmes’ room.
“Mr. Henry Baker, I believe,” said he, rising from his armchair and greeting his visitor with the easy air of geniality which he could so readily assume. “Pray take this chair by the fire, Mr. Baker. It is a cold night, and I observe that your circulation is more adapted for summer than for winter. Ah, Watson, you have just come at the right time. Is that your hat, Mr. Baker?”
“Yes, sir, that is undoubtedly my hat.”
He was a large man with rounded shoulders, a massive head, and a broad, intelligent face, sloping down to a pointed beard of grizzled brown. A touch of red in nose and cheeks, with a slight tremor of his extended hand, recalled Holmes’ surmise as to his habits. His rusty black frock-coat was buttoned right up in front, with the collar turned up, and his lank wrists protruded from his sleeves without a sign of cuff or shirt. He spoke in a slow staccato fashion, choosing his words with care, and gave the impression generally of a man of learning and letters who had had ill-usage at the hands of fortune.
“We have retained these things for some days,” said Holmes, “because we expected to see an advertisement from you giving your address. I am at a loss to know now why you did not advertise.”
Our visitor gave a rather shamefaced laugh. “Shillings have not been so plentiful with me as they once were,” he remarked. “I had no doubt that the gang of roughs who assaulted me had carried off both my hat and the bird. I did not care to spend more money in a hopeless attempt at recovering them.”
“Very naturally. By the way, about the bird, we were compelled to eat it.”
“To eat it!” Our visitor half rose from his chair in his excitement.
“Yes, it would have been of no use to anyone had we not done so. But I presume that this other goose upon the sideboard, which is about the same weight and perfectly fresh, will answer your purpose equally well?”
“Oh, certainly, certainly,” answered Mr. Baker with a sigh of relief.
“Of course, we still have the feathers, legs, crop, and so on of your own bird, so if you wish—”
The man burst into a hearty laugh. “They might be useful to me as relics of my adventure,” said he, “but beyond that I can hardly see what use the disjecta membra of my late acquaintance are going to be to me. No, sir, I think that, with your permission, I will confine my attentions to the excellent bird which I perceive upon the sideboard.”
Sherlock Holmes glanced sharply across at me with a slight shrug of his shoulders.
“There is your hat, then, and there your bird,” said he. “By the way, would it bore you to tell me where you got the other one from? I am somewhat of a fowl fancier, and I have seldom seen a better grown goose.”
“Certainly, sir,” said Baker, who had risen and tucked his newly gained property under his arm. “There are a few of us who frequent the Alpha Inn, near the Museum—we are to be found in the Museum itself during the day, you understand. This year our good host, Windigate by name, instituted a goose club, by which, on consideration of some few pence every week, we were each to receive a bird at Christmas. My pence were duly paid, and the rest is familiar to you. I am much indebted to you, sir, for a Scotch bonnet is fitted neither to my years nor my gravity.” With a comical pomposity of manner he bowed solemnly to both of us and strode off upon his way.
“So much for Mr. Henry Baker,” said Holmes when he had closed the door behind him. “It is quite certain that he knows nothing whatever about the matter. Are you hungry, Watson?”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: I had been delayed at a case, and it was a little after half-past six when I found myself in Baker Street once more. As I approached our door I saw a tall, gaunt man, with a very red face and a military air, standing in the half-light of the wintry evening. He was wrapped in a threadbare overcoat, and his hands were thrust deep into the pockets. He looked up as I approached, and I saw that his eyes were keen and observant. He was admitted along with me, and I found myself introduced to Mr. Henry Baker, a gentleman of some military bearing, though his clothes were shabby and his face bore the marks of a man who had known better days. He was a large, stout man, with rounded shoulders, a grizzled beard, and a face which, though lined and weather-beaten, still showed traces of intelligence. He had the air of a man who had once been prosperous, but who had now fallen into adversity. He was given a seat by the fire, and Holmes, with his usual quiet precision, placed a cup of coffee before him. 'You have kept these things, then?' he asked, holding up the battered hat and a small, soiled handkerchief. 'Yes, sir,' said Baker, with a look of surprise. 'I thought they were lost to me.' 'We had hoped you might advertise for them,' said Holmes. 'I couldn't afford an advertisement,' said Baker, with a sigh. 'And I thought the roughs had taken them both.' 'We had to eat the goose,' said Holmes. 'Ah!' cried Baker, with a start. 'Then you have the carbuncle?' 'No, sir,' said Holmes, with a smile. 'We have only the feathers and the crop.' 'Then I am ruined!' cried Baker, in a tone of despair. 'But you have the goose!' said Holmes, offering him a fresh bird. 'I am a poor man,' said Baker, 'but I have my pride. I cannot accept charity.' 'It is not charity,' said Holmes. 'It is a Christmas gift.' 'Then I thank you,' said Baker, with a grateful bow. 'And the remains of the bird?' asked Holmes, with a twinkle in his eye. 'I should be glad to have them,' said Baker. 'They are relics of a happy time.' 'No, no,' said Holmes, laughing. 'They are useless.' 'Then I thank you for the goose,' said Baker, and he took it with a grateful smile. 'And the hat?' 'That I must have,' said Baker. 'It is the only thing that remains to me of my former life.' 'Then take it,' said Holmes, and he handed it to him. 'And where did you get the original goose?' asked Holmes, with a casual air. 'From the Alpha Inn,' said Baker. 'It is a goose club there, run by a Mr. Windigate. We pay a weekly subscription, and at Christmas we get a bird.' 'I see,' said Holmes. 'And you are a member?' 'Yes, sir,' said Baker. 'I am a member.' 'Then I wish you a merry Christmas,' said Holmes, and he handed him the hat. 'And a happy new year.' 'And the same to you,' said Baker, and he took his leave. As the door closed behind him, Holmes turned to me with a smile. 'Well, Watson,' he said, 'what do you make of that?' 'I make nothing of it,' I said. 'He seems a simple, honest man.' 'Precisely,' said Holmes. 'He knows nothing of the carbuncle.'

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I had been delayed at a case, and it was a little after half-past six when I found myself in Baker Street once more. I was tired and hungry, and the long walk from Paddington had left me in no very amiable mood. As I turned into our street, I saw a hansom cab drawn up at our door, and a man in a dark overcoat stepping out. He was a tall, thin figure, with a sharp, aquiline face and a pair of keen, restless eyes. I recognized him at once as Mr. James Mortimer, the country doctor who had brought us the curious case of the Speckled Band. He turned as I approached, and his face wore an expression of relief and anxiety combined.

"Ah, Dr. Watson," he said, "I am glad to see you. I have been waiting for you."

"And for Mr. Holmes, I presume," I said, unlocking the door.

"Yes, for Mr. Holmes. I have come with a most extraordinary case, one that has puzzled me beyond measure."

I led him into the sitting room, where the fire was still burning, and we sat down. The room was in its usual state of disorder, with papers and books scattered about, and the scent of tobacco still lingering in the air. I looked at the empty chair opposite me and felt a pang of regret. It was strange to think that the man who had once filled it with his keen observations and brilliant deductions was now absent, and that I was left to face the mystery alone.

"I have come from the village of Stoke Moran," said Mr. Mortimer, "a quiet place in the heart of the English countryside. I have been the medical man there for many years, and I have never known a more harrowing case than the one I am about to describe to you."

He took a small leather case from his pocket and opened it. Inside was a curious-looking instrument, a metal rod with a series of small, adjustable joints. He held it up to the light and examined it carefully.

"This," he said, "is the instrument that has caused me so much concern. It is a snake's fang, sharpened and fitted with a spring mechanism. I have no doubt that it is the means by which the unfortunate Julia Stoner met her end."

I looked at the instrument with a shudder. It was a most sinister object, and I could well understand the horror it had inspired in the young woman who had been its victim.

"You say that Julia Stoner was killed by this instrument?" I asked.

"Yes," said Mr. Mortimer. "She was the daughter of my patient, Mr. Stoner, a retired baronet who lives in a large house on the edge of the village. Julia was engaged to a young man named Dr. Grimesby Roylott, a man of violent temper and a most unpleasant disposition. He had been in India for many years, and had returned to England with a reputation for cruelty and violence."

I listened with growing interest as Mr. Mortimer continued his tale. He described how Julia had been found dead in her room, with no signs of violence upon her body. The only clue was a small puncture mark on her wrist, and the peculiar sound of a whistle that had been heard by the servants. The local authorities had been baffled, and it was only when Mr. Stoner had heard of Mr. Holmes's reputation that he had sent for him.

"I have come to you, Dr. Watson," said Mr. Mortimer, "because I know that Mr. Holmes is away, and I thought that perhaps you might be able to assist me."

I looked at him in surprise. I had no doubt of my own abilities, but I was not sure that I was equal to the task of solving a case of such complexity. However, I could see that Mr. Mortimer was in a state of great distress, and I felt that I could not refuse him.

"I will do what I can," I said. "But I must warn you that I am not Mr. Holmes."

"I know that," said Mr. Mortimer. "But I have great faith in you, Dr. Watson."

With that, he handed me a bundle of letters and documents, and I began to read. The case was indeed most perplexing, and I could see that it would require all my skill and determination to solve it. I could only hope that Mr. Holmes would return soon, for I was in no doubt that his presence would be of the greatest assistance.

events.title: Following the Trail to the Alpha Inn
detailed_summary: Watson indicates he isn't particularly hungry.
Holmes suggests they postpone dinner and pursue the clue of the Alpha Inn immediately.
They bundle up against the cold night and walk briskly through London streets towards Bloomsbury.
They arrive at the Alpha Inn, a small public house.
Holmes orders beers from the landlord.
Holmes compliments the landlord's geese, mentioning his recent conversation with club member Henry Baker.
The landlord clarifies that the geese weren't raised by him.
He reveals he bought the two dozen geese from a salesman in Covent Garden named Breckinridge.
Holmes pretends not to know Breckinridge, wishes the landlord well, and they leave.
Outside, Holmes prepares to find Breckinridge.
He reminds Watson of the stakes: establishing Horner's innocence or confirming his guilt, noting they have a unique investigative path missed by the police.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Not particularly.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Faces to the south, then, and quick march!”

events.text_segment:
“Not particularly.”
“Then I suggest that we turn our dinner into a supper and follow up this clue while it is still hot.”
“By all means.”
It was a bitter night, so we drew on our ulsters and wrapped cravats about our throats. Outside, the stars were shining coldly in a cloudless sky, and the breath of the passers-by blew out into smoke like so many pistol shots. Our footfalls rang out crisply and loudly as we swung through the doctors’ quarter, Wimpole Street, Harley Street, and so through Wigmore Street into Oxford Street. In a quarter of an hour we were in Bloomsbury at the Alpha Inn, which is a small public-house at the corner of one of the streets which runs down into Holborn. Holmes pushed open the door of the private bar and ordered two glasses of beer from the ruddy-faced, white-aproned landlord.
“Your beer should be excellent if it is as good as your geese,” said he.
“My geese!” The man seemed surprised.
“Yes. I was speaking only half an hour ago to Mr. Henry Baker, who was a member of your goose club.”
“Ah! yes, I see. But you see, sir, them’s not our geese.”
“Indeed! Whose, then?”
“Well, I got the two dozen from a salesman in Covent Garden.”
“Indeed? I know some of them. Which was it?”
“Breckinridge is his name.”
“Ah! I don’t know him. Well, here’s your good health landlord, and prosperity to your house. Good-night.”
“Now for Mr. Breckinridge,” he continued, buttoning up his coat as we came out into the frosty air. “Remember, Watson that though we have so homely a thing as a goose at one end of this chain, we have at the other a man who will certainly get seven years’ penal servitude unless we can establish his innocence. It is possible that our inquiry may but confirm his guilt; but, in any case, we have a line of investigation which has been missed by the police, and which a singular chance has placed in our hands. Let us follow it out to the bitter end. Faces to the south, then, and quick march!”

**Simulated Output of `generate_literary_segment` Function:**

> “Not particularly.”  
> Dr. Watson pushed his plate away with a faint smile, his appetite dulled by the weight of the case and the cold London air pressing against the windowpane.  
>  
> “Then let us not waste time on dinner,” said Sherlock Holmes, rising from his chair with the briskness of a man who had already solved the problem before it was fully spoken. “We must pursue the clue of the Alpha Inn at once.”  
>  
> Watson hesitated only a moment before following, and together they stepped into the night, bundling up against the chill. The city streets were quiet, save for the occasional clatter of carriage wheels and the distant echo of a streetlamp flickering to life. They walked briskly through the fog-draped alleys of London, their breath visible in the air, until they reached the modest Alpha Inn in Bloomsbury.  
>  
> The public house was warm and dimly lit, the scent of roasted meat and ale mingling in the air. Holmes ordered two pints of beer and, after a pause, turned to the landlord, a broad-shouldered man with a weathered face.  
>  
> “You have a fine cook here,” Holmes remarked, sipping his drink. “The geese are particularly well-seasoned.”  
>  
> The landlord beamed with pride. “Aye, they’re a hit with the regulars,” he said. “Though I must confess, they weren’t raised by me. I bought a full two dozen from a salesman in Covent Garden—Breckinridge, I believe his name was.”  
>  
> Holmes’s eyes flickered with interest. “Breckinridge, you say?” he mused, feigning ignorance. “I don’t believe I’ve had the pleasure.”  
>  
> As they stepped back into the night, Holmes turned to Watson, his voice low. “This is the path the police missed,” he said. “If we find Breckinridge, we may yet prove Horner’s innocence—or confirm his guilt. Either way, the Blue Carbuncle is closer to the light.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Not particularly.”

I was surprised at the answer, and my surprise must have been visible upon my features.

“Why, you seem astonished,” said he, with a dry smile.

“I must confess that I am. You have been so long at work upon this case that I should have thought that it would have interested you.”

“I have not been at work upon it. I have been at work upon other things. This is a case of no importance. It is a trifle, a mere nothing. The man is a fool, and the matter is a trifle.”

I looked at him in astonishment. I had never known him to speak in this way before. He was usually so keen and so eager in his investigations that I could not understand his indifference now.

“You are not yourself, Holmes,” I said at last.

“I am quite myself,” he answered. “I am only not interested. The case is not worth the trouble. The man is a fool, and the matter is a trifle. I have no desire to waste my time upon it.”

“But you have already taken it up,” I urged.

“I have not taken it up. I have merely listened to the man’s story. That is all. I have not promised to do anything. I have not even said that I would look into the matter. I have only said that I would listen.”

“But you always do look into the matter after you have listened.”

“I do not always. I have often listened and then left the matter alone. I have no desire to be a policeman. I am a consulting detective, and I am not bound to take every case that is offered to me.”

“But this is a case of some importance. The man is in trouble, and he has come to you for help.”

“He is in trouble, no doubt. But it is not my trouble. I have no desire to meddle in the affairs of others unless they are of some interest to me.”

I was silent for a moment. I could not understand his attitude. It was unlike him. I had always thought that he was a man of great sympathy and of great interest in the affairs of others.

At last I said, “I think that you are mistaken, Holmes. I think that you are underestimating the case.”

“I may be,” he answered. “But I am not going to waste my time upon it. I have other things to do.”

And with that he turned away and left me to my thoughts.

events.title: Confronting Breckinridge the Goose Salesman
detailed_summary: Holmes and Watson navigate through slums to Covent Garden Market.
They locate Breckinridge's stall, where the proprietor is closing up with a boy.
Holmes initiates conversation by remarking on the cold and noting the sold-out geese.
Breckinridge offers to sell him geese the next morning.
Holmes claims he was specifically recommended to Breckinridge by the landlord of the Alpha.
Breckinridge confirms sending geese to the Alpha.
When Holmes asks where Breckinridge got those specific geese, the salesman becomes angry and defensive.
He demands to know Holmes's purpose, complaining about being pestered with questions about the geese.
Holmes feigns indifference but proposes a bet: he wagers a fiver that the goose he ate (Baker's) was country-bred.
Breckinridge snaps that it was town-bred.
Holmes expresses disbelief, provoking Breckinridge to defend his expertise.
Holmes escalates the bet to a sovereign to 'teach him not to be obstinate'.
Breckinridge accepts and calls for his account books.
He shows Holmes his ledger system: one book for suppliers, with separate lists for country and town suppliers.
He points to the town supplier list and asks Holmes to read the third name: 'Mrs. Oakshott, 117, Brixton Road'.
Holmes confirms the corresponding ledger entry for Mrs. Oakshott.
Breckinridge points to the last entry: 'December 22nd. Twenty-four geese at 7s. 6d.'
Underneath, it notes: 'Sold to Mr. Windigate of the Alpha, at 12s.'
Holmes pretends to be chagrined, throws down the sovereign, and walks away.
A short distance away, Holmes laughs quietly, explaining to Watson his strategy of using a bet to extract information from such a character.
He feels they are nearing the end of the quest, needing only to visit Mrs. Oakshott, but notes Breckinridge's agitation suggests others are also searching.

events.text_segment:
We passed across Holborn, down Endell Street, and so through a zigzag of slums to Covent Garden Market. One of the largest stalls bore the name of Breckinridge upon it, and the proprietor a horsey-looking man, with a sharp face and trim side-whiskers was helping a boy to put up the shutters.
“Good-evening. It’s a cold night,” said Holmes.
The salesman nodded and shot a questioning glance at my companion.
“Sold out of geese, I see,” continued Holmes, pointing at the bare slabs of marble.
“Let you have five hundred to-morrow morning.”
“That’s no good.”
“Well, there are some on the stall with the gas-flare.”
“Ah, but I was recommended to you.”
“Who by?”
“The landlord of the Alpha.”
“Oh, yes; I sent him a couple of dozen.”
“Fine birds they were, too. Now where did you get them from?”
To my surprise the question provoked a burst of anger from the salesman.
“Now, then, mister,” said he, with his head cocked and his arms akimbo, “what are you driving at? Let’s have it straight, now.”
“It is straight enough. I should like to know who sold you the geese which you supplied to the Alpha.”
“Well then, I shan’t tell you. So now!”
“Oh, it is a matter of no importance; but I don’t know why you should be so warm over such a trifle.”
“Warm! You’d be as warm, maybe, if you were as pestered as I am. When I pay good money for a good article there should be an end of the business; but it’s ‘Where are the geese?’ and ‘Who did you sell the geese to?’ and ‘What will you take for the geese?’ One would think they were the only geese in the world, to hear the fuss that is made over them.”
“Well, I have no connection with any other people who have been making inquiries,” said Holmes carelessly. “If you won’t tell us the bet is off, that is all. But I’m always ready to back my opinion on a matter of fowls, and I have a fiver on it that the bird I ate is country bred.”
“Well, then, you’ve lost your fiver, for it’s town bred,” snapped the salesman.
“It’s nothing of the kind.”
“I say it is.”
“I don’t believe it.”
“D’you think you know more about fowls than I, who have handled them ever since I was a nipper? I tell you, all those birds that went to the Alpha were town bred.”
“You’ll never persuade me to believe that.”
“Will you bet, then?”
“It’s merely taking your money, for I know that I am right. But I’ll have a sovereign on with you, just to teach you not to be obstinate.”
The salesman chuckled grimly. “Bring me the books, Bill,” said he.
The small boy brought round a small thin volume and a great greasy-backed one, laying them out together beneath the hanging lamp.
“Now then, Mr. Cocksure,” said the salesman, “I thought that I was out of geese, but before I finish you’ll find that there is still one left in my shop. You see this little book?”
“Well?”
“That’s the list of the folk from whom I buy. D’you see? Well, then, here on this page are the country folk, and the numbers after their names are where their accounts are in the big ledger. Now, then! You see this other page in red ink? Well, that is a list of my town suppliers. Now, look at that third name. Just read it out to me.”
“Mrs. Oakshott, 117, Brixton Road—249,” read Holmes.
“Quite so. Now turn that up in the ledger.”
Holmes turned to the page indicated. “Here you are, ‘Mrs. Oakshott, 117, Brixton Road, egg and poultry supplier.’”
“Now, then, what’s the last entry?”
“‘December 22nd. Twenty-four geese at 7s. 6d.’”
“Quite so. There you are. And underneath?”
“‘Sold to Mr. Windigate of the Alpha, at 12s.’”
“What have you to say now?”
Sherlock Holmes looked deeply chagrined. He drew a sovereign from his pocket and threw it down upon the slab, turning away with the air of a man whose disgust is too deep for words. A few yards off he stopped under a lamp-post and laughed in the hearty, noiseless fashion which was peculiar to him.
“When you see a man with whiskers of that cut and the ‘Pink ’un’ protruding out of his pocket, you can always draw him by a bet,” said he. “I daresay that if I had put £ 100 down in front of him, that man would not have given me such complete information as was drawn from him by the idea that he was doing me on a wager. Well, Watson, we are, I fancy, nearing the end of our quest, and the only point which remains to be determined is whether we should go on to this Mrs. Oakshott to-night, or whether we should reserve it for to-morrow. It is clear from what that surly fellow said that there are others besides ourselves who are anxious about the matter, and I should—”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: We passed across Holborn, down Endell Street, and so through a zigzag of slums to Covent Garden Market. The night was still and cold, and the streets were nearly deserted. At last we found ourselves at the stall of Breckinridge the poultry dealer, who was just closing up with the aid of a boy. "Cold for the season," said Holmes, as we approached. "Yes, sir, it is," answered the man, buttoning up his coat. "But the geese are all sold, sir." "Ah!" said Holmes, "then I must come again in the morning." "You will find me here, sir," said Breckinridge. "I have a good trade in the district." "Indeed," said Holmes. "I was recommended to you by the landlord of the Alpha." "Ah!" said the man, with a sudden interest. "I have sent a brace of geese there every day this week." "Then you must have had a special supply," said Holmes. "Where did you get these particular birds?" The man's face darkened. "What's that to do with you?" he asked sharply. "I have no secrets from the police, but I don't see why a gentleman should be so inquisitive about my trade." "I am not a policeman," said Holmes, with a smile. "But I have a fancy for knowing where my food comes from. I have a friend who is a judge of poultry, and he says that the bird I had at the Alpha was a country-bred goose." "Nonsense!" said Breckinridge. "It was a town-bred bird, and a good one too." "Then I wager a fiver that it was country-bred," said Holmes. "You are a bold man," said the dealer. "I'll take the bet." "And I'll make it a sovereign," said Holmes, "to teach you not to be so obstinate." "You're welcome," said Breckinridge, and he called to the boy to bring the account books. He opened one of them and pointed to a page. "Here is my list of suppliers," he said. "I have them all down—country and town. The third name on the town list is Mrs. Oakshott, 117, Brixton Road." Holmes read it over his shoulder. "And the last entry?" he asked. "December 22nd. Twenty-four geese at 7s. 6d. Sold to Mr. Windigate of the Alpha, at 12s." Holmes looked at it for a moment, then threw down the sovereign. "I have lost," he said, and walked away. A few paces on, he laughed softly. "He was a good-natured man, but he could not resist a bet. We have the name and address of the next link in the chain, Watson. Mrs. Oakshott, 117, Brixton Road. I fancy that we are not the only ones who are following this trail."

events.title: James Ryder's Appearance and Interception
detailed_summary: A loud argument erupts back at Breckinridge's stall.
They see Breckinridge angrily confronting a small, 'rat-faced' man.
Breckinridge threatens the man, refusing to discuss the geese further and telling him to ask Mrs. Oakshott.
The man whines that one of the geese was his, and Mrs. Oakshott told him to ask Breckinridge.
Breckinridge angrily chases the man away.
Holmes whispers to Watson that this encounter might save them a trip to Brixton.
Holmes quickly overtakes the frightened little man and touches his shoulder.
The man is startled and asks what Holmes wants.
Holmes politely states he overheard the argument and might be able to help.
The man asks how Holmes could know anything.
Holmes introduces himself, stating it's his business 'to know what other people don't know'.
He then demonstrates his knowledge by accurately tracing the geese from Mrs. Oakshott to Breckinridge, to Windigate, to the Alpha club, and Henry Baker.
The man is astonished and calls Holmes the very person he needs.
Holmes hails a cab, suggesting they discuss the matter somewhere warmer.
He asks the man for his name.
The man hesitates and gives the alias 'John Robinson'.
Holmes gently insists on the real name, stating aliases are awkward for business.
The man flushes and reveals his true name: James Ryder.
Holmes identifies him as the Head Attendant at the Hotel Cosmopolitan and invites him into the cab.
Ryder looks fearful but hopeful, then enters the cab with Holmes and Watson.
They drive back to Baker Street in silence, Ryder exhibiting extreme nervousness.

events.text_segment:
His remarks were suddenly cut short by a loud hubbub which broke out from the stall which we had just left. Turning round we saw a little rat-faced fellow standing in the centre of the circle of yellow light which was thrown by the swinging lamp, while Breckinridge, the salesman, framed in the door of his stall, was shaking his fists fiercely at the cringing figure.
“I’ve had enough of you and your geese,” he shouted. “I wish you were all at the devil together. If you come pestering me any more with your silly talk I’ll set the dog at you. You bring Mrs. Oakshott here and I’ll answer her, but what have you to do with it? Did I buy the geese off you?”
“No; but one of them was mine all the same,” whined the little man.
“Well, then, ask Mrs. Oakshott for it.”
“She told me to ask you.”
“Well, you can ask the King of Proosia, for all I care. I’ve had enough of it. Get out of this!” He rushed fiercely forward, and the inquirer flitted away into the darkness.
“Ha! this may save us a visit to Brixton Road,” whispered Holmes. “Come with me, and we will see what is to be made of this fellow.” Striding through the scattered knots of people who lounged round the flaring stalls, my companion speedily overtook the little man and touched him upon the shoulder. He sprang round, and I could see in the gas-light that every vestige of colour had been driven from his face.
“Who are you, then? What do you want?” he asked in a quavering voice.
“You will excuse me,” said Holmes blandly, “but I could not help overhearing the questions which you put to the salesman just now. I think that I could be of assistance to you.”
“You? Who are you? How could you know anything of the matter?”
“My name is Sherlock Holmes. It is my business to know what other people don’t know.”
“But you can know nothing of this?”
“Excuse me, I know everything of it. You are endeavouring to trace some geese which were sold by Mrs. Oakshott, of Brixton Road, to a salesman named Breckinridge, by him in turn to Mr. Windigate, of the Alpha, and by him to his club, of which Mr. Henry Baker is a member.”
“Oh, sir, you are the very man whom I have longed to meet,” cried the little fellow with outstretched hands and quivering fingers. “I can hardly explain to you how interested I am in this matter.”
Sherlock Holmes hailed a four-wheeler which was passing. “In that case we had better discuss it in a cosy room rather than in this wind-swept market-place,” said he. “But pray tell me, before we go farther, who it is that I have the pleasure of assisting.”
The man hesitated for an instant. “My name is John Robinson,” he answered with a sidelong glance.
“No, no; the real name,” said Holmes sweetly. “It is always awkward doing business with an alias.”
A flush sprang to the white cheeks of the stranger. “Well then,” said he, “my real name is James Ryder.”
“Precisely so. Head attendant at the Hotel Cosmopolitan. Pray step into the cab, and I shall soon be able to tell you everything which you would wish to know.”
The little man stood glancing from one to the other of us with half-frightened, half-hopeful eyes, as one who is not sure whether he is on the verge of a windfall or of a catastrophe. Then he stepped into the cab, and in half an hour we were back in the sitting-room at Baker Street. Nothing had been said during our drive, but the high, thin breathing of our new companion, and the claspings and unclaspings of his hands, spoke of the nervous tension within him.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
His remarks were suddenly cut short by a loud hubbub which broke out from the stall which we had just left. We turned, and saw Breckinridge, the poultry dealer, standing with his arms akimbo, and his face as red as a beetroot, while a small, rat-faced, sallow man was wringing his hands and writhing before him. 

"I won't discuss the geese any more," cried Breckinridge. "You can go to Mrs. Oakshott about them."

"But it was my goose," whined the other. "Mrs. Oakshott told me to come to you."

"Then I'll see Mrs. Oakshott," said Breckinridge, and with a fierce gesture he turned upon his heel and stalked off, leaving the little man writhing in the dust. 

"This may save us a trip to Brixton," whispered Holmes to me. 

He had already quickened his pace, and in a moment he had overtaken the frightened little man and touched his shoulder. The fellow started violently and turned with a look of terror in his eyes. 

"What do you want?" he gasped. 

"I heard your little argument," said Holmes, in a most ingratiating voice. "I may be able to help you."

"How can you know anything about it?"

"My name is Sherlock Holmes. It is my business to know what other people don't know."

He then proceeded to trace the whole chain of events from Mrs. Oakshott to Breckinridge, from Breckinridge to Windigate, from Windigate to the Alpha Club, and from the Alpha Club to Henry Baker. 

"You are the very person I want," said the little man, his face lighting up with hope. 

"Then we had better discuss the matter somewhere warmer," said Holmes. He hailed a passing cab. "What is your name?"

The man hesitated. 

"John Robinson," he said at last. 

"I think you had better give me your real name," said Holmes. "It is awkward to do business under an alias."

The man flushed. 

"James Ryder," he said. 

"You are the head attendant at the Hotel Cosmopolitan," said Holmes. "Come, we have a long drive before us."

Ryder looked at us with a mingling of fear and hope, and then, with a deep sigh, he stepped into the cab. We drove back to Baker Street in silence, the little man crouched in the corner, his face as white as a sheet, and his eyes darting from one of us to the other with the look of a man who is conscious that he is in the grip of a force which he cannot resist.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
His remarks were suddenly cut short by a loud hubbub which broke out from the stall which we had just left. A moment later, a man in a dark overcoat and a battered hat stumbled out of the crowd, his face pale and his hands trembling. He clutched at my arm, his breath coming in short gasps. “You—you must help me!” he cried. “They’re after me! I’ve seen something—something terrible!”

I turned to Holmes, who had already risen to his feet, his keen eyes fixed upon the man with an expression of quiet interest. “Come, come,” he said, “let us not be alarmed by melodrama. What is it that you have seen?”

The man looked around nervously, as if expecting someone to emerge from the shadows at any moment. “It was at the market,” he whispered. “I was there earlier, buying some supplies. I saw a man—tall, with a scar across his cheek. He was speaking to a woman in a red shawl. I didn’t think much of it at the time, but then I saw her again later, this time with a different man. Both of them had the same scar. It was the same scar, I swear it!”

Holmes leaned forward slightly, his eyes narrowing. “A scar, you say? On both men?”

The man nodded, his face still pale. “Yes, a long, jagged scar. It ran from the corner of his mouth up to his ear. I’ve never seen anything like it. It looked like it had been done with a knife, but it was too precise. It was almost like a brand.”

Holmes was silent for a moment, his mind clearly working rapidly. “And where did you see this woman again?”

“In the alley behind the butcher’s shop,” the man replied. “I was passing by, and I saw her speaking to another man. He had the same scar. I tried to get a better look, but they saw me. They ran off, and I followed them for a bit, but I lost them in the back streets.”

Holmes turned to me, his expression thoughtful. “This is an intriguing development, Watson. A woman with a red shawl, seen in two different places with two different men, both bearing the same scar. It suggests a pattern, perhaps a system. And the scar itself—its precision and the fact that it is repeated—suggests that it is not a natural injury, but a mark of some sort. A brand, as the man said.”

I nodded, intrigued. “A brand? That is unusual. It suggests some sort of organization, perhaps a criminal one.”

Holmes smiled slightly. “Indeed. And if this is the case, then we may be dealing with a network of criminals, each marked in a specific way. The question is, what is the purpose of the brand? And who is behind it?”

The man looked at us, his eyes wide with fear. “You must help me,” he said again. “I don’t know what I’ve stumbled upon, but I know it’s dangerous. I’ve seen them before, you know. I’ve seen the scar. I’ve seen the woman. And I’ve seen what happens to those who get in their way.”

Holmes placed a reassuring hand on the man’s shoulder. “Fear not, my friend. We shall do what we can to help you. In the meantime, I suggest you return to your lodgings and remain there until we can speak with you again. Do not go out alone, and if you see anything else, send word to me at once.”

The man nodded, his face still pale, and disappeared into the crowd. Holmes and I watched him go, then turned to each other.

“Well, Watson,” Holmes said, “it seems we have a new case on our hands. A woman with a red shawl, a mysterious scar, and a network of criminals. It is a puzzle, but I have no doubt we shall solve it.”

I smiled. “I have no doubt of that, Holmes. Let us begin our investigation at once.”

events.title: Ryder's Confession
detailed_summary: Back in Baker Street, Holmes makes Ryder comfortable.
He asks if Ryder wants to know what happened to 'those geese', or rather, the specific white goose with a black bar on its tail.
Ryder reacts emotionally, asking where it went.
Holmes reveals it came to Baker Street and proved remarkable, laying a small, bright blue 'egg' after death.
He unlocks his strongbox and reveals the Blue Carbuncle.
Ryder staggers, clutches the mantelpiece, and stares at the gem, unsure how to react.
Holmes declares 'The game's up', helps the near-fainting Ryder back to his chair with Watson's assistance, and gives him brandy.
Holmes states he has nearly all the evidence but needs Ryder to complete the story.
He confirms Ryder heard about the stone from Catherine Cusack, the Countess's maid.

Holmes outlines Ryder's crime: tempted by wealth, Ryder conspired with Cusack, knew suspicion would fall on Horner due to his past, arranged for Horner to be called for a fake job, stole the jewel after Horner left, raised the alarm, and had Horner arrested.
Ryder collapses, begging for mercy for his parents' sake, swearing he'll never offend again, and pleading not to be taken to court.
Holmes sternly orders him back to his chair, reminding him of Horner's plight.
Ryder offers to flee the country so the charge against Horner will collapse.
Holmes demands a true account of how the stone got into the goose and the goose got to market, stating truth is Ryder's only hope.
Ryder agrees to tell the whole story.
After Horner's arrest, Ryder feared being searched and took the stone to his sister's (Mrs. Oakshott's) house in Brixton, where she raised poultry.
He felt paranoid and fearful on the journey.
At his sister's, he decided to seek help from an old acquaintance, Maudsley, recently released from prison, to dispose of the stone.
Fearing being searched on the way to Maudsley, he recalled his sister promised him a goose for Christmas.
He conceived the idea of hiding the stone inside the goose.
He caught a specific large white goose with a barred tail and forced the stone down its throat.
As his sister came out, the bird struggled loose and rejoined the flock.
He covered by saying he was checking which goose was fattest for his Christmas gift.
His sister pointed out 'Jem's bird', a heavier one set aside for him, among the 26 geese (one for him, one for them, two dozen for market).
Insisting, he took the specific bird he had handled (the one with the stone).
His sister, slightly annoyed, allowed him to kill and take it.
He took the goose to his friend Maudsley in Kilburn.
They cut open the goose but found no stone.
Realizing his mistake, Ryder rushed back to his sister's, but the remaining geese had already been sent to Breckinridge, the dealer.
He frantically asked his sister if there was another goose with a barred tail; she confirmed there were two identical ones.
Ryder understood he'd taken the wrong goose.
He rushed to Breckinridge, but the dealer had already sold the batch and refused information, just as he did earlier that night.
Ryder describes his despair, feeling he's going mad and is now a branded thief without the treasure he ruined himself for.
He breaks down sobbing.

events.text_segment:
“Here we are!” said Holmes cheerily as we filed into the room. “The fire looks very seasonable in this weather. You look cold, Mr. Ryder. Pray take the basket-chair. I will just put on my slippers before we settle this little matter of yours. Now, then! You want to know what became of those geese?”
“Yes, sir.”
“Or rather, I fancy, of that goose. It was one bird, I imagine in which you were interested—white, with a black bar across the tail.”
Ryder quivered with emotion. “Oh, sir,” he cried, “can you tell me where it went to?”
“It came here.”
“Here?”
“Yes, and a most remarkable bird it proved. I don’t wonder that you should take an interest in it. It laid an egg after it was dead—the bonniest, brightest little blue egg that ever was seen. I have it here in my museum.”
Our visitor staggered to his feet and clutched the mantelpiece with his right hand. Holmes unlocked his strong-box and held up the blue carbuncle, which shone out like a star, with a cold, brilliant, many-pointed radiance. Ryder stood glaring with a drawn face, uncertain whether to claim or to disown it.
“The game’s up, Ryder,” said Holmes quietly. “Hold up, man, or you’ll be into the fire! Give him an arm back into his chair, Watson. He’s not got blood enough to go in for felony with impunity. Give him a dash of brandy. So! Now he looks a little more human. What a shrimp it is, to be sure!”
For a moment he had staggered and nearly fallen, but the brandy brought a tinge of colour into his cheeks, and he sat staring with frightened eyes at his accuser.
“I have almost every link in my hands, and all the proofs which I could possibly need, so there is little which you need tell me. Still, that little may as well be cleared up to make the case complete. You had heard, Ryder, of this blue stone of the Countess of Morcar’s?”
“It was Catherine Cusack who told me of it,” said he in a crackling voice.
“I see—her ladyship’s waiting-maid. Well, the temptation of sudden wealth so easily acquired was too much for you, as it has been for better men before you; but you were not very scrupulous in the means you used. It seems to me, Ryder, that there is the making of a very pretty villain in you. You knew that this man Horner, the plumber, had been concerned in some such matter before, and that suspicion would rest the more readily upon him. What did you do, then? You made some small job in my lady’s room—you and your confederate Cusack—and you managed that he should be the man sent for. Then, when he had left, you rifled the jewel-case, raised the alarm, and had this unfortunate man arrested. You then—”
Ryder threw himself down suddenly upon the rug and clutched at my companion’s knees. “For God’s sake, have mercy!” he shrieked. “Think of my father! Of my mother! It would break their hearts. I never went wrong before! I never will again. I swear it. I’ll swear it on a Bible. Oh, don’t bring it into court! For Christ’s sake, don’t!”
“Get back into your chair!” said Holmes sternly. “It is very well to cringe and crawl now, but you thought little enough of this poor Horner in the dock for a crime of which he knew nothing.”
“I will fly, Mr. Holmes. I will leave the country, sir. Then the charge against him will break down.”
“Hum! We will talk about that. And now let us hear a true account of the next act. How came the stone into the goose, and how came the goose into the open market? Tell us the truth, for there lies your only hope of safety.”
Ryder passed his tongue over his parched lips. “I will tell you it just as it happened, sir,” said he. “When Horner had been arrested, it seemed to me that it would be best for me to get away with the stone at once, for I did not know at what moment the police might not take it into their heads to search me and my room. There was no place about the hotel where it would be safe. I went out, as if on some commission, and I made for my sister’s house. She had married a man named Oakshott, and lived in Brixton Road, where she fattened fowls for the market. All the way there every man I met seemed to me to be a policeman or a detective; and, for all that it was a cold night, the sweat was pouring down my face before I came to the Brixton Road. My sister asked me what was the matter, and why I was so pale; but I told her that I had been upset by the jewel robbery at the hotel. Then I went into the back yard and smoked a pipe and wondered what it would be best to do.
“I had a friend once called Maudsley, who went to the bad, and has just been serving his time in Pentonville. One day he had met me, and fell into talk about the ways of thieves, and how they could get rid of what they stole. I knew that he would be true to me, for I knew one or two things about him; so I made up my mind to go right on to Kilburn, where he lived, and take him into my confidence. He would show me how to turn the stone into money. But how to get to him in safety? I thought of the agonies I had gone through in coming from the hotel. I might at any moment be seized and searched, and there would be the stone in my waistcoat pocket. I was leaning against the wall at the time and looking at the geese which were waddling about round my feet, and suddenly an idea came into my head which showed me how I could beat the best detective that ever lived.
“My sister had told me some weeks before that I might have the pick of her geese for a Christmas present, and I knew that she was always as good as her word. I would take my goose now, and in it I would carry my stone to Kilburn. There was a little shed in the yard, and behind this I drove one of the birds—a fine big one, white, with a barred tail. I caught it, and prying its bill open, I thrust the stone down its throat as far as my finger could reach. The bird gave a gulp, and I felt the stone pass along its gullet and down into its crop. But the creature flapped and struggled, and out came my sister to know what was the matter. As I turned to speak to her the brute broke loose and fluttered off among the others.
“‘Whatever were you doing with that bird, Jem?’ says she.
“‘Well,’ said I, ‘you said you’d give me one for Christmas, and I was feeling which was the fattest.’
“‘Oh,’ says she, ‘we’ve set yours aside for you—Jem’s bird, we call it. It’s the big white one over yonder. There’s twenty-six of them, which makes one for you, and one for us, and two dozen for the market.’
“‘Thank you, Maggie,’ says I; ‘but if it is all the same to you, I’d rather have that one I was handling just now.’
“‘The other is a good three pound heavier,’ said she, ‘and we fattened it expressly for you.’
“‘Never mind. I’ll have the other, and I’ll take it now,’ said I.
“‘Oh, just as you like,’ said she, a little huffed. ‘Which is it you want, then?’
“‘That white one with the barred tail, right in the middle of the flock.’
“‘Oh, very well. Kill it and take it with you.’
“Well, I did what she said, Mr. Holmes, and I carried the bird all the way to Kilburn. I told my pal what I had done, for he was a man that it was easy to tell a thing like that to. He laughed until he choked, and we got a knife and opened the goose. My heart turned to water, for there was no sign of the stone, and I knew that some terrible mistake had occurred. I left the bird, rushed back to my sister’s, and hurried into the back yard. There was not a bird to be seen there.
“‘Where are they all, Maggie?’ I cried.
“‘Gone to the dealer’s, Jem.’
“‘Which dealer’s?’
“‘Breckinridge, of Covent Garden.’
“‘But was there another with a barred tail?’ I asked, ‘the same as the one I chose?’
“‘Yes, Jem; there were two barred-tailed ones, and I could never tell them apart.’
“Well, then, of course I saw it all, and I ran off as hard as my feet would carry me to this man Breckinridge; but he had sold the lot at once, and not one word would he tell me as to where they had gone. You heard him yourselves to-night. Well, he has always answered me like that. My sister thinks that I am going mad. Sometimes I think that I am myself. And now—and now I am myself a branded thief, without ever having touched the wealth for which I sold my character. God help me! God help me!” He burst into convulsive sobbing, with his face buried in his hands.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Here we are!” said Holmes cheerily as we filed into the room. “I trust you are not too much fatigued by your journey, Mr. Ryder?”

“I am not,” said the young man, with a nervous laugh. “I am rather in a state of wonder at my own good fortune. I had no idea that I should ever see the inside of this famous room.”

“Ah, but you are not here for pleasure,” said Holmes, with a dry smile. “You are here for information. You wish to know what became of those geese?”

Ryder started and looked at him with a startled expression. “The geese?” he repeated.

“Yes, the geese,” said Holmes. “Or rather, the goose—the white goose with the black bar on its tail.”

Ryder’s face turned ashen. “Where—where did it go?” he gasped.

“It came to me,” said Holmes, unlocking his strongbox and drawing out a small, bright blue egg. “It came to Baker Street, and it proved to be a most remarkable bird. It laid this.”

He held up the egg, and then, with a flourish, he opened it and displayed the glittering Blue Carbuncle within.

Ryder staggered and clutched the mantelpiece. He stared at the gem with a look of mingled horror and amazement. “By Heaven!” he cried. “It is there! It is there!”

“The game’s up,” said Holmes. “Come, Watson, help the young man to his chair. He is not quite equal to the situation.”

I assisted the trembling youth to his seat, and Holmes handed him a glass of brandy. “You have nearly all the evidence,” he said, “but you must give me the missing link. You heard of the stone from Catherine Cusack, the Countess’s maid, did you not?”

Ryder nodded. “Yes, yes,” he said. “She told me of it, and I—”

“Tempted by the wealth,” said Holmes, “you conspired with her. You knew that suspicion would fall upon John Horner, the footman, because of his past. You arranged for him to be called away on a false errand, and then you stole the jewel after he had left. You raised the alarm, and you had him arrested.”

Ryder covered his face with his hands. “I am a wretched man,” he said. “I have brought ruin upon myself and my poor parents. I will never offend again. I beg you, Mr. Holmes, do not let me be taken to court.”

Holmes looked at him with a stern face. “You must think of Horner,” he said. “He is in a very serious position.”

“I will flee the country,” said Ryder. “If I disappear, the charge against him will collapse.”

“No, no,” said Holmes. “You must give me the truth. Tell me how the stone got into the goose, and how the goose got to market. That is your only hope.”

Ryder looked at him with a look of despair. “I will tell you everything,” he said. “After I had stolen the stone, I feared being searched, and I took it to my sister’s house in Brixton, where she keeps poultry. I was in a state of terror the whole way. At her house, I thought of my old friend Maudsley, who had just been released from prison, and I resolved to ask him to help me get rid of the jewel. But I feared being searched on the way to him, and I remembered that my sister had promised me a goose for Christmas. I conceived the idea of hiding the stone inside the goose. I caught a large white goose with a barred tail and forced the stone down its throat. Just as I did so, my sister came out, and the bird struggled loose and rejoined the flock. I covered by saying I was checking which goose was the fattest for my Christmas gift. My sister pointed out ‘Jem’s bird,’ a heavier one set aside for me, among the twenty-six geese—two for us, and the rest for market. I insisted on taking the one I had handled. My sister, a trifle annoyed, allowed me to kill and take it. I took it to Maudsley in Kilburn. We cut it open, but there was no stone. I realized my mistake and rushed back to my sister’s, but the remaining geese had already been sent to Breckinridge, the dealer. I asked my sister if there was another goose with a barred tail, and she said there were two. I understood then that I had taken the wrong one. I rushed to Breckinridge, but the dealer had already sold the batch and refused to give me any information. I am ruined, Mr. Holmes. I am a branded thief, and I have lost the treasure I ruined myself for.”

He broke down in a fit of sobbing, and Holmes looked at him with a mixture of pity and sternness.

I assisted the trembling youth to his seat, and Holmes handed him a glass of brandy. “You have nearly all the evidence,” he said, “but you must give me the missing link. You heard of the stone from Catherine Cusack, the Countess’s maid, did you not?”

Ryder nodded. “Yes, yes,” he said. “She told me of it, and I—”

“Tempted by the wealth,” said Holmes, “you conspired with her. You knew that suspicion would fall upon John Horner, the footman, because of his past. You arranged for him to be called away on a false errand, and then you stole the jewel after he had left. You raised the alarm, and you had him arrested.”

Ryder covered his face with his hands. “I am a wretched man,” he said. “I have brought ruin upon myself and my poor parents. I will never offend again. I beg you, Mr. Holmes, do not let me be taken to court.”

Holmes looked at him with a stern face. “You must think of Horner,” he said. “He is in a very serious position.”

“I will flee the country,” said Ryder. “If I disappear, the charge against him will collapse.”

“No, no,” said Holmes. “You must give me the truth. Tell me how the stone got into the goose, and how the goose got to market. That is your only hope.”

Ryder looked at him with a look of despair. “I will tell you everything,” he said. “After I had stolen the stone, I feared being searched, and I took it to my sister’s house in Brixton, where she keeps poultry. I was in a state of terror the whole way. At her house, I thought of my old friend Maudsley, who had just been released from prison, and I resolved to ask him to help me get rid of the jewel. But I feared being searched on the way to him, and I remembered that my sister had promised me a goose for Christmas. I conceived the idea of hiding the stone inside the goose. I caught a large white goose with a barred tail and forced the stone down its throat. Just as I did so, my sister came out, and the bird struggled loose and rejoined the flock. I covered by saying I was checking which goose was the fattest for my Christmas gift. My sister pointed out ‘Jem’s bird,’ a heavier one set aside for me, among the twenty-six geese—two for us, and the rest for market. I insisted on taking the one I had handled. My sister, a trifle annoyed, allowed me to kill and take it. I took it to Maudsley in Kilburn. We cut it open, but there was no stone. I realized my mistake and rushed back to my sister’s, but the remaining geese had already been sent to Breckinridge, the dealer. I asked my sister if there was another goose with a barred tail, and she said there were two. I understood then that I had taken the wrong one. I rushed to Breckinridge, but the dealer had already sold the batch and refused to give me any information. I am ruined, Mr. Holmes. I am a branded thief, and I have lost the treasure I ruined myself for.”

He broke down in a fit of sobbing, and Holmes looked at him with a mixture of pity and sternness.

“Here we are!” said Holmes cheerily as we filed into the room. The atmosphere was thick with the scent of pipe smoke and old books, a familiar and comforting aroma that always seemed to accompany our visits to his Baker Street lodgings. I had just returned from a brief errand in the East End, and the contrast between the grimy, bustling streets and the quiet, dimly lit room was striking. My companion, Dr. Watson, followed me in, his expression one of mild curiosity. 

Holmes was already seated at his desk, a half-smoked pipe in one hand and a magnifying glass in the other. He looked up as we entered, his sharp eyes gleaming with the kind of excitement that only a new mystery could inspire. “Ah, Watson,” he said, nodding in my direction. “I see you’ve returned from your expedition. I trust it was not too arduous?”

Watson chuckled. “Not at all, Holmes. A simple errand, as you said. But I must admit, I was curious as to what had brought you to the East End so suddenly.”

Holmes leaned back in his chair, steepling his fingers beneath his chin. “A matter of some delicacy, I’m afraid. A young man came to me this morning with a most peculiar story. He claimed to have been followed by a shadowy figure for several nights, and that he had finally been confronted by this mysterious pursuer last night. He was quite shaken, and I felt it best to investigate the matter in person.”

I raised an eyebrow. “A shadowy figure, you say? That sounds rather dramatic.”

Holmes gave a small smile. “Perhaps, but appearances can be deceiving. The young man is a clerk at a small bookshop in Whitechapel, and he is not the sort to invent tales for the sake of amusement. No, I believe there is something to his story.”

Watson sat down in the chair opposite Holmes. “And what did you find when you went to the bookshop?”

Holmes took a slow puff from his pipe before answering. “The shop is modest, but well-kept. The young man, whose name is Thomas Hargreaves, is a quiet and unassuming fellow. He has been working there for nearly two years, and has no enemies that he is aware of. He claims that the figure has been following him for the past week, always keeping a distance, but never disappearing. Last night, he was walking home from the shop when the figure finally approached him.”

I leaned forward, intrigued. “And what did the figure say?”

Holmes shook his head. “That is the strange part. The young man said that the figure did not speak. It simply stood before him, its face obscured by a dark hood. He was too frightened to approach it, and when he turned to run, the figure vanished into the night.”

Watson frowned. “That does sound rather odd. Do you think it could be some sort of prank?”

Holmes gave a thoughtful nod. “Possibly, but I have a feeling there is more to this than meets the eye. I have taken the liberty of speaking to the shop’s owner, Mr. Pembroke, and he has agreed to let us examine the shop and its surroundings. I believe we should visit the bookshop tomorrow evening, when the young man is on duty. If the figure is indeed following him, we may be able to catch a glimpse of it.”

I nodded in agreement. “That sounds like a good plan. I would be happy to accompany you.”

Holmes smiled. “Excellent. I was hoping you would say that. Watson, I believe this may be a case of some interest. The young man is clearly disturbed, and I have a feeling that there is more to this mystery than he has let on.”

Watson looked thoughtful. “You think he may be hiding something?”

Holmes nodded. “Perhaps. Or perhaps he is simply too frightened to speak freely. Either way, I believe we should proceed with caution. There is something about this case that feels... different.”

I was about to ask what he meant by that when the door to the room burst open, and a young man rushed in, his face pale and his eyes wide with fear. He looked around the room, and when he saw Holmes, he let out a breath of relief.

“Mr. Holmes!” he exclaimed. “Thank goodness you’re here. I was afraid I would never find you.”

Holmes stood up, his expression shifting from curiosity to concern. “What is it, young man? What has happened?”

The young man hesitated for a moment before stepping forward. “It’s Thomas Hargreaves,” he said, his voice trembling. “He’s gone missing.”

Holmes’s eyes narrowed. “Gone missing? When did this happen?”

The young man looked down at his feet. “Last night. He didn’t come home. His family is frantic. They’ve searched the house, but there is no sign of him. I was hoping you could help.”

Holmes turned to me and Watson. “It seems our mystery has taken a rather unexpected turn. Watson, I believe it is time we paid a visit to the Hargreaves residence.”

Watson nodded. “Of course. I’ll fetch my coat.”

As we prepared to leave, Holmes turned back to the young man. “You said you were hoping to find me. How did you know where to look?”

The young man hesitated again. “I... I overheard Mr. Hargreaves speaking to someone about you. He said that if anything happened, he would come to you for help.”

Holmes gave a small smile. “Then I am glad he did. Come, gentlemen. We have a mystery to solve.”

The Hargreaves residence was a modest home in the outskirts of London, and as we arrived, we were met by a group of anxious family members. The mother, a tall and imposing woman with a look of deep worry etched into her face, rushed forward to greet us.

“Mr. Holmes!” she exclaimed. “Thank you for coming. We have no idea what has happened to Thomas. He was fine when he left for work last night, and then... nothing.”

Holmes nodded. “I understand your concern, Mrs. Hargreaves. I assure you, we will do everything in our power to find your son.”

The father, a quiet and reserved man, stepped forward. “He was always a good boy. Never gave us any trouble. I can’t imagine what could have happened to him.”

Holmes looked around the room, taking in the details. The house was neat and orderly, but there was a sense of unease in the air. I could see the worry in the eyes of the younger siblings, and I felt a pang of sympathy for them.

“May we see Thomas’s room?” Holmes asked.

Mrs. Hargreaves nodded. “Of course. This way.”

She led us up the stairs and into a small, dimly lit room. The walls were lined with bookshelves, and the desk was cluttered with papers and books. Holmes walked over to the desk and began to examine the contents.

“Interesting,” he murmured. “He was clearly an avid reader.”

I looked around the room, noting the various books and notes scattered about. There was a small journal on the desk, and I could see that it was open to a recent entry.

Holmes picked it up and began to read. “It seems Thomas was keeping a record of his encounters with the shadowy figure. He wrote that he had been followed for several nights, and that he was beginning to feel afraid.”

Watson frowned. “That does sound rather ominous. Do you think he was in danger?”

Holmes nodded. “Possibly. But I believe there is more to this than he realized.”

He continued to read through the journal, his brow furrowed in thought. “He mentions that the figure was always watching him, but never approaching. It was only last night that it finally confronted him.”

I looked at the journal, trying to make sense of the entries. “And yet, he disappeared the very next day. That seems rather strange.”

Holmes gave a small smile. “Indeed. But I believe we are on the right track. The key to this mystery lies in the bookshop.”

We spent the next hour examining the room and speaking with the family. Holmes was particularly interested in the books that Thomas had been reading, and he made a note of several titles that seemed to be of particular interest.

As we prepared to leave, Mrs. Hargreaves approached Holmes. “Mr. Holmes, I don’t know what else to do. I feel as though I am losing my mind with worry.”

Holmes placed a hand on her shoulder. “You are not alone in this, Mrs. Hargreaves. We will find your son. I give you my word.”

As we walked back to the bookshop, I could see that Holmes was deep in thought. “What do you make of it, Holmes?” I asked.

He looked up at me, his expression unreadable. “I believe we are dealing with something far more complex than we initially thought. The bookshop is the key, but I suspect there is more to it than meets the eye.”

Watson nodded. “I agree. There is something about this case that feels... different.”

Holmes gave a small smile. “Indeed. And I believe we are about to uncover the truth.”

Holmes gave a small smile. “I am glad to hear it. I believe we have a mystery to solve.”

Mr. Pembroke nodded. “I have been wondering about Thomas as well. He was a good worker, always punctual and eager to please. I can’t imagine what could have happened to him.”

Holmes walked over to the counter and began to examine the books on display. “I believe the answer lies in these books, Mr. Pembroke. Thomas was clearly interested in them.”

Mr. Pembroke looked at the books in question. “You think they have something to do with his disappearance?”

Holmes nodded. “I believe they may be the key to understanding what happened to him.”

As we examined the books, I could see that Holmes was becoming more and more engrossed in the case. He was muttering to himself, his eyes scanning the pages with a keen intensity.

“Watson,” he said suddenly, “do you see this?”

I looked at the book he was holding. It was an old, leather-bound volume with a strange symbol on the cover. “What is it?” I asked.

Holmes gave a small smile. “It is a book of ancient rituals and symbols. I believe Thomas was studying it in the hopes of understanding the shadowy figure that was following him.”

Watson frowned. “That does sound rather ominous. Do you think he was in danger?”

Holmes nodded. “Possibly. But I believe he was on the verge of uncovering something important.”

events.title: Holmes's Judgment and the Case's Resolution
detailed_summary: After a long silence, Holmes gets up and throws open the door.
He tells Ryder simply to 'Get out!'.
Ryder expresses astonished gratitude.
Holmes repeats firmly, 'No more words. Get out!'.
Ryder hastily leaves the building.
Holmes explains his reasoning to Watson.
He states he isn't employed by the police to cover their shortcomings.
Since Ryder will not testify against Horner, the case against Horner must collapse, meaning Horner is no longer in danger.
Holmes acknowledges he is technically 'commuting a felony' (letting a criminal go).
He believes, however, that he might be saving Ryder's soul, as the man is too terrified to commit crimes again.
Sending Ryder to jail now would make him a hardened criminal for life.
Holmes adds that it is the season of forgiveness.
He concludes that chance presented a unique and peculiar problem, and solving it is reward enough.
He asks Watson to ring the bell, signaling they will now turn to another matter (likely dinner), which also features a bird.
