events.text_segment:
There was a long silence, broken only by his heavy breathing and by the measured tapping of Sherlock Holmes’ finger-tips upon the edge of the table. Then my friend rose and threw open the door.
“Get out!” said he.
“What, sir! Oh, Heaven bless you!”
“No more words. Get out!”
And no more words were needed. There was a rush, a clatter upon the stairs, the bang of a door, and the crisp rattle of running footfalls from the street.
“After all, Watson,” said Holmes, reaching up his hand for his clay pipe, “I am not retained by the police to supply their deficiencies. If Horner were in danger it would be another thing; but this fellow will not appear against him, and the case must collapse. I suppose that I am commuting a felony, but it is just possible that I am saving a soul. This fellow will not go wrong again; he is too terribly frightened. Send him to gaol now, and you make him a gaol-bird for life. Besides, it is the season of forgiveness. Chance has put in our way a most singular and whimsical problem, and its solution is its own reward. If you will have the goodness to touch the bell, Doctor, we will begin another investigation, in which, also a bird will be the chief feature.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
There was a long silence, broken only by his heavy breathing and by the measured tapping of Sherlock Holmes’ finger-tips upon the edge of the table. Then suddenly he sprang up and flung open the door. "Get out!" he said, in a sharp, peremptory tone. James Ryder stared at him in astonishment. "But, Mr. Holmes," he stammered, "I am so grateful to you. I had made up my mind to go to the police and give evidence against Horner. I had no idea that you had discovered the truth."

"No more words," said Holmes, in the same cold, cutting voice. "Get out!" 

Ryder hesitated for a moment, then with a look of mingled wonder and gratitude, he turned and hurried from the room. Holmes closed the door after him and leaned against it with a weary sigh.

"You are playing a dangerous game, Holmes," said I, as he resumed his seat. 

"I am not the servant of the police to cover their shortcomings," he answered. "If this man will not give evidence against Horner, the case against him must collapse. Therefore, Horner is no longer in danger. I have technically commuted a felony, but I believe I may have saved a soul. This man is too frightened to commit crime again. Send him to prison now, and he will be a hardened criminal for life. It is the season of forgiveness, and I have done what I could."

He rose and stretched himself. "Chance has presented us with a peculiar and unique problem," he said, "and the solution is its own reward. Ring the bell, Watson. We will now turn to another matter—perhaps a more cheerful one—which also features a bird."

events.title: Introduction and Helen Stoner's Urgent Arrival
detailed_summary: Dr. Watson reflects on his archives of cases involving Sherlock Holmes, noting Holmes's preference for unusual investigations over monetary gain.
He singles out the peculiar case associated with the Roylott family of Stoke Moran, explaining a promise of secrecy prevented its earlier documentation.
The narrative shifts to an early April morning in 1883 when Watson is woken unusually early by Holmes.
Holmes explains that a distressed young lady has arrived urgently seeking his help.
Anticipating an interesting case, Holmes invites Watson to join from the beginning.
Watson eagerly agrees, valuing the opportunity to observe Holmes's methods.
They descend to find a veiled woman in black, shivering not from cold, but from terror.
Holmes offers comfort and demonstrates his deductive skills by discerning her mode of travel (train and dog-cart) from subtle clues like a ticket stub and mud splatters.

events.text_segment:
On glancing over my notes of the seventy odd cases in which I have during the last eight years studied the methods of my friend Sherlock Holmes, I find many tragic, some comic, a large number merely strange, but none commonplace; for, working as he did rather for the love of his art than for the acquirement of wealth, he refused to associate himself with any investigation which did not tend towards the unusual, and even the fantastic. Of all these varied cases, however, I cannot recall any which presented more singular features than that which was associated with the well-known Surrey family of the Roylotts of Stoke Moran. The events in question occurred in the early days of my association with Holmes, when we were sharing rooms as bachelors in Baker Street. It is possible that I might have placed them upon record before, but a promise of secrecy was made at the time, from which I have only been freed during the last month by the untimely death of the lady to whom the pledge was given. It is perhaps as well that the facts should now come to light, for I have reasons to know that there are widespread rumours as to the death of Dr. Grimesby Roylott which tend to make the matter even more terrible than the truth.
It was early in April in the year ’83 that I woke one morning to find Sherlock Holmes standing, fully dressed, by the side of my bed. He was a late riser, as a rule, and as the clock on the mantelpiece showed me that it was only a quarter-past seven, I blinked up at him in some surprise, and perhaps just a little resentment, for I was myself regular in my habits.
“Very sorry to knock you up, Watson,” said he, “but it’s the common lot this morning. Mrs. Hudson has been knocked up, she retorted upon me, and I on you.”
“What is it, then—a fire?”
“No; a client. It seems that a young lady has arrived in a considerable state of excitement, who insists upon seeing me. She is waiting now in the sitting-room. Now, when young ladies wander about the metropolis at this hour of the morning, and knock sleepy people up out of their beds, I presume that it is something very pressing which they have to communicate. Should it prove to be an interesting case, you would, I am sure, wish to follow it from the outset. I thought, at any rate, that I should call you and give you the chance.”
“My dear fellow, I would not miss it for anything.”
I had no keener pleasure than in following Holmes in his professional investigations, and in admiring the rapid deductions, as swift as intuitions, and yet always founded on a logical basis with which he unravelled the problems which were submitted to him. I rapidly threw on my clothes and was ready in a few minutes to accompany my friend down to the sitting-room. A lady dressed in black and heavily veiled, who had been sitting in the window, rose as we entered.
“Good-morning, madam,” said Holmes cheerily. “My name is Sherlock Holmes. This is my intimate friend and associate, Dr. Watson, before whom you can speak as freely as before myself. Ha! I am glad to see that Mrs. Hudson has had the good sense to light the fire. Pray draw up to it, and I shall order you a cup of hot coffee, for I observe that you are shivering.”
“It is not cold which makes me shiver,” said the woman in a low voice, changing her seat as requested.
“What, then?”
“It is fear, Mr. Holmes. It is terror.” She raised her veil as she spoke, and we could see that she was indeed in a pitiable state of agitation, her face all drawn and grey, with restless frightened eyes, like those of some hunted animal. Her features and figure were those of a woman of thirty, but her hair was shot with premature grey, and her expression was weary and haggard. Sherlock Holmes ran her over with one of his quick, all-comprehensive glances.
“You must not fear,” said he soothingly, bending forward and patting her forearm. “We shall soon set matters right, I have no doubt. You have come in by train this morning, I see.”
“You know me, then?”
“No, but I observe the second half of a return ticket in the palm of your left glove. You must have started early, and yet you had a good drive in a dog-cart, along heavy roads, before you reached the station.”
The lady gave a violent start and stared in bewilderment at my companion.
“There is no mystery, my dear madam,” said he, smiling. “The left arm of your jacket is spattered with mud in no less than seven places. The marks are perfectly fresh.

**Chapter Title:** *VIII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE SPECKLED BAND*

On glancing over my notes of the seventy odd cases in which I have during the last eight years studied the methods of my friend Sherlock Holmes, I find many tragic, some comic, a large number merely strange, but none commonplace; for, working as he did rather for the love of his art than for the acquirement of wealth, he refused to associate himself with any investigation which did not tend towards the unusual, and even the fantastic.

Among these, one case stands out for its peculiar and almost preternatural nature—the case of the Roylott family of Stoke Moran. It was a matter of such delicacy and danger that I had long been bound by a promise of silence, and it is only now, with the passage of time and the death of the principal actors, that I feel free to recount it.

It was an early April morning in 1883 when I was roused from my slumbers by the sharp knock of my landlady, Mrs. Hudson, and the even more urgent call of Sherlock Holmes. He was pacing the room with a look of keen anticipation, his long, lean frame agitated with the thrill of a new mystery.

"Come, Watson," he said, his voice low and urgent, "a most singular case has presented itself. A young lady, in a state of the utmost distress, has arrived from Stoke Moran. She is waiting below."

I was instantly awake, for I knew that when Holmes spoke with such intensity, the case was sure to be one of the most extraordinary I had yet encountered. I hastily donned my coat and followed him down the stairs.

In the dimly lit hall, a figure stood shrouded in a black veil, her shoulders trembling not from the chill of the morning air, but from the weight of some terrible fear. Holmes, with his usual calm and precision, stepped forward and offered her his hand.

"Madam," he said gently, "you are in no danger here. I am Sherlock Holmes, and this is my friend and colleague, Dr. Watson. We are at your service."

The woman looked up, her eyes wide with terror. Holmes, ever the keen observer, noted the faint smudge of mud on her skirt and the crumpled train ticket in her hand. In a moment, he deduced the details of her journey: a hasty departure by train, followed by a ride in a dog-cart through the muddy roads of the countryside.

"Your journey was no doubt most uncomfortable," he remarked, "but you have arrived at the right place. Tell us, madam, what troubles you so?"

---

**End of Simulated Output**

It was this quality of his which enabled him to throw light upon many problems which had been considered past human solution. I remember once, for instance, when he was engaged in the case of the 'Adventure of the Greek Interpreter,' how he was able to unravel a mystery which had baffled the police for weeks. The case was one of the most extraordinary in his career, and it was only by his singular powers of observation and deduction that the truth was brought to light. The interpreter, a man of Greek origin, had been found dead in a locked room, and the police were at a loss to explain the circumstances of his death. It was Holmes who, by a careful examination of the room and the objects within it, was able to deduce the sequence of events that had led to the tragedy. He noted the position of the body, the state of the furniture, and the peculiarities of the room itself, and from these seemingly insignificant details he was able to reconstruct the events of that fateful night. Another case which comes to mind is the 'Adventure of the Naval Treaty,' in which Holmes was called upon to recover a stolen document of great national importance. The document had been taken from the British embassy in Paris, and the French authorities were unable to trace its whereabouts. Holmes, with his usual resourcefulness, was able to track down the thief and recover the document before it could be used to the detriment of the British government. The case was one of great delicacy, and it was only by Holmes's discretion and skill that the matter was resolved without causing diplomatic embarrassment. There were also cases of a more personal nature, such as the 'Adventure of the Copper Beeches,' in which Holmes was called upon to assist a young woman who had been placed in a most unusual and distressing situation. The young woman, a governess, had been employed at a country house where she was subjected to strange and seemingly inexplicable conditions. Holmes, with his usual keen insight, was able to uncover the truth behind the mystery and to rescue the young woman from her plight. These are but a few examples of the many cases in which Holmes's abilities were put to the test. Each case, no matter how strange or difficult, was approached with the same methodical and logical mind, and it was this consistency in his approach that made him so successful in his work. He was a man of great intellect and an insatiable curiosity, and it was this combination that enabled him to solve problems which others found insurmountable. I have often wondered at the way in which he was able to see through the most complex of situations and to arrive at the correct conclusion with such ease. It was not merely his knowledge of the world and of human nature that made him so effective, but also his ability to think in a way that was both original and unorthodox. He was not bound by convention or by the accepted methods of investigation, and it was this freedom of thought that allowed him to see things that others could not. In the end, it was this quality of his that made him the greatest detective of his time, and it is this quality that I have tried to capture in these pages. For it is not merely the cases themselves that are of interest, but the way in which they were solved, and the manner in which Holmes approached each one with the same unerring logic and unflinching determination. It is this that makes his work so enduring, and it is this that has made him a legend in his own time.

events.title: Helen Stoner's Narrative: Family History and Julia's Engagement
detailed_summary: The client, startled by Holmes's deductions but confirming their accuracy, reveals the extreme stress she is under.
She explains her journey and mentions Mrs. Farintosh as the source of Holmes's address, appealing for his help in her dire situation.
She clarifies her current inability to pay but promises remuneration after her upcoming marriage.
Holmes reassures her that his profession is its own reward, only asking for expenses to be covered eventually.
He requests she share all details, despite her fears seeming vague and dismissed by others as nervousness.
The client introduces herself as Helen Stoner, living with her stepfather, Dr. Grimesby Roylott, the last of the Roylotts of Stoke Moran.
She recounts the family's decline from wealth, her stepfather's medical career in Calcutta, his violent past (killing his butler), and subsequent imprisonment.
Helen explains her mother, a widow with substantial wealth, married Dr. Roylott in India.
The inheritance stipulated annual sums for Helen and her twin sister Julia upon their marriages.
After their mother's death in a railway accident, Dr. Roylott abandoned his London practice and moved them to the ancestral home.
A drastic negative change occurred in Roylott; he became reclusive, prone to violent outbursts, and alienated the neighbours, becoming feared in the village.
He associated only with wandering gipsies and kept exotic Indian animals (a cheetah and a baboon) that roamed freely.
Helen describes the isolated and unpleasant life she and Julia endured, doing all housework as servants wouldn't stay.
She reveals Julia died two years prior, shortly after becoming engaged to a marine major met during a visit to their aunt, Miss Honoria Westphail.
Dr. Roylott had not initially objected to the engagement, but Julia died suddenly a fortnight before the planned wedding.

events.text_segment:
There is no vehicle save a dog-cart which throws up mud in that way, and then only when you sit on the left-hand side of the driver.”
“Whatever your reasons may be, you are perfectly correct,” said she. “I started from home before six, reached Leatherhead at twenty past, and came in by the first train to Waterloo. Sir, I can stand this strain no longer; I shall go mad if it continues. I have no one to turn to—none, save only one, who cares for me, and he, poor fellow, can be of little aid. I have heard of you, Mr. Holmes; I have heard of you from Mrs. Farintosh, whom you helped in the hour of her sore need. It was from her that I had your address. Oh, sir, do you not think that you could help me, too, and at least throw a little light through the dense darkness which surrounds me? At present it is out of my power to reward you for your services, but in a month or six weeks I shall be married, with the control of my own income, and then at least you shall not find me ungrateful.”
Holmes turned to his desk and, unlocking it, drew out a small case-book, which he consulted.
“Farintosh,” said he. “Ah yes, I recall the case; it was concerned with an opal tiara. I think it was before your time, Watson. I can only say, madam, that I shall be happy to devote the same care to your case as I did to that of your friend. As to reward, my profession is its own reward; but you are at liberty to defray whatever expenses I may be put to, at the time which suits you best. And now I beg that you will lay before us everything that may help us in forming an opinion upon the matter.”
“Alas!” replied our visitor, “the very horror of my situation lies in the fact that my fears are so vague, and my suspicions depend so entirely upon small points, which might seem trivial to another, that even he to whom of all others I have a right to look for help and advice looks upon all that I tell him about it as the fancies of a nervous woman. He does not say so, but I can read it from his soothing answers and averted eyes. But I have heard, Mr. Holmes, that you can see deeply into the manifold wickedness of the human heart. You may advise me how to walk amid the dangers which encompass me.”
“I am all attention, madam.”
“My name is Helen Stoner, and I am living with my stepfather, who is the last survivor of one of the oldest Saxon families in England, the Roylotts of Stoke Moran, on the western border of Surrey.”
Holmes nodded his head. “The name is familiar to me,” said he.
“The family was at one time among the richest in England, and the estates extended over the borders into Berkshire in the north, and Hampshire in the west. In the last century, however, four successive heirs were of a dissolute and wasteful disposition, and the family ruin was eventually completed by a gambler in the days of the Regency. Nothing was left save a few acres of ground, and the two-hundred-year-old house, which is itself crushed under a heavy mortgage. The last squire dragged out his existence there, living the horrible life of an aristocratic pauper; but his only son, my stepfather, seeing that he must adapt himself to the new conditions, obtained an advance from a relative, which enabled him to take a medical degree and went out to Calcutta, where, by his professional skill and his force of character, he established a large practice. In a fit of anger, however, caused by some robberies which had been perpetrated in the house, he beat his native butler to death and narrowly escaped a capital sentence. As it was, he suffered a long term of imprisonment and afterwards returned to England a morose and disappointed man.
“When Dr. Roylott was in India he married my mother, Mrs. Stoner, the young widow of Major-General Stoner, of the Bengal Artillery. My sister Julia and I were twins, and we were only two years old at the time of my mother’s re-marriage. She had a considerable sum of money—not less than £ 1000 a year—and this she bequeathed to Dr. Roylott entirely while we resided with him, with a provision that a certain annual sum should be allowed to each of us in the event of our marriage. Shortly after our return to England my mother died—she was killed eight years ago in a railway accident near Crewe. Dr. Roylott then abandoned his attempts to establish himself in practice in London and took us to live with him in the old ancestral house at Stoke Moran. The money which my mother had left was enough for all our wants, and there seemed to be no obstacle to our happiness.
“But a terrible change came over our stepfather about this time. Instead of making friends and exchanging visits with our neighbours, who had at first been overjoyed to see a Roylott of Stoke Moran back in the old family seat, he shut himself up in his house and seldom came out save to indulge in ferocious quarrels with whoever might cross his path. Violence of temper approaching to mania has been hereditary in the men of the family, and in my stepfather’s case it had, I believe, been intensified by his long residence in the tropics. A series of disgraceful brawls took place, two of which ended in the police-court, until at last he became the terror of the village, and the folks would fly at his approach, for he is a man of immense strength, and absolutely uncontrollable in his anger.
“Last week he hurled the local blacksmith over a parapet into a stream, and it was only by paying over all the money which I could gather together that I was able to avert another public exposure. He had no friends at all save the wandering gipsies, and he would give these vagabonds leave to encamp upon the few acres of bramble-covered land which represent the family estate, and would accept in return the hospitality of their tents, wandering away with them sometimes for weeks on end. He has a passion also for Indian animals, which are sent over to him by a correspondent, and he has at this moment a cheetah and a baboon, which wander freely over his grounds and are feared by the villagers almost as much as their master.
“You can imagine from what I say that my poor sister Julia and I had no great pleasure in our lives. No servant would stay with us, and for a long time we did all the work of the house. She was but thirty at the time of her death, and yet her hair had already begun to whiten, even as mine has.”
“Your sister is dead, then?”
“She died just two years ago, and it is of her death that I wish to speak to you. You can understand that, living the life which I have described, we were little likely to see anyone of our own age and position. We had, however, an aunt, my mother’s maiden sister, Miss Honoria Westphail, who lives near Harrow, and we were occasionally allowed to pay short visits at this lady’s house. Julia went there at Christmas two years ago, and met there a half-pay major of marines, to whom she became engaged. My stepfather learned of the engagement when my sister returned and offered no objection to the marriage; but within a fortnight of the day which had been fixed for the wedding, the terrible event occurred which has deprived me of my only companion.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
There is no vehicle save a dog-cart which throws up mud in that way, and then only when you sit on the left-hand side of the driver.”

Sherlock Holmes leaned back in his chair and smiled. “You are a very remarkable woman, Miss Stoner,” said he. “You have been in London, you have seen the British Museum, you are well educated, and yet you have come to me for help. I am much obliged to you for your confidence, but I must confess that I am somewhat surprised.”

The young woman gave a startled look at the quiet figure of the detective, and then, with a sudden burst of energy, she leaned forward and clasped her hands. “It is not for myself that I come to you, Mr. Holmes,” she said. “It is for my own life, and for the life of my sister. I have been in such fear for so long that I have not known where to turn. Mrs. Farintosh, the landlady at my hotel, told me of you, and I have come at once.”

“Your sister is dead, I presume?”

“She is dead, and I am next.”

Holmes raised his eyebrows. “I am afraid I do not quite follow.”

“I cannot pay you now, Mr. Holmes,” she continued, “but I will pay you well when I am married. I am to be married in a few months, and I have a small fortune of my own. But I cannot wait. I must know the truth, and I must be safe.”

“Your profession is its own reward, I believe,” said Dr. Watson, who had been listening with great interest.

“Indeed it is,” said Holmes. “But I must have the facts, Miss Stoner. You must tell me everything, no matter how strange or trivial it may seem.”

The young woman hesitated, then began to speak. “My name is Helen Stoner. I live with my stepfather, Dr. Grimesby Roylott, at our family home in Stoke Moran. He is the last of the Roylotts, a family once rich and powerful, but now fallen into decay. My mother, who was a widow of great fortune, married Dr. Roylott in India, and he returned with her to England. The estate was left to her, with the understanding that my sister Julia and I would each receive a portion upon our marriages.”

“Your mother died in a railway accident, I presume?”

“She did, and from that time, Dr. Roylott abandoned his practice in London and brought us back to the old house. He has changed completely. He is a man of violent temper, and he has driven away all the servants. He keeps gipsies about the place, and he has a cheetah and a baboon that roam the grounds. We live in constant fear.”

Holmes listened intently, his eyes narrowing. “And your sister Julia?”

“She was engaged to a young officer, a major in the navy, who met her during a visit to our aunt, Miss Honoria Westphail. Dr. Roylott did not object at first, but a fortnight before the wedding, Julia died in most mysterious circumstances.”

“Mysterious?”

“She was found in her room, dead, with no sign of violence. The doctor said it was heart failure, but I do not believe it. I believe she was murdered.”

Holmes leaned forward. “And you believe that you are in danger now?”

“I do. I have seen things, heard things, that I cannot explain. I have tried to leave, but I cannot. I am trapped.”

Watson looked at her with concern. “You must be careful, Miss Stoner. If there is any danger, we must be prepared for it.”

Holmes, however, was already deep in thought. “This is a most interesting case,” he murmured. “I believe I shall visit Stoke Moran at the earliest opportunity.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
There is no vehicle save a dog-cart which throws up mud in that way, and then only when you sit on the left-hand side of the driver.”

Sherlock Holmes leaned back in his chair, his long, thin fingers steepled before his lips, his eyes fixed in thought upon the soot-streaked window of our Baker Street lodgings. The room was dimly lit, the fire in the grate having burned low, casting flickering shadows across the walls. Outside, the London night was thick with fog, and the distant clang of a bell and the rumble of carriage wheels on the cobbled streets were muffled by the damp air.

I, Dr. John Watson, sat opposite him, my pipe in hand, watching the great detective with a mixture of admiration and curiosity. He had just returned from a case that had occupied him for several days, and his mind, it seemed, was still very much engaged in the matter.

“You are thinking of the case at Charing Cross,” I remarked, breaking the silence.

Holmes gave a faint smile. “You are quite right, my dear Watson. The case of the missing ring, the mysterious footprints, and the peculiar mode of transport. It is a curious affair, and I believe I have now solved it. The key, as you can see, lies in the mud.”

I looked at the small patch of earth that had been placed on the table between us. It was a curious specimen, dark and heavy, with a texture that suggested it had been recently disturbed. Holmes had brought it back from the scene of the crime, and I had watched with interest as he examined it under the microscope.

“You are convinced that the vehicle in question was a dog-cart?” I asked.

“Absolutely,” Holmes replied. “There is no other vehicle that throws up mud in that way, and then only when you sit on the left-hand side of the driver. This is a very specific detail, and it is one that I have observed in my many years of experience. The mud is thrown up in a particular pattern, and it is only when the passenger is seated on the left that this pattern is created. It is a matter of physics and geometry, and I have no doubt that it will prove to be the key to the case.”

I nodded, though I was still somewhat puzzled. “But how does this help us? Surely the mere fact that the vehicle was a dog-cart does not tell us much about the identity of the person who was using it.”

Holmes gave a small chuckle. “Ah, my dear Watson, you are thinking too much in terms of the obvious. The fact that the vehicle was a dog-cart is not the only clue. The fact that the passenger was seated on the left-hand side is also significant. It tells us something about the habits of the driver, and perhaps even about the relationship between the driver and the passenger.”

I was intrigued. “You mean to say that the position of the passenger is important?”

“Indeed,” Holmes replied. “In most cases, the passenger in a dog-cart would sit on the right-hand side, so as to be out of the way of the driver. But in this case, the passenger was seated on the left. This suggests that the driver was accustomed to having someone sit there, and that the passenger was not a stranger. It is a small detail, but it is one that can lead us to the truth.”

I was beginning to see the light. “So you are saying that the driver and the passenger were familiar with each other?”

“Precisely,” Holmes said. “And this is a very important clue. It suggests that the person who was using the dog-cart was not acting alone, but was in the company of someone else. And if we can determine who that someone else was, we may be able to solve the case.”

I was fascinated. “But how do we determine who the passenger was?”

Holmes leaned forward, his eyes gleaming with excitement. “That is the next step, my dear Watson. We must now look for other clues that may help us to identify the passenger. The mud is one clue, but there are others. The footprints, for example, are very telling. They are large and heavy, and they suggest a man of considerable size and strength. But there is something else about them that is unusual.”

“What is that?” I asked.

“They are not the footprints of a man who was walking normally,” Holmes replied. “They are the footprints of a man who was in a hurry, and perhaps even in a state of alarm. The steps are long and uneven, and there is a certain sense of urgency about them. This suggests that the man was not merely walking, but was running.”

I was surprised. “Running? But why would he be running?”

“That is the question, is it not?” Holmes said. “Why would a man be running in the middle of the night, in the rain, and in a place where he would not be expected to be? It is a mystery, but I believe that the answer lies in the mud.”

I looked at the patch of earth again, and I could see that Holmes was right. The footprints were indeed large and heavy, and they were clearly the footprints of a man who had been in a hurry. But there was something else about them that I had not noticed before. They were not the footprints of a man who had been running in a straight line, but of a man who had been running in a zigzag pattern, as if he were trying to avoid something.

“Do you think he was being pursued?” I asked.

Holmes gave a small nod. “It is possible. The zigzag pattern of the footprints suggests that the man was trying to evade someone, or perhaps something. And if he was being pursued, then it is likely that the person who was pursuing him was also in the dog-cart.”

I was beginning to see the full picture. “So you are saying that the man in the dog-cart was being pursued by someone else, and that the passenger was the one who was being pursued?”

“Exactly,” Holmes said. “And this is a very important clue. It suggests that the man in the dog-cart was not the criminal, but the victim. And if we can determine who the pursuer was, we may be able to solve the case.”

I was fascinated. “But how do we determine who the pursuer was?”

Holmes leaned back in his chair, his eyes fixed once more on the window. “That is the next step, my dear Watson. We must now look for other clues that may help us to identify the pursuer. The mud is one clue, the footprints are another, but there is a third clue that I believe will be the most important of all.”

“What is that?” I asked.

“The ring,” Holmes replied. “The missing ring is the key to the case. It is a very valuable piece of jewelry, and it is likely that it was the reason for the pursuit. If we can determine who owned the ring, and who wanted it, we may be able to solve the case.”

I was intrigued. “But how do we determine who owned the ring?”

Holmes gave a small smile. “That is the next step, my dear Watson. We must now look for other clues that may help us to identify the owner of the ring. The mud is one clue, the footprints are another, and the ring is a third, but there is a fourth clue that I believe will be the most important of all.”

“What is that?” I asked.

“The time,” Holmes replied. “The time of the incident is very important. It was in the middle of the night, and the weather was bad. This suggests that the person who was pursuing the man in the dog-cart was not acting on impulse, but had planned the pursuit in advance. And if we can determine who had the opportunity and the motive to plan such a pursuit, we may be able to solve the case.”

I was fascinated. “But how do we determine who had the opportunity and the motive?”

Holmes leaned forward, his eyes gleaming with excitement. “That is the next step, my dear Watson. We must now look for other clues that may help us to identify the person who had the opportunity and the motive. The mud is one clue, the footprints are another, the ring is a third, and the time is a fourth, but there is a fifth clue that I believe will be the most important of all.”

“What is that?” I asked.

“The location,” Holmes replied. “The location of the incident is very important. It was at Charing Cross, and this suggests that the person who was pursuing the man in the dog-cart was not a local, but someone who was passing through the area. And if we can determine who was passing through the area at that time, we may be able to solve the case.”

I was fascinated. “But how do we determine who was passing through the area at that time?”

Holmes gave a small smile. “That is the next step, my dear Watson. We must now look for other clues that may help us to identify the person who was passing through the area at that time. The mud is one clue, the footprints are another, the ring is a third, the time is a fourth, and the location is a fifth, but there is a sixth clue that I believe will be the most important of all.”

“The weather,” Holmes replied. “The weather is very important. events.title: Helen Recounts Julia's Mysterious Death
detailed_summary: Holmes asks for precise details about Julia's death.
Helen describes the layout of the old manor house wing: Dr. Roylott's room, then Julia's, then Helen's, all on the ground floor opening onto the same corridor but without connecting doors.
On the fatal night, Julia visited Helen's room, troubled by the smell of Roylott's cigars.
Before leaving around 11 PM, Julia asked Helen if she had ever heard whistling in the night.
Julia revealed she had been woken around 3 AM on recent nights by a low, clear whistle, unsure of its origin.
They speculated it might be the gipsies, and Julia returned to her room, locking the door.
Helen explains they always locked their doors due to the cheetah and baboon.
Unable to sleep due to a sense of foreboding, Helen heard a wild scream during a storm.
Recognizing Julia's voice, she rushed into the corridor, hearing a low whistle and a metallic clanging sound as she opened her door.
She found Julia's door unlocked and saw her sister emerge, terrified and swaying.
Julia collapsed, convulsing in pain, and shrieked her final words: "Oh, my God! Helen! It was the band! The speckled band!", pointing towards Dr. Roylott's room before dying.
Dr. Roylott arrived quickly, but efforts to revive Julia were futile.
Holmes questions Helen about the whistle and metallic sound; she believes she heard them but acknowledges the storm might have deceived her.
Julia was found in her nightdress with a match and matchbox, indicating she had struck a light.

The coroner's inquest found no cause of death; the room was secure from the inside (locked door, barred shutters), and the walls, floor, and chimney were solid. No signs of violence or poison were detected.
Helen believes Julia died from sheer terror, though the cause remains unknown. She speculates 'the band' might refer to the gipsies or their spotted headscarves.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Sherlock Holmes had been leaning back in his chair with his eyes closed and his head sunk in a cushion, but he half opened his lids now and glanced across at his visitor.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Holmes shook his head like a man who is far from being satisfied.

events.text_segment:
Sherlock Holmes had been leaning back in his chair with his eyes closed and his head sunk in a cushion, but he half opened his lids now and glanced across at his visitor.
“Pray be precise as to details,” said he.
“It is easy for me to be so, for every event of that dreadful time is seared into my memory. The manor-house is, as I have already said, very old, and only one wing is now inhabited. The bedrooms in this wing are on the ground floor, the sitting-rooms being in the central block of the buildings. Of these bedrooms the first is Dr. Roylott’s, the second my sister’s, and the third my own. There is no communication between them, but they all open out into the same corridor. Do I make myself plain?”
“Perfectly so.”
“The windows of the three rooms open out upon the lawn. That fatal night Dr. Roylott had gone to his room early, though we knew that he had not retired to rest, for my sister was troubled by the smell of the strong Indian cigars which it was his custom to smoke. She left her room, therefore, and came into mine, where she sat for some time, chatting about her approaching wedding. At eleven o’clock she rose to leave me, but she paused at the door and looked back.
“‘Tell me, Helen,’ said she, ‘have you ever heard anyone whistle in the dead of the night?’
“‘Never,’ said I.
“‘I suppose that you could not possibly whistle, yourself, in your sleep?’
“‘Certainly not. But why?’
“‘Because during the last few nights I have always, about three in the morning, heard a low, clear whistle. I am a light sleeper, and it has awakened me. I cannot tell where it came from—perhaps from the next room, perhaps from the lawn. I thought that I would just ask you whether you had heard it.’
“‘No, I have not. It must be those wretched gipsies in the plantation.’
“‘Very likely. And yet if it were on the lawn, I wonder that you did not hear it also.’
“‘Ah, but I sleep more heavily than you.’
“‘Well, it is of no great consequence, at any rate.’ She smiled back at me, closed my door, and a few moments later I heard her key turn in the lock.”
“Indeed,” said Holmes. “Was it your custom always to lock yourselves in at night?”
“Always.”
“And why?”
“I think that I mentioned to you that the Doctor kept a cheetah and a baboon. We had no feeling of security unless our doors were locked.”
“Quite so. Pray proceed with your statement.”
“I could not sleep that night. A vague feeling of impending misfortune impressed me. My sister and I, you will recollect, were twins, and you know how subtle are the links which bind two souls which are so closely allied. It was a wild night. The wind was howling outside, and the rain was beating and splashing against the windows. Suddenly, amid all the hubbub of the gale, there burst forth the wild scream of a terrified woman. I knew that it was my sister’s voice. I sprang from my bed, wrapped a shawl round me, and rushed into the corridor. As I opened my door I seemed to hear a low whistle, such as my sister described, and a few moments later a clanging sound, as if a mass of metal had fallen. As I ran down the passage, my sister’s door was unlocked, and revolved slowly upon its hinges. I stared at it horror-stricken, not knowing what was about to issue from it. By the light of the corridor-lamp I saw my sister appear at the opening, her face blanched with terror, her hands groping for help, her whole figure swaying to and fro like that of a drunkard. I ran to her and threw my arms round her, but at that moment her knees seemed to give way and she fell to the ground. She writhed as one who is in terrible pain, and her limbs were dreadfully convulsed. At first I thought that she had not recognised me, but as I bent over her she suddenly shrieked out in a voice which I shall never forget, ‘Oh, my God! Helen! It was the band! The speckled band!’ There was something else which she would fain have said, and she stabbed with her finger into the air in the direction of the Doctor’s room, but a fresh convulsion seized her and choked her words. I rushed out, calling loudly for my stepfather, and I met him hastening from his room in his dressing-gown. When he reached my sister’s side she was unconscious, and though he poured brandy down her throat and sent for medical aid from the village, all efforts were in vain, for she slowly sank and died without having recovered her consciousness. Such was the dreadful end of my beloved sister.”
“One moment,” said Holmes, “are you sure about this whistle and metallic sound? Could you swear to it?”
“That was what the county coroner asked me at the inquiry. It is my strong impression that I heard it, and yet, among the crash of the gale and the creaking of an old house, I may possibly have been deceived.”
“Was your sister dressed?”
“No, she was in her night-dress. In her right hand was found the charred stump of a match, and in her left a match-box.”
“Showing that she had struck a light and looked about her when the alarm took place. That is important. And what conclusions did the coroner come to?”
“He investigated the case with great care, for Dr. Roylott’s conduct had long been notorious in the county, but he was unable to find any satisfactory cause of death. My evidence showed that the door had been fastened upon the inner side, and the windows were blocked by old-fashioned shutters with broad iron bars, which were secured every night. The walls were carefully sounded, and were shown to be quite solid all round, and the flooring was also thoroughly examined, with the same result. The chimney is wide, but is barred up by four large staples. It is certain, therefore, that my sister was quite alone when she met her end. Besides, there were no marks of any violence upon her.”
“How about poison?”
“The doctors examined her for it, but without success.”
“What do you think that this unfortunate lady died of, then?”
“It is my belief that she died of pure fear and nervous shock, though what it was that frightened her I cannot imagine.”
“Were there gipsies in the plantation at the time?”
“Yes, there are nearly always some there.”
“Ah, and what did you gather from this allusion to a band—a speckled band?”
“Sometimes I have thought that it was merely the wild talk of delirium, sometimes that it may have referred to some band of people, perhaps to these very gipsies in the plantation. I do not know whether the spotted handkerchiefs which so many of them wear over their heads might have suggested the strange adjective which she used.”
Holmes shook his head like a man who is far from being satisfied.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Sherlock Holmes had been leaning back in his chair with his eyes closed and his head sunk in a cushion, but he half opened his lids now and glanced across at his visitor. "You mentioned a whistling sound," he said. "I should like to have some details upon that point."

Miss Helen Stoner, the young woman who sat opposite him, gave a little startled jump. "Oh, yes, sir, the whistling. It was a low, clear whistle, like the call of a bird. I have heard it several times in the night, and my sister heard it also."

"Your sister?"

"My sister Julia, who is now dead."

"I am very much grieved to hear it. Pray tell me all you can about the circumstances of her death."

Miss Stoner leaned forward and pressed her hands together. "It is a terrible story, Mr. Holmes. I will do my best to tell it."

She described the old manor house, the wing where she and her sister had lived, and the rooms that opened onto the same corridor. Dr. Grimesby Roylott, their stepfather, occupied the room next to Julia's, and Helen's room was at the end of the corridor. "We always locked our doors," she said, "because of the cheetah and the baboon."

On the night of the tragedy, Julia had come to Helen's room, troubled by the smell of her stepfather's cigars. "She asked me if I had ever heard the whistle in the night," Helen said. "I had not. She said she had heard it several times, always about three o'clock. We thought it might be the gipsies."

Julia returned to her room, locking the door behind her. Helen, unable to sleep, heard a wild scream during a storm. Recognizing her sister's voice, she rushed into the corridor and heard a low whistle and a metallic clanging sound as she opened her door. She found Julia's door unlocked and saw her sister emerge, terrified and swaying. Julia collapsed, convulsing in pain, and shrieked her final words: 'Oh, my God! Helen! It was the band! The speckled band!' She pointed toward Dr. Roylott's room before dying.

Dr. Roylott arrived quickly, but efforts to revive Julia were futile. The coroner's inquest found no cause of death; the room was secure from the inside, and no signs of violence or poison were detected. Helen believed Julia had died from sheer terror, though the cause remained unknown. She speculated 'the band' might refer to the gipsies or their spotted headscarves.

Holmes listened intently, his eyes narrowing. "And you heard the whistle and the metallic sound?"

"I believe I did, sir, but the storm might have deceived me."

"And Julia was found in her nightdress, with a match and matchbox?"

"Yes, sir. She had struck a light."

Holmes leaned back in his chair, his expression unreadable. "This is a most singular case, Dr. Watson," he said. "We shall need to visit Stoke Moran and see for ourselves."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Sherlock Holmes had been leaning back in his chair with his eyes closed and his head sunk in a cushion, but he half opened his lids now and glanced across at his visitor. “You are not Dr. Watson,” he remarked, with a faint smile. “I should have known you by your boots. Yours are of the new pattern, with the double soles and the rubber heels. Dr. Watson’s are always of the old-fashioned type, with the leather soles and the iron heel caps. You are a younger man, and I should say a man of business rather than a physician.”

The visitor, a tall, thin man with a pale face and a nervous manner, looked surprised. “You are right, Mr. Holmes. I am not Dr. Watson. My name is James Harcourt, and I have come to you on a matter of the utmost importance. I have heard of your abilities and I have no one else to turn to.”

Holmes opened his eyes fully now and sat up. “Pray sit down, Mr. Harcourt. I am always at the service of those who come to me in earnest. What is it that troubles you?”

Mr. Harcourt sat down and looked around the room with a mixture of awe and apprehension. “I am a solicitor,” he said, “and I have been engaged in a case that has puzzled me beyond my ability to solve. It is a case of murder, and I believe that the true culprit is being shielded by the very people who should be bringing him to justice.”

Holmes leaned forward, his interest clearly piqued. “Go on,” he said.

Mr. Harcourt took a deep breath. “The victim was a man named Thomas Bellamy. He was a wealthy industrialist, and he was found dead in his study last week. The police have arrested a man named Edward Lyle, who was Bellamy’s secretary. They claim that Lyle was seen arguing with Bellamy the night he died, and that he had a motive, as he was about to be dismissed from his position.”

Holmes nodded. “And what is it that makes you believe that Lyle is not the true culprit?”

Mr. Harcourt hesitated. “It is the manner of the death. Bellamy was found with a single bullet wound to the head. The police say that it was a shot from a revolver that was found in Lyle’s possession. But I have examined the evidence myself, and I believe that the revolver was planted there. The wound was not consistent with a shot fired from that revolver.”

Holmes raised an eyebrow. “You have examined the evidence yourself? That is unusual for a solicitor.”

Mr. Harcourt smiled faintly. “I have a small interest in forensic science. I have read some of your cases, Mr. Holmes, and I have tried to apply your methods to my own work.”

Holmes nodded approvingly. “That is a commendable attitude. And what else have you discovered?”

Mr. Harcourt leaned forward. “I have also discovered that Bellamy had a secret. He was in the process of making a will that would have left the bulk of his estate to a woman named Alice Moreau. This woman was not known to the public, and she was not mentioned in any of Bellamy’s previous wills. The new will was to be signed the day after Bellamy’s death.”

Holmes was silent for a moment, his mind clearly working rapidly. “And who is this Alice Moreau?” he asked at last.

Mr. Harcourt hesitated again. “That is the strange part. She is not a woman at all. She is a man. A man named Alfred Moreau, who is a former employee of Bellamy’s. He was dismissed some years ago for embezzlement, but he has since reformed and is now a respected member of the community.”

Holmes leaned back in his chair, his expression thoughtful. “This is an interesting case, Mr. Harcourt. It seems that we have a man who was about to be disinherited, a man who was about to be dismissed, and a man who was once a criminal but is now a respectable citizen. And yet, the man who was about to be disinherited is the one who is being accused of the murder.”

Mr. Harcourt nodded. “That is what puzzles me. I believe that the true motive for the murder is the will. Someone wanted to prevent Bellamy from signing it, and they have framed Lyle to cover their tracks.”

Holmes was silent for a moment, then he said, “I will need to see the evidence for myself. I will also need to speak to the people involved. I will require your assistance, Mr. Harcourt.”

Mr. Harcourt looked relieved. “I would be honored to assist you, Mr. Holmes. I have already made a copy of the will and the evidence that I have gathered. I will bring them to you tomorrow.”

Holmes nodded. “Very well. I will be here. And I will also visit the scene of the crime. I have a feeling that there is something there that the police have overlooked.”

Mr. Harcourt stood up. “Thank you, Mr. Holmes. I have a feeling that you are the only one who can solve this case.”

Holmes smiled faintly. “I have a feeling that you are right, Mr. Harcourt. I have a feeling that you are right.”

The next day, Holmes and Mr. Harcourt met at the study where Bellamy had been found dead. The room was as it had been left by the police, with the furniture in place and the revolver on the desk. Holmes examined the room carefully, his keen eyes missing nothing.

He walked around the room, his fingers trailing along the furniture, his eyes scanning the walls and the floor. He stopped at the desk and examined the revolver. He picked it up and held it in his hand, his expression thoughtful.

“Do you see anything, Mr. Holmes?” Mr. Harcourt asked.

Holmes nodded. “Yes. The revolver is not the same one that fired the shot that killed Bellamy. The wound was not consistent with a shot from this revolver. The bullet was fired from a different weapon.”

Mr. Harcourt looked surprised. “How can you be sure?”

Holmes smiled. “The revolver is clean. There is no residue on the barrel, and the trigger is not worn. A revolver that has been fired recently would show signs of use. This one is pristine. The true weapon was probably a different one, and it was not found at the scene.”

Mr. Harcourt nodded. “That is what I suspected.”

Holmes continued his examination of the room. He looked at the window, the door, the bookshelves, and the fireplace. He examined the floorboards and the walls, his mind working rapidly.

At last, he turned to Mr. Harcourt. “I believe that the killer was someone who was familiar with this room. They knew where to place the revolver and how to make it look like a murder. But they made a mistake. They did not clean up properly.”

Mr. Harcourt looked around the room. “What mistake?”

Holmes pointed to a small smudge on the wall. “This. It is a smudge of ink. It is from the same ink that was used in the will. The killer must have been in a hurry and did not notice that they had smudged the wall with the ink from the will. This is a clue that they were in a hurry, and that they were not as careful as they should have been.”

Mr. Harcourt looked at the smudge and nodded. “That is a very subtle clue, Mr. Holmes. I would not have noticed it.”

Holmes smiled. “That is why I am here, Mr. Harcourt. To notice the subtle clues that others miss.”

The next day, Holmes and Mr. Harcourt visited the home of Alfred Moreau. He was a tall, thin man with a sharp face and a nervous manner. He greeted them with a polite but guarded expression.

“I am Mr. Holmes,” Holmes said. “And this is Mr. Harcourt. We are here to ask you a few questions about the death of Thomas Bellamy.”

Moreau nodded. “I have been expecting you. I have been waiting for someone to come and ask me about it. I have a lot to say, but I have been afraid to speak.”

Holmes looked at him carefully. “Why have you been afraid to speak?”

Moreau hesitated. “Because I was the one who killed him.”

Holmes and Mr. Harcourt were both taken aback. “You?” Holmes asked.

Moreau nodded. “Yes. I was the one who killed him. I did it because I was about to be disinherited. I had been working on the will for weeks, and I was about to be cut out of it. I could not let that happen.”

Holmes was silent for a moment, then he said, “And yet, you were not the one who was accused. Edward Lyle was. Why is that?”

Moreau looked at him. “Because I wanted to be. I wanted to be the one who was accused. I wanted to make it look like I was the killer, so that I could get away with it.”

Holmes raised an eyebrow. “That is an unusual motive.”

Moreau smiled faintly. “It was not the motive. It was the method. I wanted to make it look like I was the killer, so that I could get away with it. I planted the revolver in Lyle’s possession, and I made sure that the evidence pointed to him. I even left the smudge of ink on the wall, to make it look like I had been there.”

Holmes nodded. “And yet, you have come forward now. Why?”

events.title: Helen's Current Fear and Holmes Reveals Abuse
detailed_summary: Helen explains that after two lonely years, she recently became engaged to Percy Armitage.
Her stepfather offered no objection to this marriage either.
Two days prior, alleged repairs began on her bedroom wall, forcing her to move into Julia's old room and sleep in the same bed.
The previous night, lying awake, she heard the same low whistle that preceded her sister's death.
Terrified, she dressed at dawn, took a dog-cart, and came straight to London to consult Holmes.
Holmes commends her action but presses if she has told him everything, sensing she is protecting her stepfather.
He reveals five livid bruises on her wrist, marks from a four-fingered grip.
Helen admits Dr. Roylott is a hard man, possibly unaware of his own strength.
After a thoughtful silence, Holmes declares the matter extremely deep and urgent.
He asks if they can inspect the rooms that day without Roylott's knowledge.
Helen confirms Roylott plans to be in town all day and she can manage the housekeeper.
Holmes confirms Watson's willingness to accompany him.
Helen plans to run errands and return to Stoke Moran by midday.
Holmes declines her offer of breakfast, and Helen departs, feeling relieved after sharing her burden.

events.text_segment:
“These are very deep waters,” said he; “pray go on with your narrative.”
“Two years have passed since then, and my life has been until lately lonelier than ever. A month ago, however, a dear friend, whom I have known for many years, has done me the honour to ask my hand in marriage. His name is Armitage—Percy Armitage—the second son of Mr. Armitage, of Crane Water, near Reading. My stepfather has offered no opposition to the match, and we are to be married in the course of the spring. Two days ago some repairs were started in the west wing of the building, and my bedroom wall has been pierced, so that I have had to move into the chamber in which my sister died, and to sleep in the very bed in which she slept. Imagine, then, my thrill of terror when last night, as I lay awake, thinking over her terrible fate, I suddenly heard in the silence of the night the low whistle which had been the herald of her own death. I sprang up and lit the lamp, but nothing was to be seen in the room. I was too shaken to go to bed again, however, so I dressed, and as soon as it was daylight I slipped down, got a dog-cart at the Crown Inn, which is opposite, and drove to Leatherhead, from whence I have come on this morning with the one object of seeing you and asking your advice.”
“You have done wisely,” said my friend. “But have you told me all?”
“Yes, all.”
“Miss Roylott, you have not. You are screening your stepfather.”
“Why, what do you mean?”
For answer Holmes pushed back the frill of black lace which fringed the hand that lay upon our visitor’s knee. Five little livid spots, the marks of four fingers and a thumb, were printed upon the white wrist.
“You have been cruelly used,” said Holmes.
The lady coloured deeply and covered over her injured wrist. “He is a hard man,” she said, “and perhaps he hardly knows his own strength.”
There was a long silence, during which Holmes leaned his chin upon his hands and stared into the crackling fire.
“This is a very deep business,” he said at last. “There are a thousand details which I should desire to know before I decide upon our course of action. Yet we have not a moment to lose. If we were to come to Stoke Moran to-day, would it be possible for us to see over these rooms without the knowledge of your stepfather?”
“As it happens, he spoke of coming into town to-day upon some most important business. It is probable that he will be away all day, and that there would be nothing to disturb you. We have a housekeeper now, but she is old and foolish, and I could easily get her out of the way.”
“Excellent. You are not averse to this trip, Watson?”
“By no means.”
“Then we shall both come. What are you going to do yourself?”
“I have one or two things which I would wish to do now that I am in town. But I shall return by the twelve o’clock train, so as to be there in time for your coming.”
“And you may expect us early in the afternoon. I have myself some small business matters to attend to. Will you not wait and breakfast?”
“No, I must go. My heart is lightened already since I have confided my trouble to you. I shall look forward to seeing you again this afternoon.” She dropped her thick black veil over her face and glided from the room.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“These are very deep waters,” said he; “pray go on with your narrative.”

Miss Helen Stoner leaned forward and pressed her hands together, while her beautiful eyes, which had a peculiarly soft and sympathetic expression, filled with tears. “You are right, Mr. Holmes,” she said. “I have been trying to be brave, but I am so frightened. I have come to you because I know that no one else can help me.”

“Your case is certainly a very strange one,” said Holmes. “You have already told me that your sister died under very mysterious circumstances, and that you have reason to believe that her death was not natural. You have also told me of the peculiar whistle which you heard on the night of her death, and which you have heard again.”

“Yes,” said Miss Stoner, “and I heard it again last night. I have been so afraid ever since I heard it the first time. I have tried to be brave, but I cannot sleep in my own room. I have moved into my sister’s old room, and I have not slept at all.”

“Your stepfather, Dr. Roylott, has not interfered with you?”

“No, he has not. He has been very kind to me, I think. He has not objected to my engagement to Mr. Armitage, and he has not said anything about my moving into my sister’s room. But I have a feeling that he is watching me, and that he is waiting for something to happen.”

“Your feeling is a very natural one,” said Holmes. “But I must ask you a question. Have you told me everything that has happened to you?”

Miss Stoner hesitated for a moment. “I think I have,” she said. “I have told you everything that I know.”

“Then I must ask you to look at this,” said Holmes, and he held out his hand. Miss Stoner looked at it, and then gave a cry of horror. “Where did you get these?” she asked.

“These are the marks of a four-fingered grip,” said Holmes. “They are on your wrist. I have seen them before. They are the marks of a man who has a very strong grip, and who is not afraid to use it.”

Miss Stoner looked at her wrist, and then at Holmes. “I do not know how they got there,” she said. “I do not remember anything about them. I think I must have been dreaming.”

“Or perhaps you were not dreaming,” said Holmes. “Perhaps you were being held by a man who was very angry with you. I think that Dr. Roylott is a very dangerous man, and that he is not to be trusted.”

Miss Stoner gave a shudder. “I do not like to speak ill of him,” she said. “He has been very kind to me, I think. But I do not like to be alone with him. He is very strong, and I think he does not know his own strength.”

“Then you must be very careful,” said Holmes. “I think that we must go to Stoke Moran and see for ourselves what is happening there. I think that we must see the rooms where your sister died, and where you now sleep.”

“I can arrange for that,” said Miss Stoner. “My stepfather is going to town this morning, and I can manage the housekeeper. I can get you into the house without any difficulty.”

“Then we will go,” said Holmes. “I think that we must go at once. I have a feeling that we are on the edge of something very strange and very dangerous.”

Miss Stoner looked at him with a mixture of fear and hope. “I am so glad that you are coming,” she said. “I have been so afraid, and I have not known what to do. I have been so afraid that I would be the next to die.”

“Then you must not be afraid any longer,” said Holmes. “I will do everything that I can to help you. I will not let anything happen to you.”

Miss Stoner gave a sigh of relief. “I feel better already,” she said. “I feel as if I have been carrying a great weight, and now it is gone.”

“Then you must go and get some rest,” said Holmes. “You have had a long journey, and you must be tired. I will not keep you any longer.”

Miss Stoner rose from her chair and gave a grateful glance at both Holmes and Dr. Watson. “Thank you both,” she said. “I will go and get some rest, and I will return to Stoke Moran by midday. I will meet you there.”

“Very well,” said Holmes. “We will be there by midday. I will not let you down.”

Miss Stoner gave a final glance at Holmes and then left the room, her face still pale with fear, but with a glimmer of hope in her eyes.

events.title: Initial Theories and Dr. Roylott's Confrontation
detailed_summary: Holmes asks Watson for his assessment; Watson finds the case dark and sinister.
Holmes acknowledges its nature but questions how Julia could have met her end alone if the room was secured.
He points out the inconsistencies: the nocturnal whistles and Julia's dying words.
Holmes speculates a possible connection between the whistles, the gipsies, Roylott's motive to prevent the marriage, the 'band' reference, and the metallic clang (perhaps a falling shutter bar).
Both acknowledge significant objections to this theory, necessitating the visit to Stoke Moran.
Suddenly, the door bursts open, revealing a huge, imposing man identified as Dr. Grimesby Roylott.
Roylott aggressively demands to know which one is Holmes and confirms his stepdaughter visited.
Holmes attempts polite deflection, but Roylott furiously repeats his demand.
Roylott threatens Holmes, calling him a meddler and busybody.
To demonstrate his strength and menace, Roylott seizes the fireplace poker and bends it into a curve.
He warns Holmes to stay out of his affairs and grip, then throws the poker down and storms out.
Holmes remarks on Roylott's 'amiable' nature and, picking up the poker, effortlessly straightens it again.
He finds Roylott's confounding him with official detectives amusing and notes the incident adds zest to the case, though he worries for Helen's safety.
Holmes suggests breakfast before he heads out for research.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “And what do you think of it all, Watson?” asked Sherlock Holmes, leaning back in his chair.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And now, Watson, we shall order breakfast, and afterwards I shall walk down to Doctors’ Commons, where I hope to get some data which may help us in this matter.”

events.text_segment:
“And what do you think of it all, Watson?” asked Sherlock Holmes, leaning back in his chair.
“It seems to me to be a most dark and sinister business.”
“Dark enough and sinister enough.”
“Yet if the lady is correct in saying that the flooring and walls are sound, and that the door, window, and chimney are impassable, then her sister must have been undoubtedly alone when she met her mysterious end.”
“What becomes, then, of these nocturnal whistles, and what of the very peculiar words of the dying woman?”
“I cannot think.”
“When you combine the ideas of whistles at night, the presence of a band of gipsies who are on intimate terms with this old doctor, the fact that we have every reason to believe that the doctor has an interest in preventing his stepdaughter’s marriage, the dying allusion to a band, and, finally, the fact that Miss Helen Stoner heard a metallic clang, which might have been caused by one of those metal bars that secured the shutters falling back into its place, I think that there is good ground to think that the mystery may be cleared along those lines.”
“But what, then, did the gipsies do?”
“I cannot imagine.”
“I see many objections to any such theory.”
“And so do I. It is precisely for that reason that we are going to Stoke Moran this day. I want to see whether the objections are fatal, or if they may be explained away. But what in the name of the devil!”
The ejaculation had been drawn from my companion by the fact that our door had been suddenly dashed open, and that a huge man had framed himself in the aperture. His costume was a peculiar mixture of the professional and of the agricultural, having a black top-hat, a long frock-coat, and a pair of high gaiters, with a hunting-crop swinging in his hand. So tall was he that his hat actually brushed the cross bar of the doorway, and his breadth seemed to span it across from side to side. A large face, seared with a thousand wrinkles, burned yellow with the sun, and marked with every evil passion, was turned from one to the other of us, while his deep-set, bile-shot eyes, and his high, thin, fleshless nose, gave him somewhat the resemblance to a fierce old bird of prey.
“Which of you is Holmes?” asked this apparition.
“My name, sir; but you have the advantage of me,” said my companion quietly.
“I am Dr. Grimesby Roylott, of Stoke Moran.”
“Indeed, Doctor,” said Holmes blandly. “Pray take a seat.”
“I will do nothing of the kind. My stepdaughter has been here. I have traced her. What has she been saying to you?”
“It is a little cold for the time of the year,” said Holmes.
“What has she been saying to you?” screamed the old man furiously.
“But I have heard that the crocuses promise well,” continued my companion imperturbably.
“Ha! You put me off, do you?” said our new visitor, taking a step forward and shaking his hunting-crop. “I know you, you scoundrel! I have heard of you before. You are Holmes, the meddler.”
My friend smiled.
“Holmes, the busybody!”
His smile broadened.
“Holmes, the Scotland Yard Jack-in-office!”
Holmes chuckled heartily. “Your conversation is most entertaining,” said he. “When you go out close the door, for there is a decided draught.”
“I will go when I have had my say. Don’t you dare to meddle with my affairs. I know that Miss Stoner has been here. I traced her! I am a dangerous man to fall foul of! See here.” He stepped swiftly forward, seized the poker, and bent it into a curve with his huge brown hands.
“See that you keep yourself out of my grip,” he snarled, and hurling the twisted poker into the fireplace he strode out of the room.
“He seems a very amiable person,” said Holmes, laughing. “I am not quite so bulky, but if he had remained I might have shown him that my grip was not much more feeble than his own.” As he spoke he picked up the steel poker and, with a sudden effort, straightened it out again.
“Fancy his having the insolence to confound me with the official detective force! This incident gives zest to our investigation, however, and I only trust that our little friend will not suffer from her imprudence in allowing this brute to trace her. And now, Watson, we shall order breakfast, and afterwards I shall walk down to Doctors’ Commons, where I hope to get some data which may help us in this matter.”
