events.text_segment:
‘Hullo!’ I yelled. ‘Hullo! Colonel! Let me out!’
“And then suddenly in the silence I heard a sound which sent my heart into my mouth. It was the clank of the levers and the swish of the leaking cylinder. He had set the engine at work. The lamp still stood upon the floor where I had placed it when examining the trough. By its light I saw that the black ceiling was coming down upon me, slowly, jerkily, but, as none knew better than myself, with a force which must within a minute grind me to a shapeless pulp. I threw myself, screaming, against the door, and dragged with my nails at the lock. I implored the colonel to let me out, but the remorseless clanking of the levers drowned my cries. The ceiling was only a foot or two above my head, and with my hand upraised I could feel its hard, rough surface. Then it flashed through my mind that the pain of my death would depend very much upon the position in which I met it. If I lay on my face the weight would come upon my spine, and I shuddered to think of that dreadful snap. Easier the other way, perhaps; and yet, had I the nerve to lie and look up at that deadly black shadow wavering down upon me? Already I was unable to stand erect, when my eye caught something which brought a gush of hope back to my heart.
“I have said that though the floor and ceiling were of iron, the walls were of wood. As I gave a last hurried glance around, I saw a thin line of yellow light between two of the boards, which broadened and broadened as a small panel was pushed backward. For an instant I could hardly believe that here was indeed a door which led away from death. The next instant I threw myself through, and lay half-fainting upon the other side. The panel had closed again behind me, but the crash of the lamp, and a few moments afterwards the clang of the two slabs of metal, told me how narrow had been my escape.
“I was recalled to myself by a frantic plucking at my wrist, and I found myself lying upon the stone floor of a narrow corridor, while a woman bent over me and tugged at me with her left hand, while she held a candle in her right. It was the same good friend whose warning I had so foolishly rejected.
“‘Come! come!’ she cried breathlessly. ‘They will be here in a moment. They will see that you are not there. Oh, do not waste the so-precious time, but come!’
“This time, at least, I did not scorn her advice. I staggered to my feet and ran with her along the corridor and down a winding stair. The latter led to another broad passage, and just as we reached it we heard the sound of running feet and the shouting of two voices, one answering the other from the floor on which we were and from the one beneath. My guide stopped and looked about her like one who is at her wit’s end. Then she threw open a door which led into a bedroom, through the window of which the moon was shining brightly.
“‘It is your only chance,’ said she. ‘It is high, but it may be that you can jump it.’
“As she spoke a light sprang into view at the further end of the passage, and I saw the lean figure of Colonel Lysander Stark rushing forward with a lantern in one hand and a weapon like a butcher’s cleaver in the other. I rushed across the bedroom, flung open the window, and looked out. How quiet and sweet and wholesome the garden looked in the moonlight, and it could not be more than thirty feet down. I clambered out upon the sill, but I hesitated to jump until I should have heard what passed between my saviour and the ruffian who pursued me. If she were ill-used, then at any risks I was determined to go back to her assistance. The thought had hardly flashed through my mind before he was at the door, pushing his way past her; but she threw her arms round him and tried to hold him back.
“‘Fritz! Fritz!’ she cried in English, ‘remember your promise after the last time. You said it should not be again. He will be silent! Oh, he will be silent!’
“‘You are mad, Elise!’ he shouted, struggling to break away from her. ‘You will be the ruin of us. He has seen too much. Let me pass, I say!’ He dashed her to one side, and, rushing to the window, cut at me with his heavy weapon. I had let myself go, and was hanging by the hands to the sill, when his blow fell. I was conscious of a dull pain, my grip loosened, and I fell into the garden below.
“I was shaken but not hurt by the fall; so I picked myself up and rushed off among the bushes as hard as I could run, for I understood that I was far from being out of danger yet. Suddenly, however, as I ran, a deadly dizziness and sickness came over me. I glanced down at my hand, which was throbbing painfully, and then, for the first time, saw that my thumb had been cut off and that the blood was pouring from my wound. I endeavoured to tie my handkerchief round it, but there came a sudden buzzing in my ears, and next moment I fell in a dead faint among the rose-bushes.

**Chapter IX. THE ADVENTURE OF THE ENGINEER’S THUMB**

“‘Hullo!’ I yelled. ‘Hullo! Colonel! Let me out!’” I shouted, pounding on the door with all the strength I could muster. But the sound of the machine starting up drowned out my cries, a deep, mechanical growl that sent a chill through my spine. I turned, heart hammering, and by the flickering light of the lamp, I saw the ceiling descending slowly, inexorably, like a great iron hand reaching down to crush me.

Screaming, I threw myself against the door, clawing at the lock, pleading for release. But the machine roared louder, and the ceiling came down, forcing me to crouch, my breath coming in ragged gasps. I tried to think—was there a way to die that would be the least painful? I had no time to decide.

Then, a line of light appeared between the wooden wall panels, widening as a small panel slid back. I didn’t hesitate. I threw myself through just as the lamp was crushed and the press slammed shut behind me. I landed hard on the corridor floor, and a woman was there, pulling at my wrist with a candle in her hand.

“Come!” she implored, her voice urgent. “You must run before he finds you!”

This time, I listened. I staggered up and ran with her, our footsteps echoing through the corridors and down the stairs. We heard running feet and voices shouting from different floors. The woman, her face pale with fear, opened a bedroom door where moonlight spilled through the window.

“This is your only chance,” she said, her voice trembling. “Jump!”

A light appeared down the passage—Stark, with a lantern and a cleaver in his hand, was rushing toward us. The woman, Elise, stepped forward and pleaded with him, calling him “Fritz.” “You promised!” she cried. “You promised you wouldn’t do this again!”

Stark’s eyes burned with fury. “He’s seen too much,” he spat, shoving her aside and rushing to the window.

I flung open the window, the cool night air hitting my face. The garden was about thirty feet below, but I hesitated, wanting to make sure Elise was safe. But Stark was on me in an instant, swinging the cleaver.

I felt a dull pain in my hand, then nothing. I lost my grip and fell, tumbling into the garden below. I landed hard, but I was still alive. Shaken, I ran into the bushes, aware of the danger still looming behind me.

Suddenly, dizziness overtook me. I looked at my hand and saw my thumb—gone. Blood was pouring from the wound, and I tried to tie my handkerchief around it, but I fainted among the rose-bushes, the night air thick with the scent of blood and fear.

--- 

**End of Simulated Output**

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
‘Hullo!’ I yelled. ‘Hullo! Colonel! Let me out!’

There was no answer, and I stood for a moment in the darkness, my breath coming fast and my heart hammering in my chest. The stone walls of the cell were cold against my back, and the air was thick with the smell of damp and decay. I had been locked in here for hours, or perhaps days—I had lost all sense of time. My wrists were raw from trying to force the iron bars, and my mind was racing with the possibilities of how I had come to be in this wretched place.

I had been in London for only a few days when I met Colonel Lestrade, a man of some repute in the city's military circles. He had been kind to me, offering me a place to stay and introducing me to his many acquaintances. I had trusted him, as one does when in a strange city and in need of a friend. But now, as I sat in this cell, I could not help but wonder if I had been a fool to place my trust so easily.

The last thing I remembered was a glass of brandy, poured with a friendly hand and offered with a smile. I had drunk it without hesitation, and then... nothing. The next thing I knew, I was here, alone and in the dark.

I tried the door again, pushing against it with all my strength, but it did not budge. I ran my hands along the wall, hoping to find some weakness, some crack, some way out. But the stone was solid, and the only sound was the echo of my own voice in the silence.

I sat down on the cold floor, my back against the wall, and tried to think. Colonel Lestrade had been a man of some means, I knew that much. He had spoken of a family estate in the country, a place of great beauty and history. If I could get to that estate, perhaps I could find some clue as to what was happening to me. But how could I get there from this cell?

I had no idea where I was, but I could hear the sound of horses and the clatter of hooves on stone. There was a road nearby, and perhaps, if I could get to it, I could find someone who would help me. I had no money, no papers, and no friends in this place, but I had my wits, and I was not about to let them fail me now.

I stood up and began to pace, trying to keep my mind sharp. I had to think of a way to escape. I had to find a way to get out of this cell and back to London. I had to find Colonel Lestrade and demand an explanation.

The sound of footsteps echoed in the corridor outside, and I pressed myself against the wall, my heart pounding. The door creaked open, and a figure stepped inside. It was a man, tall and broad-shouldered, with a lantern in his hand. He looked at me for a moment, then said, 'You're awake, then.'

'Of course I'm awake,' I replied, my voice shaking. 'Let me out of this cell at once! I demand to see Colonel Lestrade!'

The man chuckled. 'Colonel Lestrade is not here to see you. He's in London, and he's not coming back.'

'What do you mean?' I asked, my voice rising. 'Where is he? What have you done with him?'

The man stepped closer, his face half in shadow. 'He's not the one you should be worried about,' he said. 'You should be worried about yourself. You're in a lot of trouble, my friend.'

'I don't know what you're talking about,' I said, my voice trembling. 'I've done nothing wrong!'

'You're a fool if you think that,' the man said. 'You've been meddling in things you don't understand. You've been asking questions about the Colonel, about his past, about his family. And now you're paying the price.'

'I was only trying to help!' I said. 'I thought he was a friend!'

'He was a friend,' the man said. 'But he was also a man with secrets. And now those secrets are coming back to haunt him. And you, by association, are in danger.'

I felt a chill run down my spine. 'What secrets?' I asked. 'What are you talking about?'

The man looked at me for a long moment, then said, 'You'll find out soon enough. But for now, you're stuck here. The Colonel has left orders that you are to be kept in this cell until he returns. And he won't be back for a while.'

'You can't do this!' I said, my voice rising. 'I have rights! I demand to see a lawyer!'

The man laughed. 'You're in the country, not London. There are no lawyers here, and no courts. You're at the mercy of the Colonel's men, and they don't take kindly to strangers asking questions.'

I felt a wave of despair wash over me. I was trapped, alone, and with no way to escape. I had to think of something, anything, to get out of this situation. I had to find a way to get back to London and warn the authorities. I had to find a way to clear my name and uncover the truth.

The man turned to leave, but before he did, he said, 'You'll be fed and watered, don't worry. But you'll stay here until the Colonel returns. And when he does, you'll wish you were still in London.'

With that, he closed the door and left me in the darkness once more. I sat on the floor, my mind racing with possibilities. I had to find a way out of this cell, and I had to do it soon. I had to find the truth about Colonel Lestrade and his secrets, and I had to do it before it was too late.

events.title: Awakening, Return to London, and Holmes's Initial Deductions
detailed_summary: Hatherley awakens at dawn, unsure how long he was unconscious.
His clothes are dew-soaked, his sleeve bloody; the pain reminds him of the night's events.
He springs up, expecting danger, but finds himself near the road by a hedge, with no house or garden in sight.
Nearby is the Eyford station building, making the night seem like a dream, except for his wound.
Dazed, he goes to the station and learns a train to Reading is due in an hour.
He speaks to the same porter from the previous night, who denies ever hearing of Colonel Lysander Stark or seeing a carriage waiting for Hatherley.
The nearest police station is three miles away, too far in his weakened state.
He decides to report to the police upon reaching London.
Arriving just after 6 AM, he first seeks medical attention (from Watson), then is brought to Baker Street.
He concludes his narrative, placing the case in Holmes's hands.
After a silence, Holmes retrieves a scrapbook and reads an advertisement from a year prior about a missing hydraulic engineer, Jeremiah Hayling, aged 26.
Holmes surmises this was the last time Stark needed his machine repaired.
Hatherley exclaims this explains the woman's warning about 'the last time'.
Holmes confirms this, characterizing the Colonel as ruthless and determined to eliminate witnesses.

events.text_segment:
“How long I remained unconscious I cannot tell. It must have been a very long time, for the moon had sunk, and a bright morning was breaking when I came to myself. My clothes were all sodden with dew, and my coat-sleeve was drenched with blood from my wounded thumb. The smarting of it recalled in an instant all the particulars of my night’s adventure, and I sprang to my feet with the feeling that I might hardly yet be safe from my pursuers. But to my astonishment, when I came to look round me, neither house nor garden were to be seen. I had been lying in an angle of the hedge close by the high road, and just a little lower down was a long building, which proved, upon my approaching it, to be the very station at which I had arrived upon the previous night. Were it not for the ugly wound upon my hand, all that had passed during those dreadful hours might have been an evil dream.
“Half dazed, I went into the station and asked about the morning train. There would be one to Reading in less than an hour. The same porter was on duty, I found, as had been there when I arrived. I inquired of him whether he had ever heard of Colonel Lysander Stark. The name was strange to him. Had he observed a carriage the night before waiting for me? No, he had not. Was there a police-station anywhere near? There was one about three miles off.
“It was too far for me to go, weak and ill as I was. I determined to wait until I got back to town before telling my story to the police. It was a little past six when I arrived, so I went first to have my wound dressed, and then the doctor was kind enough to bring me along here. I put the case into your hands and shall do exactly what you advise.”
We both sat in silence for some little time after listening to this extraordinary narrative. Then Sherlock Holmes pulled down from the shelf one of the ponderous commonplace books in which he placed his cuttings.
“Here is an advertisement which will interest you,” said he. “It appeared in all the papers about a year ago. Listen to this: ‘Lost, on the 9th inst., Mr. Jeremiah Hayling, aged twenty-six, a hydraulic engineer. Left his lodgings at ten o’clock at night, and has not been heard of since. Was dressed in,’ etc., etc. Ha! That represents the last time that the colonel needed to have his machine overhauled, I fancy.”
“Good heavens!” cried my patient. “Then that explains what the girl said.”
“Undoubtedly. It is quite clear that the colonel was a cool and desperate man, who was absolutely determined that nothing should stand in the way of his little game, like those out-and-out pirates who will leave no survivor from a captured ship.

**Chapter IX. THE ADVENTURE OF THE ENGINEER’S THUMB**

*"How long I remained unconscious I cannot tell. When I awoke, the dawn was breaking, and the air was heavy with the scent of dew. My clothes were soaked, and my sleeve was stained with blood. The pain in my hand reminded me of the night's events, though the details were still hazy. I sprang to my feet, expecting to see danger looming, but the world around me was quiet and still. I was near the road, by a low hedge, with no house or garden in sight. Only the distant silhouette of the Eyford station building stood out against the morning mist. It all seemed like a dream, except for the wound on my hand. Dazed and uncertain, I made my way to the station, where a train to Reading was due in an hour. I approached the porter, the same man I had spoken to the night before. He looked at me with polite confusion. 'Colonel Lysander Stark?' he repeated. 'No, I don't recall hearing that name. And I've certainly never seen a carriage waiting for you.' The nearest police station was three miles away, too far for me in my weakened state. I resolved to report the matter once I reached London. Arriving just after six in the morning, I first sought medical attention from Dr. Watson, who examined my hand and recommended rest. Then, I was brought to Baker Street, where I placed the case in the hands of Sherlock Holmes. After a long silence, Holmes retrieved a scrapbook and read aloud an advertisement from a year prior, about a missing hydraulic engineer named Jeremiah Hayling, aged twenty-six. 'This,' he said, 'was the last time Colonel Stark needed his machine repaired.' Hatherley's eyes widened. 'That explains the woman's warning,' he said. 'The last time.' Holmes nodded. 'A man of ruthless determination, that Colonel. He leaves no witnesses behind.'*"

---

**Notes on the Output:**

- The output is a coherent and stylistically appropriate continuation of the narrative, aligning with the tone and structure of a Sherlock Holmes story.
- It includes all the key elements from the `detailed_summary` and introduces the characters in a natural way.
- The `opening_line` is preserved and used to begin the passage.
- The chapter title is reflected in the content, with a focus on the mystery and the engineer's injury.
- The dialogue and narration are consistent with the original Sherlock Holmes canon.

**Revised Literary Segment (Improved Version):**  

**Chapter IX. THE ADVENTURE OF THE ENGINEER’S THUMB**  

*"How long I remained unconscious I cannot tell. When I awoke, the dawn was breaking. My clothes were soaked with dew, and my sleeve was stained with blood. The pain in my hand brought back the night’s events in fragments. I sprang to my feet, expecting to see some lurking danger, but the world was quiet. I stood by a low hedge near the road, with no house or garden in sight—no trace of the scene where I had fallen. Only the Eyford station building, its windows glinting in the morning light, confirmed that this was the same place I had passed through the night before. It all seemed like a dream, save for the wound on my hand. Dazed, I made my way to the station, where a train to Reading was due in an hour. I approached the porter, the same man I had spoken to the previous night. 'Colonel Lysander Stark?' he repeated, frowning. 'I don’t recall hearing that name. And I’ve certainly never seen a carriage waiting for you.' I pressed further: Had anyone arrived in a private carriage? Had the colonel’s name been mentioned? The porter shook his head. 'Nothing of the sort. The nearest police station is three miles away—too far for you in your condition.' I resolved to report the matter once I reached London. Arriving just after six in the morning, I first sought medical attention from Dr. Watson, who examined my hand and recommended rest. Then, I was brought to Baker Street, where I placed the case in the hands of Sherlock Holmes. 'I leave it entirely to you,' I said. Holmes nodded, silent for a moment. Then, he retrieved a scrapbook and read aloud an advertisement from a year prior: 'Lost: Jeremiah Hayling, hydraulic engineer, aged twenty-six. Last seen in London, April 1887.' He looked up. 'This was the last time Colonel Stark needed his machine repaired,' he said. My breath caught. 'That explains the woman’s warning,' I exclaimed. 'The last time.' Holmes’s eyes darkened. 'A man of ruthless determination, that Colonel. He leaves no witnesses behind.'*  

---

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: How long I remained unconscious I cannot tell. When I came to myself, I found that I was lying on the floor of the room, and that the door was locked from the outside. The candle had burned low, and the room was in semi-darkness. I staggered to my feet, my head reeling, and tried to collect my thoughts. I had been attacked, that much was certain, but by whom and for what reason I could not yet determine. My first instinct was to look for signs of struggle, but the room was in a state of disorder, as if someone had searched it in haste. Papers were scattered across the table, and the drawers of the writing desk had been flung open. I moved cautiously to the window, hoping to see some clue in the street below, but the night was dark and silent. I could hear the distant sound of a carriage, but nothing more. I was alone, and I had no idea how long I had been there. I tried the door again, but it was still locked. I was beginning to feel the first pangs of fear when I noticed something strange on the table. It was a small, folded piece of paper, and it bore my name in a hand that I did not recognize. I opened it carefully, and my heart sank as I read the message inside. It was a warning, written in a hurried scrawl: 'Leave this case at once, or you will regret it.' I had no doubt that it was a threat, and I could not ignore it. I had been drawn into something far more dangerous than I had anticipated, and I needed help. I thought of Sherlock Holmes, and I knew that I had no choice but to seek him out. I had heard of his reputation, and I had no doubt that he would be able to help me. I had to get out of this room, and I had to do it quickly. I searched the room again, hoping to find some way to escape, but there was no other door, and the window was too high to reach from the inside. I was trapped, and I had no idea how long I had been there. I sat down on the floor, trying to think clearly, when I heard a sound at the door. It was a soft click, and then the door opened slightly. I could see a shadow moving in the corridor, and I knew that I was not alone. I had to act quickly. I grabbed the candle and held it high, hoping to see who it was. The door opened fully, and a figure stepped into the room. It was a man, tall and thin, with a face that I did not recognize. He looked at me for a moment, then turned and fled down the corridor. I ran after him, but he was too fast. I could hear his footsteps fading into the distance. I was alone again, and I had no idea what to do next. I returned to the room and sat down, my mind racing. I had to find a way out, and I had to find it soon. I had no idea what was going on, but I knew that I was in danger. I had to get to Sherlock Holmes, and I had to do it quickly.

events.title: Planning the Investigation and Journey to Eyford
detailed_summary: Declaring time is critical, Holmes suggests going immediately to Scotland Yard before heading to Eyford, if Hatherley feels up to it.
Three hours later, Holmes, Hatherley, Watson, Inspector Bradstreet, and a plain-clothes officer are on a train from Reading to Eyford.
Bradstreet uses a map and compasses to draw a ten-mile radius circle around Eyford, assuming the house lies near that line based on Hatherley's estimate.
Hatherley clarifies it was an hour's drive; Bradstreet questions if Hatherley was brought back twelve miles while unconscious, which Hatherley believes must have happened.
Watson wonders why they spared Hatherley; Hatherley doubts Stark was softened by the woman's pleas due to his inexorable face.
Bradstreet is confident they will uncover the details.
When Bradstreet asks where on the circle the house might be, Holmes states he can pinpoint it.
The others offer differing opinions: Bradstreet (south), Hatherley (east), the plain-clothes man (west), and Watson (north), each providing a reason.
Holmes declares they are all wrong and places his finger on the center of the circle – Eyford itself.
Hatherley protests about the twelve-mile drive.
Holmes explains it was likely six miles out and six miles back, evidenced by the horse being fresh when Hatherley got in, which wouldn't be possible after twelve miles on heavy roads.
Bradstreet accepts this as a plausible ruse.
Holmes states the gang are large-scale coiners (counterfeiters), using the press to make amalgam for fake silver coins.
Bradstreet confirms they knew a clever gang was operating, traced them to Reading, but lost the trail. He believes they now have them trapped.

events.text_segment:
Well, every moment now is precious, so if you feel equal to it we shall go down to Scotland Yard at once as a preliminary to starting for Eyford.”
Some three hours or so afterwards we were all in the train together, bound from Reading to the little Berkshire village. There were Sherlock Holmes, the hydraulic engineer, Inspector Bradstreet, of Scotland Yard, a plain-clothes man, and myself. Bradstreet had spread an ordnance map of the county out upon the seat and was busy with his compasses drawing a circle with Eyford for its centre.
“There you are,” said he. “That circle is drawn at a radius of ten miles from the village. The place we want must be somewhere near that line. You said ten miles, I think, sir.”
“It was an hour’s good drive.”
“And you think that they brought you back all that way when you were unconscious?”
“They must have done so. I have a confused memory, too, of having been lifted and conveyed somewhere.”
“What I cannot understand,” said I, “is why they should have spared you when they found you lying fainting in the garden. Perhaps the villain was softened by the woman’s entreaties.”
“I hardly think that likely. I never saw a more inexorable face in my life.”
“Oh, we shall soon clear up all that,” said Bradstreet. “Well, I have drawn my circle, and I only wish I knew at what point upon it the folk that we are in search of are to be found.”
“I think I could lay my finger on it,” said Holmes quietly.
“Really, now!” cried the inspector, “you have formed your opinion! Come, now, we shall see who agrees with you. I say it is south, for the country is more deserted there.”
“And I say east,” said my patient.
“I am for west,” remarked the plain-clothes man. “There are several quiet little villages up there.”
“And I am for north,” said I, “because there are no hills there, and our friend says that he did not notice the carriage go up any.”
“Come,” cried the inspector, laughing; “it’s a very pretty diversity of opinion. We have boxed the compass among us. Who do you give your casting vote to?”
“You are all wrong.”
“But we can’t all be.”
“Oh, yes, you can. This is my point.” He placed his finger in the centre of the circle. “This is where we shall find them.”
“But the twelve-mile drive?” gasped Hatherley.
“Six out and six back. Nothing simpler. You say yourself that the horse was fresh and glossy when you got in. How could it be that if it had gone twelve miles over heavy roads?”
“Indeed, it is a likely ruse enough,” observed Bradstreet thoughtfully. “Of course there can be no doubt as to the nature of this gang.”
“None at all,” said Holmes. “They are coiners on a large scale, and have used the machine to form the amalgam which has taken the place of silver.”
“We have known for some time that a clever gang was at work,” said the inspector. “They have been turning out half-crowns by the thousand. We even traced them as far as Reading, but could get no farther, for they had covered their traces in a way that showed that they were very old hands. But now, thanks to this lucky chance, I think that we have got them right enough.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Well, every moment now is precious, so if you feel equal to it we shall go down to Scotland Yard at once as a preliminary to starting for Eyford.”

Victor Hatherley, pale and shaken, nodded his assent. Within three hours we were all on the train from Reading to Eyford, Holmes, myself, Inspector Bradstreet, and a plain-clothes officer, with Hatherley between us. The inspector had brought with him a map and compasses, and with the aid of the latter he drew a circle with Eyford as a centre and a radius of ten miles. “The house must lie somewhere near this line,” said he, tapping the circumference with his finger. “You said it was an hour’s drive from the station?”

“It was,” said Hatherley.

“Then you were carried twelve miles while you were unconscious?”

“I suppose so,” said Hatherley, with a shudder.

“I was wondering,” I remarked, “why they should have spared you?”

“They may have thought me of no use to them,” he answered. “But I don’t think it was the woman’s pleading that saved me. Stark has the face of a man who is not softened by any appeal.”

“Ah, we shall see,” said Bradstreet. “We shall see. I have no doubt that we shall soon have the whole story.”

He looked round the circle which he had drawn. “Now, where on this line do you think the house may be?” he asked.

Holmes, with a quiet smile, placed his finger in the very centre of the circle. “It is here,” said he.

There was a murmur of dissent. “South,” said Bradstreet. “East,” said Hatherley. “West,” said the plain-clothes man. “North,” said I, each of us giving our reasons.

Holmes shook his head. “You are all wrong,” said he. “It is in Eyford itself.”

Hatherley started up. “But I was twelve miles from the town.”

“Or six miles out and six miles back,” said Holmes. “You remember that the horse was fresh when you got into the trap. Could he have gone twelve miles on heavy roads without showing signs of fatigue?”

The inspector nodded. “That is a point,” said he. “It is a ruse, no doubt. They took you out and brought you back, so as to mislead us.”

Holmes leaned back in his seat. “You are right, Bradstreet. It is a gang of large-scale coiners. They are using the press to make amalgam for the silver coins. You have been on their track, I understand?”

“We have,” said the inspector. “We knew of a clever gang working in the Reading district, but we lost the trail. Now, I think we have them.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Well, every moment now is precious, so if you feel equal to it we shall go down to Scotland Yard at once as a preliminary to starting for Eyford.”

Holmes was already on his feet, his keen eyes alight with the fire of a new case. I had seen that look before, and I knew that nothing would deter him from his course. I rose quickly, for I had long since learned that to resist Holmes was to waste breath. “I am quite equal to it,” I said, adjusting my coat. “But pray, what is this mystery that has so gripped you?”

He did not answer at once, but instead took up his hat and gloves with the precision of a man who had made up his mind. “You will know all in good time, Watson,” he said, with a smile that was both enigmatic and reassuring. “But for now, let us make haste. The game is afoot.”

We hailed a hansom and set off for Scotland Yard, the city streets passing in a blur as the carriage rattled along. Holmes sat in silence, his fingers steepled beneath his chin, his mind clearly elsewhere. I watched him for a moment, noting the furrowed brow and the distant gaze. Whatever had brought him to this state of urgency, it was no ordinary case.

At Scotland Yard, we were met by Inspector Lestrade, a man I had known for years and who, though not Holmes’s equal in intellect, was a decent and capable officer. “Ah, Mr. Holmes,” he said, his face a mixture of surprise and relief. “I was just about to send for you. This case is most perplexing.”

Holmes stepped forward, his presence commanding immediate attention. “And what, pray, is the nature of the perplexity?” he asked, his voice calm but firm.

Lestrade led us into a small room where a map of the surrounding countryside was spread across a table. “A murder has been committed at a country estate near Eyford,” he said. “The victim is a man named Sir Reginald Ashcombe, a wealthy landowner. The body was found in his study, shot through the heart. The room was locked from the inside, and there are no signs of forced entry. The only clue we have is a single footprint in the dust near the window.”

Holmes leaned over the map, his eyes scanning the details with the precision of a surgeon. “And the time of death?” he asked.

“Approximately two hours ago,” Lestrade replied. “The servants found the body just after dinner.”

Holmes nodded. “Then we must not delay. The sooner we reach the scene, the better. Watson, I think you will find this case most interesting. There are, I suspect, several layers to this mystery, and the truth lies hidden beneath them.”

I could not help but smile. Holmes was in his element, and I was once again to be his companion in the pursuit of justice. We bade farewell to Lestrade and returned to the hansom, the city lights fading behind us as we set off for the country and the unknown that awaited us at Eyford.

events.title: Arrival at Eyford and Discovery of the Fire
detailed_summary: The narrative states the criminals would evade justice.
As the train arrives at Eyford, they see a massive column of smoke rising from nearby trees.
Bradstreet asks the station-master if a house is on fire.
The station-master confirms it's Dr. Becher's house, that the fire started during the night and has worsened.
Hatherley interjects, asking if Dr. Becher is thin, German, with a sharp nose.
The station-master laughs, describing Dr. Becher as a stout Englishman, but mentions he has a foreign patient staying with him who looks thin and unwell.
Before the station-master finishes, the group hastens towards the fire.
From a low hill, they see a large, whitewashed building engulfed in flames, with fire engines struggling to contain it.
Hatherley excitedly identifies the house, the gravel drive, the rose-bushes where he fainted, and the window he jumped from.
Holmes remarks that Hatherley has had his revenge, deducing the fire started when Hatherley's oil lamp was crushed in the press, unnoticed by the gang during the chase.
He advises Hatherley to look for the culprits in the crowd, but expresses doubt, suspecting they have already fled far away.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But the inspector was mistaken, for those criminals were not destined to fall into the hands of justice.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Now keep your eyes open in this crowd for your friends of last night, though I very much fear that they are a good hundred miles off by now.”

events.text_segment:
But the inspector was mistaken, for those criminals were not destined to fall into the hands of justice. As we rolled into Eyford Station we saw a gigantic column of smoke which streamed up from behind a small clump of trees in the neighbourhood and hung like an immense ostrich feather over the landscape.
“A house on fire?” asked Bradstreet as the train steamed off again on its way.
“Yes, sir!” said the station-master.
“When did it break out?”
“I hear that it was during the night, sir, but it has got worse, and the whole place is in a blaze.”
“Whose house is it?”
“Dr. Becher’s.”
“Tell me,” broke in the engineer, “is Dr. Becher a German, very thin, with a long, sharp nose?”
The station-master laughed heartily. “No, sir, Dr. Becher is an Englishman, and there isn’t a man in the parish who has a better-lined waistcoat. But he has a gentleman staying with him, a patient, as I understand, who is a foreigner, and he looks as if a little good Berkshire beef would do him no harm.”
The station-master had not finished his speech before we were all hastening in the direction of the fire. The road topped a low hill, and there was a great widespread whitewashed building in front of us, spouting fire at every chink and window, while in the garden in front three fire-engines were vainly striving to keep the flames under.
“That’s it!” cried Hatherley, in intense excitement. “There is the gravel-drive, and there are the rose-bushes where I lay. That second window is the one that I jumped from.”
“Well, at least,” said Holmes, “you have had your revenge upon them. There can be no question that it was your oil-lamp which, when it was crushed in the press, set fire to the wooden walls, though no doubt they were too excited in the chase after you to observe it at the time. Now keep your eyes open in this crowd for your friends of last night, though I very much fear that they are a good hundred miles off by now.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: But the inspector was mistaken, for those criminals were not destined to fall into the hands of justice. As the train drew up at Eyford station, a great column of black smoke was seen rising from the trees which fringed the river. Inspector Bradstreet, who had been smoking a cigar, held it up as a signal. "Is that the house on fire?" he asked of the station-master. "Yes, sir, it is Dr. Becher's house. The fire began during the night, and it has been getting worse ever since." "Is Dr. Becher a thin man, with a sharp nose, and a German accent?" asked Victor Hatherley eagerly. The station-master laughed. "No, sir, he is a stout Englishman, but he has a foreign patient staying with him who looks very thin and unwell." Before the station-master could finish his sentence, the little party had hurried off towards the fire. From a low hill they saw a large, whitewashed building, with a long line of windows, blazing fiercely. A number of firemen were struggling with the flames, but the wind was against them, and the fire was gaining ground. "That is the house," cried Hatherley, pointing eagerly. "There is the gravel drive, and there are the rose-bushes where I fainted. That is the window from which I jumped." "You have had your revenge, then," said Holmes quietly. "The fire was no accident. When your oil lamp was crushed in the press, the flame must have set the cotton waste alight. The men, in their hurry, never noticed it. They have gone, no doubt, far beyond the reach of the law."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: But the inspector was mistaken, for those criminals were not destined to fall into the hands of justice. They had planned their escape with the precision of a master strategist, and it was Sherlock Holmes himself who had foreseen their every move. The inspector, proud and overconfident, had dismissed Holmes' warnings as mere speculation, but the great detective had seen the pattern in the chaos, the subtle clues that others overlooked. The criminals, a gang of art thieves led by the elusive and cunning Victor Lestrade, had anticipated the police raid and had already vanished into the labyrinthine alleys of London. Holmes, ever the step ahead, had arranged for a decoy to be placed at the scene, a false trail that would lead the inspector and his men in the wrong direction. As the inspector and his officers stormed the warehouse, they found only empty crates and a single, cryptic note: “You are too late, Inspector. The game is over.” Meanwhile, Holmes and Dr. Watson had followed a different path, one that led them to the docks, where the criminals were preparing to flee the country aboard a waiting steamer. Holmes, with his usual flair for dramatic confrontation, confronted Lestrade in the dead of night, the fog rolling in like a shroud. “You have played a clever game, Lestrade,” Holmes said, his voice calm but firm. “But you have underestimated the power of observation and deduction.” A tense standoff followed, but in the end, the criminals were captured, not by the inspector, but by the man who had seen through their every trick. The inspector, humbled and shaken, admitted his mistake and praised Holmes for his brilliance. “You have outwitted them, Mr. Holmes,” he said. “I fear I am no match for your mind.” Holmes merely smiled. “It is not a matter of being a match, Inspector. It is a matter of seeing what others do not.”

events.title: Investigation Aftermath, Escape of Culprits, and Final Reflections
detailed_summary: Holmes's prediction proves correct; the woman, the German (Stark/'Fritz'), and the Englishman (Ferguson) vanish without a trace.
A peasant saw a cart with people and bulky boxes heading towards Reading early that morning, but the trail ended there, beyond even Holmes's ability to follow.
Firefighters were baffled by the house's internal setup and disturbed to find a freshly severed human thumb on a second-floor window-sill.
By sunset, the fire was subdued, but the house was ruined, leaving only twisted metal remnants of the machinery.
Large quantities of nickel and tin (counterfeiting materials) were found in an outhouse, but no coins, likely removed in the bulky boxes.

The mystery of Hatherley's transport from the garden to the roadside was solved by footprints in soft earth, showing two carriers: one with small feet (the woman), one with large feet (likely Ferguson).
It's surmised that Ferguson, less ruthless than Stark, helped the woman move the unconscious Hatherley to safety.
Returning to London, Hatherley laments losing his thumb and the fifty-guinea fee, gaining nothing.
Holmes counters that he gained 'experience,' which, when recounted, will make him famously good company for life.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: And Holmes’ fears came to be realised, for from that day to this no word has ever been heard either of the beautiful woman, the sinister German, or the morose Englishman.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Experience,” said Holmes, laughing. “Indirectly it may be of value, you know; you have only to put it into words to gain the reputation of being excellent company for the remainder of your existence.”

events.text_segment:
And Holmes’ fears came to be realised, for from that day to this no word has ever been heard either of the beautiful woman, the sinister German, or the morose Englishman. Early that morning a peasant had met a cart containing several people and some very bulky boxes driving rapidly in the direction of Reading, but there all traces of the fugitives disappeared, and even Holmes’ ingenuity failed ever to discover the least clue as to their whereabouts.
The firemen had been much perturbed at the strange arrangements which they had found within, and still more so by discovering a newly severed human thumb upon a window-sill of the second floor. About sunset, however, their efforts were at last successful, and they subdued the flames, but not before the roof had fallen in, and the whole place been reduced to such absolute ruin that, save some twisted cylinders and iron piping, not a trace remained of the machinery which had cost our unfortunate acquaintance so dearly. Large masses of nickel and of tin were discovered stored in an out-house, but no coins were to be found, which may have explained the presence of those bulky boxes which have been already referred to.
How our hydraulic engineer had been conveyed from the garden to the spot where he recovered his senses might have remained forever a mystery were it not for the soft mould, which told us a very plain tale. He had evidently been carried down by two persons, one of whom had remarkably small feet and the other unusually large ones. On the whole, it was most probable that the silent Englishman, being less bold or less murderous than his companion, had assisted the woman to bear the unconscious man out of the way of danger.
“Well,” said our engineer ruefully as we took our seats to return once more to London, “it has been a pretty business for me! I have lost my thumb and I have lost a fifty-guinea fee, and what have I gained?”
“Experience,” said Holmes, laughing. “Indirectly it may be of value, you know; you have only to put it into words to gain the reputation of being excellent company for the remainder of your existence.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: And Holmes’ fears came to be realised, for from that day to this no word has ever been heard either of the beautiful woman, the sinister German, or the morose Englishman. The only clue which remained was the thumb, which had been found upon the window-sill, and which had been preserved by the police. It was a curious fact that the thumb had been cut off at the first joint, and that the wound was clean and fresh. The firemen, who had been called in to assist at the suppression of the flames, were much disturbed by the discovery, and one of them, a young man named Wilson, declared that he had seen the woman in the crowd, and that she had looked at him with a face of triumph. But this, of course, was pure fancy, and no evidence could be drawn from it. The house was a complete ruin, and the only thing which remained of the machinery was a heap of twisted metal. In the outhouse, however, a quantity of nickel and tin had been found, which were clearly the materials for the manufacture of coin. There were no coins, however, and it was evident that they had been removed in the boxes which had been seen in the cart. The mystery of how Hatherley had been carried from the garden to the roadside was solved by the footprints in the soft earth. There were two sets of prints, one of small feet and one of large. The small feet were those of the woman, and the large feet were those of the Englishman. It was evident that the Englishman had helped the woman to carry the unconscious Hatherley to safety. When Hatherley returned to London, he was a changed man. He had lost his thumb and the fifty-guinea fee, and he had gained nothing. But Holmes, who had a keen eye for the value of experience, pointed out that he had gained something which was of more value than money. "You have gained a story," said he, "and a story which will make you famous in your own circle. When you tell it, you will be the cynosure of all eyes, and men will say, 'There goes the man who had his thumb cut off by a woman in Reading.'" Hatherley smiled faintly, and I saw that he was not altogether displeased at the thought.

1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion invents a character (a fireman named Wilson) and an imagined scene involving the woman in the crowd, which are not present in the original passage.
- The ending introduces a new reflection and dialogue about the story making the engineer famous, which is not part of the original conclusion.
- The completion omits the initial report of the cart and the disappearance of the fugitives, which is a key event early in the original.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The completion does not mention the peasant's sighting of the cart with people and boxes heading toward a specific location, nor the subsequent disappearance of the fugitives' trail.
- The detail about the firemen's reaction to the strange arrangements inside the house is missing.
- The process and timing of the fire being subdued, including the mention of sunset and the collapse of the roof, are not included.
- The specific mention of the machinery's remains and the absence of coins, as well as the possible explanation for the boxes, is only partially addressed.
- The reasoning about how the engineer was moved, based on the impressions in the soft ground, is simplified and lacks the original's detail.
- The original's closing exchange between the engineer and Holmes, including the rueful comment and Holmes' response about experience, is replaced with a different invented conversation.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion inaccurately describes the thumb as being preserved by the police and provides invented details about its condition, which are not in the original.
- The sequence of events is altered: the thumb is discussed before the fire and the discovery of the machinery, which does not match the original order.
- The completion attributes the footprints to specific individuals with certainty, whereas the original presents this as a probable deduction.
- The ending misattributes the nature of Holmes' final comment and the engineer's reaction, introducing new reflections and omitting the original's tone and content.

chapters.chapter_title: X. THE ADVENTURE OF THE NOBLE BACHELOR

events.title: Introduction and Holmes Receives a Noble Client
detailed_summary: The narrator, Watson, introduces the now-faded scandal of Lord St. Simon's marriage and abrupt end, hinting at Sherlock Holmes's involvement in clarifying the true events.
Set a few weeks before Watson's own marriage, while still sharing rooms with Holmes, Watson describes a dreary, rainy afternoon spent indoors due to an old war wound.
Watson observes a letter with a noble crest waiting for Holmes, speculating about the correspondent.
Holmes returns, and Watson points out the fancy letter, contrasting it with Holmes's usual, more humble correspondence.
Holmes initially dismisses it as a likely tedious social obligation but upon reading, recognizes it as a professional matter from a high-ranking client, Lord St. Simon.
Holmes confirms the client is Lord St. Simon, whose recent wedding and the bride's disappearance Watson has been following with interest in the newspapers.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Lord St. Simon marriage, and its curious termination, have long ceased to be a subject of interest in those exalted circles in which the unfortunate bridegroom moves.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Oh, yes, with the deepest interest.”

events.text_segment:
The Lord St. Simon marriage, and its curious termination, have long ceased to be a subject of interest in those exalted circles in which the unfortunate bridegroom moves. Fresh scandals have eclipsed it, and their more piquant details have drawn the gossips away from this four-year-old drama. As I have reason to believe, however, that the full facts have never been revealed to the general public, and as my friend Sherlock Holmes had a considerable share in clearing the matter up, I feel that no memoir of him would be complete without some little sketch of this remarkable episode.
It was a few weeks before my own marriage, during the days when I was still sharing rooms with Holmes in Baker Street, that he came home from an afternoon stroll to find a letter on the table waiting for him. I had remained indoors all day, for the weather had taken a sudden turn to rain, with high autumnal winds, and the jezail bullet which I had brought back in one of my limbs as a relic of my Afghan campaign throbbed with dull persistence. With my body in one easy-chair and my legs upon another, I had surrounded myself with a cloud of newspapers until at last, saturated with the news of the day, I tossed them all aside and lay listless, watching the huge crest and monogram upon the envelope upon the table and wondering lazily who my friend’s noble correspondent could be.
“Here is a very fashionable epistle,” I remarked as he entered. “Your morning letters, if I remember right, were from a fish-monger and a tide-waiter.”
“Yes, my correspondence has certainly the charm of variety,” he answered, smiling, “and the humbler are usually the more interesting. This looks like one of those unwelcome social summonses which call upon a man either to be bored or to lie.”
He broke the seal and glanced over the contents.
“Oh, come, it may prove to be something of interest, after all.”
“Not social, then?”
“No, distinctly professional.”
“And from a noble client?”
“One of the highest in England.”
“My dear fellow, I congratulate you.”
“I assure you, Watson, without affectation, that the status of my client is a matter of less moment to me than the interest of his case. It is just possible, however, that that also may not be wanting in this new investigation. You have been reading the papers diligently of late, have you not?”
“It looks like it,” said I ruefully, pointing to a huge bundle in the corner. “I have had nothing else to do.”
“It is fortunate, for you will perhaps be able to post me up. I read nothing except the criminal news and the agony column. The latter is always instructive. But if you have followed recent events so closely you must have read about Lord St. Simon and his wedding?”
“Oh, yes, with the deepest interest.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The Lord St. Simon marriage, and its curious termination, have long ceased to be a subject of interest in those exalted circles in which the unfortunate bridegroom moves. The matter has passed into the category of those scandals which are so common in the higher ranks of society that they are neither commented upon nor remembered. Yet I have always felt that the case was one of those which might have furnished material for my friend’s keen analytical mind, and I have therefore preserved the few notes which I made at the time. It was some weeks before my own marriage, and I was still sharing the rooms in Baker Street with Mr. Sherlock Holmes. The weather was dull and rainy, and I was sitting by the fire with my leg, which was still stiff from my Afghan wound, wrapped in a rug. Holmes was in one of his most abstracted moods, lying upon the sofa, and picking the notes of a waltz from the piano with one finger, while his eyes were fixed vacantly upon the ceiling. I was about to read the paper when I noticed a letter lying upon the table, addressed in a large, bold hand, and bearing the crest of a noble family. 'This is not from one of your usual correspondents,' I remarked, glancing at the envelope. Holmes turned his head with a languid smile. 'No, it is from a client of a higher station,' he said. 'I have received a request to call upon Lord St. Simon, who is desirous of consulting me upon a matter of some importance. I fancy that the newspapers have given you some idea of the nature of the case.'

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The Lord St. Simon marriage, and its curious termination, have long ceased to be a subject of interest in those exalted circles in which the unfortunate bridegroom moves. The name of Lady St. Simon is now spoken only in whispers, and the scandal which once raged in the drawing-rooms of Mayfair has long since died away. Yet there are those who still remember the case, and who recall the singular manner in which the tragedy was brought to light. It was, in fact, the first and only occasion upon which Sherlock Holmes and I were called upon to deal with a matter of such high social consequence.

The affair began with the sudden disappearance of Lady St. Simon, the wife of the nobleman, who had been married for only a few months. The marriage had been one of considerable notoriety, for the lady was the daughter of a wealthy American industrialist, and her dowry had been the subject of much discussion. The groom, Lord St. Simon, was a man of some repute in the House of Lords, but he was known to be somewhat eccentric and given to strange habits. When Lady St. Simon vanished without a trace, the first suspicion fell upon her husband.

The police were called in, and a thorough search of the house was made. Nothing was found to suggest foul play, and the case seemed to be one of a runaway bride. But it was the peculiar circumstances surrounding the disappearance that led to the involvement of Sherlock Holmes. A letter had been discovered in the lady's boudoir, written in a trembling hand and addressed to her father. It spoke of fear, of a terrible secret, and of a nameless horror that had driven her to seek refuge. The letter was unsigned, but the handwriting was unmistakably that of Lady St. Simon.

It was this letter that brought us to the case. Holmes, with his usual keenness of perception, saw at once that the matter was not as simple as it appeared. He questioned the servants, examined the house, and made inquiries in the surrounding district. It was not long before he discovered that Lady St. Simon had been seen in the company of a certain Dr. Mortimer, a physician of some repute, but whose private life was a matter of speculation. Holmes, with his usual discretion, called upon the doctor and soon found that he was in possession of a most extraordinary secret.

It was, in fact, a case of mesmerism, or what is now known as hypnotism. Lord St. Simon had become obsessed with the practice, and had used it upon his wife to such an extent that she had been rendered a complete slave to his will. The lady had been led to believe that she was in love with him, and that she had freely chosen to marry him. But in reality, she had been under his control, and her disappearance was the result of a sudden awakening to the truth.

The case was a most remarkable one, and it was only through the intervention of Sherlock Holmes that the lady was rescued and the truth brought to light. Lord St. Simon was arrested and charged with the crime of mesmerism, a practice which, though not illegal, was considered to be a most dangerous and unnatural one. The case was closed, and the lady was sent to America, where she now lives in obscurity, free from the influence of the man who had once held her in thrall.

events.title: Reviewing Press Coverage of the St. Simon Wedding
detailed_summary: Holmes states the letter is from Lord St. Simon, requesting a consultation about his wedding crisis and noting Scotland Yard's Lestrade is already involved but amenable to Holmes's cooperation.
The letter specifies a 4 p.m. appointment, leaving an hour for preparation.
Holmes observes details about the letter itself (quill pen, ink smear).
Holmes asks Watson to compile newspaper articles related to the case while he looks up Lord St. Simon in a reference book.
Holmes reads biographical details about Lord Robert St. Simon, noting his age, lineage, and previous government position, but finds it unhelpful.
Watson easily finds relevant articles, starting with the engagement announcement between Lord St. Simon and Miss Hatty Doran of San Francisco.
A society paper elaborates, highlighting the trend of American heiresses marrying into British nobility, mentioning Miss Doran's reported wealth and the Duke of Balmoral's financial troubles.
Further notices describe the planned quiet wedding ceremony at St. George's, Hanover Square, and the small reception at Mr. Doran's house.
A final curt notice confirms the wedding occurred and the couple planned to honeymoon near Petersfield.
Holmes is startled when Watson reveals these notices appeared *before* the bride's disappearance.
Watson confirms the bride vanished during the wedding breakfast, piquing Holmes's interest due to the unusual timing.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “That is well.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Pray let me have the details.”

events.text_segment:
“That is well. The letter which I hold in my hand is from Lord St. Simon. I will read it to you, and in return you must turn over these papers and let me have whatever bears upon the matter. This is what he says:
“‘MY DEAR MR. SHERLOCK HOLMES,—Lord Backwater tells me that I may place implicit reliance upon your judgment and discretion. I have determined, therefore, to call upon you and to consult you in reference to the very painful event which has occurred in connection with my wedding. Mr. Lestrade, of Scotland Yard, is acting already in the matter, but he assures me that he sees no objection to your co-operation, and that he even thinks that it might be of some assistance. I will call at four o’clock in the afternoon, and, should you have any other engagement at that time, I hope that you will postpone it, as this matter is of paramount importance. Yours faithfully,
“‘ROBERT ST. SIMON.’
“It is dated from Grosvenor Mansions, written with a quill pen, and the noble lord has had the misfortune to get a smear of ink upon the outer side of his right little finger,” remarked Holmes as he folded up the epistle.
“He says four o’clock. It is three now. He will be here in an hour.”
“Then I have just time, with your assistance, to get clear upon the subject. Turn over those papers and arrange the extracts in their order of time, while I take a glance as to who our client is.” He picked a red-covered volume from a line of books of reference beside the mantelpiece. “Here he is,” said he, sitting down and flattening it out upon his knee. “‘Lord Robert Walsingham de Vere St. Simon, second son of the Duke of Balmoral.’ Hum! ‘Arms: Azure, three caltrops in chief over a fess sable. Born in 1846.’ He’s forty-one years of age, which is mature for marriage. Was Under-Secretary for the colonies in a late administration. The Duke, his father, was at one time Secretary for Foreign Affairs. They inherit Plantagenet blood by direct descent, and Tudor on the distaff side. Ha! Well, there is nothing very instructive in all this. I think that I must turn to you Watson, for something more solid.”
“I have very little difficulty in finding what I want,” said I, “for the facts are quite recent, and the matter struck me as remarkable. I feared to refer them to you, however, as I knew that you had an inquiry on hand and that you disliked the intrusion of other matters.”
“Oh, you mean the little problem of the Grosvenor Square furniture van. That is quite cleared up now—though, indeed, it was obvious from the first. Pray give me the results of your newspaper selections.”
“Here is the first notice which I can find. It is in the personal column of the Morning Post, and dates, as you see, some weeks back: ‘A marriage has been arranged,’ it says, ‘and will, if rumour is correct, very shortly take place, between Lord Robert St. Simon, second son of the Duke of Balmoral, and Miss Hatty Doran, the only daughter of Aloysius Doran. Esq., of San Francisco, Cal., U.S.A.’ That is all.”
“Terse and to the point,” remarked Holmes, stretching his long, thin legs towards the fire.
“There was a paragraph amplifying this in one of the society papers of the same week. Ah, here it is: ‘There will soon be a call for protection in the marriage market, for the present free-trade principle appears to tell heavily against our home product. One by one the management of the noble houses of Great Britain is passing into the hands of our fair cousins from across the Atlantic. An important addition has been made during the last week to the list of the prizes which have been borne away by these charming invaders. Lord St. Simon, who has shown himself for over twenty years proof against the little god’s arrows, has now definitely announced his approaching marriage with Miss Hatty Doran, the fascinating daughter of a California millionaire. Miss Doran, whose graceful figure and striking face attracted much attention at the Westbury House festivities, is an only child, and it is currently reported that her dowry will run to considerably over the six figures, with expectancies for the future. As it is an open secret that the Duke of Balmoral has been compelled to sell his pictures within the last few years, and as Lord St. Simon has no property of his own save the small estate of Birchmoor, it is obvious that the Californian heiress is not the only gainer by an alliance which will enable her to make the easy and common transition from a Republican lady to a British peeress.’”
“Anything else?” asked Holmes, yawning.
“Oh, yes; plenty. Then there is another note in the Morning Post to say that the marriage would be an absolutely quiet one, that it would be at St. George’s, Hanover Square, that only half a dozen intimate friends would be invited, and that the party would return to the furnished house at Lancaster Gate which has been taken by Mr. Aloysius Doran. Two days later—that is, on Wednesday last—there is a curt announcement that the wedding had taken place, and that the honeymoon would be passed at Lord Backwater’s place, near Petersfield. Those are all the notices which appeared before the disappearance of the bride.”
“Before the what?” asked Holmes with a start.
“The vanishing of the lady.”
“When did she vanish, then?”
“At the wedding breakfast.”
“Indeed. This is more interesting than it promised to be; quite dramatic, in fact.”
“Yes; it struck me as being a little out of the common.”
“They often vanish before the ceremony, and occasionally during the honeymoon; but I cannot call to mind anything quite so prompt as this. Pray let me have the details.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: That is well. I have a case upon my hands which may prove interesting. Here is a letter from Lord St. Simon, who is in a most singular position. He is about to be married, and yet he is in such a state of mind that he is prepared to pay me a visit at four o'clock this afternoon, in order to consult me upon the matter. He says that Lestrade of Scotland Yard is already in communication with him, but that he is quite willing to take any assistance that I can give him. The letter is written in a very hurried and agitated hand, and the ink is smudged in places, as if the writer had been in a great hurry. It is written with a quill pen, and the paper is of a peculiar water-mark. I think I shall be able to make something out of it. In the meantime, I have asked Watson to look up the name of Lord St. Simon in the reference books, and to bring me any information that he can find. I shall go myself to the British Museum and see what I can learn about the lady who is to be the bride. Watson, I should like you to look up the name of Lord Robert St. Simon, and to bring me any information that you can find about him. I have here a volume of the Peerage, and I shall look him up myself. Let me see. Here we are. Lord Robert St. Simon, of St. Simon, in the county of Devon, eldest son of the late Earl of St. Simon, and grandson of the present Duke of Balmoral. He was educated at Eton and Oxford, and has held a seat in the House of Commons for the last five years. He is now thirty-five years of age, and is one of the most eligible bachelors in England. I don't see anything in this that would help us, however. Watson, I should like you to look up the newspapers and see if there is anything there that may throw some light upon the matter. I have here the Times, the Morning Post, and the Daily Telegraph. I shall look up the society papers myself. Let me see. Here is an announcement of the engagement of Lord St. Simon to Miss Hatty Doran, of San Francisco. It is a very brief notice, but it is sufficient to show that the engagement is a matter of public knowledge. I see that Miss Doran is the daughter of a wealthy American merchant, and that she has a considerable fortune of her own. The Duke of Balmoral, I understand, is in some pecuniary difficulties, and it is supposed that this marriage is a means of providing a solution. There is a more detailed account in the Morning Post. It says that Miss Doran is a most charming young lady, and that she has been in England for some time. She is said to be a great favourite in society, and to have many admirers. The wedding is to take place at St. George's, Hanover Square, and the reception is to be at the Doran house in Park Lane. I see that the ceremony is to be a very quiet one, and that only a few intimate friends are to be present. There is a further notice in the Daily Telegraph, which says that the wedding has taken place, and that the bride and bridegroom are to proceed at once to the Continent for their honeymoon. I think that is all, Watson. I don't see anything in these papers that would help us, but I shall read them again. I have a feeling that there is something in them which I have not yet grasped. events.title: Newspaper Account of the Bride's Disappearance
detailed_summary: Watson cautions that the available details are incomplete but reads a newspaper article titled 'Singular Occurrence at a Fashionable Wedding'.
The article recounts the quiet ceremony, listing the few high-profile guests present.
It describes a disturbance caused by an unknown woman attempting to force entry into the reception at Mr. Doran's house, claiming a connection to Lord St. Simon, before being ejected.
Inside, the bride, Hatty Doran, felt unwell, retired to her room, but then quickly left the house wearing an ulster and bonnet, seen by a footman.
Her father, Mr. Aloysius Doran, discovered her absence and alerted the police along with the bridegroom.
The article notes ongoing police inquiries and rumors of foul play, mentioning the arrest of the woman who caused the earlier disturbance (Flora Millar) on suspicion of involvement.
Watson adds a final detail from another paper: Flora Millar, identified as a former dancer known to the bridegroom, has indeed been arrested.
Holmes declares the case exceedingly interesting just as the doorbell rings, announcing the arrival of Lord St. Simon at 4 p.m.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I warn you that they are very incomplete.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “And an exceedingly interesting case it appears to be.

events.text_segment:
“I warn you that they are very incomplete.”
“Perhaps we may make them less so.”
“Such as they are, they are set forth in a single article of a morning paper of yesterday, which I will read to you. It is headed, ‘Singular Occurrence at a Fashionable Wedding’:
“‘The family of Lord Robert St. Simon has been thrown into the greatest consternation by the strange and painful episodes which have taken place in connection with his wedding. The ceremony, as shortly announced in the papers of yesterday, occurred on the previous morning; but it is only now that it has been possible to confirm the strange rumours which have been so persistently floating about. In spite of the attempts of the friends to hush the matter up, so much public attention has now been drawn to it that no good purpose can be served by affecting to disregard what is a common subject for conversation.
“‘The ceremony, which was performed at St. George’s, Hanover Square, was a very quiet one, no one being present save the father of the bride, Mr. Aloysius Doran, the Duchess of Balmoral, Lord Backwater, Lord Eustace and Lady Clara St. Simon (the younger brother and sister of the bridegroom), and Lady Alicia Whittington. The whole party proceeded afterwards to the house of Mr. Aloysius Doran, at Lancaster Gate, where breakfast had been prepared. It appears that some little trouble was caused by a woman, whose name has not been ascertained, who endeavoured to force her way into the house after the bridal party, alleging that she had some claim upon Lord St. Simon. It was only after a painful and prolonged scene that she was ejected by the butler and the footman. The bride, who had fortunately entered the house before this unpleasant interruption, had sat down to breakfast with the rest, when she complained of a sudden indisposition and retired to her room. Her prolonged absence having caused some comment, her father followed her, but learned from her maid that she had only come up to her chamber for an instant, caught up an ulster and bonnet, and hurried down to the passage. One of the footmen declared that he had seen a lady leave the house thus apparelled, but had refused to credit that it was his mistress, believing her to be with the company. On ascertaining that his daughter had disappeared, Mr. Aloysius Doran, in conjunction with the bridegroom, instantly put themselves in communication with the police, and very energetic inquiries are being made, which will probably result in a speedy clearing up of this very singular business. Up to a late hour last night, however, nothing had transpired as to the whereabouts of the missing lady. There are rumours of foul play in the matter, and it is said that the police have caused the arrest of the woman who had caused the original disturbance, in the belief that, from jealousy or some other motive, she may have been concerned in the strange disappearance of the bride.’”
“And is that all?”
“Only one little item in another of the morning papers, but it is a suggestive one.”
“And it is—”
“That Miss Flora Millar, the lady who had caused the disturbance, has actually been arrested. It appears that she was formerly a danseuse at the Allegro, and that she has known the bridegroom for some years. There are no further particulars, and the whole case is in your hands now—so far as it has been set forth in the public press.”
“And an exceedingly interesting case it appears to be.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
I warn you that they are very incomplete. I have only been able to collect these facts from the evening papers, and I have not yet had an opportunity of verifying them. Still, I will read you an account of the affair which appeared in the 'Morning Post' of this day's date. It runs as follows:—

"SINGULAR OCCURRENCE AT A FASHIONABLE WEDDING.

"The quiet and unostentatious wedding of Mr. Aloysius Doran, of Doran's Bank, to Miss Hatty Stoner, daughter of the late Mr. Stoner, of South Audley Street, took place yesterday afternoon at the registry office. The number of guests was small, as the ceremony was conducted with the utmost privacy. Among those present were Lord St. Simon, the bridegroom's particular friend, and Mr. Sherlock Holmes, the well-known consulting detective, who was said to be in London on business.

"The only incident of the day occurred at the house in South Audley Street, where the bride and bridegroom were to meet the guests. At about half-past five a woman of singular appearance, dressed in a soiled black dress and with a face of extraordinary haggardness, attempted to force her way into the room where the wedding party was assembled. She declared that she had a message for Lord St. Simon, and that she would not leave the house until she had delivered it. The police were summoned, and the woman was removed by force. She was afterwards identified as Flora Millar, a former dancer, who had been for some years a resident in the East End.

"The bride, who had been looking pale and anxious during the ceremony, fainted immediately after the arrival of the guests. She was carried to her room, and it was supposed that she would remain there for some time. But shortly afterwards she was seen by the footman, Mr. Wilson, leaving the house in great haste, wrapped in an ulster and wearing a bonnet. She was followed by her father, who, on discovering that she had disappeared, at once sent for the police and for the bridegroom. The house was searched, but the lady was nowhere to be found. The police are now engaged in inquiries, and it is feared that some foul play may have been at work. The woman Flora Millar has been arrested, and it is believed that she may be in some way connected with the disappearance of the bride."

"I have since received a telegram from the 'Times' office, which adds a new and important detail to the case. It appears that Flora Millar was once engaged to the bridegroom, Mr. Aloysius Doran, and that she had been in constant communication with him for some weeks past. This, at least, is the statement of the police, who are now treating the case with the utmost gravity."

"This is a very singular affair," said Sherlock Holmes, leaning back in his chair and lighting a cigarette. "There are many points which are obscure, but I have no doubt that the truth will come out in time."

We had just finished our meal when the doorbell rang. It was Lord St. Simon himself, who had come to consult with my friend upon the matter. He was a tall, thin man, with a pale face and a very decided manner. He had been a great friend of the Doran family, and he was now deeply concerned at the strange events which had taken place.
