events.text_segment:
“Holmes,” said I as I stood one morning in our bow-window looking down the street, “here is a madman coming along. It seems rather sad that his relatives should allow him to come out alone.”
My friend rose lazily from his armchair and stood with his hands in the pockets of his dressing-gown, looking over my shoulder. It was a bright, crisp February morning, and the snow of the day before still lay deep upon the ground, shimmering brightly in the wintry sun. Down the centre of Baker Street it had been ploughed into a brown crumbly band by the traffic, but at either side and on the heaped-up edges of the footpaths it still lay as white as when it fell. The grey pavement had been cleaned and scraped, but was still dangerously slippery, so that there were fewer passengers than usual. Indeed, from the direction of the Metropolitan Station no one was coming save the single gentleman whose eccentric conduct had drawn my attention.
He was a man of about fifty, tall, portly, and imposing, with a massive, strongly marked face and a commanding figure. He was dressed in a sombre yet rich style, in black frock-coat, shining hat, neat brown gaiters, and well-cut pearl-grey trousers. Yet his actions were in absurd contrast to the dignity of his dress and features, for he was running hard, with occasional little springs, such as a weary man gives who is little accustomed to set any tax upon his legs. As he ran he jerked his hands up and down, waggled his head, and writhed his face into the most extraordinary contortions.
“What on earth can be the matter with him?” I asked. “He is looking up at the numbers of the houses.”
“I believe that he is coming here,” said Holmes, rubbing his hands.
“Here?”
“Yes; I rather think he is coming to consult me professionally. I think that I recognise the symptoms. Ha! did I not tell you?” As he spoke, the man, puffing and blowing, rushed at our door and pulled at our bell until the whole house resounded with the clanging.
A few moments later he was in our room, still puffing, still gesticulating, but with so fixed a look of grief and despair in his eyes that our smiles were turned in an instant to horror and pity. For a while he could not get his words out, but swayed his body and plucked at his hair like one who has been driven to the extreme limits of his reason. Then, suddenly springing to his feet, he beat his head against the wall with such force that we both rushed upon him and tore him away to the centre of the room. Sherlock Holmes pushed him down into the easy-chair and, sitting beside him, patted his hand and chatted with him in the easy, soothing tones which he knew so well how to employ.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Holmes,” said I as I stood one morning in our bow-window looking down the street, “here is a madman coming along.”

My companion had been lying with his eyes closed, and with the look of weary weariness upon his face which I had learned to associate with the times when his brain was overtaxed with its burdens. He opened them now with a sudden start, and looked down into the street.

“It is a cold morning for a perambulating maniac,” he remarked. “The man is about fifty, well-dressed, and his manner is certainly peculiar. He is running, yet his eyes are fixed upon the numbers of the houses. He is evidently making for some definite point.”

“I should think he might be a man in a hurry rather than a madman,” I remarked.

“Ah, but observe his gestures and his face. He is not merely in a hurry—he is in a state of mental agony. He is acting under some sudden and overwhelming emotion. I have seen these symptoms before.”

The man had now reached our door. He rang the bell violently, and a moment later he was ushered into the room. He was a stout, middle-aged man, with a florid face and a shock of white hair. His eyes were bloodshot, and his hands trembled as he clutched the edge of the table.

“Mr. Sherlock Holmes,” he gasped, “I have come to you for help. I am in a terrible fix. I am Alexander Holder.”

He paused, and then, with a sudden burst of despair, he flung himself upon the floor and began to beat his head against the wall. Holmes and I sprang to his side, and with some difficulty we succeeded in getting him into a chair. He sat there, his face in his hands, his body shaking with sobs.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Holmes,” said I as I stood one morning in our bow-window looking down the street, “here is a madman coming along.”

My companion, who was lounging in his dressing-gown, with a half-smoked pipe in his mouth, raised his head with an expression of interest. “Why, what makes you think so?” he asked.

“I see a man running at full speed down Baker Street, shouting something about a red-headed woman and a pocket watch. He seems to be in a state of great agitation.”

Holmes sprang from his chair and came to the window. “Indeed, that is unusual,” he remarked. “Let us go down and see what the matter is.”

We descended the stairs and found the man still running, his face pale and his eyes wild. He passed us without a word and disappeared around the corner. I turned to Holmes, who was already deep in thought.

“Do you think it is a case?” I asked.

“Possibly,” he replied. “The mention of a red-headed woman and a pocket watch is intriguing. There is a connection there that I must investigate.”

We hailed a cab and set off in the direction the man had taken. After a short ride, we arrived at a small shop on the edge of the city. The shop was run by a man named Mr. Lestrade, a former police officer who had turned to the trade of selling second-hand watches.

Mr. Lestrade greeted us with a nod. “You must be Mr. Holmes,” he said. “I was just about to send for you. I have a most peculiar situation on my hands.”

“Indeed?” said Holmes. “Pray, enlighten me.”

“It seems that a woman with red hair came into my shop yesterday and purchased a pocket watch. She was very particular about the design and insisted that it be engraved with a certain phrase. I have the watch here.”

He produced a small, ornate watch and handed it to Holmes. Holmes examined it closely, then handed it to me. “The engraving reads, ‘To my dearest Clara, with all my love, J.’”

“Who is Clara?” I asked.

“I do not know,” said Mr. Lestrade. “But the woman who bought the watch was not Clara. She was a tall, red-haired woman with a scar on her cheek. She paid in gold and left in a great hurry.”

Holmes nodded thoughtfully. “This is most interesting. I believe we are on the trail of a mystery. Watson, I think it is time we paid a visit to the woman who purchased this watch.”

“Where can we find her?” I asked.

“She left a card,” said Mr. Lestrade. “It is addressed to a Miss Clara at 221B Baker Street.”

Holmes and I exchanged a glance. “Then we must act quickly,” he said. “There is much to be done, and little time to do it in.”

With that, we set off once more, the mystery of the red-headed woman and the pocket watch beginning to unfold before us.

events.title: The Banker's Narrative: The Loan, the Coronet, and the Household
detailed_summary: Holmes reassures the visitor, inviting him to share his problem once composed.
The man recovers slightly, acknowledging his perceived madness but attributing it to sudden, terrible trouble involving both public disgrace and private affliction.
He hints that the issue affects not just him but potentially the 'noblest in the land'.
Holmes prompts him for his identity and the details of his situation.
The visitor introduces himself as Alexander Holder, senior partner of the major banking firm Holder & Stevenson.
Holder explains his haste, having taken the Underground and hurried on foot due to snow, as advised by a police inspector.
He details the banking practice of providing loans against valuable collateral.
He recounts receiving a visit the previous day from an extremely prominent, unnamed individual.
This prestigious client urgently needed £50,000, preferring a business transaction over borrowing from friends.
Holder, acting for the firm, insisted on security despite the client's status.
The client offered the Beryl Coronet as collateral, revealing the priceless artifact.
Holder describes the coronet (39 beryls) and the client's assurance of reclaiming it in four days.
The client stressed the need for discretion and careful preservation due to the coronet's national importance.
After dispensing the cash, Holder felt burdened by the responsibility and decided to take the coronet home for safekeeping rather than leave it in the bank's safe.
He locked it securely in his dressing-room bureau at his Streatham home.
Holder describes his household staff: reliable long-serving maids, and a newer maid, Lucy Parr, pretty but with admirers.

He describes his family: himself (a widower), his only son Arthur (a disappointment due to wild habits, gambling debts, and association with the charming but distrusted Sir George Burnwell), and his niece Mary (adopted, beloved, capable, his 'right hand').
He mentions Arthur loves Mary and has proposed twice, but she refused.

events.text_segment:
“You have come to me to tell your story, have you not?” said he. “You are fatigued with your haste. Pray wait until you have recovered yourself, and then I shall be most happy to look into any little problem which you may submit to me.”
The man sat for a minute or more with a heaving chest, fighting against his emotion. Then he passed his handkerchief over his brow, set his lips tight, and turned his face towards us.
“No doubt you think me mad?” said he.
“I see that you have had some great trouble,” responded Holmes.
“God knows I have!—a trouble which is enough to unseat my reason, so sudden and so terrible is it. Public disgrace I might have faced, although I am a man whose character has never yet borne a stain. Private affliction also is the lot of every man; but the two coming together, and in so frightful a form, have been enough to shake my very soul. Besides, it is not I alone. The very noblest in the land may suffer unless some way be found out of this horrible affair.”
“Pray compose yourself, sir,” said Holmes, “and let me have a clear account of who you are and what it is that has befallen you.”
“My name,” answered our visitor, “is probably familiar to your ears. I am Alexander Holder, of the banking firm of Holder & Stevenson, of Threadneedle Street.”
The name was indeed well known to us as belonging to the senior partner in the second largest private banking concern in the City of London. What could have happened, then, to bring one of the foremost citizens of London to this most pitiable pass? We waited, all curiosity, until with another effort he braced himself to tell his story.
“I feel that time is of value,” said he; “that is why I hastened here when the police inspector suggested that I should secure your co-operation. I came to Baker Street by the Underground and hurried from there on foot, for the cabs go slowly through this snow. That is why I was so out of breath, for I am a man who takes very little exercise. I feel better now, and I will put the facts before you as shortly and yet as clearly as I can.
“It is, of course, well known to you that in a successful banking business as much depends upon our being able to find remunerative investments for our funds as upon our increasing our connection and the number of our depositors. One of our most lucrative means of laying out money is in the shape of loans, where the security is unimpeachable. We have done a good deal in this direction during the last few years, and there are many noble families to whom we have advanced large sums upon the security of their pictures, libraries, or plate.
“Yesterday morning I was seated in my office at the bank when a card was brought in to me by one of the clerks. I started when I saw the name, for it was that of none other than—well, perhaps even to you I had better say no more than that it was a name which is a household word all over the earth—one of the highest, noblest, most exalted names in England. I was overwhelmed by the honour and attempted, when he entered, to say so, but he plunged at once into business with the air of a man who wishes to hurry quickly through a disagreeable task.
“‘Mr. Holder,’ said he, ‘I have been informed that you are in the habit of advancing money.’
“‘The firm does so when the security is good.’ I answered.
“‘It is absolutely essential to me,’ said he, ‘that I should have £ 50,000 at once. I could, of course, borrow so trifling a sum ten times over from my friends, but I much prefer to make it a matter of business and to carry out that business myself. In my position you can readily understand that it is unwise to place one’s self under obligations.’
“‘For how long, may I ask, do you want this sum?’ I asked.
“‘Next Monday I have a large sum due to me, and I shall then most certainly repay what you advance, with whatever interest you think it right to charge. But it is very essential to me that the money should be paid at once.’
“‘I should be happy to advance it without further parley from my own private purse,’ said I, ‘were it not that the strain would be rather more than it could bear. If, on the other hand, I am to do it in the name of the firm, then in justice to my partner I must insist that, even in your case, every businesslike precaution should be taken.’
“‘I should much prefer to have it so,’ said he, raising up a square, black morocco case which he had laid beside his chair. ‘You have doubtless heard of the Beryl Coronet?’
“‘One of the most precious public possessions of the empire,’ said I.
“‘Precisely.’ He opened the case, and there, imbedded in soft, flesh-coloured velvet, lay the magnificent piece of jewellery which he had named. ‘There are thirty-nine enormous beryls,’ said he, ‘and the price of the gold chasing is incalculable. The lowest estimate would put the worth of the coronet at double the sum which I have asked. I am prepared to leave it with you as my security.’
“I took the precious case into my hands and looked in some perplexity from it to my illustrious client.
“‘You doubt its value?’ he asked.
“‘Not at all. I only doubt—’
“‘The propriety of my leaving it. You may set your mind at rest about that. I should not dream of doing so were it not absolutely certain that I should be able in four days to reclaim it. It is a pure matter of form. Is the security sufficient?’
“‘Ample.’
“‘You understand, Mr. Holder, that I am giving you a strong proof of the confidence which I have in you, founded upon all that I have heard of you. I rely upon you not only to be discreet and to refrain from all gossip upon the matter but, above all, to preserve this coronet with every possible precaution because I need not say that a great public scandal would be caused if any harm were to befall it. Any injury to it would be almost as serious as its complete loss, for there are no beryls in the world to match these, and it would be impossible to replace them. I leave it with you, however, with every confidence, and I shall call for it in person on Monday morning.’
“Seeing that my client was anxious to leave, I said no more but, calling for my cashier, I ordered him to pay over fifty £ 1000 notes. When I was alone once more, however, with the precious case lying upon the table in front of me, I could not but think with some misgivings of the immense responsibility which it entailed upon me. There could be no doubt that, as it was a national possession, a horrible scandal would ensue if any misfortune should occur to it. I already regretted having ever consented to take charge of it. However, it was too late to alter the matter now, so I locked it up in my private safe and turned once more to my work.
“When evening came I felt that it would be an imprudence to leave so precious a thing in the office behind me. Bankers’ safes had been forced before now, and why should not mine be? If so, how terrible would be the position in which I should find myself! I determined, therefore, that for the next few days I would always carry the case backward and forward with me, so that it might never be really out of my reach. With this intention, I called a cab and drove out to my house at Streatham, carrying the jewel with me. I did not breathe freely until I had taken it upstairs and locked it in the bureau of my dressing-room.
“And now a word as to my household, Mr. Holmes, for I wish you to thoroughly understand the situation. My groom and my page sleep out of the house, and may be set aside altogether. I have three maid-servants who have been with me a number of years and whose absolute reliability is quite above suspicion. Another, Lucy Parr, the second waiting-maid, has only been in my service a few months. She came with an excellent character, however, and has always given me satisfaction. She is a very pretty girl and has attracted admirers who have occasionally hung about the place. That is the only drawback which we have found to her, but we believe her to be a thoroughly good girl in every way.
“So much for the servants. My family itself is so small that it will not take me long to describe it. I am a widower and have an only son, Arthur. He has been a disappointment to me, Mr. Holmes—a grievous disappointment. I have no doubt that I am myself to blame. People tell me that I have spoiled him. Very likely I have. When my dear wife died I felt that he was all I had to love. I could not bear to see the smile fade even for a moment from his face. I have never denied him a wish. Perhaps it would have been better for both of us had I been sterner, but I meant it for the best.
“It was naturally my intention that he should succeed me in my business, but he was not of a business turn. He was wild, wayward, and, to speak the truth, I could not trust him in the handling of large sums of money. When he was young he became a member of an aristocratic club, and there, having charming manners, he was soon the intimate of a number of men with long purses and expensive habits. He learned to play heavily at cards and to squander money on the turf, until he had again and again to come to me and implore me to give him an advance upon his allowance, that he might settle his debts of honour. He tried more than once to break away from the dangerous company which he was keeping, but each time the influence of his friend, Sir George Burnwell, was enough to draw him back again.
“And, indeed, I could not wonder that such a man as Sir George Burnwell should gain an influence over him, for he has frequently brought him to my house, and I have found myself that I could hardly resist the fascination of his manner. He is older than Arthur, a man of the world to his finger-tips, one who had been everywhere, seen everything, a brilliant talker, and a man of great personal beauty. Yet when I think of him in cold blood, far away from the glamour of his presence, I am convinced from his cynical speech and the look which I have caught in his eyes that he is one who should be deeply distrusted. So I think, and so, too, thinks my little Mary, who has a woman’s quick insight into character.
“And now there is only she to be described. She is my niece; but when my brother died five years ago and left her alone in the world I adopted her, and have looked upon her ever since as my daughter. She is a sunbeam in my house—sweet, loving, beautiful, a wonderful manager and housekeeper, yet as tender and quiet and gentle as a woman could be. She is my right hand. I do not know what I could do without her. In only one matter has she ever gone against my wishes. Twice my boy has asked her to marry him, for he loves her devotedly, but each time she has refused him.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.refinement_prompt:
IMPROVEMENT GUIDANCE:
1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion only includes the very first line of the passage and omits the entire remainder, which consists of a lengthy dialogue, narrative exposition, and character background. This results in the absence of all major sections after the initial question.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The completion lacks the visitor's emotional state and physical actions upon arrival.
- There is no depiction of the exchange between the visitor and Holmes, including Holmes's responses and reassurances.
- The visitor's introduction, including his name, occupation, and the significance of his position, is missing.
- The detailed account of the banking transaction, the security offered, and the description of the valuable item are not present.
- The narrative about the visitor's decision-making regarding the security, his journey home, and the precautions taken are omitted.
- The description of the household staff, their backgrounds, and the family members, including their relationships and character traits, are not included.
- The background and character analysis of the son, his habits, and his associates are absent.
- The niece's introduction, her role in the household, and her relationship with the son are not mentioned.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- There are no explicit inaccuracies in the completion, as it only contains the opening line. However, by omitting all subsequent content, it fails to represent the sequence of events, character introductions, and narrative progression found in the original passage.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“You have come to me to tell your story, have you not?” said he.

I nodded, for I was still too shaken by the events of the past few days to speak. The room was dimly lit, the fire in the grate casting flickering shadows across the walls. Sherlock Holmes sat in his usual armchair, his long, lean form wrapped in a dressing gown, his eyes sharp and alert despite the late hour. He gestured to the chair opposite him, and I sat down, my hands trembling slightly as I clasped them together in my lap.

“Very well,” he said, leaning forward slightly. “Let us hear it, then. I am always interested in the peculiar and the unusual, and your expression suggests that you have something of the sort to relate.”

I took a deep breath, steadying myself. “It began,” I said, “a little over a week ago, when I received a letter from my cousin, Miss Emily Wren. She had been staying with her aunt in the village of Ashcombe, a quiet place in the English countryside. The letter was brief and oddly worded, but it was enough to set my mind at ease. She wrote that she was enjoying the peace and quiet, and that she was looking forward to returning to London in a few weeks. I thought nothing of it at the time, but a few days later, I received a second letter, this one much more alarming. It was unsigned, and the paper was of poor quality, but the message was clear: *Do not visit Ashcombe. It is not safe.*

“I was naturally concerned, but I assumed it was some kind of prank. I had no reason to believe that anything was wrong. However, when I received a third letter, this one written in a different hand and signed with a crude drawing of a raven, I knew I had to act. I decided to travel to Ashcombe myself to see what was going on.”

Holmes raised an eyebrow. “A raven, you say? That is an unusual symbol. Tell me, did you have any reason to believe that your cousin was in danger?”

“I had no reason to believe so,” I replied. “But I had a feeling that something was wrong. I have always had a good relationship with Emily, and I could not shake the sense that she was being watched, or perhaps even threatened.”

Holmes nodded thoughtfully. “A feeling, you say. That is often the first clue in a mystery. Tell me, what did you find when you arrived in Ashcombe?”

I hesitated for a moment, then continued. “The village was as quiet as I had expected. The people were polite but reserved, and no one seemed willing to talk about my cousin. I visited the house where she was staying, a modest cottage on the edge of the village. The door was locked, but I was able to gain entry through a side window that had been left ajar. Inside, the house was in a state of disarray. Furniture was overturned, and there were signs of a struggle. I found a note on the mantel, written in Emily’s hand, which read: *I am not safe here. I must leave. I will not return.*

“I was horrified. I immediately set out to find the local constable, but he was dismissive of my concerns. He said that there was no evidence of a crime, and that I was overreacting. I was not satisfied with his response, so I decided to investigate on my own.”

Holmes leaned back in his chair, his fingers steepled beneath his chin. “You are a brave man,” he said. “But also a foolish one. You should have come to me at once.”

“I know,” I admitted. “But I did not want to trouble you with what I thought might be a simple case of a missing person. I assumed that Emily had simply decided to leave the village and had not informed anyone.”

“Ah, but you were wrong,” said Holmes. “And it is often in the wrongness of our assumptions that the truth is revealed. Tell me, what did you discover next?”

I took another deep breath. “I began to ask questions in the village, but no one would speak to me. I was met with blank stares and muttered warnings. I was about to give up when I met an old man named Mr. Hargrave, who had once been the village schoolmaster. He was reluctant to talk at first, but when I mentioned the name of Emily Wren, he paled and looked around nervously before finally speaking.

“He told me that there was a legend in the village about a man who had once lived in the area, a man known as *The Raven*. He was said to have been a reclusive figure, a man of science who had conducted strange experiments in his home. The villagers feared him, and he was eventually driven out of the village. No one knew what had become of him, but some believed that he had returned in recent years, living in the old manor house on the outskirts of the village.”

Holmes’s eyes narrowed. “A man of science, you say? That is an interesting detail. Tell me, what kind of experiments did this man conduct?”

“I could not say for certain,” I replied. “Mr. Hargrave was vague on the details, but he did mention that the man had been obsessed with the idea of immortality. He had been trying to find a way to extend human life, and he had been experimenting on animals. Some of the villagers believed that he had succeeded, at least in part.”

Holmes was silent for a moment, his mind clearly working through the implications of what I had just told him. “This is most intriguing,” he said at last. “A man of science, obsessed with immortality, and now a missing woman with a raven symbol. There is a connection here, and I intend to find it. I will accompany you to Ashcombe.”

I was surprised. “You will come with me?”

“Of course,” said Holmes. “This is a case that has all the elements of a mystery: a missing person, a strange symbol, and a legend of a man who may or may not be real. I am most eager to see what lies at the heart of this mystery.”

The next morning, we set out for Ashcombe. The journey was long, and the weather was uncooperative, with heavy rain and strong winds making the roads treacherous. When we finally arrived in the village, I was struck by how quiet and desolate it seemed. The people were even more reserved than before, and I could see the fear in their eyes when they looked at us.

We made our way to the old manor house, a crumbling structure on the edge of the village. The house was in a state of disrepair, with ivy crawling up the walls and broken windows. Holmes examined the house carefully, noting the signs of recent activity. “This house has been occupied recently,” he said. “Look at the fresh footprints in the mud. Someone has been here.”

We entered the house cautiously, our footsteps echoing in the empty halls. The interior was dark and musty, with dust-covered furniture and faded portraits on the walls. Holmes moved through the house with the ease of a man who had seen many such places before, his eyes scanning for any sign of what we were looking for.

In the study, we found a desk covered in papers and books. Holmes examined them carefully, his brow furrowed in concentration. “These are notes on experiments,” he said. “The handwriting is old, but the ink is fresh. Someone has been continuing the work of the man who once lived here.”

I looked over his shoulder and saw references to chemical formulas and biological processes. “This is the work of a man obsessed,” I said. “He was trying to find a way to extend life, to defy death itself.”

Holmes nodded. “Yes, and it seems that someone has taken up where he left off. This is no longer just a legend. There is a man here, and he is continuing the work of *The Raven*.”

We searched the rest of the house, but found no sign of the man himself. However, we did find a hidden room behind a false wall in the library. The room was small and dimly lit, with a single table in the center. On the table was a series of vials and instruments, and in the corner of the room was a cot, as if someone had been sleeping there.

Holmes examined the room carefully, his eyes narrowing as he took in the details. “This is a laboratory,” he said. “And it is well-equipped. Whoever is here is not just experimenting for fun. They are serious about their work.”

We left the house and returned to the village, where we found Mr. Hargrave waiting for us. He looked even more nervous than before, and I could see that he was afraid to speak. “You have been to the manor house,” he said. “I know what you have found. But you must leave. It is not safe for you to be here.”

Holmes stepped forward. “Mr. Hargrave, I need to know the truth. Who is living in that house? And what are they doing?”

The old man hesitated, then finally spoke. “It is a man named Dr. Victor Langley. He was once a respected scientist, but he became obsessed with the idea of immortality. He disappeared years ago, and we thought he was dead. But he has returned, and he is continuing his work. He has taken people from the village, people who have gone missing. He is using them for his experiments.”

I felt a chill run down my spine. “Emily,” I said. “He has taken her, hasn’t he?”

Mr. Hargrave nodded. “I fear so. She was the last to disappear. No one has seen her since.”

Holmes was silent for a moment, then he turned to me. “We must act quickly. If Dr. Langley has taken your cousin, we must find her before it is too late.”

We returned to the manor house that night, armed with the information we had gathered. The house was dark and silent, but we could hear the faint sound of footsteps inside. Holmes led the way, his movements silent and precise. We moved through the house, our hearts pounding with anticipation.

In the hidden laboratory, we found Dr. Langley. He was a tall, gaunt man with wild eyes and a disheveled appearance. He was surrounded by vials and instruments, and in the center of the room was a table with a body on it. I recognized the body immediately—it was my cousin, Emily.

“Stop!” I shouted, but it was too late. Dr. Langley had already begun his experiment. He was injecting a strange substance into Emily’s arm, and her body convulsed in response.

Holmes moved quickly, grabbing Dr. Langley by the collar and pulling him away from the table. “You will stop this at once,” he said, his voice cold and commanding.

Dr. Langley struggled, but Holmes was stronger. “You have no right to do this,” he said. “You are a madman.”

“I am a scientist,” Dr. Langley spat. “And I am on the verge of a great discovery. I have found a way to extend life, to defy death itself. You cannot stop me.”

Holmes looked at me, then at Emily. “We must act quickly,” he said. “If we do not stop him now, he may succeed in his madness.”

With a swift motion, Holmes knocked Dr. Langley unconscious and tied him up. We carried Emily out of the house and into the waiting carriage. The journey back to London was long and silent, but I was grateful to have her with me.

When we arrived at 221B Baker Street, Dr. Langley was taken into custody by the police. The case was closed, and the villagers of Ashcombe were finally free from the shadow of *The Raven*.

As I sat in the armchair across from Holmes, I looked at him with a mixture of gratitude and awe. “You have done it again,” I said. “You have solved the mystery and saved my cousin.”

Holmes smiled. “It was a pleasure, my dear fellow. And I must say, the raven was a most intriguing clue. It is always the small details that lead us to the truth.”

I nodded, still in awe of the man who had once again proven that no mystery was too great for Sherlock Holmes to solve.

events.title: The Banker's Narrative: The Crime, Confrontation, and Arrest
detailed_summary: Holder shares his account of the previous evening.
After dinner, he informed Arthur and Mary about the valuable treasure (the coronet) under their roof, omitting the client's name. Lucy Parr, the maid, might have overheard before leaving the room.
Arthur expressed interest and casually remarked on the bureau's insecure lock, which Holder dismissed.
Later, Arthur gravely asked Holder for £200 to settle club debts.
Holder angrily refused, leading Arthur to state he must find other means to avoid dishonour.
After Arthur left, Holder checked the coronet was safe in the bureau.
Performing a house security check, Holder saw Mary closing and fastening the hall side window.
Mary reported seeing Lucy Parr slip in the back door, suggesting she'd met someone outside and that it should be stopped.
Holder agreed to address it and retired to bed after Mary assured him all was secure.
Around 2 AM, Holder was woken by a sound like a window closing gently.
He then heard distinct footsteps in the adjoining dressing-room.
Peeking in, he saw Arthur, partially dressed, holding the coronet and appearing to wrench it.
Holder cried out, accusing Arthur of theft.
Arthur dropped the coronet, looking deathly pale. Holder examined it and found a corner with three beryls missing.
Holder furiously accused Arthur of destroying the coronet and stealing the jewels.
Arthur denied theft and refused further discussion due to Holder's insults, declaring he would leave the house.
Holder threatened police involvement; the commotion roused the household.
Mary rushed in, saw the scene, screamed, and fainted.
Holder summoned the police.
When the police arrived, Arthur sullenly asked if Holder intended to charge him.
Holder declared it a public matter concerning national property.
Arthur requested five minutes outside before arrest, which Holder denied, suspecting he meant to escape or hide the gems.
Holder pleaded with Arthur to reveal the gems' location to avoid national scandal, offering forgiveness.
Arthur contemptuously refused.
Holder instructed the inspector to arrest Arthur.
An immediate search of Arthur, his room, and the house yielded no trace of the missing gems.
Arthur remained silent despite pleas and threats.
The following morning, Arthur was taken to a cell, and Holder rushed to Holmes, confessing the police were baffled and offering a £1000 reward.
Holder concludes his story in despair, rocking back and forth, lamenting the loss of honour, gems, and son.

events.text_segment:
I think that if anyone could have drawn him into the right path it would have been she, and that his marriage might have changed his whole life; but now, alas! it is too late—forever too late!
“Now, Mr. Holmes, you know the people who live under my roof, and I shall continue with my miserable story.
“When we were taking coffee in the drawing-room that night after dinner, I told Arthur and Mary my experience, and of the precious treasure which we had under our roof, suppressing only the name of my client. Lucy Parr, who had brought in the coffee, had, I am sure, left the room; but I cannot swear that the door was closed. Mary and Arthur were much interested and wished to see the famous coronet, but I thought it better not to disturb it.
“‘Where have you put it?’ asked Arthur.
“‘In my own bureau.’
“‘Well, I hope to goodness the house won’t be burgled during the night.’ said he.
“‘It is locked up,’ I answered.
“‘Oh, any old key will fit that bureau. When I was a youngster I have opened it myself with the key of the box-room cupboard.’
“He often had a wild way of talking, so that I thought little of what he said. He followed me to my room, however, that night with a very grave face.
“‘Look here, dad,’ said he with his eyes cast down, ‘can you let me have £ 200?’
“‘No, I cannot!’ I answered sharply. ‘I have been far too generous with you in money matters.’
“‘You have been very kind,’ said he, ‘but I must have this money, or else I can never show my face inside the club again.’
“‘And a very good thing, too!’ I cried.
“‘Yes, but you would not have me leave it a dishonoured man,’ said he. ‘I could not bear the disgrace. I must raise the money in some way, and if you will not let me have it, then I must try other means.’
“I was very angry, for this was the third demand during the month. ‘You shall not have a farthing from me,’ I cried, on which he bowed and left the room without another word.
“When he was gone I unlocked my bureau, made sure that my treasure was safe, and locked it again. Then I started to go round the house to see that all was secure—a duty which I usually leave to Mary but which I thought it well to perform myself that night. As I came down the stairs I saw Mary herself at the side window of the hall, which she closed and fastened as I approached.
“‘Tell me, dad,’ said she, looking, I thought, a little disturbed, ‘did you give Lucy, the maid, leave to go out to-night?’
“‘Certainly not.’
“‘She came in just now by the back door. I have no doubt that she has only been to the side gate to see someone, but I think that it is hardly safe and should be stopped.’
“‘You must speak to her in the morning, or I will if you prefer it. Are you sure that everything is fastened?’
“‘Quite sure, dad.’
“‘Then, good-night.’ I kissed her and went up to my bedroom again, where I was soon asleep.
“I am endeavouring to tell you everything, Mr. Holmes, which may have any bearing upon the case, but I beg that you will question me upon any point which I do not make clear.”
“On the contrary, your statement is singularly lucid.”
“I come to a part of my story now in which I should wish to be particularly so. I am not a very heavy sleeper, and the anxiety in my mind tended, no doubt, to make me even less so than usual. About two in the morning, then, I was awakened by some sound in the house. It had ceased ere I was wide awake, but it had left an impression behind it as though a window had gently closed somewhere. I lay listening with all my ears. Suddenly, to my horror, there was a distinct sound of footsteps moving softly in the next room. I slipped out of bed, all palpitating with fear, and peeped round the corner of my dressing-room door.
“‘Arthur!’ I screamed, ‘you villain! you thief! How dare you touch that coronet?’
“The gas was half up, as I had left it, and my unhappy boy, dressed only in his shirt and trousers, was standing beside the light, holding the coronet in his hands. He appeared to be wrenching at it, or bending it with all his strength. At my cry he dropped it from his grasp and turned as pale as death. I snatched it up and examined it. One of the gold corners, with three of the beryls in it, was missing.
“‘You blackguard!’ I shouted, beside myself with rage. ‘You have destroyed it! You have dishonoured me forever! Where are the jewels which you have stolen?’
“‘Stolen!’ he cried.
“‘Yes, thief!’ I roared, shaking him by the shoulder.
“‘There are none missing. There cannot be any missing,’ said he.
“‘There are three missing. And you know where they are. Must I call you a liar as well as a thief? Did I not see you trying to tear off another piece?’
“‘You have called me names enough,’ said he, ‘I will not stand it any longer. I shall not say another word about this business, since you have chosen to insult me. I will leave your house in the morning and make my own way in the world.’
“‘You shall leave it in the hands of the police!’ I cried half-mad with grief and rage. ‘I shall have this matter probed to the bottom.’
“‘You shall learn nothing from me,’ said he with a passion such as I should not have thought was in his nature. ‘If you choose to call the police, let the police find what they can.’
“By this time the whole house was astir, for I had raised my voice in my anger. Mary was the first to rush into my room, and, at the sight of the coronet and of Arthur’s face, she read the whole story and, with a scream, fell down senseless on the ground. I sent the housemaid for the police and put the investigation into their hands at once. When the inspector and a constable entered the house, Arthur, who had stood sullenly with his arms folded, asked me whether it was my intention to charge him with theft. I answered that it had ceased to be a private matter, but had become a public one, since the ruined coronet was national property. I was determined that the law should have its way in everything.
“‘At least,’ said he, ‘you will not have me arrested at once. It would be to your advantage as well as mine if I might leave the house for five minutes.’
“‘That you may get away, or perhaps that you may conceal what you have stolen,’ said I. And then, realising the dreadful position in which I was placed, I implored him to remember that not only my honour but that of one who was far greater than I was at stake; and that he threatened to raise a scandal which would convulse the nation. He might avert it all if he would but tell me what he had done with the three missing stones.
“‘You may as well face the matter,’ said I; ‘you have been caught in the act, and no confession could make your guilt more heinous. If you but make such reparation as is in your power, by telling us where the beryls are, all shall be forgiven and forgotten.’
“‘Keep your forgiveness for those who ask for it,’ he answered, turning away from me with a sneer. I saw that he was too hardened for any words of mine to influence him. There was but one way for it. I called in the inspector and gave him into custody. A search was made at once not only of his person but of his room and of every portion of the house where he could possibly have concealed the gems; but no trace of them could be found, nor would the wretched boy open his mouth for all our persuasions and our threats. This morning he was removed to a cell, and I, after going through all the police formalities, have hurried round to you to implore you to use your skill in unravelling the matter. The police have openly confessed that they can at present make nothing of it. You may go to any expense which you think necessary. I have already offered a reward of £ 1000. My God, what shall I do! I have lost my honour, my gems, and my son in one night. Oh, what shall I do!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
I think that if anyone could have drawn him into the right path it would have been she, and that his marriage might have changed his whole life; but now, alas! it is too late—forever too late!

"I have come to you, Mr. Holmes, because I know that no one else can help me. I have lost my son, my honour, and a national treasure. I have done all that I could, but I am at my wit's end."

"I will do what I can, Mr. Holder," said Holmes, "but I must ask you to tell me the whole story from the beginning."

Mr. Holder, a tall, thin man, with a face worn by anxiety, leaned forward and began his tale.

"It was last evening," he said, "that the tragedy began. After dinner, I informed my son Arthur and my daughter Mary of the matter which had brought me to their home. I had been entrusted with a valuable coronet of beryl, which was to be delivered to its rightful owner. I did not mention the name of the client, but I fear that Lucy Parr, our housemaid, may have overheard the conversation before she left the room.

"Arthur, who had been somewhat idle of late, showed a sudden interest in the matter. He remarked, in a careless way, that the bureau in which I had placed the coronet was not very secure. I laughed at the idea, for I had taken every precaution. But later, when he asked me for £200 to settle his club debts, I refused him. He looked at me with a strange expression and said that he would find other means to avoid dishonour.

"After he left, I went to the bureau and found the coronet still there. I then made a tour of the house to see that all was secure. I saw my daughter Mary closing and fastening the window on the hall side. She told me that she had seen Lucy Parr slip in at the back door, and that she had met someone outside. She thought that it should be stopped. I agreed, and I retired to bed, feeling reassured by Mary's assurance that all was well.

"About two in the morning, I was wakened by a sound like a window closing gently. Then I heard the distinct sound of footsteps in the adjoining dressing-room. I crept to the door and looked in. By the light of the moon, I saw Arthur, half-dressed, holding the coronet in his hand, and he was wrenched at it as if trying to break it.

"I cried out, 'Arthur, what are you doing?' He dropped the coronet, and I saw that a corner of it was missing, with three of the beryls gone. I accused him of theft and of destroying the coronet. He denied it, and refused to discuss the matter further, declaring that he would leave the house. I threatened to call the police, and the commotion roused the household.

"My daughter Mary rushed in, saw the scene, screamed, and fainted. I sent for the police, and when they arrived, Arthur asked me if I intended to charge him. I told him that it was a matter of public interest, and that the coronet was a national treasure. He asked for five minutes to go outside before his arrest, but I refused, fearing that he might escape or hide the gems. I pleaded with him to tell me where they were, offering to forgive him. But he only looked at me with contempt and refused to speak.

"The police searched him, his room, and the house, but found no trace of the missing gems. He remained silent, and I was forced to have him taken away. This morning, he was placed in a cell, and I came to you, Mr. Holmes, in despair. The police are baffled, and I have offered a reward of £1000 for any information which may lead to the recovery of the gems."

Mr. Holder ended his story with a groan, and rocked back and forth in his chair, his face in his hands. Holmes and I looked at each other, for we had heard many strange tales, but this one was certainly among the most perplexing.

"I have come to you, Mr. Holmes, because I know that no one else can help me. I have lost my son, my honour, and a national treasure. I have done all that I could, but I am at my wit's end."

"I will do what I can, Mr. Holder," said Holmes, "but I must ask you to tell me the whole story from the beginning."

Mr. Holder, a tall, thin man, with a face worn by anxiety, leaned forward and began his tale.

"It was last evening," he said, "that the tragedy began. After dinner, I informed my son Arthur and my daughter Mary of the matter which had brought me to their home. I had been entrusted with a valuable coronet of beryl, which was to be delivered to its rightful owner. I did not mention the name of the client, but I fear that Lucy Parr, our housemaid, may have overheard the conversation before she left the room.

"Arthur, who had been somewhat idle of late, showed a sudden interest in the matter. He remarked, in a careless way, that the bureau in which I had placed the coronet was not very secure. I laughed at the idea, for I had taken every precaution. But later, when he asked me for £200 to settle his club debts, I refused him. He looked at me with a strange expression and said that he would find other means to avoid dishonour.

"After he left, I went to the bureau and found the coronet still there. I then made a tour of the house to see that all was secure. I saw my daughter Mary closing and fastening the window on the hall side. She told me that she had seen Lucy Parr slip in at the back door, and that she had met someone outside. She thought that it should be stopped. I agreed, and I retired to bed, feeling reassured by Mary's assurance that all was well.

"About two in the morning, I was wakened by a sound like a window closing gently. Then I heard the distinct sound of footsteps in the adjoining dressing-room. I crept to the door and looked in. By the light of the moon, I saw Arthur, half-dressed, holding the coronet in his hand, and he was wrenched at it as if trying to break it.

"I cried out, 'Arthur, what are you doing?' He dropped the coronet, and I saw that a corner of it was missing, with three of the beryls gone. I accused him of theft and of destroying the coronet. He denied it, and refused to discuss the matter further, declaring that he would leave the house. I threatened to call the police, and the commotion roused the household.

"My daughter Mary rushed in, saw the scene, screamed, and fainted. I sent for the police, and when they arrived, Arthur asked me if I intended to charge him. I told him that it was a matter of public interest, and that the coronet was a national treasure. He asked for five minutes to go outside before his arrest, but I refused, fearing that he might escape or hide the gems. I pleaded with him to tell me where they were, offering to forgive him. But he only looked at me with contempt and refused to speak.

"The police searched him, his room, and the house, but found no trace of the missing gems. He remained silent, and I was forced to have him taken away. This morning, he was placed in a cell, and I came to you, Mr. Holmes, in despair. The police are baffled, and I have offered a reward of £1000 for any information which may lead to the recovery of the gems."

Mr. Holder ended his story with a groan, and rocked back and forth in his chair, his face in his hands. Holmes and I looked at each other, for we had heard many strange tales, but this one was certainly among the most perplexing.

events.title: Holmes' Initial Analysis and the Journey to Streatham
detailed_summary: Holmes sits silently, contemplating the case.
He asks Holder about visitors, learning Sir George Burnwell had visited recently.
He inquires about social activities, noting Mary's preference for staying home despite her youth.
Holmes asks about Mary's reaction, and Holder confirms she was terribly affected.
He questions Holder's certainty about Arthur's guilt, pointing out that seeing him with the coronet isn't conclusive proof.
Holmes notes the coronet was twisted and suggests Arthur might have been trying to straighten it.
Holder acknowledges Holmes' attempt to find an innocent explanation but finds the task too difficult, questioning why Arthur was there and why he didn't explain if innocent.
Holmes counters that Arthur's silence is ambiguous, as he didn't invent a lie either.
He questions the police theory about the noise waking Holder (Arthur closing his door), finding it unlikely for someone committing a crime.
Holmes asks about the police search for the gems, learning they've searched inside and minutely examined the garden.
Holmes asserts the matter is deeper than initially thought, finding Holder's theory of Arthur's complex actions (theft, breakage, concealment, return) untenable.
Holder despairs, asking for an alternative theory.
Holmes states their task is to find the explanation and proposes they go to Streatham immediately.
Watson eagerly accepts Holmes' invitation to join the expedition, intrigued by the case and trusting Holmes' judgment despite Arthur's apparent guilt.
Holmes remains deep in thought during the journey, while Holder seems slightly more hopeful and chats with Watson.

events.text_segment:
Sherlock Holmes sat silent for some few minutes, with his brows knitted and his eyes fixed upon the fire.
“Do you receive much company?” he asked.
“None save my partner with his family and an occasional friend of Arthur’s. Sir George Burnwell has been several times lately. No one else, I think.”
“Do you go out much in society?”
“Arthur does. Mary and I stay at home. We neither of us care for it.”
“That is unusual in a young girl.”
“She is of a quiet nature. Besides, she is not so very young. She is four-and-twenty.”
“This matter, from what you say, seems to have been a shock to her also.”
“Terrible! She is even more affected than I.”
“You have neither of you any doubt as to your son’s guilt?”
“How can we have when I saw him with my own eyes with the coronet in his hands.”
“I hardly consider that a conclusive proof. Was the remainder of the coronet at all injured?”
“Yes, it was twisted.”
“Do you not think, then, that he might have been trying to straighten it?”
“God bless you! You are doing what you can for him and for me. But it is too heavy a task. What was he doing there at all? If his purpose were innocent, why did he not say so?”
“Precisely. And if it were guilty, why did he not invent a lie? His silence appears to me to cut both ways. There are several singular points about the case. What did the police think of the noise which awoke you from your sleep?”
“They considered that it might be caused by Arthur’s closing his bedroom door.”
“A likely story! As if a man bent on felony would slam his door so as to wake a household. What did they say, then, of the disappearance of these gems?”
“They are still sounding the planking and probing the furniture in the hope of finding them.”
“Have they thought of looking outside the house?”
“Yes, they have shown extraordinary energy. The whole garden has already been minutely examined.”
“Now, my dear sir,” said Holmes, “is it not obvious to you now that this matter really strikes very much deeper than either you or the police were at first inclined to think? It appeared to you to be a simple case; to me it seems exceedingly complex. Consider what is involved by your theory. You suppose that your son came down from his bed, went, at great risk, to your dressing-room, opened your bureau, took out your coronet, broke off by main force a small portion of it, went off to some other place, concealed three gems out of the thirty-nine, with such skill that nobody can find them, and then returned with the other thirty-six into the room in which he exposed himself to the greatest danger of being discovered. I ask you now, is such a theory tenable?”
“But what other is there?” cried the banker with a gesture of despair. “If his motives were innocent, why does he not explain them?”
“It is our task to find that out,” replied Holmes; “so now, if you please, Mr. Holder, we will set off for Streatham together, and devote an hour to glancing a little more closely into details.”
My friend insisted upon my accompanying them in their expedition, which I was eager enough to do, for my curiosity and sympathy were deeply stirred by the story to which we had listened. I confess that the guilt of the banker’s son appeared to me to be as obvious as it did to his unhappy father, but still I had such faith in Holmes’ judgment that I felt that there must be some grounds for hope as long as he was dissatisfied with the accepted explanation. He hardly spoke a word the whole way out to the southern suburb, but sat with his chin upon his breast and his hat drawn over his eyes, sunk in the deepest thought. Our client appeared to have taken fresh heart at the little glimpse of hope which had been presented to him, and he even broke into a desultory chat with me over his business affairs.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Sherlock Holmes sat silent for some few minutes, with his brows knitted and his eyes fixed upon the fire. Then he leaned back in his chair and lit a cigarette, while his fingers idly twisted the chain of his watch. "This is a very interesting case," he remarked at last. "It is not the first time that I have been called upon to clear up a mystery in a family circle, but I confess that the present one is singularly perplexing. I should like to know, Mr. Holder, whether you have any idea of the course which my inquiries may take?" Alexander Holder, a tall, thin man, with a pale, anxious face, shook his head. "None whatever," he said. "I have no idea what to do or what to think. I have brought you the facts as they are, and I leave it to you to make what you can of them." "Very good," said Holmes. "Let us go over them once more. You say that your brother Arthur was seen by your father, Sir George Burnwell, in the room where the beryl coronet was kept, and that he was in possession of it?" "Yes, that is the charge against him," said Holder. "But it is not proved. My father saw him, but he did not see what he did with the coronet. It was found afterwards in the garden, broken and twisted, and Arthur was nowhere to be found." "Ah, that is a very important point," said Holmes. "The coronet was twisted. That suggests that it had been handled roughly, perhaps in an attempt to straighten it. But why should Arthur have done that?" "Because he had stolen it," said Holder. "That is the only explanation. He took it, broke it, and then threw it into the garden to hide it." "And yet," said Holmes, "you must admit that there is no direct proof of this. You say that your father saw him in the room, but he did not see him take the coronet. You say that the coronet was found in the garden, but you do not know who put it there. You say that Arthur was not found, but you do not know where he went. There are many possibilities, Mr. Holder, and it is not for us to assume the worst without evidence." Holder looked at him in despair. "But what else can it be?" he cried. "He was there, he had the coronet, and he disappeared. What else can we think?" "That is precisely the question I am asking myself," said Holmes. "And I am not yet satisfied with the answer. I am inclined to think that there is some other explanation, some other thread which we have not yet pulled. I should like to know, for instance, whether there were any other visitors to the house on the night in question?" Holder hesitated. "There was Sir George Burnwell," he said. "He came to dinner, and he stayed the night. He was the one who saw Arthur in the room." "And what of the other members of the household?" asked Holmes. "My sister Mary," said Holder. "She is very young, and she does not go out much. She was in her room that night, and she did not hear anything. She was very upset when she heard what had happened." "Yes, I should imagine so," said Holmes. "It is a terrible thing for a young girl to be caught in the middle of such a scandal. But I am more interested in the movements of the others. Did anyone else hear anything?" "No," said Holder. "The house was very quiet. The servants were all in bed, and no one heard anything. The police have searched the house from top to bottom, and they have examined the garden with a fine-tooth comb, but they have found nothing. They are convinced that Arthur took the coronet and threw it into the garden, and that he has fled the country." "And you?" asked Holmes. "Do you believe that?" Holder looked at him in silence for a moment. "I do not know what to believe," he said at last. "I want to believe that Arthur is innocent, but I cannot see any other explanation. He was there, he had the coronet, and he disappeared. What else can it mean?" "It may mean that he was there for a reason, and that he did not take the coronet," said Holmes. "It may mean that he was trying to find it, or that he was trying to return it. It may mean that he was trying to clear his name. There are many possibilities, Mr. Holder, and it is not for us to assume the worst without evidence. I propose that we go to Streatham at once, and that we see for ourselves what has been done. I think that there is something in this case which we have not yet seen, and I am determined to find it." Holder looked at him in surprise. "You think that there is something more to this?" he asked. "I am sure of it," said Holmes. "And I am equally sure that we shall find it. Come, Watson, I think that we shall have a most interesting expedition. What say you?" I looked at Holmes with a smile. "I am always ready to follow you," I said. "And I must confess that this case has intrigued me from the first. I have no doubt that you will find the explanation, and I am looking forward to hearing it." Holder looked at us both in silence for a moment, and then he smiled faintly. "I am glad to hear it," he said. "I have been in despair, but I feel a little more hopeful now. I shall be glad to go with you, Mr. Holmes, and to see what you can find." Holmes rose from his chair and put on his coat. "Then let us be off," he said. "There is no time to be lost, and I have a feeling that we are on the verge of a most remarkable discovery."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Sherlock Holmes sat silent for some few minutes, with his brows knitted and his eyes fixed upon the fire. The room was dimly lit, the only illumination coming from the flickering flames that danced in the hearth. Outside, the wind howled through the narrow streets of London, rattling the windows and casting long shadows across the room. Dr. Watson, who had been quietly observing his friend, finally broke the silence.

"Holmes," he said, "I take it you have some theory to explain the events of last night?"

Holmes gave a faint smile and leaned back in his chair, his long fingers steepled before him. "Indeed, Watson. The case is most singular, and the clues, though few, are most telling. You recall the peculiar circumstances of the disappearance of Mr. James Morstan, the missing letter, and the strange appearance of the woman in the cab."

Watson nodded. "Yes, I remember. The woman, Miss Mary Morstan, was most distressed and claimed to have no knowledge of her father's fate."

"Precisely," said Holmes. "And yet, there is something in her manner that suggests she knows more than she is willing to admit. The key to this mystery lies not in the letter, but in the man who wrote it."

"You mean the unknown correspondent?"

"Yes. The letter was written in a hand that is both elegant and precise, yet the ink was of a peculiar shade, and the paper bore the watermark of a rare brand. These are not the trappings of an ordinary man."

Watson frowned. "You think the letter was written by someone of high standing?"

"I think it was written by someone who wished to remain anonymous, yet who had the means to do so. The letter was not merely a message, but a cipher."

"A cipher?"

"Indeed. The words are arranged in a pattern, and the initials of the first letters of each line spell out a name."

Watson leaned forward, intrigued. "And what name does it spell?"

Holmes paused for a moment, then said, "The name of a man who has long been thought dead."

"Who?"

"Colonel Sebastian Moran."

Watson's eyes widened. "Moran? But he was presumed to have died in Afghanistan."

"Presumed, Watson. But not proven. And if he is alive, then he is the only man who could have written that letter."

"But why?"

"Because he is the only man who could have known the truth about Mr. Morstan's disappearance."

Watson sat in silence for a moment, digesting the implications of Holmes' words. "Then what do you propose we do?"

Holmes rose from his chair and began to pace the room. "We must find the letter."

"But it was destroyed."

"Not entirely. I have reason to believe that a fragment of it remains, hidden in plain sight."

"Where?"

"In the library of the British Museum."

Watson looked at him in astonishment. "You think it is there?"

"I am certain of it."

"Then we must go at once."

Holmes nodded. "Yes, Watson. The game is afoot."

And with that, the two men rose from their chairs and made their way into the night, the wind howling behind them as they set out on the trail of a mystery that had long been buried in the shadows of the past.

events.title: Investigation at Fairbank: Exterior Clues, Mary's Plea, and Interior Examination
detailed_summary: They arrive at Fairbank, Holder's residence.
Holmes meticulously inspects the house's exterior, walking around the grounds, paying attention to the tradesmen's path and stable lane, while Holder and Watson wait inside.
A young lady, Mary Holder, enters the dining room where they wait. Watson is struck by her extreme pallor and signs of grief, noting her strong character and self-restraint.
Mary goes directly to her uncle, caressing his head and asking if Arthur has been liberated.
Holder replies the matter must be investigated fully.
Mary passionately insists on Arthur's innocence based on her intuition and pleads with Holder to drop the matter, expressing distress over Arthur being in prison.
Holder refuses, stating his determination to find the gems and mentioning he has brought Holmes ('a gentleman down from London') to investigate further.
Mary identifies Holmes as he returns, expressing hope he will prove Arthur's innocence.
Holmes confirms his shared opinion and begins questioning Mary.
She states she heard nothing until her uncle raised his voice, then came down.
She confirms she fastened all windows the previous night and they were still fastened that morning.
Holmes brings up the maid (Lucy Parr) with a sweetheart, whom Mary mentioned seeing return the previous night.
Mary confirms Lucy was the maid in the drawing-room who might have overheard the conversation about the coronet.
Holmes clarifies the inference: Lucy might have told her sweetheart, leading to a planned robbery.
Holder impatiently dismisses these theories, reiterating he saw Arthur with the coronet.
Holmes urges patience and asks Mary about Lucy's return via the kitchen door.
Mary confirms meeting Lucy slipping in and seeing the man waiting outside.
She identifies the man as Francis Prosper, the greengrocer.
Holmes asks precise details about where Prosper stood and confirms he has a wooden leg, startling Mary with his knowledge.
Holmes expresses interest in examining the lower windows before going upstairs.
He swiftly checks them, pausing to carefully examine the sill of the large hall window overlooking the stable lane with his magnifying lens.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A short railway journey and a shorter walk brought us to Fairbank, the modest residence of the great financier.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Now we shall go upstairs,” said he at last.

events.text_segment:
A short railway journey and a shorter walk brought us to Fairbank, the modest residence of the great financier.
Fairbank was a good-sized square house of white stone, standing back a little from the road. A double carriage-sweep, with a snow-clad lawn, stretched down in front to two large iron gates which closed the entrance. On the right side was a small wooden thicket, which led into a narrow path between two neat hedges stretching from the road to the kitchen door, and forming the tradesmen’s entrance. On the left ran a lane which led to the stables, and was not itself within the grounds at all, being a public, though little used, thoroughfare. Holmes left us standing at the door and walked slowly all round the house, across the front, down the tradesmen’s path, and so round by the garden behind into the stable lane. So long was he that Mr. Holder and I went into the dining-room and waited by the fire until he should return. We were sitting there in silence when the door opened and a young lady came in. She was rather above the middle height, slim, with dark hair and eyes, which seemed the darker against the absolute pallor of her skin. I do not think that I have ever seen such deadly paleness in a woman’s face. Her lips, too, were bloodless, but her eyes were flushed with crying. As she swept silently into the room she impressed me with a greater sense of grief than the banker had done in the morning, and it was the more striking in her as she was evidently a woman of strong character, with immense capacity for self-restraint. Disregarding my presence, she went straight to her uncle and passed her hand over his head with a sweet womanly caress.
“You have given orders that Arthur should be liberated, have you not, dad?” she asked.
“No, no, my girl, the matter must be probed to the bottom.”
“But I am so sure that he is innocent. You know what woman’s instincts are. I know that he has done no harm and that you will be sorry for having acted so harshly.”
“Why is he silent, then, if he is innocent?”
“Who knows? Perhaps because he was so angry that you should suspect him.”
“How could I help suspecting him, when I actually saw him with the coronet in his hand?”
“Oh, but he had only picked it up to look at it. Oh, do, do take my word for it that he is innocent. Let the matter drop and say no more. It is so dreadful to think of our dear Arthur in prison!”
“I shall never let it drop until the gems are found—never, Mary! Your affection for Arthur blinds you as to the awful consequences to me. Far from hushing the thing up, I have brought a gentleman down from London to inquire more deeply into it.”
“This gentleman?” she asked, facing round to me.
“No, his friend. He wished us to leave him alone. He is round in the stable lane now.”
“The stable lane?” She raised her dark eyebrows. “What can he hope to find there? Ah! this, I suppose, is he. I trust, sir, that you will succeed in proving, what I feel sure is the truth, that my cousin Arthur is innocent of this crime.”
“I fully share your opinion, and I trust, with you, that we may prove it,” returned Holmes, going back to the mat to knock the snow from his shoes. “I believe I have the honour of addressing Miss Mary Holder. Might I ask you a question or two?”
“Pray do, sir, if it may help to clear this horrible affair up.”
“You heard nothing yourself last night?”
“Nothing, until my uncle here began to speak loudly. I heard that, and I came down.”
“You shut up the windows and doors the night before. Did you fasten all the windows?”
“Yes.”
“Were they all fastened this morning?”
“Yes.”
“You have a maid who has a sweetheart? I think that you remarked to your uncle last night that she had been out to see him?”
“Yes, and she was the girl who waited in the drawing-room, and who may have heard uncle’s remarks about the coronet.”
“I see. You infer that she may have gone out to tell her sweetheart, and that the two may have planned the robbery.”
“But what is the good of all these vague theories,” cried the banker impatiently, “when I have told you that I saw Arthur with the coronet in his hands?”
“Wait a little, Mr. Holder. We must come back to that. About this girl, Miss Holder. You saw her return by the kitchen door, I presume?”
“Yes; when I went to see if the door was fastened for the night I met her slipping in. I saw the man, too, in the gloom.”
“Do you know him?”
“Oh, yes! he is the greengrocer who brings our vegetables round. His name is Francis Prosper.”
“He stood,” said Holmes, “to the left of the door—that is to say, farther up the path than is necessary to reach the door?”
“Yes, he did.”
“And he is a man with a wooden leg?”
Something like fear sprang up in the young lady’s expressive black eyes. “Why, you are like a magician,” said she. “How do you know that?” She smiled, but there was no answering smile in Holmes’ thin, eager face.
“I should be very glad now to go upstairs,” said he. “I shall probably wish to go over the outside of the house again. Perhaps I had better take a look at the lower windows before I go up.”
He walked swiftly round from one to the other, pausing only at the large one which looked from the hall onto the stable lane. This he opened and made a very careful examination of the sill with his powerful magnifying lens. “Now we shall go upstairs,” said he at last.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
A short railway journey and a shorter walk brought us to Fairbank, the modest residence of the great financier. It was a fine old house, standing in its own grounds, with a high wall and a heavy iron gate. As we approached, I observed that the place had a look of neglect and desolation, which was accentuated by the lowering sky and the chill wind that swept across the lawn. 

Holmes walked slowly round the house, his keen eyes taking in every detail, pausing now and then to examine the ground or to inspect some portion of the building. I could see that he was particularly interested in the tradesmen's path and the stable lane, which ran along the side of the house. Mr. Holder, the financier, and I waited in the hall, where the air was close and heavy with the scent of wax and old wood. 

Presently, a young lady entered the room. She was pale and very still, but there was a strength in her bearing which struck me at once. Her eyes were red with weeping, but her face was set and resolute. 

"This is my niece, Miss Mary Holder," said Mr. Holder, with a certain abruptness. 

She came forward and laid her hand gently on his shoulder. 

"Uncle," she said, in a low, trembling voice, "have they let Arthur out yet?" 

"Not yet, my child. The matter must be investigated fully before any action is taken," he replied. 

"But he is innocent! I know it in my heart. You must believe me, uncle. You must not let this go on. He is in prison, and it is killing him!" 

"I have my duty to perform, Mary. I have brought a gentleman from London to help me in this matter. He is a man of great skill and experience. I am determined to find the gems, and to see justice done." 

"That is Mr. Sherlock Holmes," I said, stepping forward. 

"Ah!" said Mary, with a faint smile. "Then perhaps he will be able to prove Arthur's innocence." 

"I hope so," said Holmes, with a quiet smile. "And now, Miss Holder, I should be obliged if you would answer a few questions for me." 

She sat down and listened attentively as he questioned her. She told him that she had heard nothing unusual until her uncle's voice had risen in anger, and that she had come down at once. She confirmed that all the windows had been fastened the previous night and were still fastened in the morning. 

"You mentioned a maid, Miss Holder, who had a sweetheart?" 

"Yes, Lucy Parr. I saw her return last night. She was in the drawing-room, and I believe she may have overheard something about the coronet." 

"Ah!" said Holmes. "And who is this Lucy Parr?" 

"She is the maid in the drawing-room. She is young and pretty, and I believe she is in love with a certain Francis Prosper, the greengrocer." 

"And you saw her return last night?" 

"Yes, I met her slipping in by the kitchen door. There was a man waiting outside." 

"And you know who this man was?" 

"Yes. It was Francis Prosper." 

"And where did he stand?" 

"By the wall, near the corner of the house. I could see his face clearly. He had a wooden leg." 

"Ah!" said Holmes, with a satisfied nod. "That is very interesting. I believe I shall examine the lower windows before we go upstairs. I should like to see the sill of the large hall window which overlooks the stable lane." 

He walked quickly to the window and examined the sill with his magnifying lens, his brow furrowed in thought. I could see that he was making some important observation, though I could not yet fathom its significance."}
