IMPROVEMENT GUIDANCE:
1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion only includes the opening phrase and omits the entire remainder of the passage, including all dialogue, narrative description, and character actions.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The completion lacks all subsequent dialogue between the two main characters, including their exchange about the nature of the records and the discussion of sensationalism versus logic.
- There is no mention of the setting, such as the time of day, the weather, or the physical environment in which the conversation takes place.
- The completion does not include any description of character actions, such as handling objects or engaging in specific habits.
- The reflective commentary and the emotional responses of the characters are entirely absent.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- There are no invented elements in the completion, but the absence of nearly all content results in a highly incomplete and unrepresentative version of the original passage.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
To the man who loves art for its own sake,” remarked Sherlock Holmes, tossing aside the advertisement sheet of The Daily Telegraph, “it is frequently in its least important and lowliest manifestations that the keenest pleasure is to be derived. I find it in the curl of a smoke, the pattern of a footprint in the dust, or the peculiar twist of a hand in a letter. These are the little things, the trifles, which are the very soul of crime. They are the silent witnesses, the unerring pointers to the truth.”

His companion, Dr. Watson, looked up from his book with a smile. “You mean, then, that the grand and dramatic are of little interest to you?”

“Indeed, they are of none,” Holmes replied, lighting a cigarette with a practiced flick of his fingers. “The sensational is often the most deceptive. It is the quiet, the unassuming, that reveals the real story. The man who commits a crime with a flourish is usually the one who is careless. The man who does it quietly, with no fuss, is the one who has thought it through. He is the one who is dangerous.”

Watson chuckled. “You are a most singular man, Holmes. I have known many detectives, but none who would rather study a footprint than a bloodstained dagger.”

“Precisely,” said Holmes, his eyes gleaming with the light of a man who had just made a discovery. “The dagger is a weapon, but the footprint is a message. It tells me where the man walked, how he walked, and perhaps even what he was thinking as he walked. It is a language of its own, and I have learned to read it well.”

He rose from his chair and began to pace the room, his long, lean figure casting a shadow on the wall. “You see, Watson, the world is full of clues. They are all around us, waiting to be noticed. The trick is not in the noticing, but in the interpreting. That is where the art lies.”

Watson leaned back in his chair, watching his friend with admiration. “And yet, for all your art, you remain a man of science. You are not a poet, nor a dreamer. You are a logician, a man of reason.”

Holmes smiled. “Perhaps. But even reason has its poetry. The poetry of the mind, the poetry of deduction. It is a poetry that does not rhyme, but it is no less beautiful for that.”

He paused, then added, “And it is a poetry that, when properly understood, can solve the most baffling of mysteries.”

events.title: Arrival of Violet Hunter and a Seemingly Trivial Case
detailed_summary: Holmes concedes that many of the cases Watson chronicled were not technically crimes, citing examples like the King of Bohemia and Mary Sutherland.
He worries that in avoiding sensationalism, Watson might verge on the trivial.
Watson defends the novelty and interest of Holmes's methods, regardless of the outcome.
Holmes laments the decline of criminal enterprise and originality, feeling his practice is degenerating.
He presents a letter from a Miss Violet Hunter seeking consultation about a governess position as the epitome of his current trivial caseload.
As Holmes finishes reading, the doorbell rings, signaling Miss Hunter's arrival precisely at the appointed time.
Watson suggests the case might be more interesting than it appears, referencing the Blue Carbuncle affair.
Holmes remains skeptical but acknowledges they will soon know more as the young lady enters.

events.text_segment:
“At the same time,” he remarked after a pause, during which he had sat puffing at his long pipe and gazing down into the fire, “you can hardly be open to a charge of sensationalism, for out of these cases which you have been so kind as to interest yourself in, a fair proportion do not treat of crime, in its legal sense, at all. The small matter in which I endeavoured to help the King of Bohemia, the singular experience of Miss Mary Sutherland, the problem connected with the man with the twisted lip, and the incident of the noble bachelor, were all matters which are outside the pale of the law. But in avoiding the sensational, I fear that you may have bordered on the trivial.”
“The end may have been so,” I answered, “but the methods I hold to have been novel and of interest.”
“Pshaw, my dear fellow, what do the public, the great unobservant public, who could hardly tell a weaver by his tooth or a compositor by his left thumb, care about the finer shades of analysis and deduction! But, indeed, if you are trivial, I cannot blame you, for the days of the great cases are past. Man, or at least criminal man, has lost all enterprise and originality. As to my own little practice, it seems to be degenerating into an agency for recovering lost lead pencils and giving advice to young ladies from boarding-schools. I think that I have touched bottom at last, however. This note I had this morning marks my zero-point, I fancy. Read it!” He tossed a crumpled letter across to me.
It was dated from Montague Place upon the preceding evening, and ran thus:
“DEAR MR. HOLMES,—I am very anxious to consult you as to whether I should or should not accept a situation which has been offered to me as governess. I shall call at half-past ten to-morrow if I do not inconvenience you. Yours faithfully,
“VIOLET HUNTER.”
“Do you know the young lady?” I asked.
“Not I.”
“It is half-past ten now.”
“Yes, and I have no doubt that is her ring.”
“It may turn out to be of more interest than you think. You remember that the affair of the blue carbuncle, which appeared to be a mere whim at first, developed into a serious investigation. It may be so in this case, also.”
“Well, let us hope so. But our doubts will very soon be solved, for here, unless I am much mistaken, is the person in question.”
As he spoke the door opened and a young lady entered the room.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: At the same time,” he remarked after a pause, during which he had sat puffing at his long pipe and gazing down into the fire, “you can hardly be open to a charge of sensationalism, for out of these cases which you have been so kind as to interest yourself in, a fair proportion do not treat of crime, in its legal sense, at all. There are many, for instance, which are concerned with the detection of fraud, or the tracing of missing persons, or the solution of mysteries which, while not involving the law, are none the less interesting and instructive. I have had occasion to deal with the case of a man who was believed to have been poisoned, but who was really suffering from a rare form of disease; another in which a supposed murder turned out to be a case of self-defense; and a third where the disappearance of a young lady was due to a misunderstanding between her and her family. In each of these instances, the application of a logical and methodical mind was of the greatest assistance, and the results were of considerable value to those concerned. I have also been called upon to assist in the detection of forgeries, the tracing of stolen property, and the unmasking of impostors. These are not, perhaps, the most dramatic of my cases, but they are none the less important, and they illustrate the fact that the methods of observation and deduction which I employ are of wide application. It is not merely in the detection of crime that they are of use, but in the solution of all sorts of problems which may arise in the course of daily life. I have always held that the world is full of interest for those who have the patience to look for it, and that the most commonplace events may, when examined closely, reveal a surprising amount of complexity. It is this which has made my profession so attractive to me, and I have no doubt that it will do the same for you, should you ever find yourself in a position to observe the world with the same degree of attention and care.”

events.title: Violet Hunter Recounts a Strange Job Offer
detailed_summary: Miss Violet Hunter, described as plainly dressed but bright and brisk, introduces herself.
She explains she needs advice due to a strange experience and lack of family.
Holmes appears impressed and prepares to listen intently.
Miss Hunter recounts her background as a governess and her recent unemployment.
She describes visiting Westaway's agency and encountering Miss Stoper with a very stout, genial man (later identified as Jephro Rucastle).
The man enthusiastically declared her suitable for a position upon seeing her.
He offers her a governess position with a salary of £100 a year, significantly higher than her previous £4 a month, citing the importance of her ladylike bearing.
He offers half the salary in advance, further impressing the destitute Miss Hunter.
Despite the tempting offer, she feels uneasy and inquires about the location (The Copper Beeches, Hampshire) and duties (caring for one six-year-old child).
Rucastle mentions the child's disturbing amusement of killing cockroaches but laughs it off.

He adds a condition: she must obey his wife's 'little commands,' including potentially wearing specific dresses, sitting in certain places, or, astonishingly, cutting her distinctively long chestnut hair short.
Miss Hunter refuses to cut her hair, seeing it as artistic.
Rucastle insists it's essential due to his wife's 'fancy,' and withdraws the offer upon her firm refusal.
Miss Stoper expresses annoyance, implying Miss Hunter cost her a commission, and dismisses her curtly.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She struck a gong upon the table, and I was shown out by the page.

events.text_segment:
She was plainly but neatly dressed, with a bright, quick face, freckled like a plover’s egg, and with the brisk manner of a woman who has had her own way to make in the world.
“You will excuse my troubling you, I am sure,” said she, as my companion rose to greet her, “but I have had a very strange experience, and as I have no parents or relations of any sort from whom I could ask advice, I thought that perhaps you would be kind enough to tell me what I should do.”
“Pray take a seat, Miss Hunter. I shall be happy to do anything that I can to serve you.”
I could see that Holmes was favourably impressed by the manner and speech of his new client. He looked her over in his searching fashion, and then composed himself, with his lids drooping and his finger-tips together, to listen to her story.
“I have been a governess for five years,” said she, “in the family of Colonel Spence Munro, but two months ago the colonel received an appointment at Halifax, in Nova Scotia, and took his children over to America with him, so that I found myself without a situation. I advertised, and I answered advertisements, but without success. At last the little money which I had saved began to run short, and I was at my wit’s end as to what I should do.
“There is a well-known agency for governesses in the West End called Westaway’s, and there I used to call about once a week in order to see whether anything had turned up which might suit me. Westaway was the name of the founder of the business, but it is really managed by Miss Stoper. She sits in her own little office, and the ladies who are seeking employment wait in an anteroom, and are then shown in one by one, when she consults her ledgers and sees whether she has anything which would suit them.
“Well, when I called last week I was shown into the little office as usual, but I found that Miss Stoper was not alone. A prodigiously stout man with a very smiling face and a great heavy chin which rolled down in fold upon fold over his throat sat at her elbow with a pair of glasses on his nose, looking very earnestly at the ladies who entered. As I came in he gave quite a jump in his chair and turned quickly to Miss Stoper.
“‘That will do,’ said he; ‘I could not ask for anything better. Capital! capital!’ He seemed quite enthusiastic and rubbed his hands together in the most genial fashion. He was such a comfortable-looking man that it was quite a pleasure to look at him.
“‘You are looking for a situation, miss?’ he asked.
“‘Yes, sir.’
“‘As governess?’
“‘Yes, sir.’
“‘And what salary do you ask?’
“‘I had £ 4 a month in my last place with Colonel Spence Munro.’
“‘Oh, tut, tut! sweating—rank sweating!’ he cried, throwing his fat hands out into the air like a man who is in a boiling passion. ‘How could anyone offer so pitiful a sum to a lady with such attractions and accomplishments?’
“‘My accomplishments, sir, may be less than you imagine,’ said I. ‘A little French, a little German, music, and drawing—’
“‘Tut, tut!’ he cried. ‘This is all quite beside the question. The point is, have you or have you not the bearing and deportment of a lady? There it is in a nutshell. If you have not, you are not fitted for the rearing of a child who may some day play a considerable part in the history of the country. But if you have, why, then, how could any gentleman ask you to condescend to accept anything under the three figures? Your salary with me, madam, would commence at £ 100 a year.’
“You may imagine, Mr. Holmes, that to me, destitute as I was, such an offer seemed almost too good to be true. The gentleman, however, seeing perhaps the look of incredulity upon my face, opened a pocket-book and took out a note.
“‘It is also my custom,’ said he, smiling in the most pleasant fashion until his eyes were just two little shining slits amid the white creases of his face, ‘to advance to my young ladies half their salary beforehand, so that they may meet any little expenses of their journey and their wardrobe.’
“It seemed to me that I had never met so fascinating and so thoughtful a man. As I was already in debt to my tradesmen, the advance was a great convenience, and yet there was something unnatural about the whole transaction which made me wish to know a little more before I quite committed myself.
“‘May I ask where you live, sir?’ said I.
“‘Hampshire. Charming rural place. The Copper Beeches, five miles on the far side of Winchester. It is the most lovely country, my dear young lady, and the dearest old country-house.’
“‘And my duties, sir? I should be glad to know what they would be.’
“‘One child—one dear little romper just six years old. Oh, if you could see him killing cockroaches with a slipper! Smack! smack! smack! Three gone before you could wink!’ He leaned back in his chair and laughed his eyes into his head again.
“I was a little startled at the nature of the child’s amusement, but the father’s laughter made me think that perhaps he was joking.
“‘My sole duties, then,’ I asked, ‘are to take charge of a single child?’
“‘No, no, not the sole, not the sole, my dear young lady,’ he cried. ‘Your duty would be, as I am sure your good sense would suggest, to obey any little commands my wife might give, provided always that they were such commands as a lady might with propriety obey. You see no difficulty, heh?’
“‘I should be happy to make myself useful.’
“‘Quite so. In dress now, for example. We are faddy people, you know—faddy but kind-hearted. If you were asked to wear any dress which we might give you, you would not object to our little whim. Heh?’
“‘No,’ said I, considerably astonished at his words.
“‘Or to sit here, or sit there, that would not be offensive to you?’
“‘Oh, no.’
“‘Or to cut your hair quite short before you come to us?’
“I could hardly believe my ears. As you may observe, Mr. Holmes, my hair is somewhat luxuriant, and of a rather peculiar tint of chestnut. It has been considered artistic. I could not dream of sacrificing it in this offhand fashion.
“‘I am afraid that that is quite impossible,’ said I. He had been watching me eagerly out of his small eyes, and I could see a shadow pass over his face as I spoke.
“‘I am afraid that it is quite essential,’ said he. ‘It is a little fancy of my wife’s, and ladies’ fancies, you know, madam, ladies’ fancies must be consulted. And so you won’t cut your hair?’
“‘No, sir, I really could not,’ I answered firmly.
“‘Ah, very well; then that quite settles the matter. It is a pity, because in other respects you would really have done very nicely. In that case, Miss Stoper, I had best inspect a few more of your young ladies.’
“The manageress had sat all this while busy with her papers without a word to either of us, but she glanced at me now with so much annoyance upon her face that I could not help suspecting that she had lost a handsome commission through my refusal.
“‘Do you desire your name to be kept upon the books?’ she asked.
“‘If you please, Miss Stoper.’
“‘Well, really, it seems rather useless, since you refuse the most excellent offers in this fashion,’ said she sharply. ‘You can hardly expect us to exert ourselves to find another such opening for you. Good-day to you, Miss Hunter.’ She struck a gong upon the table, and I was shown out by the page.

She was plainly but neatly dressed, with a bright, quick face, freckled like a plover’s egg, and with the brisk manner of a woman who has had her own way to make in the world. “I have come to you, Mr. Holmes,” she said, “because I am in a very difficult position, and I have no one to advise me. I have had a most extraordinary experience, and I do not know what to make of it.”

Holmes leaned forward with the keenest interest. “Pray sit down, Miss Hunter,” said he. “I am much obliged to you for calling. I trust that your experience may not be quite so extraordinary as you imagine, though I confess that your manner of speaking of it gives me some hope that we may find a rational explanation.”

Miss Hunter seated herself, and I observed that her hands were very red and chapped, as though she had been accustomed to hard work. “I am a governess,” she said, “and I have been out of employment for some time. I had a small private school in the country, but it broke up, and I have been trying to get a situation ever since. I was in a very bad way when I heard of this, and I thought I would try it, though it seemed to me at the time that it was too good to be true.”

“Pray tell me all about it,” said Holmes.

events.title: Miss Hunter Accepts and Holmes Promises Support
detailed_summary: Back at her lodgings and facing financial hardship, Miss Hunter begins to regret refusing the lucrative offer, rationalizing that the eccentricities might be worth the pay.
Just as she considers returning to the agency, she receives a letter from Mr. Rucastle.
He writes from The Copper Beeches, stating his wife is keen for her to come based on his description.
He increases the salary offer to £120 a year (£30 per quarter) to compensate for the 'fads'.

He elaborates on the conditions: wearing an electric blue dress (belonging to his absent daughter Alice), sitting where requested, and reiterates the necessity of cutting her hair, hoping the increased salary makes it acceptable.
He assures her the duties regarding the child are light and asks her to inform him of her train arrival time in Winchester.
Miss Hunter tells Holmes she has decided to accept the position but wanted his input first.
Holmes notes that her decision settles the matter but admits he wouldn't want a sister of his taking such a job.
Miss Hunter asks for Holmes's interpretation, but he states he lacks sufficient data.
She proposes her own theory: Mrs. Rucastle might be mentally unstable, and Mr. Rucastle humors her strange requests to avoid her institutionalization.
Holmes concedes this is the most probable explanation given the facts, but still finds the household unsuitable.
Miss Hunter emphasizes the high salary, which Holmes agrees is suspiciously good, suggesting a strong hidden reason.
She expresses her desire for Holmes's potential future assistance, feeling stronger knowing he's aware of the situation.
Holmes assures her of his support, finding the case features novel and interesting, promising to come immediately if she telegrams day or night.
Relieved, Miss Hunter departs, planning to sacrifice her hair and travel to Winchester the next day.
Watson remarks on her capability, while Holmes gravely predicts they will hear from her soon.

events.text_segment:
“Well, Mr. Holmes, when I got back to my lodgings and found little enough in the cupboard, and two or three bills upon the table, I began to ask myself whether I had not done a very foolish thing. After all, if these people had strange fads and expected obedience on the most extraordinary matters, they were at least ready to pay for their eccentricity. Very few governesses in England are getting £ 100 a year. Besides, what use was my hair to me? Many people are improved by wearing it short and perhaps I should be among the number. Next day I was inclined to think that I had made a mistake, and by the day after I was sure of it. I had almost overcome my pride so far as to go back to the agency and inquire whether the place was still open when I received this letter from the gentleman himself. I have it here and I will read it to you:
“‘The Copper Beeches, near Winchester.
“‘DEAR MISS HUNTER,—Miss Stoper has very kindly given me your address, and I write from here to ask you whether you have reconsidered your decision. My wife is very anxious that you should come, for she has been much attracted by my description of you. We are willing to give £ 30 a quarter, or £ 120 a year, so as to recompense you for any little inconvenience which our fads may cause you. They are not very exacting, after all. My wife is fond of a particular shade of electric blue and would like you to wear such a dress indoors in the morning. You need not, however, go to the expense of purchasing one, as we have one belonging to my dear daughter Alice (now in Philadelphia), which would, I should think, fit you very well. Then, as to sitting here or there, or amusing yourself in any manner indicated, that need cause you no inconvenience. As regards your hair, it is no doubt a pity, especially as I could not help remarking its beauty during our short interview, but I am afraid that I must remain firm upon this point, and I only hope that the increased salary may recompense you for the loss. Your duties, as far as the child is concerned, are very light. Now do try to come, and I shall meet you with the dog-cart at Winchester. Let me know your train. Yours faithfully,
“‘JEPHRO RUCASTLE.’
“That is the letter which I have just received, Mr. Holmes, and my mind is made up that I will accept it. I thought, however, that before taking the final step I should like to submit the whole matter to your consideration.”
“Well, Miss Hunter, if your mind is made up, that settles the question,” said Holmes, smiling.
“But you would not advise me to refuse?”
“I confess that it is not the situation which I should like to see a sister of mine apply for.”
“What is the meaning of it all, Mr. Holmes?”
“Ah, I have no data. I cannot tell. Perhaps you have yourself formed some opinion?”
“Well, there seems to me to be only one possible solution. Mr. Rucastle seemed to be a very kind, good-natured man. Is it not possible that his wife is a lunatic, that he desires to keep the matter quiet for fear she should be taken to an asylum, and that he humours her fancies in every way in order to prevent an outbreak?”
“That is a possible solution—in fact, as matters stand, it is the most probable one. But in any case it does not seem to be a nice household for a young lady.”
“But the money, Mr. Holmes, the money!”
“Well, yes, of course the pay is good—too good. That is what makes me uneasy. Why should they give you £ 120 a year, when they could have their pick for £ 40? There must be some strong reason behind.”
“I thought that if I told you the circumstances you would understand afterwards if I wanted your help. I should feel so much stronger if I felt that you were at the back of me.”
“Oh, you may carry that feeling away with you. I assure you that your little problem promises to be the most interesting which has come my way for some months. There is something distinctly novel about some of the features. If you should find yourself in doubt or in danger—”
“Danger! What danger do you foresee?”
Holmes shook his head gravely. “It would cease to be a danger if we could define it,” said he. “But at any time, day or night, a telegram would bring me down to your help.”
“That is enough.” She rose briskly from her chair with the anxiety all swept from her face. “I shall go down to Hampshire quite easy in my mind now. I shall write to Mr. Rucastle at once, sacrifice my poor hair to-night, and start for Winchester to-morrow.” With a few grateful words to Holmes she bade us both good-night and bustled off upon her way.
“At least,” said I as we heard her quick, firm steps descending the stairs, “she seems to be a young lady who is very well able to take care of herself.”
“And she would need to be,” said Holmes gravely. “I am much mistaken if we do not hear from her before many days are past.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Well, Mr. Holmes, when I got back to my lodgings and found little enough in the cupboard, and two or three bills upon the table, I began to ask myself whether I had not done a very foolish thing. The salary which I had refused was a very handsome one, and I had no doubt that the eccentricities of the Rucastle household were not so great as to outweigh the advantages of the position. I had already made up my mind to return to the agency and to reconsider the matter, when a letter arrived from Mr. Rucastle himself.

He wrote from The Copper Beeches, and told me that his wife had taken a great fancy to me from his description, and that she would be very glad to have me as a governess. He had increased the salary to £120 a year, and he was now prepared to allow me to wear my own clothes, except for one condition—that I should wear an electric blue dress, which, he explained, belonged to his absent daughter Alice. He also insisted that I should sit where he requested, and he repeated his demand that I should cut my hair. He assured me that the duties regarding the child were light, and he asked me to inform him of the time of my arrival in Winchester.

I read the letter to Mr. Holmes, and told him that I had decided to accept the position, but I had thought it right to consult him first. He nodded gravely, and said that my decision settled the matter, though he would not have wished a sister of his to take such a post. I asked him if he could not give me some idea of what was behind these strange conditions. He shook his head, and said that he had not sufficient data. I suggested that Mrs. Rucastle might be a little unbalanced, and that her husband was humouring her whims to avoid a more serious outcome. Holmes admitted that this was the most probable explanation, but he still looked upon the household as a very unsuitable one. I reminded him of the high salary, and he agreed that it was suspiciously good, and that there must be some strong reason behind it. I told him that I should feel stronger in the position if I knew that he was aware of my situation, and he assured me that he would come at once if I sent him a telegram, day or night. With this promise, I left him, and I set out the next morning for Winchester, resolved to sacrifice my hair and to see what the strange household of The Copper Beeches might hold in store for me. Dr. Watson, who had listened to the whole conversation, remarked that I was a woman of spirit, and that I should do well in any position. Holmes, however, looked grave, and said that he had a feeling that we should hear from me very soon.

events.title: Urgent Summons and Journey to Winchester
detailed_summary: A fortnight passes, during which Watson often thinks about Miss Hunter and the abnormal circumstances of her employment.
Holmes remains preoccupied but refuses to speculate without more data, though he reiterates his disapproval of the situation.
Late one night, as Watson considers retiring and Holmes begins a chemical experiment, a telegram arrives.
Holmes reads it and tosses it to Watson, telling him to look up train times.
The telegram from Miss Hunter is brief and urgent, requesting their presence at the Black Swan Hotel in Winchester the next day, stating she is at her wit's end.
Holmes asks Watson if he will accompany him, and Watson agrees.
Watson finds a suitable train arriving in Winchester at 11:30 AM.
Holmes decides to postpone his chemical analysis to be fresh for the case.
The next day, they travel towards Winchester.
Holmes reads papers initially, then admires the spring scenery after crossing the Hampshire border.
Watson expresses delight at the beautiful countryside.
Holmes responds gravely, stating his mind forces him to see only isolation and the potential for crime in such scattered houses.
He argues that crime is more rampant and hidden in the beautiful countryside than in London's worst alleys, due to the lack of public opinion pressure and distance from law enforcement.
He believes the danger lies in the isolation of the country house, not Winchester itself, but notes Miss Hunter is not personally threatened as she can travel to meet them.
Holmes reveals he has devised seven possible explanations for the situation but needs Miss Hunter's information to determine the correct one.
They approach Winchester, spotting the cathedral tower.

events.text_segment:
It was not very long before my friend’s prediction was fulfilled. A fortnight went by, during which I frequently found my thoughts turning in her direction and wondering what strange side-alley of human experience this lonely woman had strayed into. The unusual salary, the curious conditions, the light duties, all pointed to something abnormal, though whether a fad or a plot, or whether the man were a philanthropist or a villain, it was quite beyond my powers to determine. As to Holmes, I observed that he sat frequently for half an hour on end, with knitted brows and an abstracted air, but he swept the matter away with a wave of his hand when I mentioned it. “Data! data! data!” he cried impatiently. “I can’t make bricks without clay.” And yet he would always wind up by muttering that no sister of his should ever have accepted such a situation.
The telegram which we eventually received came late one night just as I was thinking of turning in and Holmes was settling down to one of those all-night chemical researches which he frequently indulged in, when I would leave him stooping over a retort and a test-tube at night and find him in the same position when I came down to breakfast in the morning. He opened the yellow envelope, and then, glancing at the message, threw it across to me.
“Just look up the trains in Bradshaw,” said he, and turned back to his chemical studies.
The summons was a brief and urgent one.
“Please be at the Black Swan Hotel at Winchester at midday to-morrow,” it said. “Do come! I am at my wit’s end.
“HUNTER.”
“Will you come with me?” asked Holmes, glancing up.
“I should wish to.”
“Just look it up, then.”
“There is a train at half-past nine,” said I, glancing over my Bradshaw. “It is due at Winchester at 11:30.”
“That will do very nicely. Then perhaps I had better postpone my analysis of the acetones, as we may need to be at our best in the morning.”
By eleven o’clock the next day we were well upon our way to the old English capital. Holmes had been buried in the morning papers all the way down, but after we had passed the Hampshire border he threw them down and began to admire the scenery. It was an ideal spring day, a light blue sky, flecked with little fleecy white clouds drifting across from west to east. The sun was shining very brightly, and yet there was an exhilarating nip in the air, which set an edge to a man’s energy. All over the countryside, away to the rolling hills around Aldershot, the little red and grey roofs of the farm-steadings peeped out from amid the light green of the new foliage.
“Are they not fresh and beautiful?” I cried with all the enthusiasm of a man fresh from the fogs of Baker Street.
But Holmes shook his head gravely.
“Do you know, Watson,” said he, “that it is one of the curses of a mind with a turn like mine that I must look at everything with reference to my own special subject. You look at these scattered houses, and you are impressed by their beauty. I look at them, and the only thought which comes to me is a feeling of their isolation and of the impunity with which crime may be committed there.”
“Good heavens!” I cried. “Who would associate crime with these dear old homesteads?”
“They always fill me with a certain horror. It is my belief, Watson, founded upon my experience, that the lowest and vilest alleys in London do not present a more dreadful record of sin than does the smiling and beautiful countryside.”
“You horrify me!”
“But the reason is very obvious. The pressure of public opinion can do in the town what the law cannot accomplish. There is no lane so vile that the scream of a tortured child, or the thud of a drunkard’s blow, does not beget sympathy and indignation among the neighbours, and then the whole machinery of justice is ever so close that a word of complaint can set it going, and there is but a step between the crime and the dock. But look at these lonely houses, each in its own fields, filled for the most part with poor ignorant folk who know little of the law. Think of the deeds of hellish cruelty, the hidden wickedness which may go on, year in, year out, in such places, and none the wiser. Had this lady who appeals to us for help gone to live in Winchester, I should never have had a fear for her. It is the five miles of country which makes the danger. Still, it is clear that she is not personally threatened.”
“No. If she can come to Winchester to meet us she can get away.”
“Quite so. She has her freedom.”
“What can be the matter, then? Can you suggest no explanation?”
“I have devised seven separate explanations, each of which would cover the facts as far as we know them. But which of these is correct can only be determined by the fresh information which we shall no doubt find waiting for us. Well, there is the tower of the cathedral, and we shall soon learn all that Miss Hunter has to tell.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
It was not very long before my friend’s prediction was fulfilled. A fortnight passed, during which I found myself constantly revolving in my mind the strange circumstances of Miss Hunter’s employment and the singular manner in which she had spoken of her position. Sherlock Holmes, on his part, was silent and preoccupied, though I could see that his keen eyes were following every detail of the case with the closest attention. He would not, however, commit himself to any opinion until he had more definite data to work upon, and he was still in the attitude of a man who is waiting for the final piece of a puzzle before he can complete the picture.

One evening, as I was about to turn in, I found him seated at his table, bent over a test-tube, with a look of intense concentration upon his features. The lamp had been lit, and the room was in its usual state of disorder, with papers and chemicals scattered about in the most chaotic fashion. As I passed the door, he looked up and handed me a telegram with a nod.

"Look up the train times, Watson," he said. "We may find ourselves in Winchester to-morrow."

I took the telegram and glanced at it. It was from Miss Hunter, and it was brief and urgent. It read: 

"Come at once. I am at the Black Swan Hotel, Winchester. I am at my wit’s end."

"Well, what do you think of that?" I asked, as I handed it back to him.

"I think that Miss Hunter is in a very serious position," he answered gravely. "And I think that we had better start at once."

"Shall I accompany you?"

"By all means."

I looked up the train times and found that there was a train at ten minutes to eleven which would bring us to Winchester by half-past eleven the next day. Holmes, who had been about to proceed with his experiment, now put it aside with a shrug of his shoulders.

"We will leave it for to-morrow," he said. "It is not so urgent as this business of the copper beeches."

The next morning we were off, and by the time we had crossed the Hampshire border the sun was shining brightly, and the spring scenery was at its most charming. The fields were green, the hedges were in bloom, and the air was full of the scent of the early flowers. I looked out of the window with delight, but my companion, who had been reading the morning papers, now laid them aside and gazed out with a thoughtful and rather sombre expression.

"You seem to be enjoying the view," I remarked.

"I am not blind to its beauty," he answered, "but I cannot help seeing in it the conditions which are most favourable to crime."

"You mean the isolation of the country houses?"

"Precisely. The scattered dwellings, the long distances between them, the absence of any public opinion to check the doings of the inhabitants—these are the very things which make the English countryside a hotbed of crime."

"But surely the country is not so dangerous as the city?"

"Not in the open streets, perhaps, but in the drawing-rooms and dining-rooms of the country houses, where the crime is hidden and the criminals are respected members of society."

"But Miss Hunter is not in danger, is she?"

"Not personally, no. She is able to travel to meet us, which is a good sign."

"And what do you think is the cause of her trouble?"

"I have seven possible explanations," he said, "but I shall not commit myself until I have heard Miss Hunter’s story."

We were now approaching Winchester, and the great cathedral tower rose before us, a noble and stately structure against the morning sky.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
It was not very long before my friend’s prediction was fulfilled. One evening, as I sat in our lodgings at 221B Baker Street, the sound of the hansom cab drew near, and a figure stepped into the room, cloaked and weary. It was Inspector Lestrade, his face drawn with concern. He had come with a case that, he claimed, was beyond the reach of Scotland Yard. My friend, reclining in his chair with a pipe in hand, listened with the keen interest that always marked his attention to the unusual. The case, as it turned out, was one of the most singular and perplexing I have ever had the privilege of observing.

The matter concerned a wealthy industrialist, Mr. Jonathan Harcourt, whose private study had been ransacked in the dead of night. Nothing of value had been taken, but a single sheet of paper, bearing a cryptic message, had been left behind. The police were baffled. The room had been locked from the inside, the windows were bolted, and the only other person in the house was the butler, who had been found fast asleep in his quarters. Lestrade had examined the scene with his usual diligence, but the mystery remained unsolved. He had heard of my friend’s methods and had come to seek his assistance.

Holmes, with his characteristic alacrity, was soon on the case. He visited the Harcourt estate the following morning, accompanied by myself. The study was a modest room, lined with bookshelves and a heavy oak desk. The lock on the door was intact, the windows undisturbed. The only clue was the note, which read: “The truth lies in the silence.” Holmes examined the paper with his magnifying glass, then turned to the butler, a man named Thomas Granger, who had been with the family for over twenty years. He questioned him at length, but the butler swore he had heard nothing unusual during the night.

Holmes, however, was not convinced. He spent the evening in the study, pacing the room, inspecting the furniture, and even testing the floorboards with a small hammer. At one point, he paused before a bookshelf and ran his fingers along the spines of the books. “This one,” he said, pulling out a volume of Shakespeare. The book was hollowed out, and inside was a small compartment containing a key. “Ah,” he murmured, “the truth does lie in the silence.”

The key, as it turned out, opened a hidden drawer in the desk. Inside was a letter from Mr. Harcourt to his son, revealing a long-buried family secret. The letter had been written in haste and concealed for fear of scandal. The ransacking of the study had been a ruse, a way to draw attention away from the true purpose of the intruder’s visit. Holmes deduced that the intruder had been a relative of the Harcourt family, someone who had learned of the letter and wished to retrieve it. The butler, though loyal, had been bribed to feign ignorance.

The next morning, Holmes returned to the estate with the letter in hand. He confronted the intruder, a distant cousin named Evelyn Harcourt, who had been living in obscurity in London. She had learned of the letter through a chance conversation and had decided to act. Holmes, with his usual tact, allowed her to return the letter without further legal consequences, on the condition that she leave the estate and never return. Mr. Harcourt, upon reading the letter, was deeply moved. He had not seen his son in years and had no idea of the depth of his father’s regret. The letter was a plea for reconciliation, and it was accepted with open arms.

As we returned to Baker Street, I could not help but admire the brilliance of my friend’s deductions. He had solved a mystery that had eluded the best minds of Scotland Yard, and in doing so, had brought about a reconciliation that might have otherwise been impossible. “It is the little things,” he said, lighting his pipe, “that often lead to the greatest truths. The truth lies in the silence, my dear Watson, and it is our duty to listen closely.”

And so, another case was closed, another mystery unraveled. The world, as always, was full of secrets, and my friend Sherlock Holmes was the one man who could see through them all. It was not very long before my friend’s prediction was fulfilled, and I found myself once again in the company of the greatest detective of our time, ready for whatever new adventure might come our way.

events.title: Miss Hunter Recounts Strange Experiences at Copper Beeches
detailed_summary: Holmes and Watson find Miss Hunter waiting at the Black Swan Hotel in Winchester with lunch prepared.
She expresses immense relief at their arrival, needing their invaluable advice.
She must recount her story quickly as she needs to return to Copper Beeches by three.
Holmes settles in to listen.
Miss Hunter clarifies she hasn't suffered actual ill-treatment but finds the Rucastles incomprehensible and unsettling.
She describes Copper Beeches: large, square, damp-stained, surrounded by woods and a field sloping to the road.
She confirms Mrs. Rucastle is not mad, but a pale, silent woman younger than her husband, passionately devoted to him and their son.
Miss Hunter senses a secret sorrow in Mrs. Rucastle, having seen her in tears.
She describes the child as spoiled, ill-natured, disproportionately large-headed, alternating between rage and sulking, and delighting in cruelty to weaker creatures.
Holmes encourages her to include all details, relevant or not.
Miss Hunter describes the unpleasant servants, Toller (rough, often drunk) and his wife (tall, strong, sour, silent).
After two quiet days, Mrs. Rucastle prompted her husband, who then asked Miss Hunter to wear the provided electric blue dress.
The dress fit perfectly but showed signs of previous wear.
The Rucastles expressed exaggerated delight and had her sit in a specific chair in the drawing-room, facing away from the central window.
Mr. Rucastle told her funny stories for an hour, making her laugh heartily while Mrs. Rucastle remained sad and anxious.
Two days later, the performance was repeated, ending with her reading aloud from a novel for ten minutes before being abruptly told to stop.
Consumed with curiosity about what was happening outside the window, Miss Hunter concealed a piece of broken mirror in her handkerchief.
During the next 'performance,' she used the mirror while pretending to laugh and saw a small, bearded man in grey leaning on the railings by the road, looking towards the house.
She noticed Mrs. Rucastle watching her intently and believed her mirror trick was discovered.
Mrs. Rucastle pointed out the 'impertinent' man to her husband.
Mr. Rucastle asked Miss Hunter to motion the man away; she complied, and Mrs. Rucastle immediately drew the blind.
This was a week ago; she hasn't worn the dress or sat in the window since, nor seen the man.

Miss Hunter mentions another strange incident: Mr. Rucastle showing her Carlo, the large, fierce mastiff kept chained near the kitchen, warning her never to go out at night as Toller lets it loose, fed minimally to keep it keen.
She confirms the danger, having seen the huge dog prowling the moonlit lawn one night.
She recounts discovering a locked drawer in her room, opening it with one of her keys.
Inside, she found a coil of chestnut hair identical to her own distinctive hair.
Checking her trunk, she found her own cut hair still there, confirming the discovered coil was not hers.
Puzzled and unable to understand, she returned the strange hair to the drawer and said nothing.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Black Swan is an inn of repute in the High Street, at no distance from the station, and there we found the young lady waiting for us.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I returned the strange hair to the drawer, and I said nothing of the matter to the Rucastles as I felt that I had put myself in the wrong by opening a drawer which they had locked.

events.text_segment:
The Black Swan is an inn of repute in the High Street, at no distance from the station, and there we found the young lady waiting for us. She had engaged a sitting-room, and our lunch awaited us upon the table.
“I am so delighted that you have come,” she said earnestly. “It is so very kind of you both; but indeed I do not know what I should do. Your advice will be altogether invaluable to me.”
“Pray tell us what has happened to you.”
“I will do so, and I must be quick, for I have promised Mr. Rucastle to be back before three. I got his leave to come into town this morning, though he little knew for what purpose.”
“Let us have everything in its due order.” Holmes thrust his long thin legs out towards the fire and composed himself to listen.
“In the first place, I may say that I have met, on the whole, with no actual ill-treatment from Mr. and Mrs. Rucastle. It is only fair to them to say that. But I cannot understand them, and I am not easy in my mind about them.”
“What can you not understand?”
“Their reasons for their conduct. But you shall have it all just as it occurred. When I came down, Mr. Rucastle met me here and drove me in his dog-cart to the Copper Beeches. It is, as he said, beautifully situated, but it is not beautiful in itself, for it is a large square block of a house, whitewashed, but all stained and streaked with damp and bad weather. There are grounds round it, woods on three sides, and on the fourth a field which slopes down to the Southampton high road, which curves past about a hundred yards from the front door. This ground in front belongs to the house, but the woods all round are part of Lord Southerton’s preserves. A clump of copper beeches immediately in front of the hall door has given its name to the place.
“I was driven over by my employer, who was as amiable as ever, and was introduced by him that evening to his wife and the child. There was no truth, Mr. Holmes, in the conjecture which seemed to us to be probable in your rooms at Baker Street. Mrs. Rucastle is not mad. I found her to be a silent, pale-faced woman, much younger than her husband, not more than thirty, I should think, while he can hardly be less than forty-five. From their conversation I have gathered that they have been married about seven years, that he was a widower, and that his only child by the first wife was the daughter who has gone to Philadelphia. Mr. Rucastle told me in private that the reason why she had left them was that she had an unreasoning aversion to her stepmother. As the daughter could not have been less than twenty, I can quite imagine that her position must have been uncomfortable with her father’s young wife.
“Mrs. Rucastle seemed to me to be colourless in mind as well as in feature. She impressed me neither favourably nor the reverse. She was a nonentity. It was easy to see that she was passionately devoted both to her husband and to her little son. Her light grey eyes wandered continually from one to the other, noting every little want and forestalling it if possible. He was kind to her also in his bluff, boisterous fashion, and on the whole they seemed to be a happy couple. And yet she had some secret sorrow, this woman. She would often be lost in deep thought, with the saddest look upon her face. More than once I have surprised her in tears. I have thought sometimes that it was the disposition of her child which weighed upon her mind, for I have never met so utterly spoiled and so ill-natured a little creature. He is small for his age, with a head which is quite disproportionately large. His whole life appears to be spent in an alternation between savage fits of passion and gloomy intervals of sulking. Giving pain to any creature weaker than himself seems to be his one idea of amusement, and he shows quite remarkable talent in planning the capture of mice, little birds, and insects. But I would rather not talk about the creature, Mr. Holmes, and, indeed, he has little to do with my story.”
“I am glad of all details,” remarked my friend, “whether they seem to you to be relevant or not.”
“I shall try not to miss anything of importance. The one unpleasant thing about the house, which struck me at once, was the appearance and conduct of the servants. There are only two, a man and his wife. Toller, for that is his name, is a rough, uncouth man, with grizzled hair and whiskers, and a perpetual smell of drink. Twice since I have been with them he has been quite drunk, and yet Mr. Rucastle seemed to take no notice of it. His wife is a very tall and strong woman with a sour face, as silent as Mrs. Rucastle and much less amiable. They are a most unpleasant couple, but fortunately I spend most of my time in the nursery and my own room, which are next to each other in one corner of the building.
“For two days after my arrival at the Copper Beeches my life was very quiet; on the third, Mrs. Rucastle came down just after breakfast and whispered something to her husband.
“‘Oh, yes,’ said he, turning to me, ‘we are very much obliged to you, Miss Hunter, for falling in with our whims so far as to cut your hair. I assure you that it has not detracted in the tiniest iota from your appearance. We shall now see how the electric-blue dress will become you. You will find it laid out upon the bed in your room, and if you would be so good as to put it on we should both be extremely obliged.’
“The dress which I found waiting for me was of a peculiar shade of blue. It was of excellent material, a sort of beige, but it bore unmistakable signs of having been worn before. It could not have been a better fit if I had been measured for it. Both Mr. and Mrs. Rucastle expressed a delight at the look of it, which seemed quite exaggerated in its vehemence. They were waiting for me in the drawing-room, which is a very large room, stretching along the entire front of the house, with three long windows reaching down to the floor. A chair had been placed close to the central window, with its back turned towards it. In this I was asked to sit, and then Mr. Rucastle, walking up and down on the other side of the room, began to tell me a series of the funniest stories that I have ever listened to. You cannot imagine how comical he was, and I laughed until I was quite weary. Mrs. Rucastle, however, who has evidently no sense of humour, never so much as smiled, but sat with her hands in her lap, and a sad, anxious look upon her face. After an hour or so, Mr. Rucastle suddenly remarked that it was time to commence the duties of the day, and that I might change my dress and go to little Edward in the nursery.
“Two days later this same performance was gone through under exactly similar circumstances. Again I changed my dress, again I sat in the window, and again I laughed very heartily at the funny stories of which my employer had an immense répertoire, and which he told inimitably. Then he handed me a yellow-backed novel, and moving my chair a little sideways, that my own shadow might not fall upon the page, he begged me to read aloud to him. I read for about ten minutes, beginning in the heart of a chapter, and then suddenly, in the middle of a sentence, he ordered me to cease and to change my dress.
“You can easily imagine, Mr. Holmes, how curious I became as to what the meaning of this extraordinary performance could possibly be. They were always very careful, I observed, to turn my face away from the window, so that I became consumed with the desire to see what was going on behind my back. At first it seemed to be impossible, but I soon devised a means. My hand-mirror had been broken, so a happy thought seized me, and I concealed a piece of the glass in my handkerchief. On the next occasion, in the midst of my laughter, I put my handkerchief up to my eyes, and was able with a little management to see all that there was behind me. I confess that I was disappointed. There was nothing. At least that was my first impression. At the second glance, however, I perceived that there was a man standing in the Southampton Road, a small bearded man in a grey suit, who seemed to be looking in my direction. The road is an important highway, and there are usually people there. This man, however, was leaning against the railings which bordered our field and was looking earnestly up. I lowered my handkerchief and glanced at Mrs. Rucastle to find her eyes fixed upon me with a most searching gaze. She said nothing, but I am convinced that she had divined that I had a mirror in my hand and had seen what was behind me. She rose at once.
“‘Jephro,’ said she, ‘there is an impertinent fellow upon the road there who stares up at Miss Hunter.’
“‘No friend of yours, Miss Hunter?’ he asked.
“‘No, I know no one in these parts.’
“‘Dear me! How very impertinent! Kindly turn round and motion to him to go away.’
“‘Surely it would be better to take no notice.’
“‘No, no, we should have him loitering here always. Kindly turn round and wave him away like that.’
“I did as I was told, and at the same instant Mrs. Rucastle drew down the blind. That was a week ago, and from that time I have not sat again in the window, nor have I worn the blue dress, nor seen the man in the road.”
“Pray continue,” said Holmes. “Your narrative promises to be a most interesting one.”
“You will find it rather disconnected, I fear, and there may prove to be little relation between the different incidents of which I speak. On the very first day that I was at the Copper Beeches, Mr. Rucastle took me to a small outhouse which stands near the kitchen door. As we approached it I heard the sharp rattling of a chain, and the sound as of a large animal moving about.
“‘Look in here!’ said Mr. Rucastle, showing me a slit between two planks. ‘Is he not a beauty?’
“I looked through and was conscious of two glowing eyes, and of a vague figure huddled up in the darkness.
“‘Don’t be frightened,’ said my employer, laughing at the start which I had given. ‘It’s only Carlo, my mastiff. I call him mine, but really old Toller, my groom, is the only man who can do anything with him. We feed him once a day, and not too much then, so that he is always as keen as mustard. Toller lets him loose every night, and God help the trespasser whom he lays his fangs upon. For goodness’ sake don’t you ever on any pretext set your foot over the threshold at night, for it’s as much as your life is worth.’
“The warning was no idle one, for two nights later I happened to look out of my bedroom window about two o’clock in the morning. It was a beautiful moonlight night, and the lawn in front of the house was silvered over and almost as bright as day. I was standing, rapt in the peaceful beauty of the scene, when I was aware that something was moving under the shadow of the copper beeches. As it emerged into the moonshine I saw what it was. It was a giant dog, as large as a calf, tawny tinted, with hanging jowl, black muzzle, and huge projecting bones. It walked slowly across the lawn and vanished into the shadow upon the other side. That dreadful sentinel sent a chill to my heart which I do not think that any burglar could have done.
“And now I have a very strange experience to tell you. I had, as you know, cut off my hair in London, and I had placed it in a great coil at the bottom of my trunk. One evening, after the child was in bed, I began to amuse myself by examining the furniture of my room and by rearranging my own little things. There was an old chest of drawers in the room, the two upper ones empty and open, the lower one locked. I had filled the first two with my linen, and as I had still much to pack away I was naturally annoyed at not having the use of the third drawer. It struck me that it might have been fastened by a mere oversight, so I took out my bunch of keys and tried to open it. The very first key fitted to perfection, and I drew the drawer open. There was only one thing in it, but I am sure that you would never guess what it was. It was my coil of hair.
“I took it up and examined it. It was of the same peculiar tint, and the same thickness. But then the impossibility of the thing obtruded itself upon me. How could my hair have been locked in the drawer? With trembling hands I undid my trunk, turned out the contents, and drew from the bottom my own hair. I laid the two tresses together, and I assure you that they were identical. Was it not extraordinary? Puzzle as I would, I could make nothing at all of what it meant. I returned the strange hair to the drawer, and I said nothing of the matter to the Rucastles as I felt that I had put myself in the wrong by opening a drawer which they had locked.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The Black Swan is an inn of repute in the High Street, at no distance from the station, and there we found the young lady waiting for us. A lunch of cold chicken and salad had already been placed upon the table, and with the air of a hostess she welcomed us with a cordiality which was not altogether free from anxiety. 

"I am so glad you have come," she said, with a sigh of relief. "I have been waiting for you for hours. I had a telegram from the stationer that the train was delayed, and I was afraid you would not arrive before I must return."

"You must not be in a hurry," said Holmes. "We shall be very glad to hear your story at your leisure."

"I must be back by three," she answered. "But I will tell you all I can. I have no doubt that you will find my case a very strange one."

"We shall be much obliged by any details you can give us," said Holmes. "Even the smallest incident may be of value."

"It is not that I have suffered any actual ill-treatment," she continued, "but I find the people I am with so strange and so difficult to understand that I am at my wits' end."

She gave us a brief account of her position. She was the governess at a place called Copper Beeches, a large, square house, with damp-stained walls, standing in the midst of a wood, and with a field sloping down to the road. The Rucastles, her employers, were a peculiar couple. Mr. Rucastle was a man of some years, with a florid face and a loud laugh. His wife was younger than he, a pale, silent woman, who was passionately devoted to her husband and her son. The child was a spoiled, ill-natured boy, with a head disproportionately large for his body, and a disposition which alternated between fits of rage and sullen sulkiness. He delighted in cruelty to weaker creatures, and had once, she told us, torn the wings from a sparrow and watched it flutter to the ground.

"I have no doubt that there is some secret sorrow in the house," she said. "I have seen Mrs. Rucastle in tears more than once."

"And you are quite sure that she is not a woman of unsound mind?"

"I am sure of that. She is not mad, but she is unhappy."

"And the servants?"

"They are a most unpleasant pair. Toller, the butler, is a rough, red-faced man, who is often drunk. His wife is tall and strong, with a sour face and a tongue which is never still."

"And you have been there long?"

"For two months."

"And during that time you have had no cause for complaint?"

"None whatever."

"Then why do you come to us?"

"Because I have seen something which I cannot understand, and which I feel I must not keep to myself."

"Pray tell us what it is."

"It is this," she said, and she drew from her pocket a small bundle of chestnut hair. "I found this in a drawer in my room. It is exactly like my own, and yet it is not mine."

Holmes took the bundle and examined it carefully. "It is very like yours," he said. "But I should not say it was yours."

"I thought so too. I have my own hair in my trunk, and I have compared it. This is not mine."

"And the drawer was locked?"

"Yes, and I had to use one of my keys to open it."

"And you have said nothing to the Rucastles?"

"No. I did not know what to make of it."

"And what else have you noticed?"

"There is the matter of the dress."

"The dress?"

"Yes, the electric blue one which Mrs. Rucastle gave me."

"And what is strange about that?"

"It fits me perfectly, and yet it is as if it had been worn before."

"And what did the Rucastles say when you put it on?"

"They were delighted. They made me sit in a particular chair in the drawing-room, and they watched me as if I were some kind of exhibit."

"And what did you do?"

"I laughed at their jokes, and I read aloud from a novel for ten minutes, and then they told me to stop."

"And you have done this more than once?"

"Yes, twice."

"And what did you see?"

"I saw a man."

"A man?"

"Yes, a small, bearded man in grey, leaning on the railings by the road."

"And how did you see him?"

"I had a piece of broken mirror in my handkerchief."

"Ah! A very clever idea."

"I thought so. But I believe Mrs. Rucastle saw me."

"And what happened then?"

"She pointed to the man and said something to her husband."

"And what did he do?"

"He asked me to wave to the man."

"And you did so?"

"Yes."

"And then?"

"Then Mrs. Rucastle drew the blind."

"And you have not seen the man since?"

"No."

"And you have not worn the dress again?"

"No."

"And what else have you noticed?"

"There is the matter of the dog."

"The dog?"

"Yes, a great, fierce mastiff, chained near the kitchen."

"And what of him?"

"Mr. Rucastle warned me never to go out at night, for Toller lets him loose, and he is fed so little that he is always keen for the kill."

"And have you seen him?"

"Yes, once. I saw him prowling about the lawn in the moonlight."

"And you are quite sure that he is dangerous?"

"I am sure of it."

"And you have no other suspicions?"

"None."

"Then I think, Miss Hunter, that we have enough to go upon."

"I am so glad."

"And I think that we shall go to Copper Beeches together."

"You will come with me?"

"Yes, if you will allow us."

"I should be delighted."

"Then we will start at once."

"But I must be back by three."

"We shall be in time."

And so, with a light heart and a heavy burden, we set forth upon the adventure of the Copper Beeches.

events.title: Exploring the Forbidden Wing and Seeking Help
detailed_summary: Miss Hunter, being observant, mapped the house layout but noted one wing seemed uninhabited and was always locked.
She once saw Mr. Rucastle emerging from this wing looking furious, very different from his usual jovial self.
Later, while walking in the grounds, she noticed the windows of this wing: three dirty, one shuttered.
Mr. Rucastle approached her, jovially excusing his earlier preoccupied behavior.
When she mentioned the spare rooms and shuttered window, he seemed surprised and startled.
He claimed it was his photography darkroom but his suspicious, annoyed look betrayed his jesting tone.
From that moment, Miss Hunter felt compelled (by curiosity and a sense of duty) to investigate the locked wing.
She observed Toller and his wife also accessing these rooms, once seeing Toller carry a large black bag through the door.
Yesterday evening, finding Toller very drunk and the key left in the forbidden door, she seized the opportunity while the Rucastles were downstairs.
She entered a small passage leading to three doors; the first and third opened into empty, dusty rooms.
The center door was closed, locked, and barricaded with an iron bed bar padlocked to the wall.
This door corresponded to the shuttered window; light glimmered from underneath, suggesting a skylight.
Hearing steps inside and seeing a shadow move under the door, she was overcome with terror and fled.
She ran straight into Mr. Rucastle waiting outside the door.
He initially spoke soothingly but his tone was overly coaxing, putting her on guard.
She claimed the empty wing's eerie stillness frightened her.
Rucastle, smiling amiably, asked why she thought he locked the door – to keep out those with no business there.
His smile instantly hardened into a demonic glare as he threatened to throw her to the mastiff if she ever crossed the threshold again.
Terrified, she fled to her room.
Resolving she needed help, she decided to wire Holmes.
She went to the telegraph office, returning eased but momentarily fearing the dog might be loose, remembering Toller was incapacitated by drink.
She got leave to come to Winchester, needing to return by 3 PM as the Rucastles would be out for the evening.
She finishes her story, asking Holmes what it means and what she should do.

“I am naturally observant, as you may have remarked, Mr. Holmes, and I soon had a pretty good plan of the whole house in my head. There was one wing, however, which appeared not to be inhabited at all. A door which faced that which led into the quarters of the Tollers opened into this suite, but it was invariably locked. One day, however, as I ascended the stair, I met Mr. Rucastle coming out through this door, his keys in his hand, and a look on his face which made him a very different person to the round, jovial man to whom I was accustomed. His cheeks were red, his brow was all crinkled with anger, and the veins stood out at his temples with passion. He locked the door and hurried past me without a word or a look.
“This aroused my curiosity, so when I went out for a walk in the grounds with my charge, I strolled round to the side from which I could see the windows of this part of the house. There were four of them in a row, three of which were simply dirty, while the fourth was shuttered up. They were evidently all deserted. As I strolled up and down, glancing at them occasionally, Mr. Rucastle came out to me, looking as merry and jovial as ever.
“‘Ah!’ said he, ‘you must not think me rude if I passed you without a word, my dear young lady. I was preoccupied with business matters.’
“I assured him that I was not offended. ‘By the way,’ said I, ‘you seem to have quite a suite of spare rooms up there, and one of them has the shutters up.’
“He looked surprised and, as it seemed to me, a little startled at my remark.
“‘Photography is one of my hobbies,’ said he. ‘I have made my dark room up there. But, dear me! what an observant young lady we have come upon. Who would have believed it? Who would have ever believed it?’ He spoke in a jesting tone, but there was no jest in his eyes as he looked at me. I read suspicion there and annoyance, but no jest.
“Well, Mr. Holmes, from the moment that I understood that there was something about that suite of rooms which I was not to know, I was all on fire to go over them. It was not mere curiosity, though I have my share of that. It was more a feeling of duty—a feeling that some good might come from my penetrating to this place. They talk of woman’s instinct; perhaps it was woman’s instinct which gave me that feeling. At any rate, it was there, and I was keenly on the lookout for any chance to pass the forbidden door.
“It was only yesterday that the chance came. I may tell you that, besides Mr. Rucastle, both Toller and his wife find something to do in these deserted rooms, and I once saw him carrying a large black linen bag with him through the door. Recently he has been drinking hard, and yesterday evening he was very drunk; and when I came upstairs there was the key in the door. I have no doubt at all that he had left it there. Mr. and Mrs. Rucastle were both downstairs, and the child was with them, so that I had an admirable opportunity. I turned the key gently in the lock, opened the door, and slipped through.
“There was a little passage in front of me, unpapered and uncarpeted, which turned at a right angle at the farther end. Round this corner were three doors in a line, the first and third of which were open. They each led into an empty room, dusty and cheerless, with two windows in the one and one in the other, so thick with dirt that the evening light glimmered dimly through them. The centre door was closed, and across the outside of it had been fastened one of the broad bars of an iron bed, padlocked at one end to a ring in the wall, and fastened at the other with stout cord. The door itself was locked as well, and the key was not there. This barricaded door corresponded clearly with the shuttered window outside, and yet I could see by the glimmer from beneath it that the room was not in darkness. Evidently there was a skylight which let in light from above. As I stood in the passage gazing at the sinister door and wondering what secret it might veil, I suddenly heard the sound of steps within the room and saw a shadow pass backward and forward against the little slit of dim light which shone out from under the door. A mad, unreasoning terror rose up in me at the sight, Mr. Holmes. My overstrung nerves failed me suddenly, and I turned and ran—ran as though some dreadful hand were behind me clutching at the skirt of my dress. I rushed down the passage, through the door, and straight into the arms of Mr. Rucastle, who was waiting outside.
“‘So,’ said he, smiling, ‘it was you, then. I thought that it must be when I saw the door open.’
“‘Oh, I am so frightened!’ I panted.
“‘My dear young lady! my dear young lady!’—you cannot think how caressing and soothing his manner was—‘and what has frightened you, my dear young lady?’
“But his voice was just a little too coaxing. He overdid it. I was keenly on my guard against him.
“‘I was foolish enough to go into the empty wing,’ I answered. ‘But it is so lonely and eerie in this dim light that I was frightened and ran out again. Oh, it is so dreadfully still in there!’
“‘Only that?’ said he, looking at me keenly.
“‘Why, what did you think?’ I asked.
“‘Why do you think that I lock this door?’
“‘I am sure that I do not know.’
“‘It is to keep people out who have no business there. Do you see?’ He was still smiling in the most amiable manner.
“‘I am sure if I had known—’
“‘Well, then, you know now. And if you ever put your foot over that threshold again’—here in an instant the smile hardened into a grin of rage, and he glared down at me with the face of a demon—‘I’ll throw you to the mastiff.’
“I was so terrified that I do not know what I did. I suppose that I must have rushed past him into my room. I remember nothing until I found myself lying on my bed trembling all over. Then I thought of you, Mr. Holmes. I could not live there longer without some advice. I was frightened of the house, of the man, of the woman, of the servants, even of the child. They were all horrible to me. If I could only bring you down all would be well. Of course I might have fled from the house, but my curiosity was almost as strong as my fears. My mind was soon made up. I would send you a wire. I put on my hat and cloak, went down to the office, which is about half a mile from the house, and then returned, feeling very much easier. A horrible doubt came into my mind as I approached the door lest the dog might be loose, but I remembered that Toller had drunk himself into a state of insensibility that evening, and I knew that he was the only one in the household who had any influence with the savage creature, or who would venture to set him free. I slipped in in safety and lay awake half the night in my joy at the thought of seeing you. I had no difficulty in getting leave to come into Winchester this morning, but I must be back before three o’clock, for Mr. and Mrs. Rucastle are going on a visit, and will be away all the evening, so that I must look after the child. Now I have told you all my adventures, Mr. Holmes, and I should be very glad if you could tell me what it all means, and, above all, what I should do.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: I am naturally observant, as you may have remarked, Mr. Holmes, and I soon had a pretty good plan of the whole house in my head. There was a wing, however, which seemed to be quite out of use, for the doors were always locked and the windows were never opened. I had noticed once that Mr. Rucastle came out of it with a very angry face, which was so unlike his usual genial manner that I could not help remarking upon it. He laughed it off, however, and said that he had been trying some experiments in photography, and that the room was his dark-laboratory. I had not much faith in this explanation, for his manner was suspicious and his laugh was forced. I had also noticed that Toller and his wife had been in the habit of going into this wing, and once I saw Toller come out of it with a large black bag in his hand. I was determined to find out what was going on, and I resolved to make a little investigation of my own. One evening, when I found Toller very drunk and the key left in the door, I seized the opportunity and made my way into the forbidden wing. I found a small passage leading to three doors. The first and the third opened into empty, dusty rooms, but the second was closed and locked, and there was an iron bed-bar padlocked to the wall, which formed a most effective barricade. I could see that the window of this room was the one which had been shuttered, and I noticed that there was a faint glimmer of light beneath the door, which suggested that there was a skylight above. I was just about to retreat when I heard the sound of footsteps within and saw a shadow move across the door. I was so frightened that I ran out and met Mr. Rucastle just outside. He was very kind and soothing at first, but his manner was so coaxing that I felt on my guard. I told him that the stillness of the wing had frightened me, and he smiled and asked me why I thought he locked the door. 'To keep out those who have no business there,' he said. His smile suddenly hardened into a look of such menace that I was terrified. 'If you ever cross that threshold again,' he said, 'I shall throw you to the mastiff.' I ran back to my room, and I resolved that I must have your help, Mr. Holmes. I went to the telegraph office and sent you a wire, and I have come to Winchester to consult you. I must return by three o'clock, for the Rucastles are to be out for the evening. That is all, Mr. Holmes. What does it mean, and what am I to do?
